description: Microsoft Project 2013 is the latest offering by Microsoft into the software realm of PMIS (Project Management Information Systems).  This type of tool is used to help a project manager consolidate the number of tools they may use (e.g.  Calendar systems, email, contacts and some budgeting software and reporting software) into a single software tool for initiating, planning, executing, monitoring and controlling and even closing a project.  Within a single tool, a project manager can manage a project’s triple constraints:  Cost, Scope and Time.  This series covers every exam objective to help a viewer to prepare for the Microsoft exam 74-343 —Managing Projects with Microsoft Project 2013.
name: Microsoft Project 2013 - 74-343
subtitle: Managing Projects with Microsoft Project 2013

episodes.description: Microsoft Project 2013 is the latest offering by Microsoft into the software realm of PMIS (Project Management Information Systems).  This type of tool is used to help a project manager consolidate the number of tools they may use (e.g.  Calendar systems, email, contacts and some budgeting software and reporting software) into a single software tool for initiating, planning, executing, monitoring and controlling and even closing a project.  Within a single tool, a project manager can manage a project’s triple constraints:  Cost, Scope and Time.  This series covers every exam objective to help a viewer to prepare for the Microsoft exam 74-343 —Managing Projects with Microsoft Project 2013.

146
00:07:14.876 --> 00:07:20.125

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don guide through getting started with Microsoft Project 2013.  They show some of the ways that Project allows a user to get started right way using Project by creating templates, using templates, and creating a project plan from other applications.

30

So those three things that we work to

31
00:01:43.606 --> 00:01:46.986
And Microsoft Project is
packed full of tools and

00:14:43.710 --> 00:14:46.370
I don't think I've ever used a map,
because it seems like every time I fire

289
00:14:46.370 --> 00:14:48.623
up Excel I use some kind of crazy
different naming convention.

290
00:14:48.623 --> 00:14:49.498
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

291
00:14:49.498 --> 00:14:51.579
creating a new map, this is pretty common,

292
00:14:51.579 --> 00:14:56.080
and then we're just tying those columns to
what their associated value in Project is.

293
00:14:56.080 --> 00:14:59.760
>> And I do the same thing, just like Don
said, I never know, even though I think

294
00:14:59.760 --> 00:15:03.080
I'm consistent, I'll look back and
I'm like, oh, I didn't use name,

295
00:15:03.080 --> 00:15:07.210
I used something else, and so a new map
is pretty much what you'll end up seeing.

296
00:15:07.210 --> 00:15:10.500
So I'm gonna click Next here, and
then it's gonna ask me what I want to do.

297
00:15:10.500 --> 00:15:12.886
Now here's actually
something that's very neat,

298
00:15:12.886 --> 00:15:16.095
when we actually are using
the information that we're importing in.

299
00:15:16.095 --> 00:15:20.208
Notice I can just bring this into a brand
new project or I can append it or

300
00:15:20.208 --> 00:15:23.120
merge it together into an active project.

301
00:15:23.120 --> 00:15:26.945
Append means exactly what it says here,
it's to add in addition to an existing

302
00:15:26.945 --> 00:15:30.425
project and then to merge it in means hey,
take a look and see if

303
00:15:30.425 --> 00:15:34.625
anything's changed here and merge those
values in place where they need to be.

304
00:15:34.625 --> 00:15:37.595
We're just gonna do a new project at this
point cuz I don't have an existing one

305
00:15:37.595 --> 00:15:38.795
that I'm merging into.

306
00:15:38.795 --> 00:15:40.263
But you do have that ability,

307
00:15:40.263 --> 00:15:44.334
let's say later on that you choose to
actually add in that resource name, right.

308
00:15:44.334 --> 00:15:48.826
So on my Excel spreadsheet, I actually
did select a different sheet as well, and

309
00:15:48.826 --> 00:15:52.324
I just added in some of the names
that we were gonna end up using,

310
00:15:52.324 --> 00:15:54.459
some of the resources that we needed.

311
00:15:54.459 --> 00:15:57.289
Just as I was thinking about this
project as we were going through So

312
00:15:57.289 --> 00:15:59.220
I may actually use that
a little bit later on.

313
00:15:59.220 --> 00:16:00.585
I may not want to do it right away.

314
00:16:00.585 --> 00:16:02.820
I may just want to see what happens here.

315
00:16:02.820 --> 00:16:04.790
So at this point I'm gonna
select a new project, and

316
00:16:04.790 --> 00:16:06.430
then later I might add on that second one,

317
00:16:06.430 --> 00:16:11.150
to tell it to append to the existing
project to add in the other information.

318
00:16:11.150 --> 00:16:15.780
So New project, and then it's gonna say
what type of data do I want to import?

319
00:16:15.780 --> 00:16:17.490
I can choose both of them right now,

320
00:16:17.490 --> 00:16:20.440
I'm just gonna choose the tasks
to make it easy on us.

321
00:16:20.440 --> 00:16:24.770
And then do I want to import the,
the import includes headers,

322
00:16:24.770 --> 00:16:27.530
I do have one header field so
I need to make sure I mark that.

323
00:16:27.530 --> 00:16:29.045
>> And at the header
>> If you're not familiar with it that's

324
00:16:29.045 --> 00:16:30.285
just the column title.

325
00:16:30.285 --> 00:16:33.785
So in that very first row in Excel,
Ronnie had put task man.

326
00:16:33.785 --> 00:16:35.665
Right.
What he might have just left.

327
00:16:35.665 --> 00:16:38.055
And then that first row is an actual task.

328
00:16:38.055 --> 00:16:39.495
And so that's what you're saying here.

329
00:16:39.495 --> 00:16:40.890
Whether or
not you put those names on there.

330
00:16:40.890 --> 00:16:41.390
>> Right?

331
00:16:42.430 --> 00:16:43.120
>> And then, in a moment,

332
00:16:43.120 --> 00:16:45.740
you're going to see where it gives
you a nice little window about

333
00:16:45.740 --> 00:16:47.860
what is actually going to match up.

334
00:16:47.860 --> 00:16:52.620
So, I need to of course select
the tasks of the worksheet aim,

335
00:16:52.620 --> 00:16:54.660
I believe that's the one
I actually select.

336
00:16:54.660 --> 00:16:55.920
Yep.
That's task, so

337
00:16:55.920 --> 00:16:57.370
sometimes I have to verify, and

338
00:16:57.370 --> 00:17:01.770
notice that it's not mapped to any
particular project field at all.

339
00:17:01.770 --> 00:17:04.460
So, it doesn't find an automatic matching,
it's saying,

340
00:17:04.460 --> 00:17:08.510
hey I don't see this exact name
inside of Microsoft Project.

341
00:17:08.510 --> 00:17:11.770
So then it gives me that ability
to select that drop-down.

342
00:17:11.770 --> 00:17:16.090
And now I scroll down, and because I think
that I've worked with Project before,

343
00:17:16.090 --> 00:17:21.095
Don, I always believe that task name
is actually the name that is in here.

344
00:17:21.095 --> 00:17:22.720
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I scroll down to Task and

345
00:17:22.720 --> 00:17:24.950
I'm like, oh, it's not in there.

346
00:17:24.950 --> 00:17:29.600
And that is because inside of Project,
they actually don't call it task name.

347
00:17:29.600 --> 00:17:30.625
They call it Name.

348
00:17:30.625 --> 00:17:32.065
[LAUGH] That is the name.

349
00:17:32.065 --> 00:17:33.550
[LAUGH]
>> Because a task is

350
00:17:33.550 --> 00:17:36.460
the primary thing that you work with,
so they just leave that part off.

351
00:17:36.460 --> 00:17:37.760
Remember that at the end of the day,

352
00:17:37.760 --> 00:17:40.875
Microsoft Project is really
creating a database for you.

353
00:17:40.875 --> 00:17:44.665
It's creating a fairly complex Microsoft
Access database on the back-end, and

354
00:17:44.665 --> 00:17:46.995
so everything has a field
that it gets stored in.

355
00:17:46.995 --> 00:17:50.845
Everything is a column in a table
somewhere that's been defined, so

356
00:17:50.845 --> 00:17:52.445
we're just trying to match that up.

357
00:17:52.445 --> 00:17:54.580
Matching up Ronnie's column name or

358
00:17:54.580 --> 00:17:56.910
task name with the column
name inside a project.

359
00:17:56.910 --> 00:17:59.530
And you guys saw there's a lot in there.

360
00:17:59.530 --> 00:18:02.210
There's well over 100
different column names, and

361
00:18:02.210 --> 00:18:05.030
you gotta make sure you choose
the right one to do this import.

362
00:18:05.030 --> 00:18:06.650
>> Yeah.
Once we choose that right one,

363
00:18:06.650 --> 00:18:08.680
it gives you a nice little preview.

364
00:18:08.680 --> 00:18:11.630
And even though it doesn't give you a lot
of the preview, it should be enough to

365
00:18:11.630 --> 00:18:15.040
say, yeah, that's exactly what I
thought should go into that name there.

366
00:18:15.040 --> 00:18:18.100
And so you see where the first
one actually tells you Excel, and

367
00:18:18.100 --> 00:18:21.200
then Project, and what, normally,
the data's gonna be listed under there.

368
00:18:21.200 --> 00:18:25.400
Click Next and now it's gonna say hey,
are you sure that everything is done?

369
00:18:25.400 --> 00:18:28.660
If you know you're gonna be doing
this again, you can save that map.

370
00:18:28.660 --> 00:18:32.140
I'm probably not going to,
so I'm gonna click Finish.

371
00:18:32.140 --> 00:18:36.610
And in a moment, you'll actually end up
seeing, without me, Don, having to type.

372
00:18:36.610 --> 00:18:39.240
Which you know that typing
is not my best ability here.

373
00:18:39.240 --> 00:18:43.140
Without me having to type
in all this information,

374
00:18:43.140 --> 00:18:47.770
I was actually able then to
just import it directly in.

375
00:18:47.770 --> 00:18:50.340
And now I have the basis for
my new project.

376
00:18:50.340 --> 00:18:56.040
And so I go with a file save, and from
this point I save it in my documents here,

377
00:18:57.220 --> 00:19:00.960
and well call this
Project Tasks 2015 here.

378
00:19:02.630 --> 00:19:03.330
And Click save.

379
00:19:04.910 --> 00:19:09.480
And once I do that, now we have a basis
for starting to work with project.

380
00:19:09.480 --> 00:19:12.830
So, we can use something like Excel,
we can of course use

381
00:19:12.830 --> 00:19:15.980
an existing project that we're talking
about, one that was already filled out.

382
00:19:15.980 --> 00:19:17.990
But, what if we're kind of starting off,
and

383
00:19:17.990 --> 00:19:21.830
we really just don't know what
it is we needed to be doing.

384
00:19:23.700 --> 00:19:25.910
>> Well the good thing is,
Project actually helps us even there.

385
00:19:25.910 --> 00:19:28.960
If I go back to File and I click on New,

386
00:19:28.960 --> 00:19:31.700
notice that there's actually a lot
of other information here Don.

387
00:19:31.700 --> 00:19:36.850
Underneath some of the different templates
that they have so that we can get started.

388
00:19:36.850 --> 00:19:40.550
>> So with Project, there's actually
over 20 different Project templates.

389
00:19:40.550 --> 00:19:42.560
Some that relate directly
to Project management.

390
00:19:42.560 --> 00:19:45.100
But the nice thing is some of them
actually relate to things that we might be

391
00:19:45.100 --> 00:19:47.310
doing, such as software development plan.

392
00:19:47.310 --> 00:19:48.580
Somebody's already done that.

393
00:19:48.580 --> 00:19:52.330
Residential construction,
earned value Commercial,

394
00:19:52.330 --> 00:19:56.600
and they've even tried to tie it in even,
more closely towards the PnP

395
00:19:56.600 --> 00:19:59.940
using the PMBOK and
you'll see a few of them down here.

396
00:19:59.940 --> 00:20:02.690
Even talk about,
let me see if I can find it down here.

397
00:20:02.690 --> 00:20:06.850
There's PMBOK Compliance Project,
Project Management Institute, You name it.

398
00:20:06.850 --> 00:20:10.560
They went ahead and actually added in
just a few generic templates for us, too.

399
00:20:10.560 --> 00:20:13.080
>> And the ones you're seeing there
are ones that have been tested and

400
00:20:13.080 --> 00:20:13.960
approved by Microsoft.

401
00:20:13.960 --> 00:20:17.670
There's a little search box at the top
that says search for online templates.

402
00:20:17.670 --> 00:20:21.860
You can search the entire Microsoft Office
Online library, which includes hundreds,

403
00:20:21.860 --> 00:20:24.940
even thousands, of templates that
other people have posted out there.

404
00:20:24.940 --> 00:20:26.530
So it is very handy,

405
00:20:26.530 --> 00:20:32.130
very convenient the Pinbot one I know
is really valuable to me as a PNP.

406
00:20:32.130 --> 00:20:35.050
If your PNP, if you've been
certified by the PMI product

407
00:20:35.050 --> 00:20:37.520
management you've got a certain
way of doing things, and

408
00:20:37.520 --> 00:20:39.700
it's nice to have a product
that's structured that way.

409
00:20:39.700 --> 00:20:42.820
Or maybe you do Prints Two project
management, so you can search and

410
00:20:42.820 --> 00:20:46.580
there are some generic templates up there
that have been defined for Prints Two.

411
00:20:46.580 --> 00:20:48.250
You just search and find it.

412
00:20:48.250 --> 00:20:49.710
It gives you a great starting point.

413
00:20:49.710 --> 00:20:53.700
So the lesson here is, with project,
you can start with a blank project and

414
00:20:53.700 --> 00:20:57.230
set it up however you want, but
it's gonna be a lot of work.

415
00:20:57.230 --> 00:21:00.000
And so if you can, look for templates.

416
00:21:00.000 --> 00:21:01.320
Look for
templates that other people have made,

417
00:21:01.320 --> 00:21:06.260
or take your own existing projects and
turn them into templates that you can use.

418
00:21:06.260 --> 00:21:10.280
The other thing is, in your company,
you might be the only project manager.

419
00:21:10.280 --> 00:21:13.750
Or you might be on a team of
20 different project managers.

420
00:21:13.750 --> 00:21:16.860
You need consistency amongst
all of your projects, so

421
00:21:16.860 --> 00:21:19.410
that all of your project managers are
structuring their projects the same way.

422
00:21:19.410 --> 00:21:21.270
That's really important.

423
00:21:21.270 --> 00:21:24.310
Well, having a good template in place
is what's going to enforce that.

424
00:21:24.310 --> 00:21:27.220
It's going to make sure that everybody
is doing things the same way

425
00:21:27.220 --> 00:21:29.270
especially if you've got linked projects.

426
00:21:29.270 --> 00:21:32.280
If you have sub projects
underneath a parent project.

427
00:21:32.280 --> 00:21:35.590
You need the sub-projects being configured
the same way as the parent project.

428
00:21:35.590 --> 00:21:37.810
Using templates again,
it will take care of that.

429
00:21:37.810 --> 00:21:40.580
And make sure that you get
that consistent environment.

430
00:21:40.580 --> 00:21:43.300
>> So Don, I went ahead and
pulled up a simple template for us, and

431
00:21:43.300 --> 00:21:45.790
just so
that we can walk through it very easily.

432
00:21:45.790 --> 00:21:48.165
Notice that this one I'm just
selecting as new product launches,

433
00:21:48.165 --> 00:21:51.530
cuz it was the next one down
there that was fairly small.

434
00:21:51.530 --> 00:21:55.030
And I can even go ahead and enter in
a start date for this new project.

435
00:21:55.030 --> 00:21:58.680
Let's say I wanna start at the beginning
of August for this project.

436
00:21:58.680 --> 00:22:01.590
And that's just saying, hey, when you
build this template, go in and add in this

437
00:22:01.590 --> 00:22:05.930
basic information so I can customize
it even right here at the beginning.

438
00:22:05.930 --> 00:22:07.040
And select Create.

439
00:22:08.340 --> 00:22:10.140
And now it's gonna import that in.

440
00:22:10.140 --> 00:22:13.880
And it actually has a full
different information,

441
00:22:13.880 --> 00:22:16.250
they've actually opened it
up to the reports already.

442
00:22:16.250 --> 00:22:18.400
So that we can see in
this project overview,

443
00:22:18.400 --> 00:22:20.220
there's a bunch of
different reports there.

444
00:22:20.220 --> 00:22:22.190
If I select tasks and

445
00:22:22.190 --> 00:22:26.530
the gant chart view, this is more
likely what you're going to see.

446
00:22:26.530 --> 00:22:30.050
And from here, even though I've
selected a new project start date,

447
00:22:30.050 --> 00:22:31.450
it actually went back to the 2005.

448
00:22:31.450 --> 00:22:34.250
Which means we need to
modify that information, but

449
00:22:34.250 --> 00:22:36.920
now I can save it as my new project and
I'm ready to go.

450
00:22:36.920 --> 00:22:39.990
I've now downloaded that template, so
I don't have to go back out online and

451
00:22:39.990 --> 00:22:41.100
download it again.

452
00:22:41.100 --> 00:22:44.260
It'll actually be available for
me whether I'm online or offline, too.

453
00:22:46.190 --> 00:22:48.590
>> All right, Ronnie, well I think
everybody's gotten a pretty good chance

454
00:22:48.590 --> 00:22:51.870
to see how we can create new projects,
and how we can kinda get started.

455
00:22:51.870 --> 00:22:55.500
And everybody's probably excited about
actually putting this stuff to use.

456
00:22:55.500 --> 00:22:58.290
Which is what's gonna be happening
in our upcoming episodes.

457
00:22:58.290 --> 00:23:00.920
Well for this episode, this is probably
a pretty good point for us to stop.

458
00:23:00.920 --> 00:23:02.830
Ronnie do you have anything
else you wanted to throw in?

459
00:23:02.830 --> 00:23:05.080
>> Not really,
there's just a lot to go through.

460
00:23:05.080 --> 00:23:05.720
But right there,

461
00:23:05.720 --> 00:23:09.240
if you needed to get started right away,
multiple opportunities.

462
00:23:09.240 --> 00:23:10.860
Notice you don't have to
be intimidated right away,

463
00:23:10.860 --> 00:23:12.910
you can use any of the options
that we showed you.

464
00:23:12.910 --> 00:23:14.370
It's a great way to start.

465
00:23:14.370 --> 00:23:15.430
>> Absolutely.

466
00:23:15.430 --> 00:23:18.230
All right, well I hope you guys enjoyed
watching the episode as much as we

467
00:23:18.230 --> 00:23:18.970
did filming it.

468
00:23:18.970 --> 00:23:22.070
Stay tuned because we've got
more Project content coming up.

469
00:23:22.070 --> 00:23:25.350
But for now, signing of for
ITPro TV I'm your host Don Pezet.

470
00:23:25.350 --> 00:23:26.910
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

471
00:23:26.910 --> 00:23:27.466
>> And we'll see you next time.

472
00:23:27.466 --> 00:23:33.030
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Calendars
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.379
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.379 --> 00:00:13.283
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

3
00:00:13.283 --> 00:00:15.338
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.338 --> 00:00:18.087
I'm your host Don Pezet back
again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:18.087 --> 00:00:18.838
How's it going Ronnie?

6
00:00:18.838 --> 00:00:21.526
>> It is going well today,
feeling good and feeling excited,

7
00:00:21.526 --> 00:00:24.740
cuz we're taking a look at
Microsoft Project again.

8
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:26.689
>> Now we're gonna take
a look at a topic today,

9
00:00:26.689 --> 00:00:29.421
that's really important we get right,
early in the project.

10
00:00:29.421 --> 00:00:31.129
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz it's hard to fix later on.

11
00:00:31.129 --> 00:00:33.462
And that's setting our calendars.

12
00:00:33.462 --> 00:00:37.701
In our first episode, we talked a little
bit about creating tasks in Project, and

13
00:00:37.701 --> 00:00:41.213
we still had to import those, and
get our project kinda kicked off.

14
00:00:41.213 --> 00:00:44.888
But if you're starting with a blank
project, and you're about to enter in

15
00:00:44.888 --> 00:00:48.970
a bunch of tasks, well, if you're
just entering in a name, that's fine.

16
00:00:48.970 --> 00:00:53.570
But if you're gonna start assigning
durations, how long a task takes to

17
00:00:53.570 --> 00:00:58.620
complete, it's really important that
we have our calendar set first.

18
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:00.585
Now, if you're wondering
what I mean by calendars,

19
00:01:00.585 --> 00:01:03.200
cuz we kind of know the calendar.

20
00:01:03.200 --> 00:01:05.380
June 2nd is June 2nd, right?

21
00:01:05.380 --> 00:01:08.961
But, what are the work hours on June 2nd?

22
00:01:08.961 --> 00:01:12.987
What times can I expect employees
to be at the office doing work, and

23
00:01:12.987 --> 00:01:15.046
at what time do they need to leave?

24
00:01:15.046 --> 00:01:19.000
How many hours of labor can
I actually get on June 2nd?

25
00:01:19.000 --> 00:01:21.920
Well, your calendar's what defines that.

26
00:01:21.920 --> 00:01:25.530
And if you start putting in a bunch
of activities and then you go and

27
00:01:25.530 --> 00:01:28.750
change that calendar,
it can really cause some bizarre effects.

28
00:01:28.750 --> 00:01:32.550
So it's a great idea to
get your calendars set up

29
00:01:32.550 --> 00:01:36.230
before you start dumping in a bunch
of durations onto your activities.

30
00:01:36.230 --> 00:01:40.664
Now, If you just imported from Excel or
somewhere like that you may already have

31
00:01:40.664 --> 00:01:45.046
some durations, just expect to see them
change as your calendar changes too.

32
00:01:45.046 --> 00:01:47.810
And you'll have to be observing,
you'll have to watch out for that.

33
00:01:47.810 --> 00:01:50.170
>> When you start taking a look
at changing the calendar,

34
00:01:50.170 --> 00:01:53.620
you gotta remember something which
is very difficult to remember.

35
00:01:53.620 --> 00:01:56.470
Project doesn't really look at time

36
00:01:56.470 --> 00:02:01.020
as far as resources as being
a 24-hour day by default.

37
00:02:01.020 --> 00:02:04.587
It looks at it as being a regular workday,
like what you and I might experience.

38
00:02:04.587 --> 00:02:09.345
About 8 AM until about noon, and
then you take an hour break, and

39
00:02:09.345 --> 00:02:14.970
then about 1 PM until about 5 PM, and

00:24:53.950 --> 00:24:56.680
and for some reason, it's not scheduling
on a day, you're gonna go and

486
00:24:56.680 --> 00:24:59.990
figure out where that block is happening
and just having two places is easier than

487
00:24:59.990 --> 00:25:03.630
having three places to go and look, but
the task calendars are there for a reason.

488
00:25:03.630 --> 00:25:05.510
Make use of them if you
absolutely need too.

489
00:25:07.180 --> 00:25:09.810
Alright, well Ronnie I think that's
a pretty good overview of calendars and

490
00:25:09.810 --> 00:25:12.000
I just want to reiterate that
the reason we're covering this so

491
00:25:12.000 --> 00:25:16.840
soon you guys can kind of see here, if you
set up your project and you get all these

492
00:25:16.840 --> 00:25:20.940
tasks put in place, and then you go modify
your calendar, all of your tasks are gonna

493
00:25:20.940 --> 00:25:24.100
move around to accommodate that new
calendar and it creates a lot of headache.

494
00:25:24.100 --> 00:25:28.330
If you have your calendar set right in the
very beginning, as you add task they'll

495
00:25:28.330 --> 00:25:31.480
conform to it and you'll get a better
vision of how your project is going to be.

496
00:25:31.480 --> 00:25:34.330
So, this is one of the first things
that we need to tackle when setting up

497
00:25:34.330 --> 00:25:35.010
a new project.

498
00:25:35.010 --> 00:25:35.940
>> I agree.

499
00:25:35.940 --> 00:25:38.190
>> All right, well, Ronnie, this is
probably a good spot to wrap this one up.

500
00:25:38.190 --> 00:25:39.660
Do you have anything else you wanna add?

501
00:25:39.660 --> 00:25:41.930
>> Nope,
just continue to take a look into project.

502
00:25:41.930 --> 00:25:44.840
There's so many little things that
you can get easily confused in.

503
00:25:44.840 --> 00:25:48.410
If you're preparing for the exam,
make sure you spend time and

504
00:25:48.410 --> 00:25:52.120
actually doing and working with it,
because you're gonna forget so

505
00:25:52.120 --> 00:25:56.290
much, so the more time you spend it,
the better it's gonna be.

506
00:25:56.290 --> 00:25:58.170
>> All right, well ladies and
gentlemen, let's wrap this one up here.

507
00:25:58.170 --> 00:25:59.750
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

508
00:25:59.750 --> 00:26:02.300
Singing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Tom Poset.

509
00:26:02.300 --> 00:26:03.223
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

510
00:26:03.223 --> 00:26:04.422
>> And we'll see you next time.

511
00:26:04.422 --> 00:26:10.300
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don demonstrate one of the most powerful features in Project, custom fields.  Custom fields allow us to show customized data.  Instead of displaying only the default fields, we can use tools provided in Project to allow us to display a calculated field, a lookup field or even just a string field that we would like to see that project didn't specifically create by default.
episodes.title: Custom Fields
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.585
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.585 --> 00:00:13.515
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening,

3
00:00:13.515 --> 00:00:17.363
and welcome back to another episode of
ITProTV, and I'm your host, Don Pezet.

4
00:00:17.363 --> 00:00:19.520
Back again with Mr.
Ronnie Wong, how's it going Ronnie?

5
00:00:19.520 --> 00:00:20.470
>> It's going great today.

6
00:00:20.470 --> 00:00:23.660
It feels nice and good in our studio and
that means we're ready for

7
00:00:23.660 --> 00:00:25.142
another exciting episode and a project.

8
00:00:25.142 --> 00:00:29.620
>> Yeah, now in Microsoft Project, I know
I have mentioned in other episodes that

9
00:00:29.620 --> 00:00:33.500
in the background it's really just
creating a Microsoft access database and

10
00:00:33.500 --> 00:00:35.080
kind of hides that from us, right.

11
00:00:35.080 --> 00:00:38.460
And the database is completely
built out to support projects.

12
00:00:38.460 --> 00:00:40.340
So it's got tables and columns, and

13
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:44.430
all of that other data, that's built
around what we need to know for project.

14
00:00:44.430 --> 00:00:46.870
And, when I say it's got columns and data.

15
00:00:46.870 --> 00:00:48.220
>> It's got columns.

16
00:00:48.220 --> 00:00:50.100
>> It's got tons and tons of data.

17
00:00:50.100 --> 00:00:51.850
When you first launch Microsoft Project,

18
00:00:51.850 --> 00:00:55.850
you get a default view that has the stuff
that most of us expect to see, right?

19
00:00:55.850 --> 00:00:57.180
Let's take a little tour here.

20
00:00:57.180 --> 00:00:59.410
So I've got a project
pulled up on my machine.

21
00:00:59.410 --> 00:01:02.290
And this is just the default
gant view that you see when you

22
00:01:02.290 --> 00:01:04.090
fire up Microsoft Project.

23
00:01:04.090 --> 00:01:06.921
So you get a little gant chart over here,
which I don't really care about.

24
00:01:06.921 --> 00:01:08.438
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me take that and

25
00:01:08.438 --> 00:01:09.592
scoot it off to the side.

26
00:01:09.592 --> 00:01:10.759
But then you'll see some other things.

27
00:01:10.759 --> 00:01:14.343
We've got things like our task name,
the duration, or

28
00:01:14.343 --> 00:01:16.770
how long the task is gonna take.

29
00:01:16.770 --> 00:01:19.940
When the task starts,
when its scheduled to finish,

30
00:01:19.940 --> 00:01:23.600
the predecessors if it's linked to
other tasks that have to happen.

31
00:01:23.600 --> 00:01:26.090
The resources,
who's assigned to that, right?

32
00:01:26.090 --> 00:01:29.290
These are all things that Microsoft
knows that you're going to need, right?

33
00:01:29.290 --> 00:01:32.160
These are the default things.

34
00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:35.260
But boy, there's a lot more that's
out there if you really want it.

35
00:01:35.260 --> 00:01:38.090
And as we move through the different
views inside a project you'll see some of

36
00:01:38.090 --> 00:01:39.220
those other things.

37
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:41.220
But notice right here I've
got this Add New Column.

38
00:01:42.290 --> 00:01:45.820
You can click that, and
you can add in other data.

39
00:01:45.820 --> 00:01:50.370
And, it's an impressive list,
there's well over 200 things.

40
00:01:50.370 --> 00:01:51.860
>> Yeah there really is.

41
00:01:51.860 --> 00:01:54.403
Thee's so many different others,
different tasks and

42
00:01:54.403 --> 00:01:57.647
different columns that we can add
to there, that Microsoft said look,

43
00:01:57.647 --> 00:02:00.750
there's already stuff in here, and
all you have to do is choose it.

44
00:02:00.750 --> 00:02:04.188
They don't want to actually add
everything in and overwhelm it, and

45
00:02:04.188 --> 00:02:07.640
all of a sudden you have a table
that's now 1,000 columns long.

46
00:02:07.640 --> 00:02:09.211
But as you go through there,

47
00:02:09.211 --> 00:02:13.337
you'll actually notice that they also
put in some generic names in there,

48
00:02:13.337 --> 00:02:17.540
such as text and number field, and
cost field, and stuff like that.

49
00:02:17.540 --> 00:02:20.660
The reason why they did that is because
they also wanted projects to be

50
00:02:20.660 --> 00:02:21.990
customizable.

51
00:02:21.990 --> 00:02:26.246
And that means that if you are actually
not seeing what you need to see,

52
00:02:26.246 --> 00:02:29.924
you have the ability to build
the field that you need to see and

53
00:02:29.924 --> 00:02:33.336
actually have it report
the information that you want.

54
00:02:33.336 --> 00:02:36.250
Or maybe even change it up and
report some other things too.

55
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:38.310
>> Yeah, you know Microsoft
built this around the PMI,

56
00:02:38.310 --> 00:02:42.860
the Project Managers Institute's PMBOK or
their Project Management Body of Knowledge

57
00:02:42.860 --> 00:02:45.070
and so it's got a lot of stuff
in here to support that.

58
00:02:45.070 --> 00:02:48.400
But even then you might be following
a different methodology or

59
00:02:48.400 --> 00:02:50.370
you might just have other
information you wanna keep track of.

60
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:52.520
Let me give you a great example.

61
00:02:52.520 --> 00:02:54.590
When we create a task, so
I've got this task here,

62
00:02:54.590 --> 00:02:58.980
submit bond and insurance documents, and
I can see the resources assigned to it?

63
00:02:58.980 --> 00:03:03.610
Right, we've got the project management
team and some kind of GC general, right?

64
00:03:03.610 --> 00:03:05.850
So we've got a couple of different
things here assigned to it.

65
00:03:05.850 --> 00:03:07.350
These are the resources
that are assigned to it.

66
00:03:07.350 --> 00:03:09.930
These are the people who
are doing the actual work.

67
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:15.630
But you might have a RAM,
a responsibility assignment matrix,

68
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:19.130
where you've assigned people
to be responsible for a task.

69
00:03:19.130 --> 00:03:22.490
That means that person might not be
the person doing the actual work,

70
00:03:22.490 --> 00:03:24.070
they're just responsible for it.

71
00:03:24.070 --> 00:03:26.260
So if it doesn't happen, it's their fault.

72
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:27.640
This is the person you blame.

73
00:03:27.640 --> 00:03:32.760
Well in Project, we track the resource as
the person who's actually doing the work.

74
00:03:32.760 --> 00:03:34.870
We have to pay them money, but

75
00:03:34.870 --> 00:03:38.160
the person who's responsible for,
we might not be paying them money.

76
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:40.730
It might be part of their job that
they just are responsible for

77
00:03:40.730 --> 00:03:41.880
making this happen.

78
00:03:41.880 --> 00:03:44.120
So I might want to keep track of that, but

79
00:03:44.120 --> 00:03:47.530
I don't have a responsible
person field in here.

80
00:03:47.530 --> 00:03:51.440
If I look I'm looking at all sorts of
other stuff, but no responsible person.

81
00:03:52.490 --> 00:03:56.840
So I might wanna create a custom field,
and to do that, all you have to do is,

82
00:03:56.840 --> 00:04:00.090
you can actually do it from right here,
but the easier way is up top here.

83
00:04:00.090 --> 00:04:04.830
If we go to Project,
you'll see Custom Fields, and

84
00:04:04.830 --> 00:04:07.380
when you choose Custom Fields, we're gonna
see all those ones that Ronnie mentioned.

85
00:04:07.380 --> 00:04:10.640
Here's text 1 through 20, right,
or actually it's through 30.

86
00:04:10.640 --> 00:04:12.880
So, we've got 30 of these
little text fields.

87
00:04:12.880 --> 00:04:17.582
If you change them from text, you've got
cost, date, number, a number 1 through 20,

88
00:04:17.582 --> 00:04:21.576
so some of them you have only 10 of,
some you have 20, some you have 30.

89
00:04:21.576 --> 00:04:24.093
And what these are are fields
that Microsoft's already made and

90
00:04:24.093 --> 00:04:26.580
they're leaving them available for you.

91
00:04:26.580 --> 00:04:29.010
So you need to think about
the data you want to store.

92
00:04:29.010 --> 00:04:30.700
I want to store the name of a person.

93
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:33.940
This is the person I'm going to get
mad at if this job doesn't finish.

94
00:04:33.940 --> 00:04:36.550
So a person's name, that's just text.

95
00:04:36.550 --> 00:04:39.090
And so I'm gonna come in here and
I'm gonna pick text.

96
00:04:39.090 --> 00:04:41.870
And then I'm gonna take that text
field and I'm gonna rename it.

97
00:04:41.870 --> 00:04:44.520
Because text1 is not
very meaningful to me.

98
00:04:44.520 --> 00:04:47.730
So you can select it and hit Rename and
you can call it something.

99
00:04:47.730 --> 00:04:50.890
I'll call it my RAM.

100
00:04:50.890 --> 00:04:52.990
This is my responsibility
assignment matrix.

101
00:04:52.990 --> 00:04:56.070
Or I could say,
responsible person, sponsor,

102
00:04:56.070 --> 00:05:01.430
whatever it is that I wanna call it, I'll
just say responsible person, all right?

103
00:05:01.430 --> 00:05:04.630
And it's just gonna be a text field,
and that's it.

104
00:05:04.630 --> 00:05:07.670
Now the other options down here I'll talk
about in a minute, but for this one,

105
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:09.400
I'm gonna go ahead and say OK.

106
00:05:09.400 --> 00:05:13.940
And now I've got this custom text field,
and here in my project, I can hit,

107
00:05:13.940 --> 00:05:19.410
add a new column, and if I scroll down
to text one, I can find text one.

108
00:05:19.410 --> 00:05:22.540
And see how in parentheses it's
got that responsible person flag.

109
00:05:22.540 --> 00:05:25.290
And I can choose it and
it shows us responsible person.

110
00:05:25.290 --> 00:05:28.430
I have to remember that it's called
text one because that's what it is in

111
00:05:28.430 --> 00:05:30.170
the database on the back end.

112
00:05:30.170 --> 00:05:32.870
But now I've got this responsible person
field, and I come in here and I can say,

113
00:05:32.870 --> 00:05:35.720
this one's gonna be Ronnie Wong.

114
00:05:35.720 --> 00:05:36.960
Or this one's gonna be Don Pezet.

115
00:05:36.960 --> 00:05:38.160
I'm gonna put in the people.

116
00:05:38.160 --> 00:05:40.290
Now, these are not resources.

117
00:05:40.290 --> 00:05:44.020
If I go to my resource sheet,
if I jump over to that,

118
00:05:44.020 --> 00:05:47.480
I don't have a Ronnie Wong or
a Don Pezet here in the list.

119
00:05:47.480 --> 00:05:50.600
We're not resources,
we're not actually doing the work.

120
00:05:50.600 --> 00:05:54.430
We're just gonna be responsible for
it, making sure it actually happens.

121
00:05:54.430 --> 00:05:56.320
So, when I go back to my Gantt chart,
there we go,

122
00:05:56.320 --> 00:05:58.230
I've got my responsible persons.

123
00:05:58.230 --> 00:06:02.110
So, if you need number fields, if you need
anything like that, you can quickly and

124
00:06:02.110 --> 00:06:04.980
easily create them right here, all right?

125
00:06:04.980 --> 00:06:09.090
Let me give you another example,
that's a little more advanced, right?

126
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:11.760
Well, we'll create a building example.

127
00:06:11.760 --> 00:06:15.310
Let's say that you're responsible for
risk analysis, okay?

128
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:17.420
Well, what do we do for risk analysis?

129
00:06:17.420 --> 00:06:20.240
Every activity, we can go in and take
a look at it and kind of figure out what

130
00:06:20.240 --> 00:06:23.330
its risk might be, or whatever,
and we kind of start to log that.

131
00:06:23.330 --> 00:06:27.440
So, you might want to create
a way to quickly measure

132
00:06:27.440 --> 00:06:29.290
risk right here from inside a project.

133
00:06:29.290 --> 00:06:31.370
So, you can take things like, well,

134
00:06:31.370 --> 00:06:36.280
the two building blocks of risk
are probability and impact.

135
00:06:36.280 --> 00:06:37.915
For every risk you need
to know the probability.

136
00:06:37.915 --> 00:06:39.690
What's the likelihood of it happening?

137
00:06:39.690 --> 00:06:41.670
And then you need to know the impact.

138
00:06:41.670 --> 00:06:43.830
If it does happen how
bad's it going to be.

139
00:06:43.830 --> 00:06:46.450
And we normally rank those
on a scale of one to ten.

140
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:47.990
So those are just numbers.

141
00:06:47.990 --> 00:06:51.690
I can take one of my number custom field
and another number custom field and

142
00:06:51.690 --> 00:06:55.500
I could make them probability and
impact, right?

143
00:06:55.500 --> 00:06:58.190
So I'm going to do that here, I'm just
going to go back to my custom fields.

144
00:06:59.450 --> 00:07:02.910
So I'm going to go to my project tab and
to custom fields.

145
00:07:02.910 --> 00:07:06.459
I'm going to switch to
the number type right here, and

146
00:07:06.459 --> 00:07:11.243
I'll take number one, I'm going to
rename that one as Probability, and

147
00:07:11.243 --> 00:07:15.430
then I'll take number two and
I'm going to rename that Impact.

148
00:07:17.180 --> 00:07:18.520
So now I've got probability and impact,

149
00:07:18.520 --> 00:07:23.040
they're just numbers, and I can put
data in there, and it's no big deal.

150
00:07:23.040 --> 00:07:28.620
I can go through and start to rank things
by giving them that 1 through 10 value.

151
00:07:28.620 --> 00:07:31.490
So if I add some new columns here,
I'm gonna add number 1 and number 2.

152
00:07:31.490 --> 00:07:36.374
I've gotta remember what the columns
are originally called, so

153
00:07:36.374 --> 00:07:42.694
I'm just gonna come in here and add those
guys, so I'll add Number1 and Number2.

154
00:07:42.694 --> 00:07:43.790
There we go.

155
00:07:43.790 --> 00:07:47.823
And once we get them added in, and
I'm just gonna kind of move these guys,

156
00:07:47.823 --> 00:07:51.748
cause my screen's gonna keep bumping
around here as I move this stuff.

157
00:07:51.748 --> 00:07:52.683
All right, there we go.

158
00:07:52.683 --> 00:07:54.349
So I've got my probability.

159
00:07:54.349 --> 00:07:57.173
And my impact and
they're all zeroed out, right?

160
00:07:57.173 --> 00:07:59.720
I put numbers as the data type.

161
00:07:59.720 --> 00:08:02.810
So, just put a zero in each of them but
I can start going through and

162
00:08:02.810 --> 00:08:09.650
just kinda ranking them based on whatever
it was that I felt like these were.

163
00:08:09.650 --> 00:08:10.382
Whoops [LAUGH] 12.

164
00:08:10.382 --> 00:08:11.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm gonna try and

165
00:08:11.320 --> 00:08:14.140
keep it one to ten so, for
my probabilities and then for

166
00:08:14.140 --> 00:08:16.010
my impact the same kinda thing right?

167
00:08:16.010 --> 00:08:20.160
We'd go through and we'd punch in what we
think the impact on our organization will

168
00:08:20.160 --> 00:08:23.710
be and your ranking scale is
your own to choose, right?

169
00:08:23.710 --> 00:08:26.360
So, it's whatever kinda works out.

170
00:08:26.360 --> 00:08:27.190
All right.

171
00:08:27.190 --> 00:08:31.360
So, now that I've got those punched in,
I've got probability and impact.

172
00:08:31.360 --> 00:08:35.780
That was easy, I just used some custom
fields for that but to really have risk

173
00:08:35.780 --> 00:08:40.920
work, I need my risk index and
your risk index, or your

174
00:08:40.920 --> 00:08:45.010
risk rating is what most people call it,
It's where I factor these two together.

175
00:08:45.010 --> 00:08:46.750
Right.
If I have something that's really

176
00:08:46.750 --> 00:08:51.010
low probability but high impact,
it's a little probability.

177
00:08:51.010 --> 00:08:51.710
It's not gonna happen.

178
00:08:51.710 --> 00:08:55.750
I don't worry about it but
if it's a low impact and

179
00:08:55.750 --> 00:08:58.280
a high probability,
I'm not worry about it there too.

180
00:08:58.280 --> 00:09:00.490
High probability is gonna happen but
the impact is so low.

181
00:09:00.490 --> 00:09:04.430
I'm not worry about it but when it's in
between, when the probability and impact

182
00:09:04.430 --> 00:09:08.290
are both in the middle It's likely to
happen, and it's gonna cause a big impact.

183
00:09:08.290 --> 00:09:09.110
I need to plan for that.

184
00:09:09.110 --> 00:09:11.320
So, we need to average
these numbers together, or

185
00:09:11.320 --> 00:09:13.920
we usually just multiply them
together to get the value we want.

186
00:09:13.920 --> 00:09:16.720
So, I'm gonna add another column,
which is gonna be my risk rating.

187
00:09:17.890 --> 00:09:21.510
Now this time I want risk
rating to be a number but

188
00:09:21.510 --> 00:09:24.190
it's not going to be a number that I
type in because I'm bad at math and

189
00:09:24.190 --> 00:09:29.100
I make mistakes so I want it to
calculate the number for me right?

190
00:09:29.100 --> 00:09:30.420
Figure out this number for me.

191
00:09:30.420 --> 00:09:32.480
Don't make me have to type it in.

192
00:09:32.480 --> 00:09:36.200
Okay so, I'm going to go up
here to my custom fields and

193
00:09:36.200 --> 00:09:41.560
I'm going to take number three and I'm
going to rename this my risk rating but

194
00:09:41.560 --> 00:09:46.040
instead of being something I type in,
I'm going to have it calculate the value.

195
00:09:46.040 --> 00:09:49.520

the background and every time you open
your project it's going to recalculate

419
00:21:06.190 --> 00:21:10.730
that column, and anytime you make changes
it's going to recalculate that column and

420
00:21:10.730 --> 00:21:15.470
if this is a massive project
The more complex your formulas get

421
00:21:15.470 --> 00:21:17.020
the longer it takes Project to open.

422
00:21:17.020 --> 00:21:20.680
Basically it can slow things down a little
bit there so you don't wanna go too crazy.

423
00:21:20.680 --> 00:21:23.700
But on modern computers
this is a simple average.

424
00:21:23.700 --> 00:21:27.680
I mean this happens so
fast that it's really negligible.

425
00:21:27.680 --> 00:21:29.850
But just be aware that you can go a little

426
00:21:29.850 --> 00:21:30.590
crazy with it-
>> [LAUGH]

427
00:21:30.590 --> 00:21:32.540
>> And end up with some complex stuff.

428
00:21:32.540 --> 00:21:33.980
But it is a fun one to mess around with.

429
00:21:33.980 --> 00:21:36.730
There's a lot of neat
things you can do in there.

430
00:21:36.730 --> 00:21:42.060
The lookups are another neat option
because the way this is right here,

431
00:21:42.060 --> 00:21:44.320
I've got it where when I punch in a value.

432
00:21:44.320 --> 00:21:46.010
You know what, let's take a look at it.

433
00:21:46.010 --> 00:21:48.940
I wasn't gonna talk about it, we'll
talk about it anyway, we've got time.

434
00:21:48.940 --> 00:21:52.480
These are just open fields so
I can come in here and

435
00:21:52.480 --> 00:21:55.620
type whatever I wanted for probability.

436
00:21:55.620 --> 00:21:59.480
So, I can make that a five or a ten or
20 or 30, whatever it is that I wanted it

437
00:21:59.480 --> 00:22:03.320
to be even though I said I want
it to be on a scale one to ten.

438
00:22:03.320 --> 00:22:03.940
Right.

439
00:22:03.940 --> 00:22:07.920
So, if I want to force it where its
always on a scale of one to ten,

440
00:22:07.920 --> 00:22:10.300
I could create a drop-down
box here instead.

441
00:22:10.300 --> 00:22:12.670
Instead of having like this where
you can type in whatever you want,

442
00:22:12.670 --> 00:22:15.290
where it's a drop-down box,
we can do that with a lookup function.

443
00:22:15.290 --> 00:22:18.990
Right, so, if I go in here,
into my custom fields again,

444
00:22:18.990 --> 00:22:22.790
and I'm gonna take my probability, right.

445
00:22:22.790 --> 00:22:24.550
And what my probability.

446
00:22:24.550 --> 00:22:26.570
Down here,
we've got custom attributes, and

447
00:22:26.570 --> 00:22:30.960
it's set to none right now, which means
you can type in whatever you want, right?

448
00:22:30.960 --> 00:22:33.020
But if we change that to look up,

449
00:22:34.280 --> 00:22:38.890
now we can create a look
up list of possible values.

450
00:22:38.890 --> 00:22:40.960
And the cool part about doing
it here is I can come in and

451
00:22:40.960 --> 00:22:44.160
I can start to put in these custom values,
and

452
00:22:44.160 --> 00:22:48.000
these are going to be the limits for
what people can choose.

453
00:22:48.000 --> 00:22:53.900
And you can even give them descriptions
like, you know, this is the lowest or

454
00:22:53.900 --> 00:22:58.880
maybe I'll just call this like,
unlikely and

455
00:22:58.880 --> 00:23:05.030
then maybe I'll call this one likely,
and then Very likely.

456
00:23:06.190 --> 00:23:07.390
Just so people can understand.

457
00:23:07.390 --> 00:23:10.270
Some people might say well,
is ten that it's really gonna happen or

458
00:23:10.270 --> 00:23:11.700
is one that it's really gonna happen.

459
00:23:11.700 --> 00:23:12.370
I don't know.

460
00:23:12.370 --> 00:23:14.680
So, I'm just kind of setting
some basic descriptions here.

461
00:23:14.680 --> 00:23:18.560
So, now it's got this value
set of one through ten, right?

462
00:23:18.560 --> 00:23:21.480
And you could actually pull that
from another table if we wanted but

463
00:23:21.480 --> 00:23:24.050
it my case, this is what we want.

464
00:23:24.050 --> 00:23:25.950
And then We'll come down here and

00:23:25.950 --> 00:23:28.590
it's got this little option
we need to pay attention to.

466
00:23:28.590 --> 00:23:31.940
Allow addition items to be entered
into the fields, all right?

00:23:31.940 --> 00:23:36.010
If that's checked, people can still
type whatever they wanted but

00:23:36.010 --> 00:23:39.900
if it's unchecked they're going to have
to pick from this list right here.

00:23:39.900 --> 00:23:43.040
If I turn this option on and
somebody adds a new value like 11,

00:23:43.040 --> 00:23:45.270
it's actually going to add it here.

471
00:23:45.270 --> 00:23:48.190
And it's gonna add 11, and now other
people will see that in the dropdown box.

472
00:23:48.190 --> 00:23:49.210
We normally leave that off.

473
00:23:49.210 --> 00:23:50.940
I'm gonna leave mine off too.

474
00:23:50.940 --> 00:23:52.940
All right, and
I'll go ahead and close there.

475
00:23:52.940 --> 00:23:54.820
So, now I've got that list for
probability.

476
00:23:54.820 --> 00:23:57.350
Now I could've copied that over for
impact, but

477
00:23:57.350 --> 00:23:58.915
impact is a little bit The different.

478
00:23:58.915 --> 00:23:59.505
Right?

479
00:23:59.505 --> 00:24:03.295
Impact isnt about whether
somethings likely or unlikely.

480
00:24:03.295 --> 00:24:08.455
If I go into Impact and I change to a look
up, now I can go give it its values.

481
00:24:08.455 --> 00:24:11.605
And sure they might be one through 10,
just like the other one.

00:24:11.605 --> 00:24:17.390
But now these are going to
be low impact Or, you know,

483
00:24:17.390 --> 00:24:23.815
not much cost or risk or whatever,
we might have a moderate impact,

484
00:24:23.815 --> 00:24:28.010
and then we might have a severe, or
you know we kind of know that it's impact,

485
00:24:28.010 --> 00:24:32.140
we might just call it moderate low and
severe.

486
00:24:32.140 --> 00:24:37.220
All right, so now people know that
a one is low, and a ten is severe.

487
00:24:38.420 --> 00:24:39.770
I'll go in and set that.

488
00:24:39.770 --> 00:24:41.230
Now once that's done,

489
00:24:41.230 --> 00:24:45.070
when I start coming to these fields
see how I've got a drop down now?

490
00:24:45.070 --> 00:24:47.190
And I can drop that down and I can pick.

00:24:47.190 --> 00:24:48.270
And right here I can see that.

492
00:24:48.270 --> 00:24:53.630
Unlikely, likely, very likely or
I can see low, moderate, severe.

493
00:24:53.630 --> 00:24:55.890
Now people have a good
understanding of that.

494
00:24:55.890 --> 00:25:00.210
And if I come in and try to punch
something else in I get an error.

495
00:25:00.210 --> 00:25:02.900
This is not a valid lookup table value.

496
00:25:02.900 --> 00:25:05.990
And now it's forcing me
to use these values.

497
00:25:05.990 --> 00:25:09.250
I could go and remove those little white
box checks that I put in on the graphical

498
00:25:09.250 --> 00:25:11.695
side, because those should
be impossible at that point.

499
00:25:11.695 --> 00:25:12.285
Right?

500
00:25:12.285 --> 00:25:15.550
But now we can go through and
start to pick these values and

501
00:25:15.550 --> 00:25:19.765
[INAUDIBLE] straight ten here,
super severe.

502
00:25:19.765 --> 00:25:22.185
Right?
So, really powerful functionality there,

503
00:25:22.185 --> 00:25:24.405
cuz now we control the data
that's going into our database.

504
00:25:26.835 --> 00:25:28.035
All right.
Well, Ronnie,

505
00:25:28.035 --> 00:25:28.865
I think we've
>> [LAUGH]

506
00:25:28.865 --> 00:25:30.245
>> given several different examples of how

507
00:25:30.245 --> 00:25:31.535
to use the custom fields.

508
00:25:31.535 --> 00:25:34.335
We saw just creating a custom
field with simple text.

509
00:25:34.335 --> 00:25:36.310
Right?
That's one of the easiest examples.

510
00:25:36.310 --> 00:25:38.560
We saw using formulas to calculate data.

511
00:25:38.560 --> 00:25:44.070
We saw using graphical interpreters to
well kinda see stuff at a glance and

512
00:25:44.070 --> 00:25:46.240
then lastly,
we talked about look up tables.

513
00:25:46.240 --> 00:25:48.720
It's really powerful stuff,
definitely something to take advantage of.

514
00:25:48.720 --> 00:25:50.170
Can you think of anything we missed?

515
00:25:50.170 --> 00:25:51.940
>> No, we went with the custom fields,
right?

516
00:25:51.940 --> 00:25:54.720
If you know more about project management
you'll see some of the existing

517
00:25:54.720 --> 00:25:58.200
fields that are there and then be able
to use some of the formulas from project

518
00:25:58.200 --> 00:26:02.110
management that show you exactly
what you really wanted to show.

519
00:26:02.110 --> 00:26:04.630
And that is the power of
using these custom fields,

520
00:26:04.630 --> 00:26:06.490
is to give you the information
that you need so

521
00:26:06.490 --> 00:26:09.620
you can make your best business
decision for your project.

522
00:26:09.620 --> 00:26:13.840
So, it's by far one of the most powerful
things we can do here on All right,

523
00:26:13.840 --> 00:26:16.000
well ladies and gentlemen,
I hoped you guys enjoyed it.

524
00:26:16.000 --> 00:26:19.620
It's one of the more fun things where you
take project and make it work for you so,

525
00:26:19.620 --> 00:26:21.330
I always enjoy it.

526
00:26:21.330 --> 00:26:23.000
But that's it for our show today.

527
00:26:23.000 --> 00:26:26.210
So, signing of for
ITPro TV I'm your host Don Pezet.

528
00:26:26.210 --> 00:26:27.470
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

529
00:26:27.470 --> 00:26:28.249
>> And we'll see you next time.

530
00:26:28.249 --> 00:26:34.630

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don walk through some of the different customization to change default settings within project. This customization done before the project plan has progressed much will help speed up the process and make items display the way you want rather than the default settings.
episodes.title: Settings Options
episodes.transcript:

[MUSIC]

So the way that we do that

So on my computer I went ahead and

but I know that by default the way

it's gonna default to just

And what if I needed to customize that and

Well, easiest way to do that is to go to

Notice that I have the option

Go ahead and click options, and

it is right here that we actually

And at the beginning,

And you may choose to change this

But they do actually give

So here notice that the default view.

So when you actually

And you'll go, I don't really like

Notice you can change that to any of

If you wanna start off with

00:02:48.950 --> 00:02:54.080
what do I wanna call it, the task flow,

The one that actually works as a-

yeah, the network diagram, you can

And then, of course, the date format

not anybody else.

So, it's right here that you can change

that might annoy you

But some of the other ones that are also

00:03:29.780 --> 00:03:35.390
the project plan itself, is right here

00:03:35.390 --> 00:03:38.850
Of course, I kinda skipped

But right there under display,

00:03:42.190 --> 00:03:44.310
This is the one that

78

is that I don't consider it

00:03:47.380 --> 00:03:49.440
I'm here in the United States and

I know that this is the default

But if I were in different parts of the

00:03:56.650 --> 00:04:00.550
one of these other calendars that

And that way, we insure that we can

00:04:07.860 --> 00:04:11.000

And of course, even for

to go and change all these options

So, here in the states, of course,

90
00:04:21.530 --> 00:04:25.180
>> Yeah, a big thing to remember about
Microsoft Projects is, this is software

00:04:25.180 --> 00:04:28.130
normally when Microsoft creates software,
they create it to sell it.

92
00:04:28.130 --> 00:04:31.750
So they say, we're gonna make Microsoft
Word, the best word processor ever.

93
00:04:31.750 --> 00:04:34.310
And we're gonna sell it out so
other people can use it.

94
00:04:34.310 --> 00:04:36.570
With Microsoft project
that's not how it started.

95
00:04:36.570 --> 00:04:41.150
It started because Microsoft said, we need
a way to manage our own projects, and so

96
00:04:41.150 --> 00:04:42.890
they kind of created this software and
evolved it.

97
00:04:42.890 --> 00:04:45.190
And then it got to a point when they said,
man this works really well for

00:04:45.190 --> 00:04:46.950
us, we should sell it to other people.

99
00:04:46.950 --> 00:04:51.300
And then it got kinda open, but remember
Microsoft is a multi national company.

100
00:04:51.300 --> 00:04:55.440
They've got offices all over the world and
so working with different calendars,

101
00:04:55.440 --> 00:04:56.690
working with different languages and

102
00:04:56.690 --> 00:04:58.480

something they deal with.

00:04:58.480 --> 00:05:01.070
It's built right there into

104
00:05:01.070 --> 00:05:05.990
>> It sure is and it adjust again

But most of us, even though those

00:05:09.430 --> 00:05:14.620
generic information that we wanna be

107
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:17.690
That we normally are really trying
to tweak it to our projects and

108
00:05:17.690 --> 00:05:19.260
what we're going to be doing.

109
00:05:19.260 --> 00:05:24.480
So it's right here that you wanna pay most

00:05:24.480 --> 00:05:28.610

111
00:05:28.610 --> 00:05:32.500
Notice that you can change the start date
of the week, as well as changing it to

we usually do this with risk analysis,

339
00:16:10.067 --> 00:16:13.660
if you wanna do a what if,
save your project, and then go through and

340
00:16:13.660 --> 00:16:15.405
just make a bunch of changes.

341
00:16:15.405 --> 00:16:19.030
That kind of create your what-if scenario,
and then see what happens, and

342
00:16:19.030 --> 00:16:22.050
then just close the project without
saving, and reopen it again.

343
00:16:22.050 --> 00:16:24.340
And everything goes back to the way it was
and you didn't mess with your project.

344
00:16:24.340 --> 00:16:26.910
That was the way you did
what-if scenarios in every

345
00:16:26.910 --> 00:16:28.960
previous version of Microsoft Project.

346
00:16:28.960 --> 00:16:32.210
If you have auto save turned on,
you start to do your what-if scenario and

347
00:16:32.210 --> 00:16:33.210
it saves it.

348
00:16:33.210 --> 00:16:36.710
And now you're in deep trouble, right, cuz
you've got to try and undo all that stuff,

349
00:16:36.710 --> 00:16:39.690
and maybe you missed something and
now you kinda screwed your project up.

350
00:16:39.690 --> 00:16:41.370
So that's why that's off by default,

351
00:16:41.370 --> 00:16:45.310
you can turn it on, I generally don't I'm
pretty good about hitting the save button.

352
00:16:45.310 --> 00:16:48.490
But you also do have some
new what if functionality,

353
00:16:48.490 --> 00:16:51.690
we'll see in another episode
inside of Project 2013,

354
00:16:51.690 --> 00:16:56.360
where we can start to spec out
alternate paths for tasks.

355
00:16:56.360 --> 00:17:00.790
So it's not something we rely on as much
as we used to, but if you're worried about

356
00:17:00.790 --> 00:17:04.920
accidentally saving data in there, then
you want to make sure you turn that off.

357
00:17:04.920 --> 00:17:06.741
And it is off by default.

358
00:17:06.741 --> 00:17:10.591
>> Now, there's other options in here,
choosing using your default language,

359
00:17:10.591 --> 00:17:12.728
of course, for what you're working with.

360
00:17:12.728 --> 00:17:16.532
And then it is in the advance settings
that actually do overall effect

361
00:17:16.532 --> 00:17:18.290
the project itself.

362
00:17:18.290 --> 00:17:22.869
You can see where the undo levels, this
is the one that I kind of key in here.

363
00:17:22.869 --> 00:17:28.200
Back in Project 2003,
I remember it was actually one undo.

364
00:17:28.200 --> 00:17:28.958
And that was it.

365
00:17:28.958 --> 00:17:30.030
>> [LAUGH]
>> And you were like,

366
00:17:30.030 --> 00:17:33.550
okay you kept hitting undo, and you're
like, okay go, it went back one time.

367
00:17:33.550 --> 00:17:34.810
Well now they've actually saved that.

368
00:17:34.810 --> 00:17:39.640
Usually by default I think they say that
they'll allow you to have up to 99 undo's,

369
00:17:39.640 --> 00:17:43.300
but here they actually show
like 20 levels of undo as well.

370
00:17:43.300 --> 00:17:46.840
So you may wanna change that and you might
actually get that up to 99 if you're

371
00:17:46.840 --> 00:17:51.220
as bad as I am at some of these things
here, where you have to undo quite a bit.

372
00:17:51.220 --> 00:17:55.530
So, you can see a lot of different options
that are actually displayed in here.

373
00:17:55.530 --> 00:17:57.760
Now what if you wanna go a little
bit further than that, Don?

374
00:17:57.760 --> 00:18:02.230
What if you say, look, all these
different tabs that we have open up here,

375
00:18:02.230 --> 00:18:05.580
that we can actually go
from one tab to another?

376
00:18:05.580 --> 00:18:10.185
But instead you wanted to be able
to customize one for yourself.

377
00:18:10.185 --> 00:18:11.365
You can also do that as well.

378
00:18:11.365 --> 00:18:16.065
You can create your own customized ribbon
and actually have it display up here, so

379
00:18:16.065 --> 00:18:19.695
you actually have all the tools
that you want available to you.

380
00:18:19.695 --> 00:18:22.865
So, instead of actually
having to navigate around and

381
00:18:22.865 --> 00:18:25.540
figure out what you actually want,
you may actually go ahead and

382
00:18:25.540 --> 00:18:27.940
choose that option as well,
if I go back to the options.

383
00:18:29.260 --> 00:18:31.960
>> Yeah, you'll find most people really
just have a small subset of tools that

384
00:18:31.960 --> 00:18:33.120
are used on a regular basis.

385
00:18:33.120 --> 00:18:36.660
So if we can put all those
tools on one ribbon section,

386
00:18:36.660 --> 00:18:38.330
it does make life a lot easier for us.

387
00:18:38.330 --> 00:18:40.810
But Microsoft doesn't know what
tools you like the best, and so

388
00:18:40.810 --> 00:18:43.970
that's why they divide it up in
a logical category kind of set up.

389
00:18:43.970 --> 00:18:44.960
We can create our own right?

390
00:18:44.960 --> 00:18:45.600
>> Right.

391
00:18:45.600 --> 00:18:48.600
So if you take a look at
the project options again, and

392
00:18:48.600 --> 00:18:51.390
you go down to where it says
Customize Ribbons, notice that you can

393
00:18:51.390 --> 00:18:54.860
choose from the most popular commands or
if you are daring, of course,

394
00:18:54.860 --> 00:18:59.410
you can list every single command and try
and go through every single one of those.

395
00:18:59.410 --> 00:19:02.070
And if you do that,
man look at that little scroll bar,

396
00:19:02.070 --> 00:19:04.680
it went from actually filling
up the entire page here.

397
00:19:04.680 --> 00:19:08.200
Where you're actually seeing about three,
two-thirds of the page.

398
00:19:08.200 --> 00:19:10.850
And now you go to All Commands,
it now turns tiny.

399
00:19:10.850 --> 00:19:14.510
And they mean every single
command if you choose to do that.

400
00:19:14.510 --> 00:19:17.540
But I'm just gonna choose this
Popular Options for right now.

401
00:19:17.540 --> 00:19:22.400
And notice it says I can customize
a ribbon if I want to but,

402
00:19:22.400 --> 00:19:25.910
what if I wanted to make
my own section of tools?

403
00:19:25.910 --> 00:19:26.995
I can do that as well.

404
00:19:26.995 --> 00:19:30.040
So under the main tabs,
notice over here on the right hand side,

405
00:19:30.040 --> 00:19:36.620
I can select a new tab, if I wanted to,
and now in this new tab, I can rename it.

406
00:19:37.680 --> 00:19:43.200
So I'm gonna rename it and
I'm gonna call it Ronnie's Tools.

407
00:19:43.200 --> 00:19:44.242
Click OK.
And now,

408
00:19:44.242 --> 00:19:48.474
once I actually have that new section,
I can now use,

409
00:19:48.474 --> 00:19:53.646
well this section over here on
the left hand side and I can select,

410
00:19:53.646 --> 00:20:00.169
I'm gonna create new and maybe open some
old project plans that I have available.

411
00:20:00.169 --> 00:20:04.332
I may want to actually do let's say,
Print Preview, and

412
00:20:04.332 --> 00:20:08.518
then some of the other views
that I might have available.

413
00:20:08.518 --> 00:20:10.424
Let's see,
let's just show like Status Date.

414
00:20:10.424 --> 00:20:13.148
>> And notice how some of those have a
little black arrow off to the right, that

415
00:20:13.148 --> 00:20:16.175
tells you that it's actually a drop down,
so it'll appear on the bar as a button and

416
00:20:16.175 --> 00:20:18.317
you click it and
there will be more options underneath it.

417
00:20:18.317 --> 00:20:20.617
So it's like getting more than
one function at the same time.

418
00:20:20.617 --> 00:20:23.321
And he's also just in
the popular options view.

419
00:20:23.321 --> 00:20:27.948
So if you switch to some of the other
drop downs there you can pick from things

420
00:20:27.948 --> 00:20:31.847
that are focused more on formating or
scheduling or whatever.

421
00:20:31.847 --> 00:20:36.100
You just pick and choose whatever it
is that you use on a regular basis.

422
00:20:36.100 --> 00:20:38.485
>> So I'm just gonna do that
just as an example and click OK.

423
00:20:40.280 --> 00:20:42.740
And once I do that notice
that now there it is.

424
00:20:42.740 --> 00:20:45.090
There is my section of tools and

425
00:20:45.090 --> 00:20:47.930
if I wanted to continue to add
in more tools I could do that.

426
00:20:47.930 --> 00:20:51.760
Instead of having to go to every single
little tab that I have available,

427
00:20:51.760 --> 00:20:55.490
there's all of my tools readily
available right there as well.

428
00:20:55.490 --> 00:20:57.710
And that might be something
that you choose to do,

429
00:20:57.710 --> 00:21:00.880
cuz that makes it easier in navigation,
not having to figure out, oh, yeah,

430
00:21:00.880 --> 00:21:03.300
that was on this tab,
that was on this tab.

431
00:21:03.300 --> 00:21:04.480
I like it.

432
00:21:04.480 --> 00:21:06.900
>> Well, now Ronnie, let's say I didn't
want to mess with the tabs at all.

433
00:21:06.900 --> 00:21:07.410
>> Right.
>> Right?

434
00:21:07.410 --> 00:21:10.570
So, cuz maybe I changed to
a different tab to get a tool that I

435
00:21:10.570 --> 00:21:11.370
don't get to too often.

436
00:21:11.370 --> 00:21:14.005
And then I gotta remember to go
back to Ronnie's Tools, right?

437
00:21:14.005 --> 00:21:15.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> If I don't want to mess with that there

438
00:21:15.400 --> 00:21:17.280
is a way to make something
appear on the screen

439
00:21:17.280 --> 00:21:19.300
all the time regardless
of what tab I'm on.

440
00:21:19.300 --> 00:21:21.979
>> There is, it's up here in
the upper left hand corner and

441
00:21:21.979 --> 00:21:25.798
when you take a look at these options you
can actually see they've already set up

442
00:21:25.798 --> 00:21:27.750
three options for us right away.

443
00:21:27.750 --> 00:21:30.640
And this is what they call
the quick access toolbar.

444
00:21:30.640 --> 00:21:34.040
So they have a save, they have the undo,
and they have the redo and they have this

445
00:21:34.040 --> 00:21:39.080
little unusual drop down here that says,
Customize Quick Access Toolbar.

446
00:21:39.080 --> 00:21:42.100
And of course you can get
to it directly from here

447
00:21:42.100 --> 00:21:44.890
where you can add in
some more information.

448
00:21:44.890 --> 00:21:47.690
And notice they've already set
it up by default they only have

449
00:21:47.690 --> 00:21:48.830
these three showing up.

450
00:21:48.830 --> 00:21:52.230
If I wanted to add in just
a couple of new ones there,

451
00:21:52.230 --> 00:21:55.270
all I have to do is actually
just select it, and go to Open.

452
00:21:55.270 --> 00:21:57.640
And notice it starts filling this in, and

453
00:21:57.640 --> 00:22:03.020
that way we don't have to actually even
use the ribbon or the tabs themselves.

454
00:22:03.020 --> 00:22:08.920
All of my single one click, easy ways to
do things, I can have it up here as well.

455
00:22:08.920 --> 00:22:13.160
Now remember that you can also
go to File and Options, and

456
00:22:13.160 --> 00:22:16.570
you also have that ability to
customize it from right here too.

457
00:22:16.570 --> 00:22:18.990
So, the couple ways to get access to it,
and

458
00:22:18.990 --> 00:22:21.030
you may find yourself,
that's the way I want to work.

459
00:22:21.030 --> 00:22:25.410
I don't want to deal with the ribbons at
all, or the different tabs at all, and

460
00:22:25.410 --> 00:22:26.300
be able to that.

461
00:22:26.300 --> 00:22:29.930
Makes it nice and easy,
very quick for us to be able to do.

462
00:22:29.930 --> 00:22:30.590
>> Yeah.

463
00:22:30.590 --> 00:22:33.640
So, it's definitely a neat
thing you can customize.

464
00:22:33.640 --> 00:22:35.870
Changing those ribbons,
that really does make a big difference.

465
00:22:35.870 --> 00:22:38.010
Especially if you're having
a hard time finding things.

466
00:22:38.010 --> 00:22:39.560
Maybe you just upgraded from
Project 2000 or 2003 and

467
00:22:39.560 --> 00:22:41.450
you're not used to the ribbon view yet.

468
00:22:41.450 --> 00:22:42.530
Right?

469
00:22:42.530 --> 00:22:43.920
And that happens.

470
00:22:43.920 --> 00:22:46.500
And so if you skipped over
Project 2007 for example.

471
00:22:46.500 --> 00:22:49.780
Was it 2007 when the ribbons
were introduced?

472
00:22:49.780 --> 00:22:50.770
>> Yes.
>> Okay.

473
00:22:50.770 --> 00:22:54.472
So if you skipped over those versions and
you're just jumping into 2013,

474
00:22:54.472 --> 00:22:57.892
these are good ways that you can kinda
get around that, not having to deal

475
00:22:57.892 --> 00:23:01.004
with ribbons or creating ribbons
that are really useful for you.

476
00:23:01.004 --> 00:23:03.660
All right well Ronnie, I think that's
a pretty good run down of the options.

477
00:23:03.660 --> 00:23:08.150
Do we have any other ones
that we wanna really tackle?

478
00:23:08.150 --> 00:23:09.536
I do know one that I wanna mention.

479
00:23:09.536 --> 00:23:13.330
You guys might have noticed in the options
screen there was an add ins section.

480
00:23:13.330 --> 00:23:17.460
And in the add in section, that's where we
can extend the functionality of project,

481
00:23:17.460 --> 00:23:18.010
and for

482
00:23:18.010 --> 00:23:20.910
most people extending functionality
projects gonna be one of two things.

483
00:23:20.910 --> 00:23:24.052
It's either one you are gonna be
connecting to a project server.

484
00:23:24.052 --> 00:23:30.594
Or two connecting to something like
the visual studio team foundation server.

485
00:23:30.594 --> 00:23:34.061
And that's where, if you're doing
software management projects,

486
00:23:34.061 --> 00:23:37.939
you might have software builds happening
over on your foundation server, and

487
00:23:37.939 --> 00:23:40.743
then here inside of Project
you can tie into that.

488
00:23:40.743 --> 00:23:44.230
And so we recognize the build as
occurring on this date or that date.

489
00:23:44.230 --> 00:23:47.730
So you can really expand Project and
there's third party companies out there

490
00:23:47.730 --> 00:23:51.670
that sell software that can integrate a
project and do all sorts of crazy things.

491
00:23:51.670 --> 00:23:55.290
I'm seeing some pretty impressive billing
systems that tap into Project and

492
00:23:55.290 --> 00:23:56.380
other things like that.

493
00:23:56.380 --> 00:23:59.080
Definitely a lot of extensibility there,

494
00:23:59.080 --> 00:24:03.320
and it makes it an even more powerful
product than what it already is.

495
00:24:03.320 --> 00:24:04.450
It really does.

496
00:24:04.450 --> 00:24:06.870
>> There's only one other option
that we need to show you here,

497
00:24:06.870 --> 00:24:11.260
which is what we call calendar options
too, that are actually inside of Project.

498
00:24:11.260 --> 00:24:15.880
Now, unusually, when we actually went
to those options inside of that,

499
00:24:15.880 --> 00:24:18.690
you know, the back stage here.

500
00:24:18.690 --> 00:24:19.330
The options.

501
00:24:19.330 --> 00:24:22.300
I don't see calendar options
right here very easily.

502
00:24:22.300 --> 00:24:24.510
We did see some of the options
that we can change.

503
00:24:24.510 --> 00:24:27.370
But if you wanna see some of the calendar
options what you'll need to do is go to

504
00:24:27.370 --> 00:24:31.520
the Project tab and
then select Change Working Times.

505
00:24:31.520 --> 00:24:34.630
And then down here at the bottom
is where you actually have this

506
00:24:34.630 --> 00:24:36.720
little button that says Options.

507
00:24:36.720 --> 00:24:39.420
And notice it brings us back to
the Schedule, so it's actually showing us

508
00:24:39.420 --> 00:24:42.720
the same thing, so
that's what we'll also end up seeing too.

509
00:24:42.720 --> 00:24:44.300
So I didn't see that on Schedule,

510
00:24:44.300 --> 00:24:46.080
I thought it was gonna lead
us someplace different.

511
00:24:46.080 --> 00:24:48.740
But there we have some of the options too.

512
00:24:48.740 --> 00:24:50.780
So if you happen to see that in one way or
the other,

513
00:24:50.780 --> 00:24:52.960
you'll be changing those options there.

514
00:24:52.960 --> 00:24:54.460
>> It's kinda like the Quick Access Bar.

515
00:24:54.460 --> 00:24:57.521
You'll find that there's more than one
way to get to the options screen, and so

516
00:24:57.521 --> 00:24:59.759
you can go straight to the options and
set them all at once or

517
00:24:59.759 --> 00:25:02.202
you can hit it piecemeal as you
go through configuring things.

518
00:25:02.202 --> 00:25:05.106
But one lesson I've learned
over the years is that,

519
00:25:05.106 --> 00:25:09.198
it's almost always better to set these
options early on in your project,

520
00:25:09.198 --> 00:25:11.851
before you start dumping
a ton of data in there.

521
00:25:11.851 --> 00:25:15.172
Because otherwise if you change it after
the fact you can get your tasks to be

522
00:25:15.172 --> 00:25:16.290
inconsistent, right?

523
00:25:16.290 --> 00:25:19.030
Things might not match
up between old tasks and

524
00:25:19.030 --> 00:25:20.940
new tasks that were created
around that option being set.

525
00:25:20.940 --> 00:25:23.530
All right, well Ronnie,
this is probably a pretty good spot for

526
00:25:23.530 --> 00:25:26.840
us to wrap this one up, so
let's go ahead and do that.

527
00:25:26.840 --> 00:25:30.770
Hope you guys enjoyed it, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm your host Don Pezet.

528
00:25:30.770 --> 00:25:31.550
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

529
00:25:31.550 --> 00:25:32.936
>> And we'll see you next time.

530
00:25:32.936 --> 00:25:37.144
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don setup one of the most important options to get right from the beginning which is to establish the project start date.  The explore the options found within the Project Information dialog box and explain the importance of each setting.
episodes.title: Set Up Project Information
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.034 --> 00:00:12.934
All right.
Good morning, good afternoon, and

3
00:00:12.934 --> 00:00:15.986
good evening, welcome back to
another episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.986 --> 00:00:20.155
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again with
Mr. Ronnie Wong, how's it going Ronnie?

5
00:00:20.155 --> 00:00:22.485
>> It is going well today, I'm doing well,

6
00:00:22.485 --> 00:00:25.410
ready to get started into
some Microsoft Project.

7
00:00:25.410 --> 00:00:29.130
>> Now today we are going to take a look
at getting an initial project set up.

8
00:00:29.130 --> 00:00:32.480
Now when you create a new project,
you fire up Microsoft Project and

9
00:00:32.480 --> 00:00:35.320
hit the little new button and
it drop you right into a Gann chart and

10
00:00:35.320 --> 00:00:37.910
you are ready to go,
start dumping data in.

11
00:00:37.910 --> 00:00:43.920
Well there is an important step you should
take every time you create a new project,

12
00:00:43.920 --> 00:00:47.450
and that is setting some of
the default project information and

13
00:00:47.450 --> 00:00:49.460
this is really critical stuff.

14
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:51.680
It can be changed after the fact, but boy,

15
00:00:51.680 --> 00:00:53.340
does it make life
difficult if you do that.

16
00:00:53.340 --> 00:00:55.580
So when you create a new project,

17
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:58.530
these are the things that we need
to do right at the very beginning.

18
00:00:58.530 --> 00:00:59.070
Right, Ronnie?

19
00:00:59.070 --> 00:01:00.020
>> It really helps.

20
00:01:00.020 --> 00:01:03.620
When you start actually getting some
tasks already entered in there, and

21
00:01:03.620 --> 00:01:07.400
as long as you're actually just getting
it set up, you don't want things to start

22
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:10.920
maybe on the day that you're starting,
but usually by default,

23
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:13.680
that's what's gonna end up happening if
it doesn't know any other information.

24
00:01:13.680 --> 00:01:16.570
And so all of the tasks that you have,
you'll actually see that they'll

25
00:01:16.570 --> 00:01:19.250
start on the date that you're probably in,
and you probably don't want to do that.

26
00:01:19.250 --> 00:01:21.320
What you wanna do,
of course, is adjust it, and

27
00:01:21.320 --> 00:01:24.580
make sure that it's actually starting
on the day that you want it to start.

28
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:27.960
So what we're gonna be dealing with here
in this segment, is we're gonna be taking

29
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:31.620
a look at the project information that we
need to set up in the background that will

30

00:07:16.205 --> 00:07:20.795

162
00:08:36.310 --> 00:08:38.680
And for those of you with

00:08:38.680 --> 00:08:41.940

00:08:43.800 --> 00:08:46.570
And that terminology is

00:08:46.570 --> 00:08:48.770
So on the left side of your timeline,

00:08:48.770 --> 00:08:52.070

00:08:52.070 --> 00:08:52.780

Same thing.

00:08:53.340 --> 00:08:54.000
Left is today.

00:08:54.000 --> 00:08:55.560
Right is the end of the project.

00:08:55.560 --> 00:08:59.980
And if you schedule from left to right,

00:08:59.980 --> 00:09:02.290

00:09:07.200 --> 00:09:08.940
Backwards saying, all right,

00:09:08.940 --> 00:09:09.820
This is a four day task.

00:09:10.890 --> 00:09:16.270
If I want them all to finish on August 31,

And we kind of calculate it out.

00:09:17.430 --> 00:09:20.260
So it's definitely a different

00:09:20.260 --> 00:09:23.850
And it comes down to the project itself,

00:09:23.850 --> 00:09:25.430

That's what's gonna

Now, status date is used for

00:11:12.240 --> 00:11:13.770

00:11:13.770 --> 00:11:18.280

Well, when you put in status updates,

So when he submitted the form to me,

00:12:07.960 --> 00:12:10.270

00:12:23.790 --> 00:12:26.340
So what we do is we come in here and

And I might say hey, it's Monday, but

And now, when I start to enter

00:12:38.620 --> 00:12:40.810
So that's manipulating how
