00:12:40.810 --> 00:12:45.100
That's why we don't really care
about the option right now, but

252
00:12:45.100 --> 00:12:49.730
later on it's super important, any time
you are entering in new task performance

253
00:12:49.730 --> 00:12:53.480
data You gotta adjust that to when that
performance data was given to you.

254
00:12:54.790 --> 00:12:58.140
>> There's also this last option that we
have right here that we call priority.

255
00:12:58.140 --> 00:13:01.700
And this is actually a field that we can
range I believe from one to 1,000 and

256
00:13:01.700 --> 00:13:06.310
this is about resource leveling when we
have resources now assigned to projects

257
00:13:06.310 --> 00:13:10.220
and it actually gives us the ability to
go in and say hey, here's something that

258
00:13:10.220 --> 00:13:13.780
I want to actually be able to be level,
and here are other things I don't want to.

259
00:13:13.780 --> 00:13:18.050
By setting it on the project itself,
if you set it at the high number,

260
00:13:18.050 --> 00:13:20.940
I believe, at 1,000, you're saying look,

261
00:13:20.940 --> 00:13:25.450
I really don't want anything really
leveled out to adjust for over allocation.

262
00:13:25.450 --> 00:13:29.110
And if you set it at the one
it's saying over adjust for

263
00:13:29.110 --> 00:13:32.380
the over allocation at anytime you can,
as quick as you can.

264
00:13:32.380 --> 00:13:36.010
Usually 500 is default for
just about everything we have in project.

265
00:13:36.010 --> 00:13:38.180
>> Yeah.
And you can override that on a per

266
00:13:38.180 --> 00:13:39.000
task basis.

267
00:13:39.000 --> 00:13:39.840
You can go in and change it.

268
00:13:39.840 --> 00:13:42.230
And you notice like, Ron,
if you click your arrows there.

269
00:13:42.230 --> 00:13:45.210
It actually moves up and
down in increments of 10,

270
00:13:45.210 --> 00:13:47.540
so it goes from 500 to 510 to 520 and
so on.

271
00:13:47.540 --> 00:13:49.970
>> And this one does 20 by default.

272
00:13:49.970 --> 00:13:50.710
>> Increments of 20?

273
00:13:50.710 --> 00:13:51.310
>> Yeah.

274
00:13:51.310 --> 00:13:51.840
>> I might be wrong.

275
00:13:51.840 --> 00:13:52.430
Oh, it sure does.

276
00:13:52.430 --> 00:13:54.730
Look at that, 20.
I could have sworn it was 10.

277
00:13:54.730 --> 00:13:56.130
Well, it moves up in increments, and

278
00:13:56.130 --> 00:13:59.730
the reason it's doing that is
to leave you room in between.

279
00:13:59.730 --> 00:14:03.370
If I've got two tasks that
are scheduled at the same time, and

280
00:14:03.370 --> 00:14:06.580
I've got seven hours of labor
to divide between them,

281
00:14:06.580 --> 00:14:08.910
one of them's gonna get four hours and
one of them's gonna get three hours.

282
00:14:08.910 --> 00:14:10.090
How does it pick?

283
00:14:11.140 --> 00:14:16.560
Well, the higher priority task is going to
get the resources and the other one's not.

284
00:14:16.560 --> 00:14:18.860
So one will get four hours,
one will get three hours, and

285
00:14:18.860 --> 00:14:20.480
we can manipulate that priority.

286
00:14:20.480 --> 00:14:23.460
If you have two tasks that both
have a priority of 500, it's a tie.

287
00:14:24.480 --> 00:14:25.610
Who wins?

288
00:14:25.610 --> 00:14:28.400
Well on the tasks I can override that.

289
00:14:28.400 --> 00:14:30.560
And I can make one 501 versus 500.

290
00:14:30.560 --> 00:14:33.500
So that's why they move up in increments
of 20 is to give you that gap.

291
00:14:33.500 --> 00:14:35.190
You don't have to do that.

292
00:14:35.190 --> 00:14:37.190
But if I have one that's 501 and
one that's 502 and

293
00:14:37.190 --> 00:14:40.800
I want to put something in between them,
there's no room in between them.

294
00:14:40.800 --> 00:14:41.700
I can't do it.

295
00:14:41.700 --> 00:14:44.140
But if I skip by 20s I've got that room,

296
00:14:44.140 --> 00:14:47.190
I can make one 510 and
then you've got one in between.

297
00:14:47.190 --> 00:14:48.750
So, it's an interesting option.

298
00:14:48.750 --> 00:14:50.100
Here we're just setting the default.

299
00:14:50.100 --> 00:14:52.370
The default priority for
all of our stuff is gonna be 500,

300
00:14:52.370 --> 00:14:53.680
which is right in the middle.

301
00:14:53.680 --> 00:14:57.270
It goes from zero to 1,000,
this puts it right in the middle.

302
00:14:57.270 --> 00:15:00.230
>> The other nice option that we
have here in the project information

303
00:15:00.230 --> 00:15:01.770
is this statistic button.

304
00:15:01.770 --> 00:15:05.860
It doesn't really account for much right
now, what it actually gives me the ability

305
00:15:05.860 --> 00:15:10.090
to see, of course, is my project start and
finish dates on this nice little,

306
00:15:10.090 --> 00:15:13.720
easy report that they give so
that way I can see what's going on.

307
00:15:13.720 --> 00:15:16.400
If we start entering in things
like the status date and

308
00:15:16.400 --> 00:15:20.610
updating it, these numbers will also
change and be available for us.

309
00:15:20.610 --> 00:15:24.680
But this is great for a project manager
because he actually has one place where

310
00:15:24.680 --> 00:15:28.910
he can go and get a lot of statistics
right away to be able to see that.

311
00:15:28.910 --> 00:15:31.460
Yeah, it closes out the entire
project information

312
00:15:31.460 --> 00:15:32.725
window every time I select it so.

313
00:15:32.725 --> 00:15:34.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I keep going back to it.

314
00:15:34.560 --> 00:15:39.000
So it is a nice little location.

315
00:15:39.000 --> 00:15:41.990
That we can get a lot of information and
be able to see it right away.

316
00:15:41.990 --> 00:15:44.730
But setting this stuff up at
the very beginning is what you

317
00:15:44.730 --> 00:15:48.550
really want to be able to do,
because this will then go ahead and

318
00:15:48.550 --> 00:15:52.750
affect all the other tasks
that you have from here.

319
00:15:52.750 --> 00:15:55.725
And that's what will start
happening if I select these tasks.

320
00:15:55.725 --> 00:15:58.646
They'll start filling in those dates,
but from the project start date.

321
00:15:58.646 --> 00:15:59.954
>> Yeah, all right, well Ronnie,

322
00:15:59.954 --> 00:16:03.056
that's a pretty good overview of
the various project information settings.

323
00:16:03.056 --> 00:16:06.217
Do remember,
setting these early is always better.

324
00:16:06.217 --> 00:16:07.979
So this is one of the first
things that we set.

325
00:16:07.979 --> 00:16:10.216
And, I don't we covered it
in the other episode, but

326
00:16:10.216 --> 00:16:13.090
there's actually an option
inside of our project options.

327
00:16:13.090 --> 00:16:15.460
You know let's show this real quick,
cuz we do have some time.

328
00:16:15.460 --> 00:16:18.040
If you go into your
Microsoft project options.

329
00:16:18.040 --> 00:16:18.840
>> Microsoft, yep.

330
00:16:18.840 --> 00:16:19.780
>> You got it right.

331
00:16:19.780 --> 00:16:22.400
So if you jump into those options,
you could go down to advanced.

332
00:16:22.400 --> 00:16:26.630
And inside of advanced,
there's an option tucked away in there to

333
00:16:26.630 --> 00:16:31.740
display the project information screen
every time you create a new project.

334
00:16:31.740 --> 00:16:33.620
It's kinda one of the options
nested away there.

335
00:16:33.620 --> 00:16:36.410
And, let me see if I can remember,
it's one of those options where you

336
00:16:36.410 --> 00:16:39.530
just set it once and
then you never have to set it again.

337
00:16:39.530 --> 00:16:42.180
So it is tucked away under,

338
00:16:43.280 --> 00:16:48.020
if you go under Advanced, it's right
there up at the top under General.

339
00:16:48.020 --> 00:16:51.580
The second option, it says, prompt for
project info for new projects.

340
00:16:51.580 --> 00:16:54.730
And it basically says,
if you're creating a new project,

341
00:16:54.730 --> 00:16:57.860
the first thing we should do is pop
up that project information screen,

342
00:16:57.860 --> 00:16:59.590
because that's where you need to go,
right?

343
00:16:59.590 --> 00:17:01.665
So Microsoft knows this is
something that's important enough.

344
00:17:01.665 --> 00:17:02.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

345
00:17:02.420 --> 00:17:04.200
they don't check this by default so
it's not there.

346
00:17:04.200 --> 00:17:05.520
So if you're worried about forgetting it,

347
00:17:05.520 --> 00:17:09.020
this is a great way to make it prompt
anytime you create that new project.

348
00:17:09.020 --> 00:17:12.860
We wanna set it because if we change
things like, whether we're scheduling from

349
00:17:12.860 --> 00:17:16.270
a start date or scheduling from
a finish date, that's a big change.

350
00:17:16.270 --> 00:17:18.655
And it can really alter the way
your project functions.

351
00:17:18.655 --> 00:17:21.470
It can cause some problems if
you change it after the fact.

352
00:17:21.470 --> 00:17:22.740
Better to change it early.

353
00:17:22.740 --> 00:17:26.040
All right, well Ronnie, this is a pretty
good spot for us to wrap this one up.

354
00:17:26.040 --> 00:17:27.520
Do you have anything
else you wanna throw in?

355
00:17:27.520 --> 00:17:29.940
>> We have one more thing that we need
to throw in here at the very end.

356
00:17:29.940 --> 00:17:33.950
This is actually a great one cuz
it talks about summarizing things.

357
00:17:33.950 --> 00:17:38.840
And we wanna actually be able to put the
name of our project right here at the top.

358
00:17:38.840 --> 00:17:42.500
Now, I could go ahead and
just insert in a new task and

359
00:17:42.500 --> 00:17:45.680
then just type in the name that
I want the project to be, but

360
00:17:45.680 --> 00:17:48.850
Project has a way of actually
allowing us to do that.

361
00:17:48.850 --> 00:17:51.070
It's kind of a neat option that we have.

362
00:17:51.070 --> 00:17:54.260
And the way that it keys it,
is normally off of the file name as well,

363
00:17:54.260 --> 00:17:56.070
if you don't have one set.

364
00:17:56.070 --> 00:18:03.131
So the way that you do that,
let me make sure I actually remember this,

365
00:18:03.131 --> 00:18:08.370
is if I go to task,
there is field and formats.

366
00:18:08.370 --> 00:18:11.440
You know, of all the things I can't
remember, it's always under formatting.

367
00:18:11.440 --> 00:18:16.740
If I select format, and it's over here
at the end where it says show hide.

368
00:18:16.740 --> 00:18:20.640
So, notice that we have this little
box that's actually not checked here,

369
00:18:20.640 --> 00:18:22.610
says project summary task.

370
00:18:22.610 --> 00:18:27.380
If I select that, you'll see that it
added in a project summary task right up

371
00:18:27.380 --> 00:18:29.250
here at the very top for us.

372
00:18:29.250 --> 00:18:31.730
So, I didn't have to go and
name what this project was.

373
00:18:31.730 --> 00:18:33.940
I could have manually done this and

374
00:18:33.940 --> 00:18:36.880
it automatically sets it as
this auto scheduled task.

375
00:18:36.880 --> 00:18:40.060
And what that will actually allow us to
do, as we start entering in duration and

376
00:18:40.060 --> 00:18:42.630
start and finish dates here,

377
00:18:42.630 --> 00:18:46.360
we'll actually see that these numbers
will go ahead and start accumulating.

378
00:18:46.360 --> 00:18:47.840
We'll actually be able to see it here.

379
00:18:47.840 --> 00:18:50.900
Then later on we'll actually be
able to roll up all those tasks and

380
00:18:50.900 --> 00:18:53.580
essentially shrink it down to
that one line if we need to,.

381
00:18:53.580 --> 00:18:54.610
Kind of neat.

382
00:18:54.610 --> 00:18:56.440
>> Yeah, that's happening automatically so

383
00:18:56.440 --> 00:19:00.930
it's a great way to see what the full
duration of your project is.

384
00:19:00.930 --> 00:19:04.650
So for example, Ronnie, throw like a ten
day duration on one of your activities.

385
00:19:04.650 --> 00:19:06.050
And you'll see the roll up right now,

386
00:19:06.050 --> 00:19:10.170
it goes from August 17th to August 17th,
cuz everything's a one day activity.

387
00:19:10.170 --> 00:19:13.500
But now that he's added ten days see
how the start date is August 17th and

388
00:19:13.500 --> 00:19:16.540
the finish date is August 20th?

389
00:19:16.540 --> 00:19:19.420
So it knows,
hey this is a ten day project now.

390
00:19:19.420 --> 00:19:23.650
And so as our project gets more and more
complex, this roll up task lets us see

391
00:19:23.650 --> 00:19:27.280
one big time line for the whole
project and that can be pretty handy.

392
00:19:27.280 --> 00:19:28.250
It is off by default.

393
00:19:28.250 --> 00:19:30.560
When you turn it on,
it gives you the name of the file.

394
00:19:30.560 --> 00:19:31.610
You can rename that.

395
00:19:31.610 --> 00:19:35.453
So, I'll often do that, take file names,
not necessarily what we want.

396
00:19:35.453 --> 00:19:38.137
So we might rename that to be
the terminal server project.

397
00:19:38.137 --> 00:19:41.010
And it stays being that rollup,
and it's auto-calculating.

398
00:19:41.010 --> 00:19:43.360
So it's pretty neat to have that
kind of functionality in there.

399
00:19:45.500 --> 00:19:47.135
Yup, so
Ronnie's just gonna rename that one.

400
00:19:47.135 --> 00:19:49.930
And once that's in,
it takes place, and there you go.

401
00:19:49.930 --> 00:19:53.200
So, nice to have, especially if you're
managing more than one project at a time,

402
00:19:53.200 --> 00:19:56.740
you can quickly and easily identify that.

403
00:19:56.740 --> 00:19:57.710
>> There we go.

404
00:19:57.710 --> 00:20:00.800
>> Alright, well, that's about it for
our initial setup options.

405
00:20:00.800 --> 00:20:03.400
Obviously, we still have a lot
more that we can do in Project, so

406
00:20:03.400 --> 00:20:06.060
stay tuned,
we have those episodes coming up.

407
00:20:06.060 --> 00:20:09.040
But for now, signing off for
IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

408
00:20:09.040 --> 00:20:09.840
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

409
00:20:09.840 --> 00:20:11.282
>> And we'll see you next time.

410
00:20:11.282 --> 00:20:17.240
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into creating tasks manually within a project plan.  They also show how you can rearrange the tasks within a project plan, create milestones and set a task as active or inactive to do show "What if" scenarios easily.  They complete the show by adding a recurring task to our plan.
episodes.title: Creating Tasks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.019 --> 00:00:10.019
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.186 --> 00:00:12.986
All right, good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

3
00:00:12.986 --> 00:00:17.360
Welcome back to another episode of
ITProTV, I'm your host, Don Pezet.

4
00:00:17.360 --> 00:00:19.350
Back again with Mr.
Ronnie Wong, how's it going Ronnie?

5
00:00:19.350 --> 00:00:20.440
>> It is going well today,

6
00:00:20.440 --> 00:00:24.830
feeling good, ready to get started into
Microsoft Project today, so excited.

7
00:00:24.830 --> 00:00:27.720
>> Well, today we're gonna be jumping
into the topic that's probably the most

8
00:00:27.720 --> 00:00:30.700
anticipated, which is
creating tasks in project.

9
00:00:30.700 --> 00:00:34.810
Project is 100% useless if you
don't put some tasks in there,

10
00:00:34.810 --> 00:00:36.390
that's what this is really all about.

11
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:42.220
Now, I do wanna mention one thing real
quick is, if you are PMI certified or

12
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:45.450
trained in the Project Management
Institutes of Methodology.

13
00:00:45.450 --> 00:00:47.300
They hate the word task,

14
00:00:47.300 --> 00:00:50.590
they just do not like it,
they like the word activity, right?

15
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:52.730
Well, inside a project,
it kind of goes either way.

16
00:00:52.730 --> 00:00:55.530
So when we talk about a task or
an activity,

17
00:00:55.530 --> 00:00:57.240
it's something people need to do.

18
00:00:57.240 --> 00:01:00.322
And we have a string of these things
that people need to do that lead to

19
00:01:00.322 --> 00:01:01.687
the project being finished.

20
00:01:01.687 --> 00:01:04.240
So it doesn't really matter if you
call them activities or tasks,

21
00:01:04.240 --> 00:01:06.250
Microsoft generally calls them tasks.

22
00:01:06.250 --> 00:01:08.010
So we need to get those created,

23
00:01:08.010 --> 00:01:10.340
otherwise we're not gonna be able to take
advantage of the project, right Ronnie?

24
00:01:10.340 --> 00:01:13.220
>> That's true, when you talk about
activities or tasks, a lot of times you

25
00:01:13.220 --> 00:01:16.230
also use the term you're probably
familiar with it more than I am.

26
00:01:16.230 --> 00:01:20.420
The term work package is also another
great term that you also end up

27
00:01:20.420 --> 00:01:21.680
putting out there.

28
00:01:21.680 --> 00:01:25.900
But once you do have in mind what you
want to start to be able to control and

29
00:01:25.900 --> 00:01:27.960
monitor, well, it's fairly simple.

30
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:31.120
You can actually do it of course
a couple of different ways.

31
00:01:31.120 --> 00:01:35.890
One is by simply typing in tasks
directly into the project.

32
00:01:35.890 --> 00:01:39.479
So I simply opened up a brand new
project that has nothing in it and

33
00:01:39.479 --> 00:01:43.480
I can just go ahead and begin to go in and
type in information as I want to.

34
00:01:43.480 --> 00:01:47.280
So I'm gonna call it Task1, Task2, Task3.

35
00:01:49.110 --> 00:01:53.442
Oops, so much for Task3 being
something that's easy for me to do.

36
00:01:53.442 --> 00:01:55.191
[LAUGH]
>> You've ruined everything.

37
00:01:55.191 --> 00:01:55.899
>> I know.

38
00:01:55.899 --> 00:01:59.450
It's amazing how easily I can
actually ruin something like that.

39
00:01:59.450 --> 00:02:02.740
But we can simply go ahead and just start
typing that in and from that point.

40
00:02:04.050 --> 00:02:09.150
You've now created three different work
packages that you have available and

41
00:02:09.150 --> 00:02:11.680
now you're ready to add in some durations.

42
00:02:11.680 --> 00:02:15.320
From that point if your project calendar
is set up, it will start to go ahead and

43
00:02:15.320 --> 00:02:19.595
put in those Start dates and even Finish
dates as your duration actually shows up.

44
00:02:19.595 --> 00:02:22.875
So we're kind of done, Don, I don't see
anything else we really need to do.

45
00:02:22.875 --> 00:02:24.840
>> That's it,
this project is gonna finish itself.

46
00:02:24.840 --> 00:02:28.715
This is really kind of where we start
with the early planning stages,

47
00:02:28.715 --> 00:02:31.025
maybe even in the initiation stages,
right?

48
00:02:31.025 --> 00:02:34.267
Where we say, all right, here's the
project we're gonna do, let's just try and

49
00:02:34.267 --> 00:02:36.507
come up with a list of all
the stuff that needs to get done.

50
00:02:36.507 --> 00:02:39.112
In the planning phase, a lot of people
refer to this as the work breakdown

51
00:02:39.112 --> 00:02:41.092
structure, we're trying to
figure out all the work.

52
00:02:41.092 --> 00:02:43.498
But this might not be directly
tied to work packages,

53
00:02:43.498 --> 00:02:46.030
it might just be activities
that need to happen.

54
00:02:46.030 --> 00:02:47.630
So we start laying it out, and

55
00:02:47.630 --> 00:02:51.330
you might do exactly like Ronnie did,
let's just do the names first, all right?

56
00:02:51.330 --> 00:02:53.010
After we got all of the names in place,

57
00:02:53.010 --> 00:02:55.060
then we start thinking about the order,
right?

58
00:02:55.060 --> 00:02:56.825
Which order these are gonna
have to get done in.

59
00:02:56.825 --> 00:02:59.190
Because we might be thinking of
the tasks that have to get done and

60
00:02:59.190 --> 00:03:01.070
not necessarily how they
relate to each other.

61
00:03:01.070 --> 00:03:04.310
And we're gonna talk about
relationships in another episode.

62
00:03:04.310 --> 00:03:07.762
Project relationships, not personal ones,
that would be a fun episode.

63
00:03:07.762 --> 00:03:11.120
[LAUGH] So we'll break it down there and
kind of have tackle that.

64

00:07:27.530 --> 00:07:28.690

00:07:46.860 --> 00:07:48.328

So, in a very small project

Put it in order by the type of

Divide up into something that's

Now often times that means that I'm

Now the easiest way to do that, and

If I select task number two,
Installing and

Configuring Server 2008 here,

And when I do that, you actually watched

00:09:57.060 --> 00:10:01.000
It looks like a staple, Don,

So I can go ahead and,

And now anything is actually, or

So for

00:10:52.155 --> 00:10:52.900

00:10:52.900 --> 00:10:54.570

The second advantage is you can

So to the left of the testing page

That's kind of a nice function there.

00:11:34.450 --> 00:11:37.870

Right, it looks like it's only 3 lines of

If I want to just focus in on the

And then of course the tuning.

00:11:56.750 --> 00:12:01.320
So it gives us that ability to be able

00:12:01.320 --> 00:12:04.870

We're just getting our project ready for

00:12:09.370 --> 00:12:13.130
>> Now, once we've got that kind of set

If you grab the roll up task and

00:12:31.079 --> 00:12:33.505

00:12:33.505 --> 00:12:36.230
>> Gonna talk about setting milestones,

00:12:36.230 --> 00:12:38.930
So when we talk about

00:12:38.930 --> 00:12:42.470
it's actually fairly easy to do

255
00:12:42.470 --> 00:12:44.680
But, Don, what's the importance

256
00:12:44.680 --> 00:12:46.280
>> All right.
So, we're gonna see whether

257
00:12:46.280 --> 00:12:49.020
certain activities that we create
that aren't actual activities,

258
00:12:49.020 --> 00:12:52.730
it's not somebody has do to something,
it's just marking a point in time.

259
00:12:52.730 --> 00:12:55.340
So like that rollup task where it
marks kind of the beginning and

260
00:12:55.340 --> 00:12:56.550
end of that activity,

261
00:12:56.550 --> 00:13:01.110
we might have milestones that are dates
set by our customer that we intend to hit.

262
00:13:01.110 --> 00:13:03.002
So maybe we have an intended date for

263
00:13:03.002 --> 00:13:07.150
the testing phase that we want
it to be done by August 31st.

264
00:13:07.150 --> 00:13:09.070
So I might wanna create a milestone for
August 31st.

265
00:13:09.070 --> 00:13:12.700
I'm not saying there's work that
needs to be done on August 31st.

266
00:13:12.700 --> 00:13:14.940
I'm saying we should be
done by August 31st.

267
00:13:15.950 --> 00:13:18.560
So we might want to create an activity
right there at the end of the testing

268
00:13:18.560 --> 00:13:21.640
phase that says something
like testing phase complete.

269
00:13:21.640 --> 00:13:22.410
Right?

270
00:13:22.410 --> 00:13:27.270
And I want that to be set for August 31st,
but I don't want it to be work.

271
00:13:27.270 --> 00:13:28.700
So, how do we identify that?

272
00:13:28.700 --> 00:13:32.100
We identify it by setting
a duration of zero days.

273
00:13:32.100 --> 00:13:36.120
If you have a duration of zero,
the project will make it a milestone.

274
00:13:36.120 --> 00:13:39.560
And it's just a marker we can use for
our own tracking purposes, and

275
00:13:39.560 --> 00:13:41.512
we'll see that later in
the reporting shows.

276
00:13:41.512 --> 00:13:44.853
If we're like, well, are we behind
schedule, are we ahead of schedule,

277
00:13:44.853 --> 00:13:47.413
did we meet our milestone, or
did we miss our milestone.

278
00:13:47.413 --> 00:13:50.150
And we'll be able to see that
because we got that entry.

279
00:13:50.150 --> 00:13:54.480
So Ronnie just created that testing phase
complete, he gave it a zero duration, and

280
00:13:54.480 --> 00:13:56.550
look what happened over
in the Gantt chart.

00:13:56.550 --> 00:13:58.700
It changed into a diamond.

282
00:13:58.700 --> 00:14:02.710
That little diamond is the way that
Microsoft Project represents a milestone.

283
00:14:02.710 --> 00:14:06.900
And now we know this isn't actual work,
this is a target.

284
00:14:06.900 --> 00:14:08.910
This is something that we
need to finish this by.

285
00:14:08.910 --> 00:14:11.700
The testing phase should
be done on August 31st.

286
00:14:11.700 --> 00:14:15.260
And if we're still working on
activities past August 31st, we can

287
00:14:15.260 --> 00:14:18.860
visually see that, the activities are
extending beyond where that milestone is.

288

two weeks if I need to.

508
00:25:23.610 --> 00:25:25.780
But I can go ahead and set that up.

509
00:25:25.780 --> 00:25:29.870
And then I can set up a range of
the actual occurrences too and

510
00:25:29.870 --> 00:25:31.450
tell it when to end by.

511
00:25:31.450 --> 00:25:36.155
If I know that my project is possibly
gonna end by let's say December 31st,

512
00:25:37.531 --> 00:25:40.357
At least that's what I'm hoping for,
I can go ahead and

513
00:25:40.357 --> 00:25:44.290
select that to actually have that
recurring status meeting in there.

514
00:25:44.290 --> 00:25:47.602
Every two hours, and then on the project
calendar, if I'd created one,

515
00:25:47.602 --> 00:25:49.920
I would select that one, but
I just have the standard calendar.

516
00:25:50.950 --> 00:25:52.950
And then it says scheduling
ignores resource calendars.

517
00:25:52.950 --> 00:25:55.980
Now, this is actually an important
resource for us because,

518
00:25:55.980 --> 00:26:00.410
remember that a resource calendar will
override the project's default calendar.

519
00:26:00.410 --> 00:26:02.290
So, if we are actually saying, look,

520
00:26:02.290 --> 00:26:07.250
we need the meeting to occur, regardless
of what that resource says it can do.

521
00:26:07.250 --> 00:26:09.070
We might also wanna check that too, so

522
00:26:09.070 --> 00:26:11.500
that way it actually still goes ahead and
happens.

523
00:26:11.500 --> 00:26:15.577
So, I'm going to do that here.

524
00:26:15.577 --> 00:26:19.774
And once I do that, noticed it added
in all of those meetings right there at

525
00:26:19.774 --> 00:26:22.076
the project where I actually selected,

526
00:26:22.076 --> 00:26:24.601
probably not a great
point at where I put it.

527
00:26:24.601 --> 00:26:27.810
[LAUGH] I should have actually selected
where I wanted it to go first.

528
00:26:27.810 --> 00:26:30.789
>> Well, you could move them
which you might wanna do.

529
00:26:30.789 --> 00:26:34.320
Or, you might wanna put them in their
own subtask so you can collapse it and

530
00:26:34.320 --> 00:26:37.120
you're not be bugged with it all the time,
but they still show up in your calendar,

531
00:26:37.120 --> 00:26:38.360
which is pretty handy.

532
00:26:38.360 --> 00:26:40.830
Or if you're printing a to do list for
somebody it'll show up in there,

533
00:26:40.830 --> 00:26:42.640
which is a pretty nice thing too.

534
00:26:42.640 --> 00:26:45.855
And notice that it's not just
creating these tasks and

535
00:26:45.855 --> 00:26:47.975
just throwing them out
there as individual tasks.

536
00:26:47.975 --> 00:26:51.485
They are still kind of
associated in a way.

537
00:26:51.485 --> 00:26:55.355
So, you'll see on the left side there
how it's got the little circle icon

538
00:26:55.355 --> 00:26:58.605
in the status column, it's letting
us know it is a recurring task.

539
00:26:58.605 --> 00:27:02.355
So, you can always go back and modify the
whole series as opposed to being forced to

540
00:27:02.355 --> 00:27:05.105
edit each one individually,
it's a pretty nice feature.

541
00:27:05.105 --> 00:27:07.600
>> It really is and
you start seeing all these meetings.

542
00:27:07.600 --> 00:27:11.150
So we were to start having these project
status meetings every week, it shows me,

543
00:27:11.150 --> 00:27:14.040
it looks like I'm gonna have 25 different
meetings all the way to the end of

544
00:27:14.040 --> 00:27:16.500
the year, if my project goes that long.

545
00:27:16.500 --> 00:27:18.120
More than likely,
it's not gonna go that long.

546
00:27:18.120 --> 00:27:20.340
>> Hey, with that many meetings,
you're definitely guaranteed success,

547
00:27:20.340 --> 00:27:21.350
right Ronnie?

548
00:27:21.350 --> 00:27:21.985
>> Eh, no.

549
00:27:21.985 --> 00:27:24.520
[LAUGH]
>> I thought project success was measured

550
00:27:24.520 --> 00:27:25.460
based on how many meetings you have.

551
00:27:25.460 --> 00:27:28.060
>> I think it's based on
how many meetings you have

552
00:27:28.060 --> 00:27:30.500
times some other duration
that we might not know about.

553
00:27:30.500 --> 00:27:32.830
>> Times quantity of synergy.

554
00:27:32.830 --> 00:27:34.250
>> That's right synergy.

555
00:27:34.250 --> 00:27:36.880
>> So it's.
[LAUGH] All right so,

556
00:27:36.880 --> 00:27:40.700
as far as getting tasks created,
there's some neat features in there, but

557
00:27:40.700 --> 00:27:44.160
the basic functions of getting a task
created is super simple, right?

558
00:27:44.160 --> 00:27:46.770
And we can indent them to
create the nested tasks.

559
00:27:46.770 --> 00:27:49.880
That's usually step 1 for
getting tasks loaded in our project.

560
00:27:49.880 --> 00:27:53.640
Step 2, it's setting up all
the relationships between the projects,

561
00:27:53.640 --> 00:27:57.120
or between the activities, but
that's a much bigger task for us.

562
00:27:57.120 --> 00:27:59.150
So let's save that one for
another episode.

563
00:27:59.150 --> 00:28:02.070
As far as creating tasks, so Ronnie,
you have anything else you wanna throw in?

564
00:28:02.070 --> 00:28:05.770
>> No, just remember, if you're not
familiar with it, play with it.

565
00:28:05.770 --> 00:28:08.400
This is the way to get to learn it,
cuz if not you're gonna go,

566
00:28:08.400 --> 00:28:09.830
okay, I don't know what I'm
supposed to do with it.

567
00:28:09.830 --> 00:28:12.690
So, more often you're in it,
the better it's gonna be.

568
00:28:12.690 --> 00:28:13.600
>> Absolutely.

569
00:28:13.600 --> 00:28:16.540
All right, well ladies and gentlemen,
I hope you guys enjoyed the episode.

570
00:28:16.540 --> 00:28:18.630
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

571
00:28:18.630 --> 00:28:19.840
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

572
00:28:19.840 --> 00:28:20.585
>> And we'll see you next time.

573
00:28:20.585 --> 00:28:26.090
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don discuss and demonstrate some of the different ways to control the project schedule using date constraints and dependencies and show how to link task together so that Project 2013 can use it's scheduling engine to put things in proper order. Understanding where and when to use the constraints in Project 2013 is an important part of working with the software.
episodes.title: Task Relationships
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.459
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.459 --> 00:00:13.270
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.270 --> 00:00:14.090
Welcome back.

4
00:00:14.090 --> 00:00:15.580
To another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:15.580 --> 00:00:18.900
I'm your host, Don Bassett,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:18.900 --> 00:00:19.660
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:21.070
>> It is going great.

8
00:00:21.070 --> 00:00:23.240
Excited today, ready for

9
00:00:23.240 --> 00:00:26.992
another great time to take
a look at the Microsoft Project.

10
00:00:26.992 --> 00:00:29.510
All right well, today we're going to
be taking a very important part of

11
00:00:29.510 --> 00:00:30.390
Microsoft Project,

12
00:00:30.390 --> 00:00:34.580
which is the relationships
between the tasks that we make.

13
00:00:34.580 --> 00:00:36.940
When you put tasks into
project by default,

14
00:00:36.940 --> 00:00:42.290
every task is it's own individual entity
completely independent of everything else.

15
00:00:42.290 --> 00:00:44.530
But in real life,
we know it's not like that.

16
00:00:44.530 --> 00:00:48.000
There's a lot of things
that influence a task.

17
00:00:48.000 --> 00:00:50.050
They might influence when it can start,

18
00:00:50.050 --> 00:00:53.440
when it can finish, might influence
who's available to work on them.

19
00:00:53.440 --> 00:00:56.190
And these are all things that
are called constraints, and

20
00:00:56.190 --> 00:00:58.510
there's a number of different
types of constraints.

21
00:00:58.510 --> 00:01:01.040
Microsoft Project has
the bulk of them in there.

22
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:02.180
The ones that people really deal with.

23
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:05.220
They're all in there, we just need to
know what they are, how they work, and

24
00:01:05.220 --> 00:01:07.870
kind of how they affect
the way that our tasks work.

25
00:01:07.870 --> 00:01:10.350
So Ronnie, where are we gonna start
on this, because there's so many?

26
00:01:10.350 --> 00:01:13.470
>> Well a lot of times you have to just
kind of logically remember what we've done

27
00:01:13.470 --> 00:01:14.590
so far, right?

28
00:01:14.590 --> 00:01:17.570
We've just kind of added
in tasks into Project.

29
00:01:17.570 --> 00:01:19.810
It's just like you opened up
an Excel spreadsheet right now and

30
00:01:19.810 --> 00:01:21.330
you just started adding them in.

31
00:01:21.330 --> 00:01:24.000
We've seen a little bit of different
things that we can add in,

32
00:01:24.000 --> 00:01:26.970
as far as properties and
changes to the individual task, but

33
00:01:26.970 --> 00:01:28.360
right now it's really not doing anything.

34
00:01:28.360 --> 00:01:32.690
So, Project is really not showing
us its full ability to do things.

35
00:01:32.690 --> 00:01:34.410
We start talking about
adding in constraints,

36
00:01:34.410 --> 00:01:37.750
now we're gonna actually make
project do some of the things

37
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:40.820
that it has to do to set our
schedule on the right track.

38
00:01:40.820 --> 00:01:43.510
So one of the ways we can
do that is by taking a look

39
00:01:43.510 --> 00:01:47.030
at some of the different constraints
that we can put in place on each and

40
00:01:47.030 --> 00:01:50.200
every individual task that
we have inside a project.

41
00:01:50.200 --> 00:01:52.010
And by that, what do we mean?

42
00:01:52.010 --> 00:01:56.220
We mean setting the limitations of when
the project may be able to begin or

43
00:01:56.220 --> 00:01:57.820
when it has to end as well.

44
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:00.590
And there's a range of different
constraints that are actually

45
00:02:00.590 --> 00:02:01.950
in between that too.

46
00:02:01.950 --> 00:02:04.820
So let me show you an example
of what I'm talking about.

47
00:02:04.820 --> 00:02:06.790
Here on my computer, I went ahead and

48
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:10.570
opened up a Project plan
that we had already started.

49
00:02:10.570 --> 00:02:15.330
But I don't have anything actually there,
it's just showing me a list of different

50
00:02:15.330 --> 00:02:20.580
tasks that I have available, and if I want
to set a constraint on these tasks, a lot

51
00:02:20.580 --> 00:02:25.010
of times, it's fairly simple, but you
have to keep a couple of things in mind.

52
00:02:25.010 --> 00:02:28.710
So, I'm gonna select this 2.1 Installing
and Configuring Server 2008 R2,

53
00:02:28.710 --> 00:02:31.900
I'm gonna right-click, and
I'm gonna go down to information.

54
00:02:31.900 --> 00:02:35.520
And that should bring up my
Task Information dialog box.

55
00:02:35.520 --> 00:02:38.120
When I do that, what I'm looking for here,

56
00:02:38.120 --> 00:02:42.840
inside of Task Information is
gonna be under this Advanced tab.

57
00:02:42.840 --> 00:02:46.960
Now when I take a look at it I can
just see right away that it says hey,

58
00:02:46.960 --> 00:02:48.170
I can set a deadline.

59
00:02:48.170 --> 00:02:50.540
And that might be something I want to set.

60
00:02:50.540 --> 00:02:54.300
But what I'm really trying to get to is
where it says right here, constraint type.

61
00:02:54.300 --> 00:02:57.380
And Don right away,
I look at it and it's grayed out.

62
00:02:57.380 --> 00:02:58.730
It looks like, okay.

63
00:02:58.730 --> 00:03:02.560
So as soon as possible looks like
the only option that I have, but

64
00:03:02.560 --> 00:03:05.010
it really isn't the only
option that we have.

65
00:03:05.010 --> 00:03:08.920
But only by working with Microsoft Project
do you understand what's going on.

66
00:03:08.920 --> 00:03:11.470
And why you can't get
to this right here too.

67
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:15.950
So next we can set a constraint type and
a constraint date but it's not letting me

68
00:03:15.950 --> 00:03:19.910
do it and believe it or not, all of my
tasks are actually going to be that way.

69
00:03:19.910 --> 00:03:23.770
If I select another one,
just to show you a quick example here, and

70
00:03:23.770 --> 00:03:26.320
I go on down through the list
you'll see the same thing.

71
00:03:26.320 --> 00:03:31.060
And the reason why that's happening,
is because Microsoft or the Project,

72
00:03:31.060 --> 00:03:33.010
the way that I have it set up right now.

73
00:03:33.010 --> 00:03:36.188
It is saying Ronnie you said that
you wanna control everything.

74
00:03:36.188 --> 00:03:40.140
Okay, so you're gonna manually set
all of these things into place,

75
00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:42.690
so that means I'm not gonna worry about
constraints because you're gonna actually

76
00:03:42.690 --> 00:03:44.780
type in everything that you need to do.

77
00:03:44.780 --> 00:03:49.120
It's over here under this second column
that says Task Mode that I actually have

78
00:03:49.120 --> 00:03:52.890
to change something, cuz everything right
now that I have is actually manually set.

79
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:56.990
If I click on that for line 22,
notice it says Manually Scheduled.

80
00:03:56.990 --> 00:03:58.760
That's means I'm gonna control everything.

81
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:02.250
But what I want to do is I wanna
let projects start to help me out.

82
00:04:02.250 --> 00:04:05.400
So I change that task type
to Auto Scheduled, and

83
00:04:05.400 --> 00:04:07.870
when I do that we see the icon change.

84
00:04:07.870 --> 00:04:12.590
And then if I right click on that task and
I go to task information, and

85
00:04:12.590 --> 00:04:18.050
once my Task Information dialog box comes
back up, I click on this Advanced tab.

86
00:04:18.050 --> 00:04:21.360
Now notice that I have options
to not only set a Deadline,

87
00:04:21.360 --> 00:04:26.160
the Constraint type as well as
the date that I also have ready to go.

88
00:04:26.160 --> 00:04:28.680
Now it's here, Don, that we have so
many different options.

89
00:04:28.680 --> 00:04:29.320
Right?

90
00:04:29.320 --> 00:04:31.060
>> Yeah.
And when you create a constraint,

91
00:04:31.060 --> 00:04:34.030
if you're manually scheduling,
it's like you said, Ron.

92
00:04:34.030 --> 00:04:36.930
You don't need constraints cuz you
manually put it on a particular date.

93
00:04:36.930 --> 00:04:41.260
If I've got contractors that are available
just the first three days in June,

94
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:44.480
I manually create the task,
it's not gonna move unless I move it.

95
00:04:44.480 --> 00:04:49.070
But, if we're auto scheduling, I can
stretch out a task that happened before,

96
00:04:49.070 --> 00:04:52.030
and it would push this one
back with auto scheduling.

97
00:04:52.030 --> 00:04:56.130
And so constraints are how we
override the Auto Schedule.

98
00:04:56.130 --> 00:04:59.040
And you'll see that list of all
the constraints that are there.

99
00:04:59.040 --> 00:05:02.005
As soon as possible is kinda
the default for a project.

100
00:05:02.005 --> 00:05:02.980
Right?
Which means

101
00:05:02.980 --> 00:05:05.670
if we're auto scheduling this needs
to just happen as soon as it can.

102
00:05:05.670 --> 00:05:07.500
It doesn't have to happen
on a particular date,

103
00:05:07.500 --> 00:05:12.040
it just has to happen as soon as it can
and as late as possible is the same thing.

104
00:05:12.040 --> 00:05:16.050
What's the latest we can make this happen
without disrupting the other tasks.

105
00:05:16.050 --> 00:05:18.030
But there's a lot of other choices
in there, aren't there, Ronnie?

106
00:05:18.030 --> 00:05:21.010
>> There are a lot of other choices that
actually fall in the range in between.

107
00:05:21.010 --> 00:05:22.580
And when you start hearing about them,

108
00:05:22.580 --> 00:05:25.680
you might hear about what we call
the flexible types of constraints.

109
00:05:25.680 --> 00:05:27.600
And then there's some
inflexible ones as well.

110
00:05:27.600 --> 00:05:28.440
Let me go ahead and

111
00:05:28.440 --> 00:05:32.660
talk about the inflexible ones that really
kind of lock us into a particular date.

112
00:05:32.660 --> 00:05:36.630
Notice that what I have here is also
where it actually has the words must.

113
00:05:36.630 --> 00:05:37.756
So I like skipping around.

114
00:05:37.756 --> 00:05:40.280
It's just the way that my mind works here.

115
00:05:40.280 --> 00:05:41.830
But must finish on.

116
00:05:41.830 --> 00:05:45.520
Now, what that's saying is that whatever
the task is, if the task takes three days

117
00:05:45.520 --> 00:05:50.690
and I want it to finish on August 31, I'm
going to start that task before that but

118
00:05:50.690 --> 00:05:54.650
I have to make sure that that actually
finishes on that date itself.

119
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:57.590
And that means everything else
needs to revolve around this.

120
00:05:57.590 --> 00:05:59.760
This particular task is not gonna move.

121
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:02.230
Or I have to actually say I can start on.

122
00:06:02.230 --> 00:06:04.750
These are what we call
the inflexible constraints.

123
00:06:04.750 --> 00:06:05.790
They are not going to move.

124
00:06:05.790 --> 00:06:09.500
Once we actually set something like that,
we're saying here's where it's gonna be,

125
00:06:09.500 --> 00:06:13.160
and that's not gonna actually adjust, the
automatic scheduling is not gonna actually

126
00:06:13.160 --> 00:06:15.230
take that into consideration at all.

127
00:06:15.230 --> 00:06:19.850
But notice that there's also, of course,
the Start No Earlier Than and

128
00:06:19.850 --> 00:06:21.838
also Start No Later Than, as well.

129
00:06:21.838 --> 00:06:25.180
When Don was talking about what if you
do have some contractors that say look,

130
00:06:25.180 --> 00:06:28.860
I really can't make it any
earlier than September 1st.

131
00:06:28.860 --> 00:06:31.640
Well, you may choose that constraint and
say look, I don't know what the day's

132
00:06:31.640 --> 00:06:35.900
gonna be but I know that I'm not gonna be
able to start on this task because those

133
00:06:35.900 --> 00:06:38.880
contractors are not gonna be able
to come in before September 1st.

134
00:06:38.880 --> 00:06:41.110
So that may be a possibility as well.

135
00:06:41.110 --> 00:06:44.530
And then of course, there's the Start
No Later Than, which also makes sense.

136
00:06:44.530 --> 00:06:48.470
And then there's also the other ones
here that are little bit more flexible

137
00:06:48.470 --> 00:06:51.890
Finish No Earlier Than, and
also Finish No Later Than.

138
00:06:51.890 --> 00:06:54.470
Now, Don I've never actually
worked with a task like that and

139
00:06:54.470 --> 00:06:56.590
I can't even think of an example
right now that I might think of.

140
00:06:56.590 --> 00:07:00.695
>> Yeah, well you used some great terms
a second ago Ronnie when you said

141
00:07:00.695 --> 00:07:04.075
a flexible constraint versus
a fixed constraint, right?

142
00:07:04.075 --> 00:07:06.055
Sometimes we have some flexibility.

143
00:07:06.055 --> 00:07:10.371
Maybe I need to get the foundation poured
on a house and I need it to be done so

144
00:07:10.371 --> 00:07:13.135
the drywallers can come in and install it.

145
00:07:13.135 --> 00:07:16.088
Okay.
Well the drywallers are coming in Monday,

146
00:07:16.088 --> 00:07:19.685
June 2nd, I need it to be
finished by Sunday, June 1st.

147
00:07:19.685 --> 00:07:21.730
I need to be finished before
the drywallers get here.

148
00:07:21.730 --> 00:07:25.790
So I might say,
must finish on June 1st, so

149
00:07:25.790 --> 00:07:27.740
that June 2nd, the drywallers can get in.

150
00:07:27.740 --> 00:07:32.000
But when I say it must finish on June 1st,
that means it's got to finish on June 1st.

151
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:34.370
It can't finish on May 31st or May 30th.

152
00:07:34.370 --> 00:07:36.030
So there's no point in
getting ahead on it.

153
00:07:36.030 --> 00:07:37.570
It's gotta finish on that date.

154
00:07:37.570 --> 00:07:41.250
But Finish No Later Than,
that's a different story.

155
00:07:41.250 --> 00:07:43.650
We can pour the foundation early,
get it dried and

156
00:07:43.650 --> 00:07:47.830
done early, as long as it's done before

00:08:31.410 --> 00:08:34.720

00:08:34.720 --> 00:08:40.890
Now, Microsoft's official recommendation

173
00:08:40.890 --> 00:08:42.790

00:08:42.790 --> 00:08:44.760
Don't use those unless

00:08:44.760 --> 00:08:49.800
So make sure that your example is truly

00:08:49.800 --> 00:08:50.600

Use them, but you've gotta be careful.

This is the one that you use the most,

actually linking it and also,

382
00:18:46.510 --> 00:18:50.320
notice what's happening to the dates
since we started linking them as well.

383
00:18:50.320 --> 00:18:54.870
So on these, you can tell that 3.1 is
scheduled to begin on the 30th, but

384
00:18:54.870 --> 00:18:58.050
notice that on the last one that I
linked is scheduled to start on 10/6.

385
00:18:58.050 --> 00:19:02.850
So now we're starting to see the power
of Project's scheduling engine.

386
00:19:02.850 --> 00:19:05.770
In the background saying, hey,
you're using these links.

387
00:19:05.770 --> 00:19:08.420
Here's all the constraints that you have,
that default constraint.

388
00:19:08.420 --> 00:19:11.930
And so when one task finishes,
the other task is gonna begin.

389
00:19:11.930 --> 00:19:13.840
And it starts linking them together.

390
00:19:13.840 --> 00:19:17.300
And so that's where you see the result
of what we're talking about here,

391
00:19:17.300 --> 00:19:19.800
is now we're actually allowing
it to do it this way.

392
00:19:19.800 --> 00:19:21.470
>> Yeah, and we can always go back and

393
00:19:21.470 --> 00:19:25.620
update those to change them from finish
to start, to start to start or whatever.

394
00:19:25.620 --> 00:19:27.890
Now, finish to start and start to start.

395
00:19:27.890 --> 00:19:29.690
I used those two all the time.

396
00:19:29.690 --> 00:19:34.500
But there's two more types of dependency
that we set that are less commonly used.

397
00:19:34.500 --> 00:19:35.130
All right.

398
00:19:35.130 --> 00:19:38.648
For example, start to finish,
and finish to finish.

399
00:19:38.648 --> 00:19:39.241
All right.

400
00:19:39.241 --> 00:19:42.030
Finish to finish means
I've got two activities

401
00:19:42.030 --> 00:19:43.860
that need to finish at the same time.

402
00:19:43.860 --> 00:19:46.320
One can't finish if
the other isn't finished.

403
00:19:46.320 --> 00:19:49.030
And I know that sounds weird, but
let me give you a great example.

404
00:19:49.030 --> 00:19:50.590
We'll use construction again.

405
00:19:50.590 --> 00:19:53.050
So if you're building the house, and

406
00:19:53.050 --> 00:19:56.810
your last step is to prepare the house for
sale.

407
00:19:56.810 --> 00:19:58.230
Well, when you're done building a house,

408
00:19:58.230 --> 00:20:00.140
you've got to have inspectors come and
inspect.

409
00:20:00.140 --> 00:20:03.420
And let's break it down even to a smaller
piece, maybe the plumber is doing

410
00:20:03.420 --> 00:20:06.430
the plumbing work, and now the inspector
needs to sign off on that.

411
00:20:06.430 --> 00:20:07.000
All right?

412
00:20:07.000 --> 00:20:08.450
So you might have an activity for

413
00:20:08.450 --> 00:20:13.690
installing the plumbing, and can they
finish before the permits are done?

414
00:20:13.690 --> 00:20:16.135
No, we have to pass inspection.

415
00:20:16.135 --> 00:20:18.930
Can the inspection finish,
if the plumbing isn't done?

416
00:20:18.930 --> 00:20:21.250
No, they actually finish at the same time.

417
00:20:21.250 --> 00:20:24.580
If the inspector finds a problem,
the plumbers gotta fix it.

418
00:20:24.580 --> 00:20:26.210
And so those two are linked.

419
00:20:26.210 --> 00:20:28.710
So they would be finish to finish.

420
00:20:28.710 --> 00:20:32.690
Installing the plumbing doesn't
finish until we pass inspections, and

421
00:20:32.690 --> 00:20:34.970
passing inspections doesn't
finish until plumbing is done.

422
00:20:34.970 --> 00:20:38.710
So those two are linked together, and that
would be a finish to finish, all right.

423
00:20:38.710 --> 00:20:41.230
Not as common, but they are out there.

424
00:20:41.230 --> 00:20:45.403
And then the least common, the absolute
least way, one that I can honestly tell

425
00:20:45.403 --> 00:20:48.716
you I've never used in production,
Is the finished to start.

426
00:20:48.716 --> 00:20:49.752
>> The start to finish.

427
00:20:49.752 --> 00:20:53.755
>> It's, oh sorry.

428
00:20:53.755 --> 00:20:54.299
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> So

429
00:20:54.299 --> 00:20:58.850
start to finish says that I can't
finish until something else starts and

430
00:20:58.850 --> 00:21:01.990
that's why I got it backwards
with the other one.

431
00:21:01.990 --> 00:21:04.150
>> Yeah.
>> So that seems weird, right?

432
00:21:04.150 --> 00:21:06.600
Something else finishes and
I can start, that makes sense.

433
00:21:06.600 --> 00:21:10.460
But I can't finish until
somebody else starts.

434
00:21:10.460 --> 00:21:11.350
What's that all about?

435
00:21:11.350 --> 00:21:14.090
And I really only have
one good example of it.

436
00:21:14.090 --> 00:21:15.890
And it's studying for a test, right?

437
00:21:15.890 --> 00:21:19.800
Think about when you were in school, or
maybe you were in college or whatever.

438
00:21:19.800 --> 00:21:21.120
And you're studying for an exam.

439
00:21:22.280 --> 00:21:24.760
Well, when do you finish studying?

440
00:21:24.760 --> 00:21:25.605
Technically, you don't finish
studying until you start the exam.

441
00:21:25.605 --> 00:21:29.280
>> [LAUGH]
>> You're studying right up until that

442
00:21:29.280 --> 00:21:29.800
last minute.

443
00:21:29.800 --> 00:21:33.240
You sit down and start on the exam, and
that's when your studying stops All right.

444
00:21:33.240 --> 00:21:38.630
So, I can't finish studying
until the exams starts.

445
00:21:38.630 --> 00:21:41.870
It's not studying that determines
when the exam is gonna start.

446
00:21:41.870 --> 00:21:46.700
Right, normally when we have finish
to start, It's activity one finishing

447
00:21:46.700 --> 00:21:49.840
that determines when
activity two is gonna start.

448
00:21:49.840 --> 00:21:51.740
But when I'm talking about the exam,

449
00:21:51.740 --> 00:21:54.240
it's not when I finish
studying that the exam starts.

450
00:21:54.240 --> 00:21:56.580
The exam has a date that it's gonna start.

451
00:21:56.580 --> 00:21:59.600
And that's what determines when
activity one is gonna finish.

452
00:21:59.600 --> 00:22:01.960
So that's kind of a weird relationship.

453
00:22:01.960 --> 00:22:02.660
But it is there.

454
00:22:02.660 --> 00:22:03.640
It is something that's out there.

455
00:22:03.640 --> 00:22:05.560
And just think about who it is.

456
00:22:05.560 --> 00:22:09.360
Which activity is actually
in control of the link?

457
00:22:09.360 --> 00:22:11.690
If it's the second activity
that's in control of the link and

458
00:22:11.690 --> 00:22:16.120
not the first one, then you're gonna
have one of those start to finishes.

459
00:22:16.120 --> 00:22:20.190
The second activity starting is what
allows the first activity to finish.

460
00:22:20.190 --> 00:22:20.860
It's weird.

461
00:22:20.860 --> 00:22:22.050
It's backwards.

462
00:22:22.050 --> 00:22:25.130
I've never had to use that
in a production project.

463
00:22:25.130 --> 00:22:27.590
But it is there, and
the support is available if you need it.

464
00:22:27.590 --> 00:22:31.170
>> Yeah, I get confused by the language as
well, cuz start to finish sounds natural.

465
00:22:31.170 --> 00:22:33.070
You know start to finish.

466
00:22:33.070 --> 00:22:35.900
Finish to start doesn't sound natural,
but that's actually the most common.

467
00:22:35.900 --> 00:22:38.690
So when you do see that start to finish,
more than likely it's probably not gonna

468
00:22:38.690 --> 00:22:41.310
be the general choice that we're
gonna make for most things.

469
00:22:41.310 --> 00:22:45.460
But remember those other three, right, the
start to start, the finish to finish, and

470
00:22:45.460 --> 00:22:48.290
of course the most common by
far is the finish to start.

471
00:22:48.290 --> 00:22:50.940
So those are some of the different
ways we can link then.

472
00:22:50.940 --> 00:22:53.110
Each of those tasks to a dependency,

473
00:22:53.110 --> 00:22:56.250
and then we'll actually start seeing
the project scheduling engine

474
00:22:56.250 --> 00:23:00.130
really start beginning to fill out
the actual dates for us from that point.

475
00:23:00.130 --> 00:23:00.930
>> Yeah, and

476
00:23:00.930 --> 00:23:04.250
we had some good questions in the chat
room there about the smaller components.

477
00:23:04.250 --> 00:23:05.200
You have to be careful.

478
00:23:05.200 --> 00:23:08.850
When you have smaller components in your
project, if you start setting up a lot

479
00:23:08.850 --> 00:23:12.590
of dependencies, saying all these
different components can't finish

480
00:23:12.590 --> 00:23:16.370
until something else finishes, you can end
up with a lot of open ended activities.

481
00:23:16.370 --> 00:23:20.370
And it makes reporting really difficult
cuz they might be 100% done, but

482
00:23:20.370 --> 00:23:22.810
two weeks goes by and
they still show that they're not complete,

483
00:23:22.810 --> 00:23:24.710
it really starts to skew your reports.

484
00:23:24.710 --> 00:23:27.000
So even though it might be true that yeah,

485
00:23:27.000 --> 00:23:29.510
they're not truly finished
until the over all one is done.

486
00:23:29.510 --> 00:23:32.170
You might choose to go ahead and
flag them as finished anyway, and

487
00:23:32.170 --> 00:23:34.780
use a standard finish
to start relationship.

488
00:23:34.780 --> 00:23:38.480
So it kinda depends on how big the project
is, how you're gonna handle that.

489
00:23:38.480 --> 00:23:40.840
Everybody's usage is a little
bit different there.

490
00:23:40.840 --> 00:23:43.780
And you can always use milestones for
tracking this stuff too.

491
00:23:43.780 --> 00:23:46.600
Instead of relying on the link
dependencies to do that, so

492
00:23:46.600 --> 00:23:49.360
it's really up to you how
you want to handle that.

493
00:23:49.360 --> 00:23:51.997
That's the neat part about Project
is they give you all these tools,

494
00:23:51.997 --> 00:23:53.416
you don't have to use them, right?

495
00:23:53.416 --> 00:23:56.820
You kind of pick the ones that make
good sense for your environment.

496
00:23:56.820 --> 00:23:59.190
Now, if you've got a ton
of smaller elements,

497
00:23:59.190 --> 00:24:01.190
you might even wanna break
those out into sub projects.

498
00:24:01.190 --> 00:24:03.900
And we're gonna talk about sub
projects in another episode, but

499
00:24:03.900 --> 00:24:06.900
it is another option that's out there.

500
00:24:06.900 --> 00:24:09.910
All right, so Ronnie, we talked about
some of the links and dependencies.

501
00:24:09.910 --> 00:24:14.240
We talked about some of
the constraints that can get created,

502
00:24:14.240 --> 00:24:15.940
those are all gonna manipulate it.

503
00:24:15.940 --> 00:24:17.030
What else do we have?

504
00:24:17.030 --> 00:24:18.400
Is that?

505
00:24:18.400 --> 00:24:20.100
>> We just really talked
about those two things.

506
00:24:20.100 --> 00:24:21.740
And making sure that we
could link them together and

507
00:24:21.740 --> 00:24:23.370
showed you how to be able to do it.

508
00:24:23.370 --> 00:24:24.740
There are multiple ways to do this.

509
00:24:24.740 --> 00:24:27.140
So don't just think the way that I
showed you through the property,

510
00:24:27.140 --> 00:24:30.340
the task information properties,
that that's the only way to do it.

511
00:24:30.340 --> 00:24:33.280
Remember you can do it directly
from the entry table itself, or

512
00:24:33.280 --> 00:24:35.210
even just using the column too.

513
00:24:35.210 --> 00:24:37.130
Now when we start taking look at this.

514
00:24:37.130 --> 00:24:38.970
This is the very beginning here.

515
00:24:38.970 --> 00:24:40.870
Remember that there are a couple
of different things.

516
00:24:40.870 --> 00:24:43.240
If all the sudden everything's grayed out,
more than likely,

517
00:24:43.240 --> 00:24:47.750
that task is manually set, and that means,
yeah, Project, don't mess with me.

518
00:24:47.750 --> 00:24:51.390
But now that we actually set that as auto,
it actually started filling things in,

519
00:24:51.390 --> 00:24:53.260
and that's what we're also wanting to see.

520
00:24:53.260 --> 00:24:56.130
So some of those little tricky things,
and pay attention,

521
00:24:56.130 --> 00:24:59.390
especially, to the links as
you're preparing for the exam.

522
00:24:59.390 --> 00:25:01.840
I guarantee you'll see a question or
two on those things.

523
00:25:01.840 --> 00:25:03.840
>> Yeah, and, Ronnie,
you mentioned auto scheduling, and

524
00:25:03.840 --> 00:25:05.700
we've talked about it a few times.

525
00:25:05.700 --> 00:25:07.400
As we build these dependencies,

526
00:25:07.400 --> 00:25:11.470
it is really important to understand
how auto scheduling works.

527
00:25:11.470 --> 00:25:14.000
And we don't have enough time
left in this episode, but Ronnie,

528
00:25:14.000 --> 00:25:15.930
I think we should probably
do a part two on this one,

529
00:25:15.930 --> 00:25:18.770
and take a look at the formulas
that go into that mix.

530
00:25:18.770 --> 00:25:20.250
>> Right.
>> Because when you set these

531
00:25:20.250 --> 00:25:24.000
dependencies, it's kind of laying them
out in that Gantt chart in a certain way.

532
00:25:24.000 --> 00:25:27.160
And as we start manipulating activities,
things happen.

533
00:25:27.160 --> 00:25:27.890
Things start to move.

534
00:25:27.890 --> 00:25:29.640
That's what auto scheduling is all about.

535
00:25:29.640 --> 00:25:32.910
And you've really gotta have a good
understanding of that to know when do

536
00:25:32.910 --> 00:25:37.780
I need to do a constraint,versus when
it okay to just let Project handle it.

537
00:25:37.780 --> 00:25:39.640
Hopefully we can let Project
handle it in most cases.

538
00:25:39.640 --> 00:25:40.730
Sometimes you can't.

539
00:25:40.730 --> 00:25:41.810
Making that decision,

540
00:25:41.810 --> 00:25:45.430
requires us to understand the math
that's going on behind the scenes.

541
00:25:45.430 --> 00:25:50.210
And so a big part of that is the auto
scheduling formulas that Microsoft uses,

542
00:25:50.210 --> 00:25:54.020
and they want to hide that from the user
for the most part, don't deal with it.

543
00:25:54.020 --> 00:25:55.610
But if you want to be
successful with Project,

544
00:25:55.610 --> 00:25:56.490
you do have to have an understanding.

545
00:25:56.490 --> 00:25:58.530
So we're gonna do a part two on
this episode where we'll take

546
00:25:58.530 --> 00:25:59.950
a look at that math behind the scenes.

547
00:25:59.950 --> 00:26:01.790
>> Right.
>> Get a chance to see how auto scheduling

548
00:26:01.790 --> 00:26:03.540
is working and breaking that down.

549
00:26:03.540 --> 00:26:08.400
But for most people, setting up the four
link type dependencies; finish to start,

550
00:26:08.400 --> 00:26:11.970
start to start, start to finish and
finish to finish,

551
00:26:11.970 --> 00:26:15.430
those four that is going to be more than
enough to kind of set the hierarchy.

552
00:26:15.430 --> 00:26:18.320
And then we use the constraints,
the fixed and

553
00:26:18.320 --> 00:26:22.270
flexible constraints to force certain
activities to happen on certain days.

554
00:26:22.270 --> 00:26:25.450
Between those,
that is more than enough for most people.

555
00:26:25.450 --> 00:26:27.710
In advance scenarios you'll
need to know a little more and

556
00:26:27.710 --> 00:26:29.520
that's where part two will come in.

557
00:26:29.520 --> 00:26:30.360
>> Sounds good.

558
00:26:30.360 --> 00:26:32.120
>> All right.
Well Ronnie I think that's a good episode

559
00:26:32.120 --> 00:26:33.610
right here, so
we'll go ahead and wrap it up.

560
00:26:33.610 --> 00:26:34.840
Hope you guys enjoyed it.

561
00:26:34.840 --> 00:26:37.320
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

562
00:26:37.320 --> 00:26:38.140
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

563
00:26:38.140 --> 00:26:39.087
>> And we'll see you next time.

564
00:26:39.087 --> 00:26:45.240
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into the math and calculation of work, duration and resources that Microsoft Project 2013 works in the background.  They talk about the differences between effort-driven and non-effort driven tasks. The show where to set the task types as well as how to view how the formulas work out using the details view.
episodes.title: Task Relationships Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.056 --> 00:00:12.041
All right.

3
00:00:12.041 --> 00:00:13.858
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening.

4
00:00:13.858 --> 00:00:16.500
Welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.500 --> 00:00:19.280
I'm your host Don Pizet back
again with Mister Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:19.280 --> 00:00:20.150
How's it going, Ronnie?

7
00:00:20.150 --> 00:00:21.210
>> I am doing well today,

8
00:00:21.210 --> 00:00:25.410
but not really excited because we're
talking about math today, Don.

9
00:00:25.410 --> 00:00:26.000
>> Pesky math.

10
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:26.680
>> Math.

11
00:00:26.680 --> 00:00:29.750
>> Well we're kinda lucky though
because one of the nice things that

12
00:00:29.750 --> 00:00:33.530
Microsoft Project does for
us is hide the math.

13
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:37.270
When we put data in here, there's actually
a lot of formulas and calculations that

14
00:00:37.270 --> 00:00:41.330
are going on in the background and
we don't have to worry about that.

15
00:00:41.330 --> 00:00:44.840
However, to really understand how
our product is being managed and

16
00:00:44.840 --> 00:00:46.650
how things like auto scheduling work,

17
00:00:46.650 --> 00:00:49.520
we do need to have a good grasp of
what's going on in the background.

18
00:00:49.520 --> 00:00:54.150
And Project 2013's really good about this,
but previous versions of Project

19
00:00:54.150 --> 00:00:58.500
like Project 2010 and earlier,
they sometimes really screw up the math.

20
00:00:58.500 --> 00:01:00.420
Have you ever had that happen,
Ronnie, where the math gets broken?

21
00:01:00.420 --> 00:01:00.990
>> I have.
Yeah.

22
00:01:00.990 --> 00:01:05.080
Sometimes when you actually do set things
inside of Project, also you're expecting

23
00:01:05.080 --> 00:01:07.830
to see something, and wait a minute,
that didn't turn out right.

24
00:01:07.830 --> 00:01:10.350
So you remove it, and
now you see another thing appear, and

25
00:01:10.350 --> 00:01:12.980
you're like, wait a minute,
I didn't mean for all that to happen.

26
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:15.820
The only recourse you had is
hopefully you didn't hit save and

27
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:18.010
you just kind of start all over and
do that again.

28
00:01:18.010 --> 00:01:22.150
Project 2013 has kind of helped to
simplify some of the things and try and

29
00:01:22.150 --> 00:01:24.510
correct some of the previous
things that they had.

30
00:01:24.510 --> 00:01:27.840
But they've also offered a lot more
explanations on their support forums to

31
00:01:27.840 --> 00:01:30.280
try and help you out as well.

32
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:32.800
>> Yeah, and you can avoid that

33
00:01:32.800 --> 00:01:35.650
if you understand the math that's
happening in the background, and this is

34
00:01:35.650 --> 00:01:38.550
a frustration point with a lot of people
that try to use Microsoft Project and

35
00:01:38.550 --> 00:01:41.620
they're self-taught, like, I'm just
gonna get in here and figure it out.

36
00:01:41.620 --> 00:01:43.250
Well you can figure out a lot of stuff,
but

37
00:01:43.250 --> 00:01:45.725
the math almost starts to look
like voodoo magic, before the end.

38
00:01:45.725 --> 00:01:48.580
[LAUGH] I don't understand,
why did this number not change?

39
00:01:48.580 --> 00:01:52.590
And it's because there's a certain order
that Microsoft expects us to put data in

40
00:01:52.590 --> 00:01:56.460
and it all boils down
to how a task is setup.

41
00:01:56.460 --> 00:01:58.230
So Ronnie let's take a look at that.

42
00:01:58.230 --> 00:02:02.190
When I create a task,
there's a default right, that's happening.

43
00:02:02.190 --> 00:02:05.890
Every task is created equally when
we start setting up projects.

44
00:02:05.890 --> 00:02:07.930
But that's not really true in real life.

45
00:02:07.930 --> 00:02:08.630
So we're gonna have to

46
00:02:08.630 --> 00:02:11.070
manipulate some tasks that
are a little bit different right?

47
00:02:11.070 --> 00:02:12.180
>> They really are.

48
