>> [LAUGH] You know, it's a wonderful way
to get back in to the high school math.

494
00:25:09.425 --> 00:25:12.125
Like somebody's mentioning
in our chat here.

495
00:25:12.125 --> 00:25:15.535
But it is stuff that you've
got to watch out for.

496
00:25:15.535 --> 00:25:17.325
On that simple one task, right?

497
00:25:17.325 --> 00:25:19.945
It threw me for numbers cuz one,
I'm bad at math.

498
00:25:19.945 --> 00:25:22.555
But now imagine if you have 100 tasks?

499
00:25:22.555 --> 00:25:26.370
This is where, when you're not sure,
you go back and you do the math.

500
00:25:26.370 --> 00:25:28.790
Knowing that simple formula is
going to help you out tremendously.

501
00:25:30.500 --> 00:25:32.570
>> All right, well Ronnie I think that's
a pretty good run down of the formulas.

502
00:25:32.570 --> 00:25:34.360
Do you have anything else
you want to throw in?

503
00:25:34.360 --> 00:25:35.210
>> Not really.

504
00:25:35.210 --> 00:25:37.710
Just again practice,
understand the formulas.

505
00:25:37.710 --> 00:25:38.820
Because it's gonna help you out.

506
00:25:38.820 --> 00:25:41.900
You're probably gonna see a question or
two about it on the exam.

507
00:25:41.900 --> 00:25:43.540
All right, well ladies and
gentlemen that's a good spot for

508
00:25:43.540 --> 00:25:44.650
us to wrap this one up.

509
00:25:44.650 --> 00:25:48.570
Hope you guys enjoyed it, stay tuned
we got more project content coming up.

510
00:25:48.570 --> 00:25:51.780
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV I'm Don Pezet.

511
00:25:51.780 --> 00:25:52.320
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

512
00:25:52.320 --> 00:25:53.272
>> And we'll see you next time.

513
00:25:53.272 --> 00:25:56.755
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don guide us through creating a manually controlled scheduled.  This type of scheduling will give the user the most direct control over each task and resource.  They show how it can affect a auto-scheduled plan as well how to do PERT analysis to manually estimate task durations.
episodes.title: Creating a Schedule
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.832
>> [MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.832 --> 00:00:13.854
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:13.854 --> 00:00:15.879
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.879 --> 00:00:18.838
I'm your host Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:18.838 --> 00:00:19.710
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:19.710 --> 00:00:23.040
>> It is going well today, ready for
another exciting day into the world of

7
00:00:23.040 --> 00:00:26.390
Microsoft Project, a lot of stuff for
us to take a look at.

8
00:00:26.390 --> 00:00:28.320
>> All right,
now Ronnie in our previous episodes,

9
00:00:28.320 --> 00:00:32.440
we talked a bit about Microsoft Project's
Auto-Scheduling functionality and

10
00:00:32.440 --> 00:00:34.710
how we can link our activities together,
and

11
00:00:34.710 --> 00:00:39.080
Project will just automatically
lay that out, and it works great.

12
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:41.730
But there's a bit of
a limitation with that.

13
00:00:41.730 --> 00:00:44.410
The biggest problem with
doing auto-scheduling is

14
00:00:44.410 --> 00:00:48.480
Project is assuming we
have ultimate flexibility.

15
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:50.750
If somebody comes to you and
gives you a project and says, Ronnie,

16
00:00:50.750 --> 00:00:52.370
I need you to build this house.

17
00:00:52.370 --> 00:00:54.630
I need you to start right away and
just get done as soon as you can.

18
00:00:55.970 --> 00:00:59.522
Well, if you have that kind of
flexibility, I need to start now, but

19
00:00:59.522 --> 00:01:03.462
the rest of the timeline is kind of up
to me, auto-scheduling works great.

20
00:01:03.462 --> 00:01:07.086
But if I've gotta series of milestones
that have to be set on certain dates and

21
00:01:07.086 --> 00:01:11.157
I've gotta finish at a particular day, and
I've gotta lot of kind of requirements and

22
00:01:11.157 --> 00:01:14.470
constraints, auto-scheduling
starts to break down a bit.

23
00:01:14.470 --> 00:01:16.470
And it doesn't necessarily work so well.

24
00:01:16.470 --> 00:01:18.460
And that's why it's off by default.

25
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:21.640
And instead,
we have an alternative, Ronnie?

26
00:01:21.640 --> 00:01:26.380
>> We do, we have what we call Manual
Schedules that we can create instead.

27
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:29.540
Or also what is called
User-Controlled Scheduling.

28
00:01:29.540 --> 00:01:31.370
Now the big difference is simple.

29
00:01:31.370 --> 00:01:34.820
When we start using that automated
scheduling, we're depending on Microsoft

30
00:01:34.820 --> 00:01:38.110
to go ahead and set up all the rest of the
dates if we have a project start date or

31
00:01:38.110 --> 00:01:39.492
a project finish date.

32
00:01:39.492 --> 00:01:42.870
That it's gonna be able to calculate that
for us and do everything that we need to.

33
00:01:42.870 --> 00:01:46.950
But with a manually created schedule,
you are in control of every aspect

34
00:01:46.950 --> 00:01:51.250
of the tasks that you set, and it can
go ahead and do some basic things once

35
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:54.280
you set those dependencies to say hey,
here's how things fall in line.

36
00:01:54.280 --> 00:01:55.520
But it's not gonna try and

37
00:01:55.520 --> 00:01:58.650
maintain all of the different
connections that it needs to.

38
00:01:58.650 --> 00:02:01.680
So there are things that can
actually be done by you.

39
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:02.710
And the problem is,

40
00:02:02.710 --> 00:02:06.908
with the manual scheduling, is that you
really need to know all the stuff that you

41
00:02:06.908 --> 00:02:10.580
want to actually have put in there and
to be able to set all those dates,

42
00:02:10.580 --> 00:02:14.500
all the times, everything,
if you're gonna do something like that.

43
00:02:14.500 --> 00:02:16.470
But it doesn't mean you can't even mix and
match.

44
00:02:16.470 --> 00:02:18.560
You can even do some of that as well.

45
00:02:18.560 --> 00:02:20.600
So when you do the manual scheduling,
that's what you're doing,

46
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:24.530
is you're typing in every little aspect of
it, and then you're actually saying all

47
00:02:24.530 --> 00:02:27.430
right, from this point,
I will also put in every link.

48
00:02:27.430 --> 00:02:29.000
I will also do this stuff.

49
00:02:29.000 --> 00:02:31.580
And then you have to make sure it
calculates out exactly the way that you

50
00:02:31.580 --> 00:02:36.600
want to, but I do want show you a little
bit here in contrast of what happens

51
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:40.840
when you actually have the difference
between auto and also manual scheduling.

52
00:02:40.840 --> 00:02:43.110
So on my computer, I went ahead and

53
00:02:43.110 --> 00:02:47.440
brought up my sample project that we have
in place, and I just turned all of these

54
00:02:47.440 --> 00:02:52.410
tasks instead into auto-scheduling because
I wanted to show you something right here.

55
00:02:52.410 --> 00:02:55.850
I didn't really actually have to type in
all these dates that we see over here,

56
00:02:55.850 --> 00:02:58.160
on the right-hand side,
the start and finish dates.

57
00:02:58.160 --> 00:02:59.400
With the auto-scheduling,

58
00:02:59.400 --> 00:03:02.050
the only thing I had to pick out
was that project start date.

59
00:03:02.050 --> 00:03:06.710
Once I picked out that project start date,
I was now able to not ever have to worry

60
00:03:06.710 --> 00:03:11.800
about entering the start or finish dates
at all, and Project filled it in for me.

61
00:03:11.800 --> 00:03:14.730
But if I needed to do something else and

62
00:03:14.730 --> 00:03:19.870
I didn't want this automatic scheduling to
take over everything, notice that I have,

63
00:03:19.870 --> 00:03:24.170
let's say down here on 3.1
Installing Premise Cabling,

64
00:03:24.170 --> 00:03:27.680
that I didn't actually get anything
completed in time that I wanted to,

65
00:03:27.680 --> 00:03:29.760
such as the testing on my ThinClients.

66
00:03:29.760 --> 00:03:34.420
If I change one of these ThinClients
to let's say five days here or

67
00:03:34.420 --> 00:03:36.280
six days, that would work, five days,

68
00:03:36.280 --> 00:03:40.850
notice that the rest of my
schedule now was effected by it.

69
00:03:40.850 --> 00:03:43.790
You can tell by that kind of light blue or
you might be able to

70
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:47.540
not see that on the screen, but actually
effected the rest of the schedule.

71
00:03:47.540 --> 00:03:50.756
You could see all the dates ended up
changing, so that's perfectly fine,

72
00:03:50.756 --> 00:03:52.860
because that's what all
those schedules says.

73
00:03:52.860 --> 00:03:53.590
It says, hey,

74
00:03:53.590 --> 00:03:57.790
I need to keep everything in relationship
to what happens when we make a change.

75
00:03:57.790 --> 00:04:02.462
But let me set that back down to two days,
or the way that I had it before.

76
00:04:02.462 --> 00:04:08.130
I'll just change it back, and
now I'm going to uncheck one of these.

77
00:04:08.130 --> 00:04:13.670
So I'm gonna select this line 29 for 3.1,
and I'm gonna go over here to Task Mode,

78
00:04:13.670 --> 00:04:17.860
and now I'm gonna choose to set
it to Manually Scheduled instead.

79
00:04:17.860 --> 00:04:19.890
Now, it doesn't look
like it changed anything.

80
00:04:19.890 --> 00:04:22.730
Well, the only thing I actually said is
that here, I actually see a little bit

81
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:27.100
of an off-color three days, and
the start and finish dates.

82
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:32.410
Now I can manipulate just that information
in there as well, and it really can effect

83
00:04:32.410 --> 00:04:36.230
the rest of the schedule, but what happens
though is the other part of the schedule.

84
00:04:36.230 --> 00:04:39.520
So if I go back here to
the testing that ThinClient, and

85
00:04:39.520 --> 00:04:43.980
I change this back up to the five
days again, and I press Enter.

86
00:04:43.980 --> 00:04:49.550
Notice that it actually didn't effect
really anything after that too,

87
00:04:49.550 --> 00:04:53.230
so the Installing the Premise Cabling
here stayed at three days.

88
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:56.812
But now notice that the rest of
the schedules stayed the same, and

89
00:04:56.812 --> 00:04:58.712
the reason why is the dependency.

90
00:04:58.712 --> 00:05:02.093
The rest of the schedule
depends now on this 3.1 and

91
00:05:02.093 --> 00:05:07.102
actually completing and doing
everything it needs to before we go on.

92
00:05:07.102 --> 00:05:09.080
Whereas when we changed it before,

93
00:05:09.080 --> 00:05:12.610
the five day schedule would have
thrown everything else off.

94
00:05:12.610 --> 00:05:15.680
Now when we have something like that,
that's really the difference, so

95
00:05:15.680 --> 00:05:19.280
notice that that one change
there in the manual scheduling

96
00:05:19.280 --> 00:05:21.830
really did affect the rest
of that calendar.

97
00:05:21.830 --> 00:05:25.590
So when you actually set everything in
place by yourself from the very beginning,

98
00:05:25.590 --> 00:05:28.220
it means you're controlling
the way that that project's

99
00:05:28.220 --> 00:05:30.150
gonna end up laying out here.

100
00:05:30.150 --> 00:05:34.087
Now notice something else that
also happened with Project too.

101
00:05:34.087 --> 00:05:39.057
Once Project's said all right,
I see this manual scheduling,

102
00:05:39.057 --> 00:05:43.934
but notice now in my finished column for
this line 3.1 here,

103
00:05:43.934 --> 00:05:48.004
notice it says Monday, August 24th, 2015.

104
00:05:48.004 --> 00:05:49.529
It has this red line under it,

105
00:05:49.529 --> 00:05:53.840
and that's now saying that there is
some type of conflict that's going on.

106
00:05:53.840 --> 00:05:58.711
If I hover over it, it tells me that
there is a potential scheduling problem.

107
00:05:58.711 --> 00:06:02.920
The reason why we wanna see that is
because sometimes that's what happens when

108
00:06:02.920 --> 00:06:05.790
you start actually introducing
manual scheduling or

109
00:06:05.790 --> 00:06:08.930
user-controlled scheduling
into your project as well.

110
00:06:08.930 --> 00:06:11.420
And you'll probably see more
of this if you actually do

111
00:06:11.420 --> 00:06:15.150
all of these manual schedules if
every line was actually there.

112
00:06:15.150 --> 00:06:19.320
So it's actually trying to help us out
by saying, you may need to adjust this.

113
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:22.700
The nice thing is that it actually tells
you exactly what you need to do, and

114
00:06:22.700 --> 00:06:27.050
when you right-click on that, it actually
gives you two options up here at the top.

115
00:06:27.050 --> 00:06:29.980
There's some other things that we have
down there for the entire task, but

116
00:06:29.980 --> 00:06:32.910
notice it says Fix in Task Inspector.

117
00:06:32.910 --> 00:06:35.450
We're getting a notification, a warning,

118
00:06:35.450 --> 00:06:40.270
a message from Project that something
is going to actually not be right.

119
00:06:40.270 --> 00:06:44.230
And it gives us this option which
is the Fix in Task Inspector.

120
00:06:44.230 --> 00:06:46.990
And Don,
this is an option that I really do like

121
00:06:46.990 --> 00:06:50.800
because it really helps me out if I'm
not exactly sure what's going on.

122
00:06:50.800 --> 00:06:55.554
And over here on the left-hand side,
it tells me on this particular task,

123
00:06:55.554 --> 00:06:59.720
Installing the Premise Cabling, notice
it says look, the way that you have it,

124
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:03.790
once this is done because manually
scheduled, the task may need to be delayed

125
00:07:03.790 --> 00:07:08.476
by three days, and I have the chance here
to fix it in a couple of different ways.

126
00:07:08.476 --> 00:07:13.530
I can say hey, let's just keep those links
respected in the way that they need to,

127
00:07:13.530 --> 00:07:16.340
and it moves the task
based on the predecessor.

128
00:07:16.340 --> 00:07:18.940
Or I can just say let's just
follow that auto-scheduling and

129
00:07:18.940 --> 00:07:21.290
put everything in place that we need to.

130
00:07:21.290 --> 00:07:23.510
And so
those were good options to help you.

131
00:07:23.510 --> 00:07:25.440
If you're not as familiar with Project,

132
00:07:25.440 --> 00:07:28.210
in other words if you haven't
seen something like that before,

133
00:07:28.210 --> 00:07:31.640
these are some of the actions that
you actually can take to help fix

134
00:07:31.640 --> 00:07:34.810
a scheduling problem like this, especially
with the manual scheduling here.

135
00:07:34.810 --> 00:07:38.450
So if I change that now to
the auto-schedule, you'll notice now it

136
00:07:38.450 --> 00:07:41.270
went ahead, and that's what happened,
is that the rest of the project got

137
00:07:42.660 --> 00:07:47.440
pushed down the way that we actually
needed to, and now we are back into it.

138
00:07:47.440 --> 00:07:51.136
So the manual scheduling offers
a lot of different options that you

139
00:07:51.136 --> 00:07:55.294
have available to you, but only if
you're good at actually entering in all

140
00:07:55.294 --> 00:07:57.806
the things that you
actually wanna enter in.

141
00:07:57.806 --> 00:08:00.457
If not, you're gonna see a lot of
those red marks and you can go,

142
00:08:00.457 --> 00:08:01.751
why is everything doing that?

143
00:08:01.751 --> 00:08:03.462
And you'll do like I did at times,

144
00:08:03.462 --> 00:08:07.250
which is you right click on like ten of
them in a row and why did it affect that?

145
00:08:07.250 --> 00:08:09.470
Why did this do that?

146
00:08:09.470 --> 00:08:12.150
And it continues to cascade down.

147
00:08:12.150 --> 00:08:17.000
So it's a great way to begin cuz that's
probably what you're expecting to see

148
00:08:17.000 --> 00:08:19.000
If you're really new at project.

149
00:08:19.000 --> 00:08:21.670
But most of the time if you've been
working with project for a long time,

150
00:08:21.670 --> 00:08:22.825
you'll probably expect,

151
00:08:22.825 --> 00:08:26.050
now all this stuff should kind of
shift the way that we want to.

152
00:08:26.050 --> 00:08:29.420
So most of us stick with
the auto scheduling when we can.

153
00:08:29.420 --> 00:08:34.210
>> Or what I usually do is during
the planning phases of the project,

154
00:08:34.210 --> 00:08:36.970
I'll use auto scheduling
to get everything laid out.

155
00:08:36.970 --> 00:08:38.880
And then once we're ready to baseline and

156
00:08:38.880 --> 00:08:42.670
move from planning to execution
I convert everything to manual.

157
00:08:42.670 --> 00:08:47.350
And the reason I do that is I want to make
sure that if I make one adjustment, and

158
00:08:47.350 --> 00:08:49.640
it goes to change a bunch
of other activities,

159
00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:51.660
I want to know exactly what's changing.

160
00:08:51.660 --> 00:08:52.260
Right?

161
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:55.110
And there there's two ways
to solve that problem.

162
00:08:55.110 --> 00:08:57.600
One way is my way,
which is to kind of micro-manage it.

163
00:08:57.600 --> 00:09:00.290
Go ahead and just flip it so
they're all manually scheduled, and

164
00:09:00.290 --> 00:09:03.240
now you can kind of go and and
manipulate all that by hand.

165
00:09:03.240 --> 00:09:05.990
The other option, though,
is to keep auto-scheduling.

166
00:09:05.990 --> 00:09:08.640
And you've probably noticed on
the screen as Ronnie's done it.

167
00:09:08.640 --> 00:09:10.030
If you make a change and

168
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:13.800
it's a cascade effect where one change
effects the next one, the next one, and

169
00:09:13.800 --> 00:09:17.930
the next one it'll highlight in
purple everything that's changed.

170
00:09:17.930 --> 00:09:20.790
I don't know if it's always purple,
it might depend on your theme, but

171
00:09:20.790 --> 00:09:22.620
in the default theme it's purple.

172
00:09:22.620 --> 00:09:24.858
And it just gives you
that kind of visual cue.

173
00:09:24.858 --> 00:09:28.790
So, where Ronnie's got several
tasks linked in a row,

174
00:09:28.790 --> 00:09:31.290
if he modifies one of the early tasks,
like Ronnie,

175
00:09:31.290 --> 00:09:34.600
bump up the duration or
something on one of those early tasks.

176
00:09:34.600 --> 00:09:37.120
And what you'll see is
the tasks that follow that

177
00:09:37.120 --> 00:09:39.950
are gonna get moved ahead if
they're auto-scheduled and

178
00:09:39.950 --> 00:09:43.366
it's gonna show that highlight to kinda
let us know that change happened.

179
00:09:43.366 --> 00:09:48.430
And, oh you know on ours we've
broken the formula, haven't we?

180
00:09:49.610 --> 00:09:51.050
>> Yeah, no, it actually is purple.

181
00:09:51.050 --> 00:09:53.000
You just can't see it on that screen.

182
00:09:53.000 --> 00:09:54.709
>> Oh, [CROSSTALK]
>> So yeah, it's actually there.

183
00:09:54.709 --> 00:09:59.010
[LAUGH] At least, I think it's there,
but it does look like it.

184
00:09:59.010 --> 00:10:00.277
>> Yeah,
if you really stare at the screen.

185
00:10:00.277 --> 00:10:01.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's light purple, but

186
00:10:01.680 --> 00:10:04.680
you'll see where all the dates of
the future activities have been

187
00:10:04.680 --> 00:10:05.750
highlighted that way.

188
00:10:05.750 --> 00:10:07.540
And that's the reason it does that.

189
00:10:07.540 --> 00:10:12.340
Is once you understand that a change
that you make can be a cascading change,

190
00:10:12.340 --> 00:10:14.400
and more than one thing is related,

191
00:10:14.400 --> 00:10:17.850
more than one thing gets affected,
that happens with auto scheduling.

192
00:10:17.850 --> 00:10:20.945
When manually scheduled,
because things are manually scheduled,

193
00:10:20.945 --> 00:10:25.055
if I modify one activity,
the future ones are now overlapping.

194
00:10:25.055 --> 00:10:27.105
And I've got to take them and
move them ahead if I want.

195
00:10:27.105 --> 00:10:29.265
So now I really understand
which changes are happening,

196
00:10:29.265 --> 00:10:30.455
because I'm the one making them.

197
00:10:30.455 --> 00:10:33.682
So it's kind of a choice that we have
to make between auto schedule and

198
00:10:33.682 --> 00:10:35.042
manually scheduling.

199
00:10:35.042 --> 00:10:37.982
>> You know there's a lot of different
ways, once you start getting everything in

200
00:10:37.982 --> 00:10:40.682

[LAUGH] Yeah when you take

Here's kind

284
00:14:20.085 --> 00:14:23.900
In the way that Pert works you take
what you consider the most optimistic

285
00:14:23.900 --> 00:14:26.350

able to complete a task.

00:14:26.350 --> 00:14:29.960

00:14:29.960 --> 00:14:32.710

00:14:36.350 --> 00:14:39.480

00:14:39.480 --> 00:14:43.250

not everything in this formula is

00:14:43.250 --> 00:14:44.980

00:14:44.980 --> 00:14:48.340
So a lot of time you can change
these weights if you choose to, but

293
00:14:48.340 --> 00:14:51.780
the standard default formula
says four times most likely.

294
00:14:51.780 --> 00:14:54.920
In other words their saying hey it's
gonna be four times more likely that

295
00:14:54.920 --> 00:15:00.170
when you consider that most likely
guess is probably going to happen.

296
00:15:00.170 --> 00:15:03.160
Then you take that entire formula and
you divide it by six.

297
00:15:03.160 --> 00:15:03.940
And it makes sense.

298
00:15:03.940 --> 00:15:08.480
Because you have four here, and

00:15:08.480 --> 00:15:10.690
And when you do that it actually
ends up giving you a number.

00:15:10.690 --> 00:15:13.010
And we are doing our

00:15:13.010 --> 00:15:16.100

424
00:21:42.790 --> 00:21:44.320
show this in this one summary role.

425
00:21:45.340 --> 00:21:51.900
But they talk about using a manually

426
00:21:51.900 --> 00:21:55.360
scheduled summary task,
I can't say what I wanted to say there.

427
00:21:55.360 --> 00:21:59.740
So I'm gonna click on the drop down and
select manually scheduled at this point.

428
00:21:59.740 --> 00:22:04.130
And there's my one day duration
,now it is still a summary task,

429
00:22:04.130 --> 00:22:05.830
we see the little bar here.

430
00:22:05.830 --> 00:22:06.880
And this time, Don,

431
00:22:06.880 --> 00:22:11.930
if I do the same thing,
oh look at what's happening over here now.

432
00:22:11.930 --> 00:22:14.840
We start seeing this little red bar, and

433
00:22:14.840 --> 00:22:20.010
notice that this start and finish date
Don, is still at the same date but

434
00:22:20.010 --> 00:22:22.990
we're starting to see some
other information also appear.

435
00:22:22.990 --> 00:22:27.290
So this is actually saying, look,
I'm not actually adding up anything, so

436
00:22:27.290 --> 00:22:32.750
if you're gonna do this with some type
of manual scheduled summary task,

437
00:22:32.750 --> 00:22:34.456
notice that the duration didn't change?

438
00:22:34.456 --> 00:22:35.470
And it's saying, look,

439
00:22:35.470 --> 00:22:39.180
this is not the correct finish date for
all these things that you have in place,

440
00:22:39.180 --> 00:22:43.080
so it's something that allows you to
manually go back and set it in there.

441
00:22:43.080 --> 00:22:44.840
But if you're controlling
the entire project schedule,

442
00:22:44.840 --> 00:22:46.390
this may be something you want to do.

443
00:22:46.390 --> 00:22:49.860
>> In the past what we
would use was a milestone,

444
00:22:49.860 --> 00:22:52.700
you'd put a milestone at the end of
the project with a date constraint on it,

445
00:22:52.700 --> 00:22:54.790
if your target date was
to finish in four days,

446
00:22:54.790 --> 00:22:58.750
you would just create a milestone with
a constraint that put it four days later.

447
00:22:58.750 --> 00:23:03.110
And as your other activities move past it,
you just see that with a milestone.

448
00:23:03.110 --> 00:23:06.030
But if you do a manually
scheduled summary task,

449
00:23:06.030 --> 00:23:07.520
you don't need the milestone anymore.

450
00:23:07.520 --> 00:23:10.410
You can see when you're moving past when
it's supposed to finish because it's right

451
00:23:10.410 --> 00:23:11.720
there, the big red bar.

452
00:23:11.720 --> 00:23:14.470
So, it's just one less thing,
it's designed to help kind of reduce

453
00:23:14.470 --> 00:23:18.360
the clutter of your screen a little bit
and eliminate all those crazy milestones.

454
00:23:18.360 --> 00:23:22.140
Now I'll tell you, I still use milestones
just cuz that's what I've used for

455
00:23:22.140 --> 00:23:25.100
years and years and years, so it's kinda
hard to break me of that habit, but

456
00:23:25.100 --> 00:23:27.220
it is nice to have that
option that's available.

457
00:23:27.220 --> 00:23:30.500
And if you're doing manually scheduled
tasks, you probably want to do a manual

458
00:23:30.500 --> 00:23:33.750
summary too just because as you
make a change, again, you want

459
00:23:33.750 --> 00:23:36.670
to verify that you know exactly what's
changing and how that's affecting it.

460
00:23:36.670 --> 00:23:40.480
So I might be making one
individual task longer, but

461
00:23:40.480 --> 00:23:44.430
now the entire plumbing part of my
construction project is gonna take longer

462
00:23:44.430 --> 00:23:46.355
and I can recognize that
impact on the system, so.

463
00:23:46.355 --> 00:23:50.784
Yep, all things that you need to think
about, there really is a choice and

464
00:23:50.784 --> 00:23:55.872
I'm sure some of you guys are wondering
right now, well, so what do you recommend?

465
00:23:55.872 --> 00:23:58.660
Should I do auto schedule or
should I do manual schedule?

466
00:23:58.660 --> 00:24:02.800
And the reality is,
it does come down to your preference, and

467
00:24:02.800 --> 00:24:05.420
how sensitive your data is, right?

468
00:24:05.420 --> 00:24:09.050
So, a lot of people prefer auto
scheduling because it's easier,

469
00:24:09.050 --> 00:24:12.040
then there's people like me that prefer
manual scheduling because I hate it

470
00:24:12.040 --> 00:24:14.830
when mistakes creep in that
I don't notice, right?

471
00:24:14.830 --> 00:24:19.130
Now on a project that's
not a high risk project,

472
00:24:19.130 --> 00:24:22.420
we might not worry about those little type
issues that pop up with auto scheduling.

473
00:24:22.420 --> 00:24:27.020
But if it's a high risk project, or a high
money project, you wanna be precise, and

474
00:24:27.020 --> 00:24:29.920
so manually scheduling usually
kinda becomes the victor there.

475
00:24:29.920 --> 00:24:33.230
And you'll notice in Project if you
fire it up, what does it default to?

476
00:24:33.230 --> 00:24:33.890
>> Manual.

477
00:24:33.890 --> 00:24:38.320
>> Yeah, so while auto scheduling is nice,
it's not the default,

478
00:24:38.320 --> 00:24:41.250
now for me,
I actually do use a mixture of both.

479
00:24:41.250 --> 00:24:45.120
I think I said this earlier where when
I'm in the early planning phases,

480
00:24:45.120 --> 00:24:48.850
I'll use auto scheduling just cuz it is
faster to just lay things out and get that

481
00:24:48.850 --> 00:24:53.450
project structured, and then switch it
over to manual and kind of run from there.

482
00:24:53.450 --> 00:24:56.711
So, you can certainly do a mix,
you can change things after the fact,

483
00:24:56.711 --> 00:24:57.940
just be careful, right?

484
00:24:57.940 --> 00:25:01.500
Understand that changing one activity is
gonna modify everything that's linked

485
00:25:01.500 --> 00:25:02.420
down the line.

486
00:25:02.420 --> 00:25:04.520
>> And that's a good thing for
us to remember, too.

487
00:25:04.520 --> 00:25:08.430
The good thing about Project is that it
visually lets you know when things like

488
00:25:08.430 --> 00:25:13.170
this happen, and so that you can
actually inspect what has changed or

489
00:25:13.170 --> 00:25:17.740
what has gone wrong, use that task
inspector that's also there to help you

490
00:25:17.740 --> 00:25:20.120
to know exactly what's happening as well.

491
00:25:20.120 --> 00:25:23.970
And the reason why you wanna actually do
that is because it's there to help you.

492
00:25:23.970 --> 00:25:28.320
If not, if Don were having to do this
with a calendar, a manual calendar and

493
00:25:28.320 --> 00:25:31.726
having to write out everything, he'd have
to actually go back every single time and

494
00:25:31.726 --> 00:25:34.160
not be notified, hey,
here's something that did change,

495
00:25:34.160 --> 00:25:35.640
here's something I need to change.

496
00:25:35.640 --> 00:25:39.308
But with Project you have all these
visual reminders, it's a good thing for

497
00:25:39.308 --> 00:25:40.291
you to take note of.

498
00:25:40.291 --> 00:25:42.996
>> Yeah, well Ronnie, I think that's a
pretty good rundown of manual scheduling,

499
00:25:42.996 --> 00:25:44.420
can you think of anything
else to throw in?

500
00:25:44.420 --> 00:25:48.744
>> I really can't, once again just think
about, for you, those that are actually

501
00:25:48.744 --> 00:25:53.004
preparing for the exam, get into it every
day cuz you're gonna need to feel that

502
00:25:53.004 --> 00:25:56.360
you feel comfortable and
familiar with it for the exam.

503
00:25:56.360 --> 00:25:59.170
So the more often that you're working
with it, the better it's gonna be.

504
00:25:59.170 --> 00:26:01.070
>> All right, well, ladies and
gentlemen, that's a pretty good spot for

505
00:26:01.070 --> 00:26:03.380
us to wrap this one up,
I hope that you guys enjoyed it.

506
00:26:03.380 --> 00:26:05.880
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

507
00:26:05.880 --> 00:26:06.710
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

508
00:26:06.710 --> 00:26:08.585
>> And we'll see you next time.

509
00:26:08.585 --> 00:26:13.570
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look at how to work with multiple related projects using a single pool of resources. Project 2013 provides the ability to create Master Project Plans and to link those projects together so that we can see how they affect the schedule.  They also show now multiple projects can connect and use a shared resource pools.
episodes.title: Managing Multiple Projects
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.740
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.740 --> 00:00:13.136
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.136 --> 00:00:17.410
And welcome back to another episode
of ITProTV I'm your host Don Pezet.

4
00:00:17.410 --> 00:00:18.570
Back again with Mister Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:18.570 --> 00:00:19.290
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:19.290 --> 00:00:20.450
>> It's going well today.

7
00:00:20.450 --> 00:00:24.040
We're ready to actually take a look
into the world of Microsoft Project.

8
00:00:24.040 --> 00:00:26.340
And it's actually something that we've
actually worked with quite a bit,

9
00:00:26.340 --> 00:00:28.960
so excited to actually get to
learn some new stuff here in 2013.

10
00:00:28.960 --> 00:00:29.605
>> Yeah.

11
00:00:29.605 --> 00:00:32.335
Yeah, what were going to be talking
about in this episode is managing

12
00:00:32.335 --> 00:00:33.985
multiple projects.

13
00:00:33.985 --> 00:00:36.755
Now, maybe you're one of those people
who's fortunate enough to work in

14
00:00:36.755 --> 00:00:39.850
a company that only takes on
one project at a time and

15
00:00:39.850 --> 00:00:42.130
sees it through to completion and
does the job right.

16
00:00:42.130 --> 00:00:45.785
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the odds are you're like me and

17
00:00:45.785 --> 00:00:47.105
you never worked for a company like that.

18
00:00:47.105 --> 00:00:47.765
You've always worked for

19
00:00:47.765 --> 00:00:51.645
a company with ten projects going on at
the same time, none of which are complete.

20
00:00:51.645 --> 00:00:53.560
They're all just kind of moving through.

21
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:56.100
And it becomes a bit of
a coordination nightmare.

22
00:00:56.100 --> 00:01:01.990
Well, Microsoft has a great solution to
that called Microsoft Project Server.

23
00:01:01.990 --> 00:01:04.770
Project Server is where, instead of
hosting our project files right here in

24
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:07.950
our machine, we store them up here
on a server, we can access it, and

25
00:01:07.950 --> 00:01:10.260
you can get to work, do some stuff.

26
00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:13.410
Well, I'll tell you guys right now very
honestly, Project Server is awesome.

27
00:01:13.410 --> 00:01:14.600
It works great.

28
00:01:14.600 --> 00:01:16.920
But it's pretty darn expensive.

29
00:01:16.920 --> 00:01:22.530
So, what do we do if we can't afford
that expensive Project Server?

30
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:25.760
Well, what you'll find is that
Project Server is really designed for

31
00:01:25.760 --> 00:01:28.570
companies that have more
than one project manager.

32
00:01:28.570 --> 00:01:33.030
Your company might have ten projects,
but you're the only project manager.

33
00:01:33.030 --> 00:01:36.070
And if that's the case, you don't
need a full blown Project Server.

34
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:40.570
You can actually do everything you need
right from inside of Microsoft Project.

35
00:01:40.570 --> 00:01:45.400
Microsoft Project on your own machine is
capable of managing more than one project,

36
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:46.900
and it's actually a pretty neat system.

37
00:01:46.900 --> 00:01:51.530
All right, so what we can set up is what's
called, well it's actually a few different

38
00:01:51.530 --> 00:01:54.110
took here that go together to
form this ultimate solution, but

39
00:01:54.110 --> 00:01:55.700
it is all right here inside our project.

40
00:01:55.700 --> 00:01:59.970
Let's start with the idea of
a master project, all right?

41
00:01:59.970 --> 00:02:04.350
A master project, or sometimes people
will refer to this as a portfolio, but

42
00:02:04.350 --> 00:02:09.130
your master project, that's either either
just your entire portfolio of projects for

43
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:11.120
your company, or

44
00:02:11.120 --> 00:02:15.930
it's a single project that's being broken
up into multiple smaller elements.

45
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:18.610
And that happens when we do
things like subcontract out or

46
00:02:18.610 --> 00:02:20.710
just trying to make things more granular.

47
00:02:20.710 --> 00:02:24.820
If we're trying to manage more than one
project, we can tell Microsoft Project,

48
00:02:24.820 --> 00:02:29.350
hey, this is a master project and these
other ones are sub projects underneath it.

49
00:02:29.350 --> 00:02:33.020
And we can link them together so
we see them all at once.

50
00:02:33.020 --> 00:02:35.630
So now, as the single project manager,
I can get in there and

51
00:02:35.630 --> 00:02:37.660
work and it's not a nightmare for me.

52
00:02:37.660 --> 00:02:40.065
I don't have to have an IT guy
setting up a Project Server.

53
00:02:40.065 --> 00:02:41.100
I don't have to pay Microsoft.

54
00:02:41.100 --> 00:02:46.700
I think it's $25 per month per user for
Project Server.

55
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:50.370
So I think that's retail pricing,
your pricing might be different, but

56
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:51.680
it certainly does vary.

57
00:02:51.680 --> 00:02:54.130
So we don't necessarily have to do that.

58
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:56.650
We're the only project manager,
we can set it up here.

59
00:02:56.650 --> 00:02:59.600
>> Now Don, when you talk about that,
if I have five or

60
00:02:59.600 --> 00:03:02.670
six different projects, why don't I just
open up a project plan for each one and

61
00:03:02.670 --> 00:03:04.720
just leave it on the desktop and
manage it that way?

62
00:03:04.720 --> 00:03:05.930
>> You certainly can.

63
00:03:05.930 --> 00:03:09.870
Right, if there are five completely
independent projects with no overlap

64
00:03:09.870 --> 00:03:11.950
whatsoever, just manage them separate.

65
00:03:11.950 --> 00:03:13.580
That is the easiest solution.

66
00:03:14.730 --> 00:03:20.420
But what if I have an employee who's
doing work on three different projects,

67
00:03:20.420 --> 00:03:26.190
and I've booked them on Monday for project
one and I'm looking at project two?

68
00:03:26.190 --> 00:03:29.940
Do I know that employee is booked in
project one if I'm looking at project two?

69
00:03:29.940 --> 00:03:32.260
I don't, I don't know that.

70
00:03:32.260 --> 00:03:36.060
So if they're separate projects, we can
end up with some accidental overlap.

71
00:03:36.060 --> 00:03:39.260
We can over-allocate a resource and
not know it.

72
00:03:39.260 --> 00:03:43.710
Now, if you have no shared resources, if
you have ten projects running at once and

73
00:03:43.710 --> 00:03:47.820
it's completely independent teams and
equipment and materials, then yes,

74
00:03:47.820 --> 00:03:48.460
separate files.

75
00:03:48.460 --> 00:03:49.180
Keep it separate.

76
00:03:49.180 --> 00:03:51.290
That's the best solution there.

77
00:03:51.290 --> 00:03:52.660
But it's rare that that happens.

78
00:03:52.660 --> 00:03:55.620
Just look at ITProTV, right, we've got
all these different projects that go on

79
00:03:55.620 --> 00:03:59.870
here and I can guarantee you that there's
people, like Ronnie, who's on every single

80
00:03:59.870 --> 00:04:05.360
one of those projects, and so it causes
a lot of tracking issues, really.

81
00:04:05.360 --> 00:04:08.060
So linking the projects
together helps to solve that,

82
00:04:08.060 --> 00:04:12.710
helps to work around it where
we might have a project for

83
00:04:12.710 --> 00:04:16.090
deploying a website and another
project for building a virtual lab.

84
00:04:16.090 --> 00:04:19.610
And they might seem separate,
but there might be some

85
00:04:19.610 --> 00:04:23.190
feature that's being introduced on the
website that this new virtual lab needs.

86
00:04:23.190 --> 00:04:27.460
And so now the virtual lab becomes
dependent on the website project.

87
00:04:27.460 --> 00:04:28.900
It's not the same people doing the work,

88
00:04:28.900 --> 00:04:31.170
it's just kind of a timing
of feature release.

89
00:04:31.170 --> 00:04:34.840
Or we want to have two unrelated projects
that we decide to combine because there's

90
00:04:34.840 --> 00:04:36.730
some element they can share.

91
00:04:36.730 --> 00:04:40.290
Maybe project one needs to rent a truck,
and

92
00:04:40.290 --> 00:04:42.860
project two needs to rent a truck also.

93
00:04:42.860 --> 00:04:44.860
But they only need it for two hours.

94
00:04:44.860 --> 00:04:49.370
But we find that if we combine those two,
we can rent a truck and use it half

95
00:04:49.370 --> 00:04:52.720
the day on one project and half the day on
the other project, and save some money.

96
00:04:52.720 --> 00:04:56.920
Now these two independent projects become
linked by this shared resource, and

97
00:04:56.920 --> 00:05:01.010
so those are all scenarios when we need
to have a better vision of that and

98
00:05:01.010 --> 00:05:02.210
Project will let us do that.

99
00:05:02.210 --> 00:05:05.910
You can manage more than one project
from inside of Microsoft Project.

100
00:05:05.910 --> 00:05:08.590
All right,
let me show you the first technique.

101
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:14.280
The first technique is to basically
link in an external project into yours.

102
00:05:14.280 --> 00:05:18.570
We can convert any project here in
Microsoft Project into a master project.

103
00:05:18.570 --> 00:05:20.530
Here, for example,
I've got this construction project.

104
00:05:20.530 --> 00:05:22.580
So we're building a house.

105
00:05:22.580 --> 00:05:25.690
So we've got all this stuff laid out and
these are all the things, maybe I work for

106
00:05:25.690 --> 00:05:26.980
a general contractor.

107
00:05:26.980 --> 00:05:29.550
And so this is all the work that
I can do as a general contractor.

108
00:05:29.550 --> 00:05:31.320
We can do some carpentry,

109
00:05:31.320 --> 00:05:35.268
roofing, put in some elevators,
apparently it's a big house.

110
00:05:35.268 --> 00:05:37.330
>> [LAUGH]
>> Maybe an office building then.

111
00:05:37.330 --> 00:05:39.260
So we can put in all this stuff.

112
00:05:39.260 --> 00:05:40.290
These are the things that we can do.

113
00:05:41.410 --> 00:05:45.720
But there's other things that we need
to contract out, like the plumbing and

114
00:05:45.720 --> 00:05:49.650
electric, the masonry work,
we decide we're gonna contract those out.

115
00:05:49.650 --> 00:05:53.920
And so that contractor, you know,
maybe I have a sub-project manager,

116
00:05:53.920 --> 00:05:57.540
it's somebody who's gonna be handling
just the electric, or just the HVAC, and

117
00:05:57.540 --> 00:06:02.020
so I wanna create a separate project
file for that and just link it in here.

118
00:06:02.020 --> 00:06:03.060
All right and so that's,

119
00:06:03.060 --> 00:06:07.460
that's exactly what I've done is I've
created this construction project, and

120
00:06:07.460 --> 00:06:12.780
than I've created separated projects for
each of these other sub-projects.

121
00:06:12.780 --> 00:06:15.190
And I might have a sub-project
manager dedicated to each one, or

122
00:06:15.190 --> 00:06:18.130
it might just be me managing them and
I broken them out here to create a,

123
00:06:18.130 --> 00:06:20.000
you know it's just a little
more simpler for me.

124
00:06:20.000 --> 00:06:23.580
So if I want to look at my masonry work,
I can pull that up and

125
00:06:23.580 --> 00:06:25.590
now here I am in the masonry project.

126
00:06:25.590 --> 00:06:27.690
And so
I can see here's the foundation work for

127
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:31.160
laying the foundation of the building,
here's form and pour concrete,

128
00:06:31.160 --> 00:06:34.815
to actually get that done, and then the
final masonry work which is things like

129
00:06:34.815 --> 00:06:38.265
putting grout work in for
tile and stuff, right?

130
00:06:38.265 --> 00:06:42.155
So this is all the cement stuff that's
gonna happen inside of my project,

131
00:06:42.155 --> 00:06:43.435
all right?

132
00:06:43.435 --> 00:06:45.575
Now I've gotta separate it out here so
it's easier to work with.

133
00:06:45.575 --> 00:06:47.430
It's a smaller chunk of the project.

134
00:06:47.430 --> 00:06:52.230
But, this stuff is gonna happen
inside of my other project, right?

135
00:06:52.230 --> 00:06:55.770
So, I can jump back over to
my other project, right here.

136
00:06:55.770 --> 00:06:57.710
What's gonna be my master project.

137

00:15:14.510 --> 00:15:17.380

00:15:17.380 --> 00:15:20.500

00:15:20.500 --> 00:15:25.320
It's a great technique, and

362
00:18:43.140 --> 00:18:45.600
This is just right here in
this one empty project.

363
00:18:45.600 --> 00:18:46.210
But it looks good.

364
00:18:46.210 --> 00:18:48.220
I don't see any duplicates off-hand.

365
00:18:48.220 --> 00:18:50.510
So now I'm gonna save this project.

366
00:18:50.510 --> 00:18:52.690
All right now, when you save the project,

367
00:18:52.690 --> 00:18:55.410
it's just saving this
resource sheet basically.

368
00:18:55.410 --> 00:18:57.220
The rest of the project is empty.

369
00:18:57.220 --> 00:18:59.800
That's fine, it's exactly what I want.

370
00:18:59.800 --> 00:19:03.470
So I am gonna call this my Resource Pool.

371
00:19:05.455 --> 00:19:09.545
So that project file is now gonna
serve as the resource pool.

372
00:19:09.545 --> 00:19:14.851
And I can go to my other projects and
I can link them to this pool.

373
00:19:14.851 --> 00:19:17.453
The tricky part here is in
order to link to a pool,

374
00:19:17.453 --> 00:19:21.497
you have to have the pool open at
the same time as your main project.

375
00:19:21.497 --> 00:19:24.327
So what I need to do is
I need to take this and

376
00:19:24.327 --> 00:19:28.437
there's this little Restore button up here
in the corner, we usually overlook it.

377
00:19:28.437 --> 00:19:32.767
But it lets me drop that
project into a window and

378
00:19:32.767 --> 00:19:36.280
now I can have more than one project
on my screen at the same time.

379
00:19:36.280 --> 00:19:40.390
And so here on the left I
see my construction project.

380
00:19:40.390 --> 00:19:42.780
And on the right I see my resource pool,
right?

381
00:19:42.780 --> 00:19:44.440
So I've got these both
open at the same time.

382
00:19:44.440 --> 00:19:49.390
And when that happens,
we can go to our construction project and

383
00:19:49.390 --> 00:19:53.340
under Resource,
you'll see the Resource Pool option.

384
00:19:53.340 --> 00:19:56.900
And you can choose that and
choose to share resources, and

385
00:19:56.900 --> 00:20:01.080
from here we can tell it where we
are going to get our resources from.

386
00:20:01.080 --> 00:20:06.340
If we are the pool, you will say use
your own resources, but if you are not

387
00:20:06.340 --> 00:20:10.370
the pool you will choose to use resources
from someone else and you will pick it.

388
00:20:10.370 --> 00:20:13.520
Now notice how I only have one
option here, resource pool, and

389
00:20:13.520 --> 00:20:14.710
I can't change it.

390
00:20:14.710 --> 00:20:18.550
If I had more than one project open, I'd
have to tell it which one was the pool.

391
00:20:18.550 --> 00:20:20.420
I called mine Resource Pool,
you can call it whatever you want.

392
00:20:20.420 --> 00:20:22.070
You can call it Human Resources.

393
00:20:22.070 --> 00:20:23.930
Call it Employees,
it doesn't matter right?

394
00:20:23.930 --> 00:20:26.820
I just called it Resource Pool so
I could remember.

395
00:20:26.820 --> 00:20:31.020
And then down here,
what happens if there is a conflict?

396
00:20:31.020 --> 00:20:35.430
If I have an employee who is booked in two
different projects at the same time, or

397
00:20:35.430 --> 00:20:39.820
if there is a conflict where
John Smith exists in the pool and

398
00:20:39.820 --> 00:20:41.590
he exists in my project.

399
00:20:41.590 --> 00:20:42.380
Which one wins?

400
00:20:42.380 --> 00:20:44.500
Which one becomes the final resource?

401
00:20:44.500 --> 00:20:47.350
And you can choose for
the pool to take precedence or the sharer,

402
00:20:47.350 --> 00:20:49.490
which in this case would
be my main project.

403
00:20:50.580 --> 00:20:53.660
Because I copied mine right over,
they're the same so

404
00:20:53.660 --> 00:20:54.930
I'm just gonna let the pool take place.

405
00:20:54.930 --> 00:20:56.480
It doesn't really matter for me.

406
00:20:56.480 --> 00:21:00.180
In real life land,
it depends on how accurate your data is.

407
00:21:00.180 --> 00:21:02.820
If the data's identical,
then it doesn't matter which one you pick.

408
00:21:02.820 --> 00:21:04.670
Right, you usually pick the pool.

409
00:21:04.670 --> 00:21:07.670
But if you just copied names to the pool,
and

410
00:21:07.670 --> 00:21:11.520
didn't copy things like their pay rate and
schedules and

411
00:21:11.520 --> 00:21:15.290
stuff, then you might want sharer to
take precedence and have that come in.

412
00:21:15.290 --> 00:21:17.880
But you normally want the pool,
that's what's gonna create that stable,

413
00:21:17.880 --> 00:21:18.509
single location.

414
00:21:20.180 --> 00:21:23.910
And when I say OK,
something interesting is gonna happen.

415
00:21:23.910 --> 00:21:25.450
Over here in my construction project,

416
00:21:25.450 --> 00:21:28.360
I'm still gonna see,
all my resources just like normal.

417
00:21:28.360 --> 00:21:29.200
There's all my resources.

418
00:21:30.620 --> 00:21:37.540
And if I go to my Gantt chart,
I can assign resources just like normal,

419
00:21:37.540 --> 00:21:40.620
things aren't gonna look any different
here, things work just like normal.

420
00:21:41.620 --> 00:21:46.500
But what's different is when I
assign somebody a task here,

421
00:21:46.500 --> 00:21:51.410
in the background, it's copying
that to the resource over here.

422
00:21:51.410 --> 00:21:54.120
And so
now I am going to have one project that

423
00:21:54.120 --> 00:21:58.070
is like a central calendar that
shows people's availability.

424
00:21:58.070 --> 00:22:00.930
And whenever I schedule
somebody in my master project,

425
00:22:00.930 --> 00:22:03.850
it is going to look to that pool and say
is this person available on this day or

426
00:22:03.850 --> 00:22:05.530
am I about to over allocate them.

427
00:22:05.530 --> 00:22:08.910
I am now going to get availability
between all my projects.

428
00:22:10.040 --> 00:22:12.000
And all I have to do,
you do have to do this for

429
00:22:12.000 --> 00:22:17.400
each project,
I do need to open my other projects, and

430
00:22:17.400 --> 00:22:21.590
make sure that I set them to use
the resource pool and save them.

431
00:22:21.590 --> 00:22:26.820
And so, here it's, because I've done the
linking, it gets a little bit weird here.

432
00:22:26.820 --> 00:22:31.320
But, I'm gonna go ahead and save my
construction project, and get that saved.

433
00:22:31.320 --> 00:22:34.920
But what I like to do just to
be on the safe side is open each

434
00:22:34.920 --> 00:22:39.760
project individually and just double check
to make sure they're set to use that pool.

435
00:22:39.760 --> 00:22:42.660
In the future you could create a template
that was already linked to the pool,

436
00:22:42.660 --> 00:22:45.850
and that way when you create new projects
they would all be using the resource pool

437
00:22:45.850 --> 00:22:46.710
all ready.

438
00:22:46.710 --> 00:22:50.110
But basically, if you just go in and
open each of your projects, so

439
00:22:50.110 --> 00:22:53.280
I could take electrical,
I'll fire that one up.

440
00:22:53.280 --> 00:22:58.630
And I'll go to Resource > Resource
pool > Share resources and

441
00:22:58.630 --> 00:23:02.120
I'm gonna tell it to use the resources
from that resource pool.

442
00:23:02.120 --> 00:23:03.670
Pool takes precedence, right?

443
00:23:03.670 --> 00:23:07.650
So now it's set and see how that
person just became over allocated?

444
00:23:07.650 --> 00:23:10.880
They weren't over allocated a second ago,
now they are.

445
00:23:10.880 --> 00:23:12.000
What happened?

446
00:23:12.000 --> 00:23:13.780
Well, it looked in the pool and

447
00:23:13.780 --> 00:23:17.980
it saw where that person is assigned
a task in a different project, and

448
00:23:17.980 --> 00:23:22.110
now we've got an overlap, and now I can
see that because we got a resource pool.

449
00:23:22.110 --> 00:23:23.410
Very, very powerful.

450
00:23:23.410 --> 00:23:26.760
This is all stuff that Microsoft Project
server does for you, too, but

451
00:23:26.760 --> 00:23:29.120
notice that I don't have
a project server here.

452
00:23:29.120 --> 00:23:29.730
I just did this.

453
00:23:29.730 --> 00:23:30.430
It was super easy.

454
00:23:30.430 --> 00:23:32.360
It was right here on this machine.

455
00:23:32.360 --> 00:23:36.100
That really is hand,
if you're the only project manager, or

456
00:23:36.100 --> 00:23:37.810
you know if you just have one or
two project managers, and

457
00:23:37.810 --> 00:23:39.820
you don't want that whole
server infrastructure.

458
00:23:39.820 --> 00:23:42.250
I'm just gonna make sure I save that,
and I would just go through and

459
00:23:42.250 --> 00:23:43.980
do that for each of my existing projects.

460
00:23:43.980 --> 00:23:46.268
And in the future we'd set
that up ahead of time, but

461
00:23:46.268 --> 00:23:48.403
now we get that visibility
between our systems.

462
00:23:48.403 --> 00:23:52.243
>> Now this is a really nice resource
because we do have a limited amount of

463
00:23:52.243 --> 00:23:56.428
resources, and we tend to work on them
on multiple projects in one company.

464
00:23:56.428 --> 00:23:59.990
The other best practice of
using a resource pool, as well,

465
00:23:59.990 --> 00:24:05.360
Is that they recommend that you take that
resource pool and open it as read only.

466
00:24:05.360 --> 00:24:08.390
So, that way, whatever you actually set,
somebody doesn't come behind you and

467
00:24:08.390 --> 00:24:09.580
actually change those resources.

468
00:24:09.580 --> 00:24:13.570
In other words, knock one person off of
a project and then say hey, I don't care.

469
00:24:13.570 --> 00:24:16.310
You know, Don set it first,
Ronnie you set the second.

470
00:24:16.310 --> 00:24:18.210
It will actually go ahead and do that.

471
00:24:18.210 --> 00:24:19.850
So you can use it any
way that you want to but

472
00:24:19.850 --> 00:24:23.520
that's usually also the best recommended
practice when using a resource pool.

473
00:24:24.560 --> 00:24:26.120
>> Yeah, it's definitely a cool thing,

474
00:24:26.120 --> 00:24:28.960
if you only do one project at
a time you don't need a pool.

475
00:24:28.960 --> 00:24:32.175
It's not, you're not going to have
conflict, you can only do one at a time.

476
00:24:32.175 --> 00:24:37.375
But if you're managing several
projects running at the same time,

477
00:24:37.375 --> 00:24:39.835
you need some way to coordinate conflicts.

478
00:24:39.835 --> 00:24:41.355
Project server is one route,

479
00:24:41.355 --> 00:24:43.852
which is great if you have more
than one project Project manager.

480
00:24:43.852 --> 00:24:45.822
Resource pools are another route, and

481
00:24:45.822 --> 00:24:48.162
that's great if you're
the only project manager.

482
00:24:48.162 --> 00:24:50.882
And the reason I keep saying if
you're the only project manager,

483
00:24:50.882 --> 00:24:53.052
is because these are files for
right here on the hard drive, and

484
00:24:53.052 --> 00:24:55.620
the links are made with direct
hard links on the file.

485
00:24:55.620 --> 00:24:59.160
You could put them on a network share,
and when they're on a network share,

486
00:24:59.160 --> 00:25:00.950
if you've referenced the files,
the links and

487
00:25:00.950 --> 00:25:04.330
stuff with the network share,
other people could open it too.

488
00:25:04.330 --> 00:25:08.010
But these project files are data bases,
and so when you open the master project,

489
00:25:08.010 --> 00:25:10.390
you're opening all the child projects too.

490
00:25:10.390 --> 00:25:13.750
If somebody tries to open up one of the
child projects, they're gonna get a read

491
00:25:13.750 --> 00:25:17.040
only copy because you're already in it and
you start to get conflicts.

492
00:25:17.040 --> 00:25:20.870
Project Server solves that so
one product manager can use this,

493
00:25:20.870 --> 00:25:24.020
multiple project managers really
do need to go to Project Server.

494
00:25:24.020 --> 00:25:26.690
So that's definitely a big deal there.

495
00:25:26.690 --> 00:25:28.620
Something we definitely
need to be in mind about.

496
00:25:28.620 --> 00:25:31.500
I'm looking something up real quick
cuz I made a comment a second ago and

497
00:25:31.500 --> 00:25:32.970
I'm starting to question myself.

498
00:25:32.970 --> 00:25:38.600
I said that resource pools were in the pro
version and not the standard version.

499
00:25:38.600 --> 00:25:40.580
And Microsoft changed that.

500
00:25:40.580 --> 00:25:43.520
And so, I was just pulling it
up here in the background.

501
00:25:43.520 --> 00:25:47.830
But it does say that the standard
version does support resource pools now.

502
00:25:47.830 --> 00:25:51.180
And that's important because
the price difference is pretty big.

503
00:25:51.180 --> 00:25:54.220
And if you pay full retail like we do,
the standard version's like $300,

504
00:25:54.220 --> 00:25:56.827
the pro version, is it $1200?

505
00:25:56.827 --> 00:25:57.955
>> It's about $1100.

506
00:25:57.955 --> 00:25:58.520
>> $1100.

507
00:25:58.520 --> 00:26:00.550
So it's a big difference so

508
00:26:00.550 --> 00:26:03.440
sorry you don't have to have
the enterprise edition any more.

509
00:26:03.440 --> 00:26:06.150
You used to have,
not the enterprise, the pro version.

510
00:26:06.150 --> 00:26:07.430
You used to have the pro version.

511
00:26:07.430 --> 00:26:08.840
Now you can just do it
in the standard version.

512
00:26:08.840 --> 00:26:10.420
It's a cool functionality and

513
00:26:10.420 --> 00:26:13.580
it's supported in every version
of Microsoft Project App.

514
00:26:13.580 --> 00:26:16.870
>> We can see now the flexibility
of working with multiple projects

515
00:26:16.870 --> 00:26:21.390
just using Project itself without having
to have that additional project server.

516
00:26:21.390 --> 00:26:23.021
It handy to actually know
the techniques to do so.

517
00:26:23.021 --> 00:26:26.240
>> All right well Ronnie I think that's
a pretty good run down right there of

518
00:26:26.240 --> 00:26:27.910
managing multiple projects.

519
00:26:27.910 --> 00:26:29.860
Just be aware, Project Server's out there.

520
00:26:29.860 --> 00:26:31.660
It's great, but
it's not right for everybody.

521
00:26:31.660 --> 00:26:32.760
Resource pools are there.

522
00:26:32.760 --> 00:26:34.750
It's great, but again,
not right for everybody.

523
00:26:34.750 --> 00:26:36.790
So choose the solution that's right for
your environment.

524
00:26:36.790 --> 00:26:39.620
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

525
00:26:39.620 --> 00:26:41.720
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

526
00:26:41.720 --> 00:26:42.554
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

527
00:26:42.554 --> 00:26:43.934
>> And we'll see you next time.

528
00:26:43.934 --> 00:26:49.790
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don show us how to add resources to a project plan.  It's not enough just to list the resources but a user should be able to different resources and the data associated with the resource so it can be tracked by Project. They talk about all the fields associated with resources and show how the resources can be created in the project plan.
episodes.title: Resource Information
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.001 --> 00:00:10.790
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.790 --> 00:00:13.450
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.450 --> 00:00:15.750
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.750 --> 00:00:18.770
I'm your host, Don Pezet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:18.770 --> 00:00:19.510
How's it going, Ronnie?

6
00:00:19.510 --> 00:00:20.580
>> It is going great.

7
00:00:20.580 --> 00:00:21.460
Another exciting day,

8
00:00:21.460 --> 00:00:24.250
cuz we get to actually spend
time in Microsoft Project 2013.

9
00:00:24.250 --> 00:00:26.035
So can't ask for a better day.

10
00:00:26.035 --> 00:00:30.420
>> [LAUGH] Well, today we're going to be
tackling an important part of Project,

11
00:00:30.420 --> 00:00:33.690
which is when we start to add
resources into our system,

12
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:36.600
there's a lot of different
values that we can set on

13
00:00:36.600 --> 00:00:39.400
that resource that indicate all
sorts of crazy information.

14
00:00:39.400 --> 00:00:43.190
And I know we've already talked about some
of them in other episodes, but we want to

15
00:00:43.190 --> 00:00:46.170
make sure that we're thorough and
complete so you're prepared for that exam.

16
00:00:46.170 --> 00:00:48.600
So, we're going to take a look at
each one and kinda what they mean.

17
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:50.270
The type of values that
we put in there and

18
00:00:50.270 --> 00:00:52.600
how they affect our project as a whole.

19
00:00:52.600 --> 00:00:54.160
So Ronnie, where should we start?

20
00:00:54.160 --> 00:00:56.790
>> Let's go and start by taking
a look at a project plan itself.

21
00:00:56.790 --> 00:00:59.720
Remember that up until this point if
you've been following along in this

22
00:00:59.720 --> 00:01:01.920
series, we've done create task.

23
00:01:01.920 --> 00:01:03.110
We've talked about scheduling.

24
00:01:03.110 --> 00:01:04.620
We've done all of that and

25
00:01:04.620 --> 00:01:07.380
we've even assigned a couple of resources,
but if you're like me,

26
00:01:07.380 --> 00:01:10.490
you're maybe like where in the world did
you pull these resources from Ronnie?

27
00:01:10.490 --> 00:01:12.210
What, but where's this coming from?

28
00:01:12.210 --> 00:01:16.660
Well, inside of Microsoft Project you can
actually insert in a resource sheet, and

29
00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:19.890
that's where you keep track of
the resources that you need.

30
00:01:19.890 --> 00:01:24.570
Now, at the very heart of that resource
sheet, it really is a listing of

31
00:01:24.570 --> 00:01:28.530
the names of people or
even just a subject matter expert,

32
00:01:28.530 --> 00:01:31.560
or a particular generic individual
name that you might have.

33
00:01:31.560 --> 00:01:35.070
You might choose something like a software
developer or a project manager or

34
00:01:35.070 --> 00:01:36.090
something like that.

35
00:01:36.090 --> 00:01:38.780
At the heart of it, that's all it
really is is listing those things.

36
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:41.910
But it can also be what we call
material resources as well.

37
00:01:41.910 --> 00:01:43.560
In other words,
things that we will use during

38
00:01:43.560 --> 00:01:45.490
the project that are consumables too.

39
00:01:45.490 --> 00:01:49.200
But the way that we actually use that
right here is that I have this project

40
00:01:49.200 --> 00:01:54.380
plan, and so with this project plan,
if I scroll over to the right-hand side.

41
00:01:54.380 --> 00:01:58.222
Normally what we'll see are resources
that will appear over here, but

42
00:01:58.222 --> 00:02:02.511
you'll take a note, there are no resources
that appear, so what we have to do,

43
00:02:02.511 --> 00:02:05.411
is we need to go ahead and
create this resource sheet.

44
00:02:05.411 --> 00:02:08.873
And the easiest way that to do
that is to go up to View, and

45
00:02:08.873 --> 00:02:12.880
then under Resource Views,
I'm gonna select Resource Sheet.

46
00:02:12.880 --> 00:02:16.473
So think about this as your main
spreadsheet of where your resources

47
00:02:16.473 --> 00:02:18.220
are going to be housed.

48
00:02:18.220 --> 00:02:20.560
And it not only gives
us that list of names,

49
00:02:20.560 --> 00:02:24.916
you actually see that there's a lot of
different attributes that we can also add

50
00:02:24.916 --> 00:02:28.571
in over here that will help us when
we start using those resources.

51
00:02:28.571 --> 00:02:33.280
Such as how much they're gonna get paid,
how often, and even a lot of times here

52
00:02:33.280 --> 00:02:37.100
differences between things like
standard and over time rates.

53
00:02:37.100 --> 00:02:39.740
So what do we normally do
to get a resource in here?

54
00:02:39.740 --> 00:02:43.660
So I'm just going to go ahead and do
something generic here which is, I'm just

55
00:02:43.660 --> 00:02:47.870
going to call it resource one because I'm
not real creative this morning to do that.

56
00:02:47.870 --> 00:02:50.350
Now, the first thing is once
I actually type that in and

57
00:02:50.350 --> 00:02:54.570
I hit Tab, notice that it went ahead and
started filling in some other things.

58
00:02:54.570 --> 00:02:57.830
And so by default you're
actually starting to see,

59
00:02:57.830 --> 00:03:02.280
hey here's what Project is actually
expecting to see here right away.

60

00:14:16.800 --> 00:14:19.610
And here they talk about the measurement
that we'll actually be using.

283
00:14:19.610 --> 00:14:22.220
Let me see if I can hover over that again.

284
00:14:22.220 --> 00:14:23.550
The unit of measurement you enter for

285
00:14:23.550 --> 00:14:27.270
this material resource is boxes,
tons, however much it might be.

286
00:14:27.270 --> 00:14:30.700
So let's say that I buy two
boxes of 1,000 feet of cable.

287
00:14:30.700 --> 00:14:33.480
You know, you might actually
set something like that up.

288
00:14:33.480 --> 00:14:35.570
So that we can actually account for
that if we needed to.

289
00:14:35.570 --> 00:14:37.880
>> Or if you're buying it by the foot or
by the meter,

290
00:14:37.880 --> 00:14:40.610
you are going to put in that
unit of measure, whatever it is.

291
00:14:40.610 --> 00:14:44.920
And when we buy CAT5,
we might set it by a standard box size.

292
00:14:44.920 --> 00:14:48.940
But what if I buy a 500 foot box today and
a 1,000 foot box next month?

293
00:14:48.940 --> 00:14:49.860
That's gonna be different.

294
00:14:49.860 --> 00:14:53.300
So you could add those in
just two different materials.

295
00:14:53.300 --> 00:14:55.700
Or you could do it as one material
if it was a fixed cost, but

296
00:14:55.700 --> 00:14:57.053
unfortunately that doesn't always happen.

297
00:14:57.053 --> 00:14:59.900
So if I buy that 1,000 foot box,

298
00:14:59.900 --> 00:15:02.990
I get a bigger discount than
if I buy the 500 foot box.

299
00:15:02.990 --> 00:15:05.880
So you might not be able to
do it by a unit of measure.

300
00:15:05.880 --> 00:15:08.230
You might have to do it by
boxes like Ronnie was saying.

301
00:15:08.230 --> 00:15:11.910
Or you might have to be really specific
and say, this is a 500 foot box and

302
00:15:11.910 --> 00:15:12.850
do another line item for

303
00:15:12.850 --> 00:15:18.250
1000 foot box because it will have
a different price associated with them.

304
00:15:18.250 --> 00:15:19.690
>> Now, we have a choice.

305
00:15:19.690 --> 00:15:22.320
These other initials, even though
they actually show us a cable and

306
00:15:22.320 --> 00:15:24.310
we can use that, but notice that group and

307
00:15:24.310 --> 00:15:29.170
max, these aren't actually not filled in
because there's no, and I can't even click

308
00:15:29.170 --> 00:15:33.320
on the scroll wheel here to try and
actually increase the maximum size.

309
00:15:33.320 --> 00:15:36.560
They're saying, hey, here's a resource
that's gonna end up being used up so

310
00:15:36.560 --> 00:15:38.830
you're probably gonna use all of it or
none of it.

311
00:15:38.830 --> 00:15:39.690
That's perfectly fine.

312
00:15:39.690 --> 00:15:43.050
And you have Standard Rate and
then of course Cost Per Use.

313
00:15:43.050 --> 00:15:46.020
Now you may choose here, if I'd chose like
a box, I think I looked it up the other

314
00:15:46.020 --> 00:15:49.930
day for 1,000 feet and
it was like $102 or maybe like $80.

315
00:15:49.930 --> 00:15:51.430
I can't remember.

316
00:15:51.430 --> 00:15:53.625
There were a couple of different
ones that I looked up.

317
00:15:53.625 --> 00:15:56.519
So I can actually enter that in in
standard rate, on the overtime,

318
00:15:56.519 --> 00:15:58.537
notice I went ahead and
shifted it over there,

319
00:15:58.537 --> 00:16:02.080
it doesn't give me the actual ability to
go ahead and type anything I'm trying.

320
00:16:02.080 --> 00:16:05.080
And that won't actually let
me type in anything there.

321
00:16:05.080 --> 00:16:09.488
But then if I were running it,
I could also set up this work resource for

00:16:09.488 --> 00:16:14.268
a cost per use as well, and then say how
much I'm actually using of it too, so

00:16:14.268 --> 00:16:16.710
you're sending up the same thing.

324
00:16:16.710 --> 00:16:19.900
>> Yeah, you've got to think about
the difference here in materials,

325
00:16:19.900 --> 00:16:21.540
especially with things that you rent.

326
00:16:21.540 --> 00:16:24.730
So if I'm buying lumber
from the lumber store,

327
00:16:24.730 --> 00:16:27.411
from whatever store it is
that you buy lumber from.

328
00:16:27.411 --> 00:16:29.454
[LAUGH] I'm ruining this example.

329
00:16:29.454 --> 00:16:31.950
So if you buy lumber,
you get 100% of that lumber.

330
00:16:31.950 --> 00:16:34.260
It's not like your getting
just a part of the lumber,

331
00:16:34.260 --> 00:16:36.460
it's not like it's just
available just some of the time.

332
00:16:36.460 --> 00:16:38.110
You bought it, you got it,
it's available 100%.

333
00:16:38.110 --> 00:16:41.390
So that's why we can't
modify that max unit.

334
00:16:41.390 --> 00:16:43.360
You've bought it, you've got it.

335
00:16:43.360 --> 00:16:45.550
Now when you put that in, that's it.

336
00:16:45.550 --> 00:16:48.690
You already paid for it,
you bought it, it's a tangible item.

337
00:16:48.690 --> 00:16:52.690
But if it's a truck that you rent,
right, well if you're renting it,

338
00:16:52.690 --> 00:16:54.630
you don't get it a hundred
percent of the time.

339
00:16:54.630 --> 00:16:56.330
You only have it when you're using it.

340
00:16:56.330 --> 00:16:59.170
And every time you use it,
there's a cost associated.

341
00:16:59.170 --> 00:17:01.360
So there's a cost per use.

342
00:17:01.360 --> 00:17:03.400
If I buy that lumber,
there's a one time cost.

343
00:17:03.400 --> 00:17:05.310
I pay for it and I've got it.

344
00:17:05.310 --> 00:17:07.350
And if I need to buy more lumber,
that's a different story.

345
00:17:07.350 --> 00:17:10.860
I go and buy more lumber, but
with that truck, every time I use it,

346
00:17:10.860 --> 00:17:11.880
there is a cost per use.

347
00:17:11.880 --> 00:17:13.590
So we have that separate
column to be able to track it.

348
00:17:13.590 --> 00:17:18.040
It just comes down to the different types
of resources that you're working with.

349
00:17:18.040 --> 00:17:20.660
>> And then if I were purchasing this, I
might actually say, hey, I went ahead and

350
00:17:20.660 --> 00:17:26.340
spent the whole $102 and I don't get to
tie a project calendar to it as well.

351
00:17:26.340 --> 00:17:29.220
So you'll see that there's some of these
that are just not gonna be available

352
00:17:29.220 --> 00:17:32.520
to you if you choose something
like this type of resource here.

353
00:17:32.520 --> 00:17:33.760
And that's where you would go in.

354
00:17:33.760 --> 00:17:37.880
If you have all of the data available
to you to enter in, as much as you can,

355
00:17:37.880 --> 00:17:39.390
that's what you wanna do here.

356
00:17:39.390 --> 00:17:42.810
You wanna make this as complete as
you can, and as accurate as you can

357
00:17:42.810 --> 00:17:46.230
because here's the data that's going
to be used as a basis for some of

358
00:17:46.230 --> 00:17:49.750
the reports that you're gonna run later
and also for calculating out all the other

359
00:17:49.750 --> 00:17:54.630
information on your project plan when you
start assigning them to resources as well.

360
00:17:54.630 --> 00:17:58.400
Now this is not the only place that
we need to take a look at though when

361
00:17:58.400 --> 00:18:01.108
we start taking a look
at resources themselves.

362
00:18:01.108 --> 00:18:05.430
If I right-click let's say on resource
one here and I right-click and

363
00:18:05.430 --> 00:18:07.470
I go down to Information and

364
00:18:08.560 --> 00:18:12.560
hopefully right here this is what we
also want to be able take a look at too.

365
00:18:12.560 --> 00:18:16.970
So it may be for this resource, itself,

366
00:18:16.970 --> 00:18:21.010
we may find out that he can't
work the standard eight or

367
00:18:21.010 --> 00:18:24.700
the standard calendar that we normally
would work on that base calendar.

368
00:18:24.700 --> 00:18:29.190
Well notice I can come in here and
change his working time if I needed to.

369
00:18:29.190 --> 00:18:32.120
When I do that I'm really
changing his work calendar.

370
00:18:32.120 --> 00:18:37.040
So you might actually go in there and add
in a different schedule at that point for

371
00:18:37.040 --> 00:18:39.430
that resource to be able to come in.

372
00:18:39.430 --> 00:18:44.480
Or like you have over here in the lower
left-hand corner of this generic, or

373
00:18:44.480 --> 00:18:48.000
the general tab where it
says Resource Availability.

374
00:18:48.000 --> 00:18:52.460
What if you find out that that resource is
not gonna be available for the first two

375
00:18:52.460 --> 00:18:57.020
weeks, because he's either on vacation or
he's actually assigned to another project.

376
00:18:57.020 --> 00:19:00.140
Well, you can also set that up here and
say, look,

377
00:19:00.140 --> 00:19:03.145
he's only going to be available from
this particular time to this time, but

378
00:19:03.145 --> 00:19:05.275
after that, he's supposed to
be on a different project.

379
00:19:05.275 --> 00:19:08.185
We may go ahead and
set that up right here as well.

380
00:19:08.185 --> 00:19:10.295
>> Yeah, the cool part is
you can set the units too.

381
00:19:10.295 --> 00:19:11.985
So maybe it's not that
he's completely out,

382
00:19:11.985 --> 00:19:14.535
maybe he just has reduced
availability those days.

383
00:19:14.535 --> 00:19:18.625
So he's going to be split between other
projects, so we said it's 50% for

384
00:19:18.625 --> 00:19:20.555
that period of time, but
it's good flexibility.

385
00:19:20.555 --> 00:19:21.385
>> It really is.

386
00:19:21.385 --> 00:19:24.785
And there's only one other thing that
you can actually start seeing some

387
00:19:24.785 --> 00:19:25.570
other things.

388
00:19:25.570 --> 00:19:28.100
And notice if you type in all
these other things, like group and

389
00:19:28.100 --> 00:19:31.990
code, that stuff should also fill in

390
00:19:31.990 --> 00:19:34.790
But right here where it
says booking type too.

391
00:19:34.790 --> 00:19:39.560
If I select that booking type, I can
select it as a proposed booking type or

00:19:39.560 --> 00:19:40.620
a committed one.

00:19:40.620 --> 00:19:43.470
Now that doesn't really
affect the schedule.

394
00:19:43.470 --> 00:19:46.030
What it allows you to do is
to actually know whether or

00:19:46.030 --> 00:19:50.070
not this is a tentative commitment,
that this person can make it or

396
00:19:50.070 --> 00:19:54.910
whether you absolutely 100% believe
that they're also gonna make it too.

397
00:19:54.910 --> 00:19:58.480
So you have this booking type that you
can go ahead and set that up on and

00:19:58.480 --> 00:20:01.960
that way you know whether or not you're
actually going to be able to use them or

00:20:01.960 --> 00:20:05.250
your likelihood of using
them is also greater.

400
00:20:05.250 --> 00:20:08.600
And again, this comes down to
the reports that you're gonna run.

401
00:20:08.600 --> 00:20:12.010
If you need to take a look at
all of your committed bookings,

00:20:12.010 --> 00:20:14.160
in other words,
all the people that you're gonna have.

403
00:20:14.160 --> 00:20:16.260
And you wanna go all right,
who's actually committed to this,

404
00:20:16.260 --> 00:20:18.490
versus who's proposed,
it helps you out here.

405
00:20:18.490 --> 00:20:22.060
So the more details that you can fill out
here, the better it's also going to be.

406
00:20:23.700 --> 00:20:27.260
>> Yeah, like a lot of things in project,
there's just more than one way you can do

407
00:20:27.260 --> 00:20:30.785
things, more than one place you can put
things, so this is kind of a quick way.

408
00:20:30.785 --> 00:20:32.930
Apeaking of more than
one place to do things,

409
00:20:32.930 --> 00:20:36.150
you came here to the resource
sheet to create these resources.

00:20:36.150 --> 00:20:39.140
If you're just in the planning phases,
you can really quickly and

easily create resources

00:20:41.240 --> 00:20:44.270
If you just type in a new resource name
and press enter, it will create one.

413
00:20:44.270 --> 00:20:47.060
But it will create it as a work type.

414
00:20:47.060 --> 00:20:50.900
Assuming that it's a person and
not material or cost.

415
00:20:50.900 --> 00:20:53.060
If you enter them in that way you've
got to come back here to go and

00:20:53.060 --> 00:20:54.820
update those and change them too.

417
00:20:54.820 --> 00:20:58.960
While there is more than one way to do it,
here in the resource sheet kind of gives

00:20:58.960 --> 00:21:01.350
you that all in one spot where

419
00:21:01.350 --> 00:21:03.910
>> Yeah, let's kind of show what happen

00:21:03.910 --> 00:21:05.130
created as well.

00:21:05.130 --> 00:21:08.600
I went ahead and switched backed

00:21:08.600 --> 00:21:13.430
I selected Task, then I selected Gantt
Chart and that brings me back over here.

423
00:21:13.430 --> 00:21:16.150
Then to the right hand side
there's resource names.

424
00:21:16.150 --> 00:21:20.170
If I created that resource sheet,
I just need to click on the drop down and

00:21:20.170 --> 00:21:24.290
this way I can actually choose
what resource I'm going to assign.

426
00:21:24.290 --> 00:21:27.150
So all your available
resources are right there for

00:21:27.150 --> 00:21:31.110
you if you needed to actually
assign a multiple resources to.

00:21:31.110 --> 00:21:34.430
So you can actually do that as well for

00:21:34.430 --> 00:21:37.790
So, I want to assign two resources,

00:21:37.790 --> 00:21:40.580
So it doesn't always have to

00:21:40.580 --> 00:21:43.130
You can go through and actually add in

432
00:21:43.130 --> 00:21:47.800
The way that Don was talking about, if I
wanted to add in, let's say, resource two.

433
00:21:48.980 --> 00:21:50.600
Notice it takes it perfectly.

00:21:50.600 --> 00:21:52.190
There it is and actually adds it in.

435
00:21:52.190 --> 00:21:54.750
And now notice it actually

436
00:21:54.750 --> 00:21:59.330
And so we go back to what Don was talking
about, view and then resource sheets.

437
00:21:59.330 --> 00:22:02.710
Notice that resource number two

00:22:02.710 --> 00:22:06.780
You don't always have to do it from here,
but this is where you want to set up as

00:22:06.780 --> 00:22:12.100
many of those standard attributes
that you have available to you

440
00:22:12.100 --> 00:22:14.900
to be able to create what you need to and

00:22:14.900 --> 00:22:17.490
So you still have to come

00:22:17.490 --> 00:22:19.710

00:22:19.710 --> 00:22:21.735
Probably better if you can

00:22:21.735 --> 00:22:26.580

00:22:26.580 --> 00:22:29.260
once you do that you can come back over

446
00:22:29.260 --> 00:22:31.430
>> You know something just
popped into my mind Ronnie.

447
00:22:31.430 --> 00:22:35.000
If you watched our previous episode where
we were talking about managing multiple

00:22:35.000 --> 00:22:38.140
projects, we talked about
creating a resource pool,

449
00:22:38.140 --> 00:22:41.090
where our resources weren't
actually in the project itself, but

450
00:22:41.090 --> 00:22:44.120
we're in a separate resource pool so
it can be shared amongst projects.

451
00:22:44.120 --> 00:22:46.090
So if your about to do
a bunch of data entry for

452
00:22:46.090 --> 00:22:49.960
new resources, it's probably a good
idea to put them in the pool,

453
00:22:49.960 --> 00:22:52.130
that way they can be shared
across the projects.

454
00:22:52.130 --> 00:22:52.950
You don't have to.

455
00:22:52.950 --> 00:22:55.760
You could have resources that were
just in the individual projects, but

456
00:22:55.760 --> 00:22:57.970
if you've got a pool,
it's a good idea to put them there.

457
00:22:57.970 --> 00:23:00.090
The data entry's done the same exact way.

458
00:23:00.090 --> 00:23:01.110
It's the same fields.

459
00:23:01.110 --> 00:23:03.400
You just punch them in and
now they can be shared.

460
00:23:03.400 --> 00:23:08.790
Really handy with employees, not so handy
with things like lumber or cat five cable.

461
00:23:08.790 --> 00:23:12.692
But with employees and equipment that's
really nice because you can see when you

462
00:23:12.692 --> 00:23:16.590
over allocate and
that's a pretty important feature.

463
00:23:16.590 --> 00:23:17.180
All right Ronnie,

00:23:17.180 --> 00:23:19.830
well I think we've pretty exhaustively

00:23:19.830 --> 00:23:21.575
Are there any other things
