00:23:21.575 --> 00:23:22.235
Not right now.

467
00:23:22.235 --> 00:23:26.255
Now what we have to do in the future is
that now that we've got these resource

468
00:23:26.255 --> 00:23:30.575
pools, we next talk about how we attach to
them to the tasks and see what happens.

469
00:23:30.575 --> 00:23:33.505
>> And see how angry our employees

00:23:33.505 --> 00:23:34.970
work they have to do.

471
00:23:34.970 --> 00:23:36.720
All right, well we're gonna
wrap this one up right here.

472
00:23:36.720 --> 00:23:40.350
Stay tuned, we've got more resource
activity coming down the line from

00:23:40.350 --> 00:23:44.660
Microsoft project, but signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

474
00:23:44.660 --> 00:23:45.390
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

475
00:23:45.390 --> 00:23:46.476
>> And we'll see you next time.

476
00:23:46.476 --> 00:23:51.970
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Ronnie dive into assigning resources to tasks.  It is this action that connects tasks and resource together to see how the project engine starts to change the schedule.  It's important for the project manager to know not only how to assign a resource but how to change a resource and even change the availability.
episodes.title: Resource Assignments

Remember that everything we've done up to

Besides that, it's really been the data

Once we actually start linking

00:01:05.880 --> 00:01:07.840

It's going to be neat as

25
00:01:10.390 --> 00:01:12.980
little series on resource assignments.

26
00:01:12.980 --> 00:01:14.840
>> All right, so
let's say you've sat down and

27
00:01:14.840 --> 00:01:16.870
you've punched in all of your resources.

28
00:01:16.870 --> 00:01:19.090
Or maybe you haven't thought of some yet
and

29
00:01:19.090 --> 00:01:21.030
you're gonna create them
kind of on the fly.

30
00:01:21.030 --> 00:01:25.380
Well, once we've got our resources made,
we're ready to assign them some work.

31
00:01:25.380 --> 00:01:29.750
And there's a few different ways to
go about it based on what level or

32
00:01:29.750 --> 00:01:31.990
what point you're at in the project and
what level of comfort you have.

33
00:01:33.020 --> 00:01:36.230
If you're in the very early
planning basis of a project,

34
00:01:36.230 --> 00:01:37.310
let me show you an example here.

35
00:01:37.310 --> 00:01:39.670
I'm a going to just whip
a new project on my machines.

36
00:01:39.670 --> 00:01:40.920
Here I got a blank project.

37
00:01:40.920 --> 00:01:42.390
And we're just in the planning phases and

38
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:45.980
I say something like, all right Ronnie,
what's involved in building a house.

39
00:01:45.980 --> 00:01:46.950
We're going to build a house.

40
00:01:46.950 --> 00:01:48.970
So we got to buy some land.

41
00:01:48.970 --> 00:01:51.400
We got to pull permits.

42
00:01:51.400 --> 00:01:53.600
You just start thinking of
the things you have to do.

43
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:57.570
You have to level the ground or break
ground, or what ever we want to call it.

44
00:01:57.570 --> 00:02:00.520
Lay a foundation and so on.

45
00:02:00.520 --> 00:02:03.350
So you're just starting to come over
the things that have to be done to get

46
00:02:03.350 --> 00:02:04.000
that house built.

47
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:08.180
And then you start thinking about the kind
of people you're going to need for it.

48
00:02:08.180 --> 00:02:11.445
Well, if you've already created this
resource sheet with all of your stuff in

49
00:02:11.445 --> 00:02:12.635
there, that's great.

50
00:02:12.635 --> 00:02:16.025
But if you're just trying to think of it
here from a ballpark, you can actually

51
00:02:16.025 --> 00:02:19.795
kinda stretch this Gantt chart over so
that we can see the resource names, and

52
00:02:19.795 --> 00:02:23.447
you can just start typing
in placeholder names.

53
00:02:23.447 --> 00:02:26.867
And if it's something that a single
person could do, so, buy land.

54
00:02:26.867 --> 00:02:28.847
Well, somebody's gotta buy that land.

55
00:02:28.847 --> 00:02:29.627
Who's it gonna be?

56
00:02:29.627 --> 00:02:34.897
Well, maybe that's the investor, or
whoever the homeowner is gonna be.

57
00:02:34.897 --> 00:02:36.017
Let's say it's me.

58
00:02:36.017 --> 00:02:39.917
So if I know who it is specifically,
I can just put in my name.

59
00:02:39.917 --> 00:02:45.500
Or if I think it's gonna be somebody
generic, I could just say Homeowner.

60
00:02:45.500 --> 00:02:46.650
Is that one word or two words?

61
00:02:46.650 --> 00:02:47.630
>> I think it's one word.

62
00:02:47.630 --> 00:02:48.390
>> All right, well we'll find out.

63
00:02:48.390 --> 00:02:49.120
There you go.

64
00:02:49.120 --> 00:02:50.370
So you just type it in.

65
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:55.040
Now when I did that,
I created a resource called homeowner and

66
00:02:55.040 --> 00:02:58.360
assigned it to the buy land activity.

67
00:02:58.360 --> 00:03:01.730
So I did two things at once
automatically in the background.

68
00:03:01.730 --> 00:03:03.499
If I jump over to my resource sheet.

69
00:03:05.240 --> 00:03:08.090
I can see I've got a resource
named homeowner now.

70
00:03:08.090 --> 00:03:10.270
It made it for
me with all the default values.

71
00:03:10.270 --> 00:03:12.470
That may be a problem now
because it's not accurate, but

72
00:03:12.470 --> 00:03:14.930
in the planning phase I"m okay with that.

73
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:19.330
When I go back to my Gantt chart, I can
see the Homeowner is assigned to it and

74
00:03:19.330 --> 00:03:24.290
if I find it in my chart, it's going to
have to have some kind of duration here,

75
00:03:24.290 --> 00:03:26.845
let's say it's going to take me 30 days.

76
00:03:26.845 --> 00:03:28.610
I"ll put that in as an estimate.

77
00:03:28.610 --> 00:03:31.010
There we go.
And when we look inside of our Ganttchart,

78
00:03:31.010 --> 00:03:32.420
I can see that laid out.

79
00:03:32.420 --> 00:03:35.920
And I can see right there
the resource assigned to it.

80
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:39.300
Now if it's something that's gonna
involve more than one person,

81
00:03:39.300 --> 00:03:41.310
we just separate them by commas.

82
00:03:41.310 --> 00:03:44.480
So I might have something like
pull permits and I put for

83
00:03:44.480 --> 00:03:46.490
that my general contractor.

84
00:03:47.600 --> 00:03:49.270
They're the ones that are gonna do that.

85
00:03:49.270 --> 00:03:52.700
But then all the way down here at the end,
I might have some kind of activity that

86
00:03:52.700 --> 00:03:57.770
says, sign off on completion.

87
00:03:57.770 --> 00:04:03.070
And that might actually be a team
thing between the general contractor,

88
00:04:03.070 --> 00:04:06.840
which you can see it's auto completing for
me right there.

89
00:04:06.840 --> 00:04:12.090
And if I keep typing,
I can just add a comma after, whoops.

90
00:04:12.090 --> 00:04:15.940
I can try and add a comma after
the general contractor's name and

91
00:04:15.940 --> 00:04:18.930
then I can come in and
type in homeowner and

92
00:04:18.930 --> 00:04:22.560
I can have more than one resource
there separated by commas.

93
00:04:22.560 --> 00:04:24.520
Now I know that the general contractor and

94
00:04:24.520 --> 00:04:28.470
the homeowner have to work together
on signing off for completion.

95
00:04:28.470 --> 00:04:34.850
And if we just assign that $1,
apparently a one day.

96
00:04:34.850 --> 00:04:37.770
There.
And we find it in our Gantt chart.

97
00:04:37.770 --> 00:04:38.960
We should see where.

98
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:40.040
There.
So now it's got those

99
00:04:40.040 --> 00:04:41.570
two resources assigned to it.

100
00:04:41.570 --> 00:04:43.320
I can see what's going on.

101
00:04:43.320 --> 00:04:47.670
So pretty easy to assign
a resource to an activity.

102
00:04:47.670 --> 00:04:51.210
In fact, once the resources are already
there I don't even have to type them.

103
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:56.290
I can take something like level the ground
and you'll see that's a drop down box and

104
00:04:56.290 --> 00:05:00.770
it will list all of the resources in my
project and I can just check them off.

105
00:05:00.770 --> 00:05:05.270
So if I have a project that is
a little more fully developed,

106
00:05:05.270 --> 00:05:07.960
like this project that I've
got tucked away back here.

107
00:05:07.960 --> 00:05:09.830
This one has a full resource sheet.

108
00:05:09.830 --> 00:05:12.000
And so if I take something and

109
00:05:12.000 --> 00:05:14.200
let me just kind of blank out
the resources on this one.

110
00:05:14.200 --> 00:05:18.750
So now I've got this job submit shop
drawings, and nobody's attached to it,

111
00:05:18.750 --> 00:05:23.220
I can hit the drop-down for this one and
I'm going to see all the resources for

112
00:05:23.220 --> 00:05:25.390
that project, and
I can come in and choose them.

113
00:05:25.390 --> 00:05:29.280
This is going to be people,
as well as material and costs.

114
00:05:29.280 --> 00:05:32.610
I just go down the line and check off
who all's going to be involved in this.

115
00:05:32.610 --> 00:05:34.500
And I wasn't paying attention
to what job that was,

116
00:05:34.500 --> 00:05:36.560
but let's just say it's
something electric, and so

117
00:05:36.560 --> 00:05:40.520
I might assign my electrical contractor
under electrical contractor management.

118
00:05:40.520 --> 00:05:43.590
And I punch them in, and
now, they're assigned.

119
00:05:44.700 --> 00:05:47.570
So it's really easy to
give somebody work to do

120
00:05:47.570 --> 00:05:50.650
right here through the Gantt chart and
task list.

121
00:05:50.650 --> 00:05:52.960
The only problem is,

122
00:05:52.960 --> 00:05:57.480
I can't really tell if I'm assigning
somebody work that's overlapping.

123
00:05:57.480 --> 00:05:59.830
So for example,
I assign the electrical contractor and

124
00:05:59.830 --> 00:06:04.150
electrical manager right here to this
activity that's Monday, August 10th.

125
00:06:05.420 --> 00:06:07.690
Well, I've got another activity
right after that that's Monday,

126
00:06:07.690 --> 00:06:09.250
August 10th also.

127
00:06:09.250 --> 00:06:12.670
What happens if I go in and
assign the same people?

128
00:06:12.670 --> 00:06:16.060
And I could pick them in
the drop-down boxes again, or

129
00:06:16.060 --> 00:06:21.450
I could actually just drag this box and
do it like that to copy them,

130
00:06:21.450 --> 00:06:24.770
but when I do it, see how I just
over allocated those people?

131
00:06:24.770 --> 00:06:28.860
So I get my little warning bell over here
letting me know I got an over allocation.

132
00:06:28.860 --> 00:06:31.800
Assigning it this way is really easy, but

133
00:06:31.800 --> 00:06:34.180
it doesn't give us a lot of
advance functionality, like,

134
00:06:34.180 --> 00:06:38.200
seeing we're about to over allocate people
until after the fact, until it's too late.

135
00:06:38.200 --> 00:06:41.540
So that method works great in the planning
phase and the early stages, but

136
00:06:41.540 --> 00:06:44.200
in the late stages,
where I really have detailed information,

137
00:06:44.200 --> 00:06:47.280
I need something better because I gotta
worry about over allocating people, and

138
00:06:47.280 --> 00:06:50.490
giving people overtime,
I gotta worry about that stuff.

139
00:06:50.490 --> 00:06:54.150
And just punching it there in the research
names field, that's not gonna work.

140
00:06:54.150 --> 00:06:57.120
So I've got a few other
tools that I can use.

141
00:06:57.120 --> 00:06:59.660
There's one that I'm gonna tell you about
that we're gonna save for another episode,

142
00:06:59.660 --> 00:07:00.430
it's kind of a bigger one.

143
00:07:00.430 --> 00:07:02.140
And then one that we'll use right here.

144
00:07:02.140 --> 00:07:03.200
Let me show you.

145
00:07:03.200 --> 00:07:07.110
So when I come in and I pick an activity,
like here, clear and grub site,

146
00:07:07.110 --> 00:07:10.720
I don't even know what grub site means,
but we're gonna clear and grub a site.

147
00:07:10.720 --> 00:07:12.500
I need to assign some people to that.

148
00:07:12.500 --> 00:07:16.010
Well, you can go up here
to your Resource tab and

149
00:07:16.010 --> 00:07:19.330
there's what's called the Team Planner,
and the Team Planner is awesome.

150
00:07:19.330 --> 00:07:22.070
It's so awesome that we're going
to use it in another show, so

151
00:07:22.070 --> 00:07:23.170
we'll get a chance to see it.

152
00:07:23.170 --> 00:07:26.460
But it basically lays out
in almost a calendar view.

153
00:07:26.460 --> 00:07:28.170
You can see all of your resources.

154
00:07:28.170 --> 00:07:29.850
When they're busy, when they're not busy.

155
00:07:29.850 --> 00:07:31.589
You can kind of pick and choose from that.

156
00:07:33.610 --> 00:07:35.320
The team planner is really neat,
really cool,

157
00:07:35.320 --> 00:07:37.830
we definitely wanna cover that in depth,
so I'm gonna save that one.

158
00:07:37.830 --> 00:07:42.610
But another tool that's available for
us is right next to it, assign resources.

159
00:07:42.610 --> 00:07:44.140
So if you highlight an activity and

160
00:07:44.140 --> 00:07:48.000
choose assign resources,
you get this cool little pop-up.

161
00:07:48.000 --> 00:07:52.690
And what the pop up does is it displays
the resources that are available to us and

162
00:07:52.690 --> 00:07:57.760
it shows us some key information that's
handy in helping us make a decision.

163
00:07:57.760 --> 00:08:01.950
The first thing that it's showing
us is our units and our cost.

164
00:08:03.210 --> 00:08:05.820
Our units,
how much availability do they have?

165
00:08:05.820 --> 00:08:08.820
Is this person available 100%
of the time of my project?

166
00:08:08.820 --> 00:08:11.640
Or are they only available 50%
of the time on my project?

167
00:08:11.640 --> 00:08:15.030
And you'll see, all of my guys are empty
and that just means they're 100%.

168
00:08:15.030 --> 00:08:16.180
They're at the default.

169
00:08:16.180 --> 00:08:18.490
If somebody wasn't at the default
it would show it in here and

170
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:21.270
I would know,
that person has limited availability.

171
00:08:21.270 --> 00:08:24.130
So if I have an effort driven task, and

172
00:08:24.130 --> 00:08:27.200
I assign somebody who's
50% availability on it,

173
00:08:27.200 --> 00:08:32.620
it'll take twice as long as an activity
for somebody who has 100% availability.

174
00:08:32.620 --> 00:08:34.720
So that's going to
influence my choice here.

175
00:08:34.720 --> 00:08:37.020
If I need to get it done fast,
I'm not going to pick a part timer,

176
00:08:37.020 --> 00:08:38.970
I'm going to pick a full timer.

177
00:08:38.970 --> 00:08:43.740
Or a full timer and a part timer to get it
done even faster if it's effort driven.

178
00:08:43.740 --> 00:08:45.460
If it's not effort driven,
then it doesn't matter.

179
00:08:45.460 --> 00:08:47.860
I just pick one of those people and
throw them in there.

180
00:08:47.860 --> 00:08:50.790
And cost, I might have three people

181
00:08:50.790 --> 00:08:53.353
that are perfectly capable of
achieving the same job, but

182
00:08:53.353 --> 00:08:58.000
one of them might be really expensive, one
of them might be really inexpensive and

183
00:08:58.000 --> 00:09:01.410
I might choose the inexpensive one to
shave off some money from my project.

184
00:09:01.410 --> 00:09:03.190
Now there's a trade off there.

185
00:09:03.190 --> 00:09:05.750
The person who's expensive is
probably better at their job.

186
00:09:05.750 --> 00:09:06.425
I should hope.

187
00:09:06.425 --> 00:09:08.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> And the person who's less expensive is

188
00:09:08.010 --> 00:09:09.460
probably not as good at their job.

189
00:09:09.460 --> 00:09:13.240
So you're introducing risk,
here we get to make that decision.

190
00:09:13.240 --> 00:09:15.030
So it's all kind of laid out.

191
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:19.250
The only negative here is it's
showing all of our resources.

192
00:09:19.250 --> 00:09:21.430
And so, if you have a lot of resources,

193
00:09:21.430 --> 00:09:23.540
it can be hard to find
the ones that you want.

194
00:09:23.540 --> 00:09:26.740
So you'll see that you have this
resource list options up at the top,

195
00:09:26.740 --> 00:09:29.630
where we can come in and
we can filter things.

196
00:09:29.630 --> 00:09:31.370
And you can filter it by a few things.

197
00:09:31.370 --> 00:09:36.400
Like filtering it right here by
group is what I normally do.

198
00:09:36.400 --> 00:09:38.480
If your resources have
groups assigned to them.

199
00:09:38.480 --> 00:09:42.070
So you can group your IT guys together,
group your accounting people together,

200
00:09:42.070 --> 00:09:44.870
you can filter by that group and
that makes life a lot easier.

201
00:09:44.870 --> 00:09:50.010
You can filter by a lot of other things,
too, based on what kind of work complete,

202
00:09:50.010 --> 00:09:53.660
date range, created after,
all sorts of other things.

203
00:09:53.660 --> 00:09:56.540
Nine times out of ten I"m using
group to reduce this down and

204
00:09:56.540 --> 00:09:58.290
get just a certain amount of people.

205
00:09:59.430 --> 00:10:00.750
And you create more filters.

206
00:10:00.750 --> 00:10:02.870
You can actually create
custom filters if you want.

207
00:10:02.870 --> 00:10:06.090
So you can create a filter that said just
show me people who's name start with A.

208
00:10:06.090 --> 00:10:09.110
I don't know how useful that would be,
but you certainly could do it.

209
00:10:09.110 --> 00:10:11.600
So you can create all sorts
of filters in there for that.

210
00:10:13.180 --> 00:10:15.720
And then you can also choose
available to work and

211
00:10:15.720 --> 00:10:17.470
specify a certain amount of hours.

212
00:10:17.470 --> 00:10:20.460
Only show me people that are available
to work eight hours a day.

213
00:10:20.460 --> 00:10:22.840
If somebody's part time,
I don't even want to see them.

214
00:10:22.840 --> 00:10:24.600
So you can filter out based on that too.

215
00:10:24.600 --> 00:10:26.950
That helps to get those lists reduced and

216
00:10:26.950 --> 00:10:30.145
kind of filter things down until
you only see a particular values.

217
00:10:32.140 --> 00:10:35.000
Now, when we wanna assign somebody
the activity, we can come in here and

218
00:10:35.000 --> 00:10:36.520
we can choose them and

219
00:10:36.520 --> 00:10:40.120
then you just hit the assign button and
it's going to assign them.

220
00:10:40.120 --> 00:10:42.750
And see how the units
in cost just filled in?

221
00:10:42.750 --> 00:10:46.740
So I can see that person has 100% and
their cost is $0.

222
00:10:46.740 --> 00:10:47.730
I can actually go in and

223
00:10:47.730 --> 00:10:50.980
update their cost right from here
because I know it's incorrect.

224
00:10:50.980 --> 00:10:55.100
And so we can come in and punch that in if
we needed to by double clicking on them

225
00:10:55.100 --> 00:10:56.990
and coming in and
changing their cost right there.

226
00:10:58.510 --> 00:11:02.330
Then, oops,
I'm messing with my chart here.

227
00:11:02.330 --> 00:11:06.065
So then we can go in and we can pick
other people if we needed to and

228
00:11:06.065 --> 00:11:07.495
start to get them assigned.

229
00:11:07.495 --> 00:11:09.695
So I just did the electrical
contract manager.

230
00:11:09.695 --> 00:11:13.385
I could come in here and pick the
electrical contractor and hit Assign, and

231
00:11:13.385 --> 00:11:14.565
they're now added too.

232
00:11:14.565 --> 00:11:16.705
And I just start adding
the ones that I want.

233
00:11:16.705 --> 00:11:19.125
Or I could take somebody and
I could remove them.

234
00:11:19.125 --> 00:11:21.955
Another option is I could take
somebody and replace them.

235
00:11:21.955 --> 00:11:25.125
That's pretty cool because otherwise,
I'd have to remove them and

236
00:11:25.125 --> 00:11:26.185
then add somebody else.

237
00:11:26.185 --> 00:11:27.460
It's two options.

238
00:11:27.460 --> 00:11:29.440
Here I just choose Replace and

239
00:11:29.440 --> 00:11:31.620
then I'm able to come and
pick the person to replace them.

240
00:11:31.620 --> 00:11:33.340
And see how it's listing out the cost?

241
00:11:33.340 --> 00:11:34.980
That's how we normally make the decision.

242
00:11:34.980 --> 00:11:38.890
Cost in units, that's what's gonna
influence who it is that I'm gonna choose.

243
00:11:38.890 --> 00:11:43.390
So it makes it real easy to pick the best
fit for this job, based on what I want.

244
00:11:43.390 --> 00:11:46.170
I might be okay with it taking a little
bit longer if I can get it done

245
00:11:46.170 --> 00:11:47.740
for less money.

246
00:11:47.740 --> 00:11:49.420
Or I might be okay with
spending more money,

247
00:11:49.420 --> 00:11:52.970
if I know I can get the job done faster or
more reliably.

248
00:11:52.970 --> 00:11:54.598
If I wanna guarantee
a certain finish date,

249
00:11:54.598 --> 00:11:56.232
I might wanna pay more
to get better talent.

250
00:11:58.761 --> 00:12:02.590
One of my favorite features
though is this button right here.

251
00:12:02.590 --> 00:12:03.110
The graph.

252
00:12:04.130 --> 00:12:09.230
The graph is what we had
prior to the team planner.

253
00:12:09.230 --> 00:12:11.580
The team planner wasn't always in Project.

254
00:12:11.580 --> 00:12:13.475
And so before we had the team planner,
we had this graph.

255
00:12:13.475 --> 00:12:16.530
And when I clicked on it,
what you'll notice is that this

256
00:12:16.530 --> 00:12:19.730
little box up here down here
in the bottom of my chart, and

257
00:12:19.730 --> 00:12:22.970
what it's showing me is
the electrical contractor.

258
00:12:22.970 --> 00:12:27.510
And as I scroll around on this thing and
start picking these different people,

259
00:12:27.510 --> 00:12:31.030
it's gonna be showing me
information about them and

260
00:12:31.030 --> 00:12:35.940
their availability, so I can spot whether
or not they're being over allocated.

261
00:12:35.940 --> 00:12:37.960
And I've got my screen
kinda scaled weird so

262
00:12:37.960 --> 00:12:40.990
here let me change this around
a little bit so you guys can see it.

263
00:12:40.990 --> 00:12:43.360
So here's laying out this graph and

264
00:12:43.360 --> 00:12:47.990
see my electrical contract manager
where I've got him assigned.

265
00:12:47.990 --> 00:12:51.070
Here he's assigned for eight hour days,
he's at 100% utilization.

266
00:12:51.070 --> 00:12:53.380
But on this thing I've got
over 400% utilization.

267
00:12:53.380 --> 00:12:57.220
I might have gone just a little
bit overboard on that one.

268
00:12:57.220 --> 00:12:57.992
Well, I don't know about.

269
00:12:57.992 --> 00:12:59.729
[CROSSTALK]
>> 22 hours in a 24 hours day.

270
00:12:59.729 --> 00:13:00.711
[CROSSTALK] Pretty difficult.

271
00:13:00.711 --> 00:13:02.510
>> Yeah, he's gonna have a hard
time pulling that one off.

272
00:13:02.510 --> 00:13:05.330
He'd have to be really talented but, so,

273
00:13:05.330 --> 00:13:08.170
hey, maybe that's not
the person I want to use.

274
00:13:08.170 --> 00:13:11.040
And so we can start to take a look at some
of the other guys, and you just pick them,

275
00:13:11.040 --> 00:13:13.460
so I could say,
maybe the manager's not available,

276
00:13:13.460 --> 00:13:17.510
let me just try the regular contractor,
and hit graph, and there's their graph,

277
00:13:17.510 --> 00:13:19.030
and well, they're a little over too.

278
00:13:19.030 --> 00:13:22.862
Let me just kind of keep hunting
around until I can find somebody.

279
00:13:22.862 --> 00:13:24.720
Have I over-allocated everybody?

280
00:13:24.720 --> 00:13:25.630
>> Every single person.

281
00:13:25.630 --> 00:13:26.130
>> Apparently I have.

282
00:13:27.330 --> 00:13:30.640
So that's gonna be a problem to work out,
isn't it?

283
00:13:30.640 --> 00:13:31.840
So, yeah.

284
00:13:31.840 --> 00:13:35.690
Well, actually you know what, it's not, oh
because I haven't assigned these people.

285
00:13:35.690 --> 00:13:38.160
I do need to assign them before
the graph goes active and so

286
00:13:38.160 --> 00:13:42.290
right now it's [INAUDIBLE] to these
other guys, so let me back out of that.

287
00:13:42.290 --> 00:13:44.860
Now, one thing that does
slightly annoy me with this

288
00:13:44.860 --> 00:13:49.200
is the graph stays up after you're done,
right, after you've kinda moved on.

289
00:13:49.200 --> 00:13:50.450
So, if you want to get rid of that graph,

290
00:13:50.450 --> 00:13:53.970
you need to go up to your View tab and
it's over here on the right, the Details.

291
00:13:53.970 --> 00:13:56.630
And see how the details are set
to show this resource graph, and

292
00:13:56.630 --> 00:13:58.370
you can change it to
something else if you want or

293
00:13:58.370 --> 00:14:01.720
you can just get rid of it all together
and get back to your original view.

294
00:14:01.720 --> 00:14:04.780
But yeah, we can jump back in here and
kind of reassign that.

295
00:14:04.780 --> 00:14:07.040
Let me run through that process again.

296
00:14:07.040 --> 00:14:11.540
So I'll take Install Storm Drainage,
I'm gonna go to Resource, and

297
00:14:11.540 --> 00:14:12.680
Assign Resources.

298
00:14:14.150 --> 00:14:16.210
And I can see who's currently assigned,
and

299
00:14:16.210 --> 00:14:19.970
I can assign other people if I take
somebody and I pull up their graph.

300
00:14:19.970 --> 00:14:24.280
Like I'll take the elevator
contractor this time, and graph them.

301
00:14:24.280 --> 00:14:26.930
And so, oh sorry, forgot to assign them.

302
00:14:26.930 --> 00:14:28.620
I keep forgetting to assign them first.

303
00:14:28.620 --> 00:14:33.160
So I'll assign that elevator contractor
and now if I pull their graft,

304
00:14:33.160 --> 00:14:36.960
it should switch to show me and
you know it's not switching.

305
00:14:36.960 --> 00:14:37.750
We can scroll down.

306
00:14:37.750 --> 00:14:38.440
There we go.

307
00:14:38.440 --> 00:14:40.640
So I get that elevator contractor.

308
00:14:40.640 --> 00:14:44.560
I just chose the graft and scrolled down
with my mouse wheel to see that other

309
00:14:44.560 --> 00:14:49.660
person and I can see that person
right here is not over allocated.

310
00:14:49.660 --> 00:14:52.540
They're given eight hours to
work on each of those days.

311
00:14:52.540 --> 00:14:55.900
But notice Friday,
Friday they have no work.

312
00:14:55.900 --> 00:14:57.160
They're not doing anything Friday.

313
00:14:57.160 --> 00:14:59.690
So if I have an activity that's taking
place on Friday, I can assign them.

314
00:14:59.690 --> 00:15:02.210
I know they're available and
I'm not going to oversubscribe them or

315
00:15:02.210 --> 00:15:03.760
over allocate them.

316
00:15:03.760 --> 00:15:05.340
So pretty cool utility.

317
00:15:05.340 --> 00:15:06.450
>> It really is.

318
00:15:06.450 --> 00:15:09.150
And there's one other view that
we wanna take a look at as well.

319
00:15:09.150 --> 00:15:13.247
Don, when you go back to that Details,
where you had that under Format?

320
00:15:13.247 --> 00:15:14.987
And the, where is it?

321
00:15:14.987 --> 00:15:17.828
[CROSSTALK]
>> Oh, hang on, I'm in my wrong grid here.

322
00:15:17.828 --> 00:15:18.388
Okay.

323
00:15:18.388 --> 00:15:19.830
>> And then.

324
00:15:19.830 --> 00:15:21.528
>> Go to View and Details, there we go.

325
00:15:21.528 --> 00:15:24.357
>> What we wanna take a look at
is that task form, which actually

326
00:15:24.357 --> 00:15:28.170
gives you the most usage when you're
actually talking an assignment.

327
00:15:28.170 --> 00:15:33.080
So here you can change the effort driven
whether you're manually scheduling it and

328
00:15:33.080 --> 00:15:36.120
you can actually see the number of hours
as well as the duration that group can

329
00:15:36.120 --> 00:15:37.130
be assigned.

330
00:15:37.130 --> 00:15:39.560
It's right here that you can
actually go ahead an manipulate and

331
00:15:39.560 --> 00:15:40.710
change a lot of different things.

332
00:15:40.710 --> 00:15:43.510
You'll see a lot of information
about the task as well as that

333
00:15:43.510 --> 00:15:44.850
resource it's assigned to.

334
00:15:44.850 --> 00:15:46.940
>> Yeah and you can quickly
add more resources right here.

335
00:15:46.940 --> 00:15:49.440
You can add existing resources or
you can create new ones.

336
00:15:49.440 --> 00:15:54.030
So I might have John Doe,
I might have Jane Smith, and so

337
00:15:54.030 --> 00:15:56.520
I'm creating new resources on the fly.

338
00:15:56.520 --> 00:16:00.570
And they're created, and
they're assigned to the activity, and

339
00:16:00.570 --> 00:16:04.510
I can come in here and
adjust their units, so maybe John and

340
00:16:04.510 --> 00:16:08.800
Jane are only working 50% of the time,
and so I can punch them in.

341
00:16:08.800 --> 00:16:10.030
I don't want to punch in their work

342
00:16:10.030 --> 00:16:12.160
because I want that to
be auto calculated out.

343
00:16:12.160 --> 00:16:13.610
So now we start getting them assigned.

344
00:16:13.610 --> 00:16:17.180
And you can double click on them to jump
to their individual settings and go in and

345
00:16:17.180 --> 00:16:21.200
set all the other values to be a little
more specific on them if you need to.

346
00:16:21.200 --> 00:16:22.720
It's all right here.

347
00:16:22.720 --> 00:16:24.440
You can go about this more than one way.

348
00:16:24.440 --> 00:16:27.060
In the previous episode,
we did it all from the resource sheet.

349
00:16:27.060 --> 00:16:28.760
But here we're doing it
right in the Gantt chart,

350
00:16:28.760 --> 00:16:32.570
right in the activity list,
and right in our Details pane.

351
00:16:32.570 --> 00:16:35.720
You pretty much figure out which way
is easiest for you and stick with it.

352
00:16:35.720 --> 00:16:37.590
But just know that all
these options are here.

353
00:16:37.590 --> 00:16:39.420
And we haven't even touched
the team planner yet, so

354
00:16:39.420 --> 00:16:41.542
that's a cool one that we
definitely want to remember.

355
00:16:41.542 --> 00:16:48.200
All right, Ronnie as far as
assigning out my resources, the only

356
00:16:48.200 --> 00:16:52.855
other thing we need to remember is to keep
an eye out for over allocated resources.

357
00:16:52.855 --> 00:16:54.780
So if I look here at clear and

358
00:16:54.780 --> 00:16:58.420
grub sight I've got that little red
figure over there on the left side and

359
00:16:58.420 --> 00:17:02.840
it's telling me the task is over
allocated, right click for options.

360
00:17:02.840 --> 00:17:05.950
And if you right click on it,
it'll give you some options here.

361
00:17:05.950 --> 00:17:10.350
Fix in task inspector or
reschedule to available date.

362
00:17:10.350 --> 00:17:14.440
If I know that the person I've assigned
it to I absolutely have to have,

363
00:17:14.440 --> 00:17:18.580
I can reschedule and it'll move that task
to the next time that person's available.

364
00:17:19.650 --> 00:17:24.050
That's gonna push my schedules by
my project's completion date back.

365
00:17:24.050 --> 00:17:25.120
That may be okay.

366
00:17:25.120 --> 00:17:27.610
If this is one of those projects where
they say just get it done as soon as

367
00:17:27.610 --> 00:17:29.189
you can, then it's okay to
move it back a little bit.

368
00:17:30.230 --> 00:17:33.110
But if I'm gonna finish on a certain date,
that's not gonna work for me.

369
00:17:33.110 --> 00:17:37.240
So you could go to the task inspector,
and it's gonna show us a little bit more

370
00:17:37.240 --> 00:17:42.330
information about that task and who it is
that's over allocated, and what I'm gonna

371
00:17:42.330 --> 00:17:45.881
need to do and see what it's offering
to do to take me to that team planner.

372
00:17:45.881 --> 00:17:48.286
>> [LAUGH]
>> It keeps popping up cuz it's so

373
00:17:48.286 --> 00:17:53.670
awesome, but we could also just
take this activity and go into our

374
00:17:53.670 --> 00:17:58.500
resource assignment screen, and we could
take the people that are assigned, and

375
00:17:58.500 --> 00:18:00.310
figure out who it is
that's over allocated.

376
00:18:00.310 --> 00:18:03.232
And I think in my case,
both of them are over allocated, so

377
00:18:03.232 --> 00:18:05.031
we can find that out from the graph.

378
00:18:05.031 --> 00:18:09.606
So I can see right there, my electric
contractor is over allocated, and

379
00:18:09.606 --> 00:18:14.430
we can find there we go the electric
manager, he's over allocated also.

380
00:18:14.430 --> 00:18:16.120
They're both over allocated in my case.

381
00:18:16.120 --> 00:18:20.630
So I can come in and add new people and
maybe those new people are gonna be just

382
00:18:20.630 --> 00:18:23.230
completely new or
maybe it's somebody else in here.

383
00:18:23.230 --> 00:18:26.390
I might wanna come in and
choose them and re-assign them.

384
00:18:26.390 --> 00:18:31.670
Replace them with somebody else
based on what my needs are.

385
00:18:31.670 --> 00:18:34.370
It's really all just about figuring
out what solution is gonna work

386
00:18:34.370 --> 00:18:36.630
best now that we've over allocated.

387
00:18:36.630 --> 00:18:40.458
And we'll see later on in our reporting
shows where there's other ways to see

388
00:18:40.458 --> 00:18:45.580
over allocation, because I visually
saw this little red stick man, but

389
00:18:45.580 --> 00:18:47.525
what if i have 2000 activities?

390
00:18:47.525 --> 00:18:49.230
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'd have to scroll all the way down to

391
00:18:49.230 --> 00:18:49.970
look for that stick man.

392
00:18:49.970 --> 00:18:53.200
So there's some special reports
that can show over-allocation also.

393
00:18:53.200 --> 00:18:55.480
And we just need to go and
reassign resources for that.

394
00:18:57.058 --> 00:18:57.590
All right, Ronnie,

395
00:18:57.590 --> 00:19:01.510
can you think of anything else we need
to throw in on assigning resources.

396
00:19:01.510 --> 00:19:05.180
>> No, those are some of the different
ways, remember, just try them out, see

397
00:19:05.180 --> 00:19:08.470
which one's gonna be the best one for you
to work with, and you'll start noticing

398
00:19:08.470 --> 00:19:13.355
the way that Don actually did that, at the
beginning, fairly easy to just type those.

399
00:19:13.355 --> 00:19:17.255
But later on you still have to go back and
change some options so you may find

400
00:19:17.255 --> 00:19:19.765
your particular way of actually assigning
that's going to be the best way for

401
00:19:19.765 --> 00:19:21.935
you, so use them.

402
00:19:21.935 --> 00:19:24.285
>> All right, well ladies and gentleman,
we'll go and wrap this episode up here.

403
00:19:24.285 --> 00:19:27.155
Definitely stay tuned for
our team planner episode, it's fine I

404
00:19:27.155 --> 00:19:29.655
know I mentioned it like ten times now and
people are like why don't you show it now.

405
00:19:29.655 --> 00:19:33.135
We just want to do it justice, so
you get to see it in the next episode.

406
00:19:33.135 --> 00:19:34.845
But as far as resource assignments,

407
00:19:34.845 --> 00:19:37.810
we showed you several different
methods that are all very effective.

408
00:19:37.810 --> 00:19:38.610
And pretty easy to use.

409
00:19:38.610 --> 00:19:40.680
Defiantly take advantage of those.

410
00:19:40.680 --> 00:19:43.950
Well signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

411
00:19:43.950 --> 00:19:44.640
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

412
00:19:44.640 --> 00:19:45.709
>> And we'll see you next time.

413
00:19:45.709 --> 00:19:46.209
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don take a look into one of the most useful views that shows resources and allocation.  This view, the Team Planner, allows you also to manipulate the resources visually and easily see resource conflicts and overallocations.  From the Team planner, you can also manually level resources too.  It's a great view for the project manager to know.
episodes.title: Team Planner
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.046
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.046 --> 00:00:13.219
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

3
00:00:13.219 --> 00:00:15.641
and welcome back to another
episode of iTProTV.

4
00:00:15.641 --> 00:00:16.890
I'm your host Don Pezet.

5
00:00:16.890 --> 00:00:18.650
Back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:18.650 --> 00:00:19.400
How's it going Ronnie?

7
00:00:19.400 --> 00:00:20.840
>> It is going well today.

8
00:00:20.840 --> 00:00:24.070
We are ready and excited for
another day of project and

9
00:00:24.070 --> 00:00:27.510
since we've actually been building up to
it, we're going to actually look at your

10
00:00:27.510 --> 00:00:31.780
favorite part of the project,
team planner, I think what it's called.

11
00:00:31.780 --> 00:00:34.990
>> That last episode we filmed
was kind of tough for me, right.

12
00:00:34.990 --> 00:00:38.090
I shamelessly plugged the team
planner several times.

13
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:42.720
In the last episode we covered
how to add resources to tasks.

14
00:00:42.720 --> 00:00:45.900
How do you assign a person or
a material or whatever to a task and

15
00:00:45.900 --> 00:00:51.280
how do you check for over-allocations and
replace people and all that?

16
00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:53.350
And we did it all without
the team planner.

17
00:00:53.350 --> 00:00:55.600
And we did that because
it's on the exam that way.

18
00:00:55.600 --> 00:00:57.550
And we gotta make sure
we cover everything.

19
00:00:57.550 --> 00:01:00.880
But I'll you guys, as soon as Microsoft
released the team planner in Project,

20
00:01:00.880 --> 00:01:01.496
I stopped using every other method.

21
00:01:01.496 --> 00:01:03.989
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is the only method that I use to

22
00:01:03.989 --> 00:01:05.764
assign people anymore.

23
00:01:05.764 --> 00:01:08.920
But it does come down to
people's personal preference.

24
00:01:08.920 --> 00:01:13.150
During the early stages of a project
during just the quick planning or

25
00:01:13.150 --> 00:01:16.790
whatever I will use the methods I showed
you in that last video just to kind of

26
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:22.610
type in some of those values, but once
I start to have an idea of real people

27
00:01:22.610 --> 00:01:26.750
that are going to be performing my tasks I
usually switch over to the team planner.

28
00:01:26.750 --> 00:01:28.760
Now what do I mean by real people?

29
00:01:28.760 --> 00:01:31.640
In the early planning days,
you might have a task where you say,

30
00:01:31.640 --> 00:01:34.280
you know what,
I need a network engineer for this task.

31
00:01:34.280 --> 00:01:38.110
And so I'm just gonna create
a generic network engineer resource.

32
00:01:38.110 --> 00:01:40.180
And I'm gonna assign that to this task.

33
00:01:40.180 --> 00:01:43.130
But then, as your planning phase
starts to near completion and

34
00:01:43.130 --> 00:01:46.410
you're getting ready for execution,
that's when you reach out to your PMO,

35
00:01:46.410 --> 00:01:49.290
or your HR department,
or you put out your ads.

36
00:01:49.290 --> 00:01:51.310
And you contract, or hire, or

37
00:01:51.310 --> 00:01:55.100
you use internally an actual person
to be that network engineer.

38
00:01:55.100 --> 00:01:57.750
And so I find out that I don't just
have a generic network engineer.

39
00:01:57.750 --> 00:01:59.420
I have Ronnie Wong.

40
00:01:59.420 --> 00:02:03.050
And so Ronnie's my real resource,
I need to know his calendar.

41
00:02:03.050 --> 00:02:07.420
When are his vacation days, what hours
does he work, everything starts to change

42
00:02:07.420 --> 00:02:11.080
because now it's Ronnie specifically,
not generic network engineer number one.

43
00:02:12.280 --> 00:02:17.140
And when that happens, now we've got to
start realigning our schedule a bit and

44
00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:19.130
that's when the team planner really helps.

45
00:02:19.130 --> 00:02:22.713
Now if you watched that last episode,
you probably noticed where there

46
00:02:22.713 --> 00:02:25.997
were some parts where I had a little
bit of difficulty doing things

47
00:02:25.997 --> 00:02:29.837
like seeing whether somebody was
already over-allocated or not, right?

48
00:02:29.837 --> 00:02:32.843
So if I have a task and
I wanna assign some employees to it,

49
00:02:32.843 --> 00:02:36.440
the interface is kind of cumbersome
to be able to view that.

50
00:02:36.440 --> 00:02:38.530
The team planner fixes that.

51
00:02:38.530 --> 00:02:41.390
So here I have my construction project
pulled up that I just whipped up

52
00:02:41.390 --> 00:02:43.480
from one of the templates
inside of project.

53
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:45.630
And you can see where we've got
a couple activities here and

54
00:02:45.630 --> 00:02:47.080
they've assigned resources to it.

55
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:52.480
And I know I can scroll over here to
the resources column or resource names.

56
00:02:52.480 --> 00:02:56.770
And I can see that people or
stuff have been assigned to it.

57
00:02:56.770 --> 00:03:00.980
So you can see general management,
project management, the scheduler,

58
00:03:00.980 --> 00:03:02.290
the project manager.

59
00:03:02.290 --> 00:03:04.310
Right, so each person being assigned this.

60
00:03:04.310 --> 00:03:07.790
And some of them are given, you know,
like a percentage of utilization.

61
00:03:07.790 --> 00:03:09.634
So they're only hear 10%.

62
00:03:09.634 --> 00:03:13.750
That means 90% of the time it's still
available to use for other activities.

63
00:03:13.750 --> 00:03:15.000
That's where this gets really hard,

64
00:03:15.000 --> 00:03:19.100
cuz we can't just look at whether there's
two activities scheduled at the same time.

65
00:03:19.100 --> 00:03:21.250
The person might be 10% on one and
90% on the other,

66
00:03:21.250 --> 00:03:25.940
and now you've got two at the same time
but it's fine because it adds up to 100%.

67
00:03:25.940 --> 00:03:27.940
That's something we don't
really see in this view.

68
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:30.300
I mean, you do see it if you sit here and
do the math.

69
00:03:30.300 --> 00:03:32.450
But it's not very easy to spot that.

70
00:03:32.450 --> 00:03:35.510
It's really hard to spot it
if they've got 10% here and

71
00:03:35.510 --> 00:03:39.400
the other 90% is way down at the bottom
of your list, a thousand tasks later.

72
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:42.070
Right, now you don't get
it at a glance at all.

73
00:03:42.070 --> 00:03:44.560
So, for
managing our basic team utilization.

74
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:48.720
This view, it certainly works,
but it's not ideal, all right?

75
00:03:48.720 --> 00:03:52.300
Instead, we can switch
to our team planner, and

00:03:52.300 --> 00:03:55.400
it's gonna show us a much

00:03:55.400 --> 00:03:56.740
So if I take somebody,

00:03:56.740 --> 00:04:00.560
like here where I've got this

00:04:00.560 --> 00:04:04.380

Those are the two resources, and

GC general management is

00:04:11.330 --> 00:04:13.810
But it's all allocated that
means one of those two or

00:04:13.810 --> 00:04:16.330
both of those two resources

85
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:16.850
Which one is it?

00:04:17.980 --> 00:04:19.170

00:04:19.170 --> 00:04:19.790

But

even if I jump into the task detail view,

00:04:21.510 --> 00:04:23.830
it doesn't give me much

00:04:23.830 --> 00:04:27.130
When we jump into the task inspector,

00:04:27.130 --> 00:04:29.170
it's gonna give you some basic details.

00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:31.230

00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:34.490
To let me know that I've got resources
over-allocated and it is telling me that

00:04:34.490 --> 00:04:38.360
it is actually GC Project Management

00:04:38.360 --> 00:04:42.080
And, does it tell me how

00:04:42.080 --> 00:04:43.090

00:04:43.090 --> 00:04:47.740
So, what I can do is, instead of relying

00:04:49.450 --> 00:04:52.160

00:04:53.580 --> 00:04:55.480
The Gantt chart shows you tasks, and

00:04:58.270 --> 00:05:01.050
Here, it gives me a list of resources.

00:05:01.050 --> 00:05:03.787
And then over here, it shows me well,

00:05:03.787 --> 00:05:07.760
where that activities

00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:11.365
So, I can see GC general management,

00:05:13.355 --> 00:05:15.335

00:05:15.335 --> 00:05:19.565
And if I look along the line here,

00:05:19.565 --> 00:05:21.575
Gray means that something

111
00:05:21.575 --> 00:05:23.405
blue means it's something

112
00:05:23.405 --> 00:05:26.335
And so if I can see all that
stuff laid out, and that's fine.

113
00:05:26.335 --> 00:05:30.325
But I can see GC project
management is over-allocated.

114
00:05:30.325 --> 00:05:34.250
I know they're over-allocated because
they're red and then I can see right here

115
00:05:34.250 --> 00:05:37.520
where they've got two activities
scheduled at the same time.

116
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:38.420
Submit bond and

117
00:05:38.420 --> 00:05:43.080
insurance documents is going on at

118
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:45.370
I've got an overlap right there.

119
00:05:45.370 --> 00:05:48.420
I don't have to scroll through this
big list to find other activities or

120
00:05:48.420 --> 00:05:52.400
anything like that because I'm seeing
everything that GC project management is

121
00:05:52.400 --> 00:05:55.340
doing on this particular day.

122
00:05:55.340 --> 00:05:58.860
So, super easy to spot over-allocations.

123
00:05:58.860 --> 00:06:03.630
It's also easy to spot tasks that don't

124
00:06:03.630 --> 00:06:05.300
Notice down here at

00:06:05.300 --> 00:06:09.510
let me just stretch this up here

00:06:09.510 --> 00:06:11.630
If I start creating more tasks and

00:06:15.220 --> 00:06:18.250

00:06:18.250 --> 00:06:19.350

00:06:19.350 --> 00:06:20.155
So for example.

00:06:20.155 --> 00:06:23.130
Let's clean this up cause

00:06:23.130 --> 00:06:24.550
Lets do a new one.

00:06:25.640 --> 00:06:30.060
I'm gonna create a new project here and
so this is just gonna be I don't know,

00:06:30.060 --> 00:06:31.370
some kind of computer project.

135
00:06:32.650 --> 00:06:39.120
And inside of it I'll have simple things

00:06:39.120 --> 00:06:41.690
And so I know I'm going to

00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:46.360
I might say I need a network engineer and

00:06:46.360 --> 00:06:49.320
These are gonna be my two people that

And for the duration, maybe setting

00:07:01.555 --> 00:07:03.215

So here's my project.

And these two could

00:07:06.675 --> 00:07:08.515
I don't need them to be

00:07:08.515 --> 00:07:09.745
They can happen at the same time.

00:07:09.745 --> 00:07:10.805
That's fine.

148
00:07:10.805 --> 00:07:14.055
And, from here,
I've got my project set up.

149
00:07:14.055 --> 00:07:16.140
And it looks like I've got
a ten-day project ahead of me.

150
00:07:16.140 --> 00:07:16.870
Right?

151
00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:18.250
I can jump over to my resource sheet.

00:07:18.250 --> 00:07:20.240
And here's where I can

00:07:20.240 --> 00:07:22.370
And so right now I've got this

154
00:07:22.370 --> 00:07:24.020
this generic desktop engineer.

00:07:24.020 --> 00:07:28.750
But later on, I actually find out that

00:07:28.750 --> 00:07:31.670
And I'm gonna have myself on staff too.

00:07:31.670 --> 00:07:33.090
So these are my employees.

158
00:07:33.090 --> 00:07:36.900
And Ronnie and I we're both trained up to

159
00:07:36.900 --> 00:07:39.100
So we could really perform
both of those roles.

160
00:07:39.100 --> 00:07:43.300
That's why I didn't just rename these
because I might have one person who

161
00:07:43.300 --> 00:07:46.800
fits more then one of those roles so
I usually keep them laying around.

162
00:07:46.800 --> 00:07:48.310
Different people handle

163
00:07:49.390 --> 00:07:53.468
So now, I need to go back and reassign

00:07:53.468 --> 00:07:55.367
I can use the team planner for that.

165
00:07:55.367 --> 00:08:00.048
If I go to resource and team planner,

00:08:00.048 --> 00:08:01.549

167
00:08:01.549 --> 00:08:06.066
And I've got these unscheduled tasks

00:08:06.066 --> 00:08:09.468
These are tasks that don't have

I set a duration for them, but

00:08:12.682 --> 00:08:17.780
they're just kind of floating out there,

00:08:17.780 --> 00:08:19.580
And, now, the reason it does that is,

00:08:19.580 --> 00:08:22.730
I can take a look at this network engineer

And I can say,

00:08:27.160 --> 00:08:29.810
If I had a calendar on the network

175
00:08:29.810 --> 00:08:30.420
a particular week.

00:08:30.420 --> 00:08:33.220
It would be blocked out right

00:08:33.220 --> 00:08:36.350
And so I can see,
don't assign it to that person that week,

00:08:37.780 --> 00:08:41.450
And all I have to do is take that task,

00:08:41.450 --> 00:08:44.250

181
00:08:44.250 --> 00:08:46.370
And I can even take it to somebody else,

182
00:08:46.370 --> 00:08:49.910
So, maybe I give Setup a Network
to Ronnie, cuz he likes networks.

00:08:49.910 --> 00:08:52.570
And I'll bite the bullet and

184
00:08:52.570 --> 00:08:55.410
And I can just drag those out and

185
00:08:55.410 --> 00:08:58.280
Now I do have a slight problem,
this little green line represents today.

186
00:08:58.280 --> 00:09:03.000
I'm setting these tasks to start in
the past, and if it's gray, that's kind of

187
00:09:03.000 --> 00:09:06.160
your indicator that hey, this is
supposed to all ready be happening.

188
00:09:06.160 --> 00:09:11.020
So a good project plans for the future,
let's move that ahead, there we go, and

189
00:09:11.020 --> 00:09:12.660
now I've got them scheduled out there.

190
00:09:12.660 --> 00:09:16.790
So I'm quickly and easily able to
move these tasks between people and

191
00:09:16.790 --> 00:09:17.700
assign them out.

192
00:09:17.700 --> 00:09:21.150
And that's one of the easiest ways
to solve an overallocation, right?

193
00:09:21.150 --> 00:09:23.560
Let's go back to my Gantt chart.

194
00:09:23.560 --> 00:09:27.740
And let's say that in haste,
I wasn't really thinking about it much and

00:09:27.740 --> 00:09:29.910
I just assigned everything to Ronnie,
right?

196
00:09:29.910 --> 00:09:31.690
Ronnie can do a lot of work,
so there you go.

197
00:09:31.690 --> 00:09:34.570
So, now Ronnie's doing all
the work in this project.

198
00:09:34.570 --> 00:09:38.090
Well, Ronnie is overallocated, okay?

199
00:09:38.090 --> 00:09:42.190
Now, it shows me that right here
I can see he's overallocated.

200
00:09:42.190 --> 00:09:42.780
At a glance,

201
00:09:42.780 --> 00:09:46.360
it's very easy to spot where the problem
is because it's a small project.

202
00:09:46.360 --> 00:09:50.190
But in a large project, it would be very
hard to spot where that overallocation is.

203
00:09:50.190 --> 00:09:53.930
So I can just jump right back to the
Team Planner, and I can look at Ronnie.

204
00:09:53.930 --> 00:09:57.230
Ronnie is in red, so
I know he's got some overallocation.

205
00:09:57.230 --> 00:10:00.920
And I can see Setup Network and
Setup PCs right there, and you know,

206
00:10:00.920 --> 00:10:02.430
my font switched really small again.

207
00:10:02.430 --> 00:10:06.330
Let me bump that font size up so that we
can actually read some of this stuff.

208
00:10:06.330 --> 00:10:07.180
There we go.

209
00:10:07.180 --> 00:10:12.030
So, now I can see Ronnie right there,
and I can see over here on July 19th,

00:10:12.030 --> 00:10:14.770
he's scheduled two
things at the same time.

211
00:10:14.770 --> 00:10:17.600
He's got a Setup the Network and

00:10:17.600 --> 00:10:19.680
it's got that red block around it.

00:10:19.680 --> 00:10:25.090
Notice how the red block does

00:10:25.090 --> 00:10:29.380
Ronnie's not overallocated for

00:10:29.380 --> 00:10:33.060
He's only overallocated for

216
00:10:33.060 --> 00:10:34.160
So how do I correct this?

217
00:10:35.390 --> 00:10:37.564
Well, there's a few different
ways that I can correct it.

218
00:10:37.564 --> 00:10:39.510
Let's start with the easy ones.

219
00:10:39.510 --> 00:10:42.520
The easy one is,
give one of these jobs to somebody else.

00:10:43.670 --> 00:10:47.675
He's overallocated this week, I can just
take Setup PC's, move that down to me,

00:10:47.675 --> 00:10:49.770

00:10:49.770 --> 00:10:53.460

00:10:53.460 --> 00:10:56.740
But, if that doesn't work,

00:10:56.740 --> 00:10:59.770
well maybe I don't have another person,

225
00:11:00.920 --> 00:11:04.630
I can move one of these tasks back, or
move one of them forward for that matter.

226
00:11:04.630 --> 00:11:07.730
So I could say, you know what, I'll just

227
00:11:07.730 --> 00:11:10.040
Or I'll delay setting up the PCs for
two weeks.

228
00:11:10.040 --> 00:11:11.360
I probably don't want that.

229
00:11:11.360 --> 00:11:16.190
So, we probably push the network back,
and there we go, allocation solved.

230
00:11:16.190 --> 00:11:19.850
So, the cool part about the Team Planner,
you get really good visibility,

231
00:11:19.850 --> 00:11:21.550
it's a calendar for each person.

232
00:11:21.550 --> 00:11:23.730
What they're doing on what day, and
really easy to drag and drop and

233
00:11:23.730 --> 00:11:24.550
move things around.

234
00:11:24.550 --> 00:11:25.560
That's great.

235
00:11:25.560 --> 00:11:30.410
And then two, it's a GUI, so corrections
are simple, I don't have to type anything,

236
00:11:30.410 --> 00:11:32.000
I just drag them and move them, right?

237
00:11:32.000 --> 00:11:37.080
So at a glance status,
and easy what you see is

238
00:11:37.080 --> 00:11:41.260
what you get calendar settings for these
tasks, it really does make life easy.

239
00:11:41.260 --> 00:11:45.030
And it also saves you from the pitfall

240
00:11:45.030 --> 00:11:46.150
to it, right?

241
00:11:46.150 --> 00:11:49.330
So maybe one day I'm in a meeting and
somebody says, hey Don,

00:11:49.330 --> 00:11:54.930
have you planned for
setting up battery backups?

00:11:54.930 --> 00:11:56.100
And I say ooh, no I didn't.

00:11:56.100 --> 00:11:56.864
So let me add that.

245
00:11:56.864 --> 00:12:01.640
I'm gonna put in here,
Setup Battery Backups, right?

246
00:12:01.640 --> 00:12:04.340
And I say all right, well, that'll
probably just take somebody two days.

247
00:12:04.340 --> 00:12:05.980
So I'm just gonna pop that in here,
and I set it.

248
00:12:05.980 --> 00:12:08.270
And I'm like, all right,
I'll deal with that one later.

249
00:12:08.270 --> 00:12:10.860
And then I forget about it.

250
00:12:10.860 --> 00:12:15.040
In a project that has 1,500 activities.

00:12:15.040 --> 00:12:17.450
It's easy to have ones that don't
have anybody assigned to them,

252
00:12:17.450 --> 00:12:18.970
you lose sight of it.

253
00:12:18.970 --> 00:12:21.650
And so, then all of a sudden you
get to that point, your like,

254
00:12:21.650 --> 00:12:22.485
who's gonna work on this?

255
00:12:22.485 --> 00:12:25.560
Ooh, I forgot to assign somebody,
I didn't get the resource.

256
00:12:25.560 --> 00:12:27.060
Now I gotta get an extra resource.

257
00:12:27.060 --> 00:12:30.330
My budget starts to go up and
that becomes a real problem.

258
00:12:30.330 --> 00:12:34.270
Well, I can just jump right
back over to that Team Planner.

259
00:12:34.270 --> 00:12:37.090
And I can see right down here
at the bottom of my screen,

260
00:12:37.090 --> 00:12:38.390
I've got unassigned tasks.

261
00:12:38.390 --> 00:12:39.110
And it tells me how many.

262
00:12:39.110 --> 00:12:41.620
I've got one,
Setup Battery Backups, right?

263
00:12:41.620 --> 00:12:44.090
It's just floating out out there,
nobody's assigned to it.

264
00:12:44.090 --> 00:12:47.050
I need to give that to somebody.

265
00:12:47.050 --> 00:12:49.490
And it's floating over
here in the left column,

266
00:12:49.490 --> 00:12:51.970
because I didn't set a date for it.

267
00:12:51.970 --> 00:12:53.070
Let's say I set a date for it.

268
00:12:53.070 --> 00:12:56.210
If I go back to my GANTT chart,
and I take this one and

269
00:12:56.210 --> 00:13:01.990
I say this one is gonna happen,
we'll schedule it out here.

270
00:13:01.990 --> 00:13:04.170
Okay, so now it's got a date.

271
00:13:04.170 --> 00:13:07.180
Now when I go back to that Team Planner.

272
00:13:07.180 --> 00:13:10.660
Instead of floating over here on the left
column, which means it's unassigned and

273
00:13:10.660 --> 00:13:13.210
doesn't have a date,
now it's showing a date.

274
00:13:13.210 --> 00:13:15.190
Now, why is that important?

275
00:13:15.190 --> 00:13:17.020
Just because nobody's assigned to it,

276
00:13:17.020 --> 00:13:20.290
I might have a particular date
it has to happen on, right?

277
00:13:20.290 --> 00:13:23.780
I've gotta have those battery backups
set up before I can set up the network.

278
00:13:23.780 --> 00:13:25.400
Maybe there's some kind
of dependency there.

279
00:13:25.400 --> 00:13:26.960
So I might have a date, and

280
00:13:26.960 --> 00:13:30.150
that's when it's gonna appear right
over here in this calendar view.

281
00:13:30.150 --> 00:13:33.660
But if it's completely flexible,
I can put it wherever I want.

282
00:13:33.660 --> 00:13:35.220
We don't set a date that
appears right here, and

283
00:13:35.220 --> 00:13:37.470
that gives us the flexibility to move it.

284
00:13:37.470 --> 00:13:39.398
I can still move it to
a different date if I want.

285
00:13:39.398 --> 00:13:42.940
If I wanna assign this to me, right?

286
00:13:42.940 --> 00:13:45.720
I can bring bring this up here,
and assign it to Don Pezet.

287
00:13:45.720 --> 00:13:50.440
I can still move it forward too, or
backwards, or wherever we wanted to go.

288
00:13:50.440 --> 00:13:53.370
So we've got that flexibility to
be able to reassign these things.

289
00:13:53.370 --> 00:13:57.220
And you can just sit here all day long and
kinda rearrange your project.

290
00:13:57.220 --> 00:14:01.080
To get it where you've got the right
people working on the right jobs

291
00:14:01.080 --> 00:14:02.250
at the right time.

292
00:14:02.250 --> 00:14:05.650
That's the real glory of the Team Planner.

00:14:05.650 --> 00:14:08.300
Yeah, the graphical user interface
just makes it a lot easier and

294
00:14:08.300 --> 00:14:10.840
you can see multiple
resources at the same time.

295
00:14:10.840 --> 00:14:14.050
When we have it all kind of zoomed in,
it doesn't look like that, but

296
00:14:14.050 --> 00:14:16.360
imagine if you had 10 or 15 people.

297
00:14:16.360 --> 00:14:19.164
And you weren't really sure where
the overallocation can happen.

298
00:14:19.164 --> 00:14:23.000
Well, by using that Team Planner,
you can see a lot more on your screen.

299
00:14:23.000 --> 00:14:25.060
And then just use that click and

300
00:14:25.060 --> 00:14:27.200
drag to be able to move
some of these tasks around.

301
00:14:27.200 --> 00:14:29.755
But Don, we were talking about earlier
that that can also cause problems at

302
00:14:29.755 --> 00:14:30.370
times, right?

303
00:14:30.370 --> 00:14:36.030
Yeah, you do have to be careful because
activities are oftentimes linked,

304
00:14:36.030 --> 00:14:37.720
they're linked one after the other.

305
00:14:37.720 --> 00:14:39.770
And so when you start messing
around here in the Team Planner,

306
00:14:39.770 --> 00:14:40.670
that can cause some problems.

307
00:14:40.670 --> 00:14:42.030
Let me show you an example.

308
00:14:42.030 --> 00:14:46.616
So if I jump back to my task view,
and let's say that

309
00:14:46.616 --> 00:14:52.180
Battery Backups have to be done
prior to setting up the PCs.

310
00:14:52.180 --> 00:14:54.486
That's just the order
it's got to be done in.

311
00:14:54.486 --> 00:15:00.069
So, what I would do is, I would set
up the PCs to have a predecessor.

312
00:15:00.069 --> 00:15:02.380
Oops, I just went backwards,
that's not gonna help me, is it?

313
00:15:02.380 --> 00:15:08.420
So, I would set a predecessor to say that
the Battery Backups have to be done first.

314
00:15:10.210 --> 00:15:10.950
There.

315
00:15:10.950 --> 00:15:12.930
And then the PCs can be set up.

316
00:15:12.930 --> 00:15:16.080
And so when I set that, see how it
created that dependency link for me.

317
00:15:16.080 --> 00:15:19.490
So now I've got where setting up
the Backups happens first, and

318
00:15:19.490 --> 00:15:21.600
then setting up the PCs, right?

319
00:15:21.600 --> 00:15:23.360
When I jump to my Team Planner.

320
00:15:26.319 --> 00:15:28.640
I can see what's assigned to me.

321
00:15:28.640 --> 00:15:30.960
And see how I don't see the links?

322
00:15:30.960 --> 00:15:33.940
I don't see the dependencies or
whatever that's between them.

323
00:15:33.940 --> 00:15:36.950
So if I decide, man,
Don's not doing anything this week.

324
00:15:36.950 --> 00:15:39.990
So let's go ahead and
just take this and move it up.

325
00:15:39.990 --> 00:15:42.000
It let me move it up, right?

326
00:15:42.000 --> 00:15:45.120
And there's nothing else
happening here in between.

327
00:15:45.120 --> 00:15:51.210
If I go back to my Gantt chart, see how
I've got this huge lead time now, right?

328
00:15:51.210 --> 00:15:53.470
Or, I guess this would be lag time,
it's afterwards.

329
00:15:53.470 --> 00:15:55.142
So, now I've got this
big gap in the schedule.

330
00:15:55.142 --> 00:15:59.147
And I saw that looking at myself in
the Team Planner, there was this gap, and

331
00:15:59.147 --> 00:16:03.278
I could have started moving that, But
if you've got manually scheduled tasks

332
00:16:03.278 --> 00:16:06.426
like these,
it doesn't automatically move them around.

333
00:16:06.426 --> 00:16:09.222
Now that does change
if we come in here and

334
00:16:09.222 --> 00:16:12.710
change these guys to like auto scheduled.

335
00:16:12.710 --> 00:16:19.954
So if I move everybody over to
auto scheduling, there we go.

336
00:16:19.954 --> 00:16:22.630
Now, I'm auto scheduling and
you'll see it's already kind of

337
00:16:22.630 --> 00:16:25.165
bumped those activities up to
say let's start them today.

338
00:16:25.165 --> 00:16:29.530
Cuz that's what auto scheduling likes
to do, and now if I jump back to my

339
00:16:29.530 --> 00:16:33.370
team planner, right, things have
kind of moved around a bit on me.

340
00:16:35.510 --> 00:16:37.650
And if I start to take
something like setup PC's and

341
00:16:37.650 --> 00:16:40.760
I decide I wanted to start that next week,
I can move it forward.

342
00:16:40.760 --> 00:16:44.080
And see what just happened, how set up
battery back up's didn't follow it?

343
00:16:44.080 --> 00:16:46.880
These are set to auto schedule,
shouldn't it have moved?

344
00:16:46.880 --> 00:16:49.910
Well, it assumes you
know what you're doing.

345
00:16:49.910 --> 00:16:52.610
And that if you want the other one
to move then you'll move it too.

346
00:16:52.610 --> 00:16:53.230
Right.

347
00:16:53.230 --> 00:16:54.220
I didn't do that.

348
00:16:54.220 --> 00:16:57.220
So if I go back to my task view,
into my Gantt chart.

349
00:16:57.220 --> 00:17:00.900
I can see, even though I'm auto
scheduling, that lead time or

350
00:17:00.900 --> 00:17:04.650
lag time here just got reintroduced and
now I've got a constraint.

351
00:17:04.650 --> 00:17:07.580
All right, see my little icon that
appeared over here on my status column

352
00:17:07.580 --> 00:17:11.610
letting me know that there is a constraint
on this activity, and if I float over it,

353
00:17:11.610 --> 00:17:16.120
it's gonna show me that this has
a start no earlier than constraint.

354
00:17:16.120 --> 00:17:19.855
So when you start dragging things around,
if you are auto scheduling,

355
00:17:19.855 --> 00:17:21.230
you're gonna end up with some constraints.

356
00:17:21.230 --> 00:17:23.370
So you just have to be careful with that,
all right.

357
00:17:23.370 --> 00:17:25.331
Look for it, correct it if you need to.

358
00:17:25.331 --> 00:17:28.340
If your manually scheduling,
it works great, it's fine.

359
00:17:28.340 --> 00:17:30.380
You really won't have any
problems in manually scheduling.

360
00:17:31.980 --> 00:17:33.470
All right,
another thing that I wanna talk about.

361
00:17:33.470 --> 00:17:37.760
We haven't really talked about it in this
show yet, is if I've got people that

362
00:17:37.760 --> 00:17:42.090
are over allocated, I mentioned that there
were a couple of different solutions and

363
00:17:42.090 --> 00:17:44.120
I really only showed you two.

364
00:17:44.120 --> 00:17:47.526
Option one, was if somebody's doing,
well, here, let's kind of repeat it so

365
00:17:47.526 --> 00:17:48.390
it all makes sense.

366
00:17:48.390 --> 00:17:50.250
We'll tie all of this back together again.

367
00:17:50.250 --> 00:17:54.050
So I'm gonna take some activities here and

368
00:17:54.050 --> 00:17:55.780
we'll just assign Ronnie to everything,
right.

369
00:17:55.780 --> 00:17:59.230
So I'm gonna take Ronnie and
I'm gonna assign him every activity.

370
00:18:00.400 --> 00:18:02.750
Now when I do that,
Ronny's full on over allocated and

371
00:18:02.750 --> 00:18:04.470
I can see that right over here.

372
00:18:04.470 --> 00:18:10.790
And if I go to my team planner I can
spot his over allocation right there.

373
00:18:10.790 --> 00:18:13.080
So he's over allocated on Friday and
Monday and

374
00:18:13.080 --> 00:18:15.010
he's over allocated this following week.

375
00:18:15.010 --> 00:18:17.410
So he's got some difficult times ahead.

376
00:18:17.410 --> 00:18:19.320
Ronnie's gonna be putting in some OT.

377
00:18:19.320 --> 00:18:20.805
And maybe that's fine.

378
00:18:20.805 --> 00:18:24.095
So, I could correct this
the way I did earlier, right?

379
00:18:24.095 --> 00:18:26.745
Option one, assign some of these
activities to somebody else.

380
00:18:26.745 --> 00:18:28.485
I could take setup battery backups.

381
00:18:28.485 --> 00:18:31.765
I could assign that to me, problem solved.

382
00:18:31.765 --> 00:18:34.105
Or I can take it and
assign it back to Ronnie.

383
00:18:34.105 --> 00:18:35.315
And now he's over allocated.

384
00:18:35.315 --> 00:18:37.366
I'm just going to shift
these around a bit, there so

385
00:18:37.366 --> 00:18:38.905
it just looks a little better.

386
00:18:38.905 --> 00:18:42.840
All right, so option one,
assign it to somebody else.

387
00:18:42.840 --> 00:18:47.980
Option two is make them not
happen at the same time, right.

388
00:18:47.980 --> 00:18:51.915
So, if he's over allocated for
setting up these PCs, oh,

389
00:18:51.915 --> 00:18:54.210
you're already over allocated.

390
00:18:54.210 --> 00:18:56.450
I'm trying to over, over allocate you.

391
00:18:56.450 --> 00:18:59.490
So I can take set up PCs and
move them to the next week, right.

392
00:18:59.490 --> 00:19:01.420
And then that problem is solved.

393
00:19:01.420 --> 00:19:06.890
And now he's not oversubscribed anymore,
so that's another option for me.

394
00:19:06.890 --> 00:19:10.670
But there's yet another option.

395
00:19:10.670 --> 00:19:15.535
The other option is I could take Ronnie
and say you're gonna work 50% of your time

396
00:19:15.535 --> 00:19:20.211
on one activity, and 50% time on the other
and there just gonna take longer.

397
00:19:20.211 --> 00:19:22.323
All right,
that's called resource leveling.

398
00:19:22.323 --> 00:19:23.876
Resource leveling is where you say,

399
00:19:23.876 --> 00:19:26.340
I really need both these things
to happen at the same time.

400
00:19:26.340 --> 00:19:28.011
You just gotta split
your time between them.

401
00:19:28.011 --> 00:19:32.960
All right, and we can resource level
right from within the team planner.

402
00:19:32.960 --> 00:19:36.680
So the way resource leveling works is
you come in and you find your resource.

403
00:19:36.680 --> 00:19:39.140
So my resource in this case is Ronnie.

404
00:19:39.140 --> 00:19:42.930
And when I choose Ronnie I'll have
a button up here that says level resource.

405
00:19:42.930 --> 00:19:45.680
Now there's actually three different
buttons, and I wanna talk about

406
00:19:45.680 --> 00:19:48.595
each because the two that are lit up by
default are the two you don't wanna use.

407
00:19:48.595 --> 00:19:49.105
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

408
00:19:49.105 --> 00:19:53.850
[LAUGH] the first one that I
pointed out was level resource.

409
00:19:53.850 --> 00:19:56.140
What that's going to do is it's
going to look at Ronnie, and

410
00:19:56.140 --> 00:19:59.090
it's going to look at
Ronnie's whole calendar,

411
00:19:59.090 --> 00:20:03.880
his whole schedule, everything assigned to
him all the way to the end of the project.

412
00:20:03.880 --> 00:20:05.970
And it's going to level him
all the way throughout it.

413
00:20:05.970 --> 00:20:09.320
So, anywhere he's over allocated, it's
going to make those tasks take longer.

414
00:20:09.320 --> 00:20:11.850
It's going to stretch them out so
that he can do it.

415
00:20:11.850 --> 00:20:13.040
All right.

416
00:20:13.040 --> 00:20:15.500
But I probably don't want that.

417
00:20:15.500 --> 00:20:17.770
I probably don't want to do it for
the whole thing.

418
00:20:17.770 --> 00:20:19.510
And the next button's even worse, right.

419
00:20:19.510 --> 00:20:20.620
Level All.

420
00:20:20.620 --> 00:20:22.990
Level All says not just Ronnie,
lets do the whole project.

421
00:20:22.990 --> 00:20:25.280
We're gonna level the whole daggone thing.

422
00:20:25.280 --> 00:20:28.150
And that's probably not
something that we want, right.

423
00:20:28.150 --> 00:20:32.100
So most commonly,
we're gonna want to Level Selection.

424
00:20:32.100 --> 00:20:34.510
And that's grayed out because,
well I don't have a selection, right.

425
00:20:34.510 --> 00:20:36.670
You gotta come in and pick the jobs.

426
00:20:36.670 --> 00:20:42.240
And you can just select one, hold control
on your keyboard, and click another one.

427
00:20:42.240 --> 00:20:45.560
Now, I'm just leveling
these two activities.

428
00:20:45.560 --> 00:20:46.610
And that's normally what we want.

429
00:20:46.610 --> 00:20:49.080
We want a much more focussed leveling.

430
00:20:49.080 --> 00:20:52.420
So don't be tempted to go with these other
two buttons cuz they usually have much

431
00:20:52.420 --> 00:20:54.980
bigger affect on your
project than what you want.

432
00:20:56.320 --> 00:20:57.530
If that's the case,
why are they even there?

433
00:20:57.530 --> 00:20:59.500
Why do we even have those options?

434
00:20:59.500 --> 00:21:04.110
In the early stages of your project, when
you're just in the very early planning and

435
00:21:04.110 --> 00:21:06.040
you haven't even figured out
what your finish date is,

436
00:21:06.040 --> 00:21:07.390
these two buttons are awesome.

437
00:21:07.390 --> 00:21:08.540
They work great.

438
00:21:08.540 --> 00:21:11.440
You're throwing in your activities,
you're kind of laying them out there and

439
00:21:11.440 --> 00:21:13.200
you wanna do a what if, all right?

440
00:21:13.200 --> 00:21:16.160
What if I only have one network engineer,
how long is this gonna take?

441
00:21:16.160 --> 00:21:17.330
Let me level them out.

442
00:21:17.330 --> 00:21:18.470
Right?
Ooh, that's pretty bad.

443
00:21:18.470 --> 00:21:22.780
Let me add a second network engineer,
let me relevel it, what's it like now?

444
00:21:22.780 --> 00:21:24.230
Oh, that's much better, right?

445
00:21:24.230 --> 00:21:26.950
It's great for
doing scenarios in the early stages.

446
00:21:26.950 --> 00:21:30.420
But in the later stages of planning, when
you've got your baselines in place, you're

447
00:21:30.420 --> 00:21:33.930
trying to solidify those dates, you don't
wanna level out through a whole project.

448
00:21:33.930 --> 00:21:38.970
That can really cause some,
it's not that it causes problems,

449
00:21:38.970 --> 00:21:41.400
it's that it causes changes that
we might not notice right away, so

450
00:21:41.400 --> 00:21:43.720
it's us that causes the problem
by not noticing, right.

451
00:21:43.720 --> 00:21:46.650
It creates that opportunity for mistake.

452
00:21:46.650 --> 00:21:51.060
So, instead, in the later stages of
planning and through the whole rest of

453
00:21:51.060 --> 00:21:53.840
your project you'll usually just
level individual activities.

454
00:21:53.840 --> 00:21:55.890
And so, I'm going to pick setup network.

455
00:21:55.890 --> 00:21:58.400
And I'm gonna hold Ctrl and
pick Setup Battery Backups, and

00:21:58.400 --> 00:22:00.260
I'm gonna choose the level
of the selection.

457
00:22:00.260 --> 00:22:05.300
And what that's gonna do is it's
going to rearrange things in a way

458
00:22:05.300 --> 00:22:07.900
where we don't have the over allocation,
all right?

459
00:22:07.900 --> 00:22:10.370
And in my case instead of
dropping Ronnie down to 50%,

00:22:10.370 --> 00:22:15.110
it apparently decided to go ahead and just
take it and move setup network back and

00:22:15.110 --> 00:22:17.410
put Setup Battery Backups

00:22:17.410 --> 00:22:19.930
Now that may not be what I wanted, right?

00:22:19.930 --> 00:22:22.300
I may have wanted him to drop down
to 50% on each of those activities,

464
00:22:22.300 --> 00:22:23.470
and it didn't do that.

465
00:22:23.470 --> 00:22:28.040
So I'm gonna undo, and what you'll see
is up top you've got your level options.

466
00:22:29.360 --> 00:22:30.700
And you can go in there, and

467
00:22:30.700 --> 00:22:34.070
you can kind of tweak the way
that it's going to be leveling.

468
00:22:34.070 --> 00:22:35.760
And you'll see different options in here,

469
00:22:35.760 --> 00:22:38.930
like doing automatic leveling
calculations, or manual.

470
00:22:38.930 --> 00:22:41.670
We can look for
allocations on a day by day basis, or

471
00:22:41.670 --> 00:22:44.760
month by month, hour by hour,
or minute by minute.

472
00:22:44.760 --> 00:22:47.370
You can tweak a lot of this stuff,
and we're gonna talk more about

473
00:22:47.370 --> 00:22:50.540
resource leveling in another
episode cuz it isn't important.

474
00:22:50.540 --> 00:22:55.070
But you can tweak that behavior right here
to tell it what to do, how we want it

475
00:22:55.070 --> 00:22:58.540
to rearrange it, and make sure that it
does drop that to the way that we want.

476
00:22:58.540 --> 00:23:01.500
And, we do always have
the option to change

00:23:01.500 --> 00:23:04.010
exactly how somebody's

00:23:04.010 --> 00:23:05.000
You can just double click.

479
00:23:05.000 --> 00:23:08.030
Like, I can do this manually if I

480
00:23:08.030 --> 00:23:12.835
I could come in here and take resources

00:23:15.860 --> 00:23:19.410
And than I can do the same thing for

00:23:19.410 --> 00:23:24.370
when I come in here and

00:23:24.370 --> 00:23:28.580
what you'll notice is that that was

00:23:28.580 --> 00:23:30.700
I've effectively manually leveled.

485
00:23:30.700 --> 00:23:32.560
So, you don't have to
use the auto levelling.

486
00:23:32.560 --> 00:23:35.080
If you want to do it by hand,
here, it's done it, and

487
00:23:35.080 --> 00:23:37.360
I've solved that over
allocation right there.

488
00:23:37.360 --> 00:23:40.220
I haven't solved this one, right,
so I still have this problem.

00:23:40.220 --> 00:23:45.115
I can take setup PCs and

00:23:45.115 --> 00:23:49.980
And there, now,
Ronnie is no longer over allocated, but

00:23:49.980 --> 00:23:52.260
my stuff takes a lot longer to run.

492
00:23:52.260 --> 00:23:54.350
Using the resource leveling
buttons up here makes it happen

493
00:23:54.350 --> 00:23:56.510
a little more automatic so

494
00:23:56.510 --> 00:23:59.270
But if you're just doing a handful of

495
00:23:59.270 --> 00:24:00.710
It's really the same result.

496
00:24:00.710 --> 00:24:02.500
Now, Ronnie can do all of the work.

497
00:24:02.500 --> 00:24:04.430
The project is just going to

498
00:24:04.430 --> 00:24:07.230
And I can see that back
here in my Gantt chart,

499
00:24:07.230 --> 00:24:10.590
where my project is now a 20 day project,
as opposed to

500
00:24:10.590 --> 00:24:13.226
the 10 day that I was originally
working with if I had two employees.

501
00:24:13.226 --> 00:24:17.160
So on an effort driven project,
that makes a big difference.

502
00:24:17.160 --> 00:24:19.330
>> Yeah, so being able to actually
level these resources and

00:24:19.330 --> 00:24:23.690
seeing them is actually kind of a neat
way that we know that we can go ahead and

00:24:23.690 --> 00:24:28.380
just manually move them or if you used

505
00:24:28.380 --> 00:24:31.270
Be careful on those leveling
options when you go to automatic,

00:24:31.270 --> 00:24:34.670
because if you just accidentally check it,

00:24:34.670 --> 00:24:37.750
But the good thing is there's also another

00:24:37.750 --> 00:24:41.910
you can revert it back to the times

509
00:24:41.910 --> 00:24:44.800
And I know I've done that before where
I said, I didn't want to level it and

00:24:44.800 --> 00:24:48.140
it leveled it anyways, good thing
I had that option available to me.

511
00:24:48.140 --> 00:24:51.360
>> All right well Ronnie,
that's about it on the team planner.

00:24:51.360 --> 00:24:52.940
You guys see how useful it is and

00:24:52.940 --> 00:24:56.170
you kinda understand why I don't

00:24:56.170 --> 00:25:00.300
The team planner just shows me everything

00:25:00.300 --> 00:25:02.950
It really works out great,

00:25:02.950 --> 00:25:03.720
