I think you'll have fun.

518
00:25:04.610 --> 00:25:07.412
It is a neat product or
a neat part of Microsoft Project.

519
00:25:07.412 --> 00:25:10.940
>> All right, well that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap this episode up.

520
00:25:10.940 --> 00:25:12.230
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

521
00:25:12.230 --> 00:25:13.730
Signing out for ITProTV I'm Don Pezet.

522
00:25:13.730 --> 00:25:14.840
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

523
00:25:14.840 --> 00:25:16.510
>> And we'll see you next time.

524
00:25:16.510 --> 00:25:22.280
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to model the project cost of a project plan.  A project plan is nearing nearing completion for execution when you can see not only what needs to be done and who is going to do it but when you have at least a knowledge of what the cost of the project is projected to be. Knowing how to enter cost to a plan is essential to that. They show how to center cost and have it show up for a baseline cost model.
episodes.title: Model Project Costs
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.085 --> 00:00:10.344
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.344 --> 00:00:13.250
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening.

3
00:00:13.250 --> 00:00:15.570
And welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.570 --> 00:00:18.450
I'm your host Don Pizet,
back again with Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:18.450 --> 00:00:19.350
How's it going Ronnie?

6
00:00:19.350 --> 00:00:20.510
>> It is going great.

7
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:23.240
It's another great day to
be here in the studio to

8
00:00:23.240 --> 00:00:25.120
take a look at some Microsoft projects.

9
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:26.270
Excited and ready to get started.

10
00:00:26.270 --> 00:00:30.230
>> Yeah and now in today's episode we're
gonna take a look at cost modeling.

11
00:00:30.230 --> 00:00:32.560
And if that doesn't sound exciting,

12
00:00:32.560 --> 00:00:34.790
you're not gonna hurt my
feelings when you say that.

13
00:00:34.790 --> 00:00:37.520
You know managing costs for
a project is really important.

14
00:00:37.520 --> 00:00:39.010
I know I said it in an earlier episode.

15
00:00:39.010 --> 00:00:41.305
Every project has the triple constraints.

16
00:00:41.305 --> 00:00:42.500
Right?
The triangle.

17
00:00:42.500 --> 00:00:46.652
Where we have our cost or budget,
our schedule or time, and

18
00:00:46.652 --> 00:00:49.655
then we have our quality or requirements.

19
00:00:49.655 --> 00:00:51.235
Different people have different names for
these things.

20
00:00:51.235 --> 00:00:56.240
So you'll hear quality, requirements or
scope, all really mean the same thing.

21
00:00:56.240 --> 00:01:01.790
So, when we talk about cost, in earlier
versions of project, Microsoft just said,

22
00:01:01.790 --> 00:01:05.020
you can use other software for
that and didn't worry about it.

23
00:01:05.020 --> 00:01:07.590
But a couple of versions
ago Microsoft said well,

24
00:01:07.590 --> 00:01:10.240
we at least need to have a basic idea
of our cost about the project, so

25
00:01:10.240 --> 00:01:13.050
we can create reports and
have a better understanding.

26
00:01:13.050 --> 00:01:17.270
And so they started adding support for
things like Planned Value Analysis or

27
00:01:17.270 --> 00:01:19.040
Earned Value Analysis,
all that good stuff.

28
00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:20.900
And so you'll see things of that nature.

29
00:01:20.900 --> 00:01:23.570
But just general cost and budgeting.

30
00:01:23.570 --> 00:01:26.980
And so we wanna take a quick look
at that and see what we can do.

31
00:01:26.980 --> 00:01:31.340
Now don't expect this amazing
accounting suite and billing and

32
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:34.140
invoicing outside of our project,
it's not gonna happen.

33
00:01:34.140 --> 00:01:36.020
You still need third-party software for
that.

34
00:01:36.020 --> 00:01:38.680
But if you're just trying to make sure
your project's not going over budget,

35
00:01:38.680 --> 00:01:42.590
or to see if you're coming in
under budget, Project can do that.

36
00:01:42.590 --> 00:01:44.210
It just takes using it.

37
00:01:44.210 --> 00:01:46.990
It takes putting in a little extra
data and getting that stuff in there.

38
00:01:46.990 --> 00:01:49.300
So, Ronnie, you're gonna give
us the guided tour, right?

39
00:01:49.300 --> 00:01:50.170
>> We are.
We're gonna take

40
00:01:50.170 --> 00:01:54.790
a look at where costs do normally start
to accrue inside of our project plan.

41
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:57.380
And make sure that we can
actually account for them.

42
00:01:57.380 --> 00:01:59.910
And where it begins is
how much information that

43
00:01:59.910 --> 00:02:03.160
you have on-hand to be able to
enter in the project itself.

44
00:02:03.160 --> 00:02:06.370
And we're gonna see some of the different
ways that you can actually enter in some

45
00:02:06.370 --> 00:02:08.820
of the different resources as well.

46
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:11.995
And then show you were they actually
apply and then show you over all,

47
00:02:11.995 --> 00:02:13.820
where does that model actually fit in.

48
00:02:13.820 --> 00:02:16.920
So, lets go ahead take a look
at my project plan here.

49
00:02:16.920 --> 00:02:19.850
Let me show you just a few
thinks as we get started.

50
00:02:19.850 --> 00:02:24.080
So, lets say that this project plan
up in this point I've went ahead, and

51
00:02:24.080 --> 00:02:29.110
it's completed up until the point where
I'm just about ready to get started.

52
00:02:29.110 --> 00:02:31.660
And so I went ahead and
everything is actually there.

53
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:34.960
I have Resources, I have Predecessors,
I have Finish Dates, Start Dates.

54
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:37.320
And it's telling me it's gonna
take about 30 days to do this.

55
00:02:37.320 --> 00:02:41.090
Overall about 562 hours of work.

56
00:02:41.090 --> 00:02:44.030
But remember that I have
different people working at

57
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:48.570
different rates in terms of hourly cost
that are actually in this project.

58
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:52.290
So how do I know what that
overall figure is going to be?

59
00:02:52.290 --> 00:02:56.810
Well the more information that you can
provide here for Project to work with,

60
00:02:56.810 --> 00:03:00.310
the more that you're gonna actually
get even more information out of this.

61
00:03:00.310 --> 00:03:01.210
And it's gonna help you out,

62
00:03:01.210 --> 00:03:04.350
especially when you're starting
to do that baseline cost as well.

63
00:03:04.350 --> 00:03:08.000
So let's go back and review just a couple
of things that we've also seen from

64
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:12.290
earlier episodes, but is actually good
to make the point even now as well.

65
00:03:12.290 --> 00:03:14.300
Which is to take a look at
our resource sheet, and

66
00:03:14.300 --> 00:03:16.720
actually entering in
those resources again.

67
00:03:16.720 --> 00:03:20.050
So from my standard view
that I have right here.

68
00:03:20.050 --> 00:03:20.960
I'm in the default view.

69
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:25.030
I'm going to click on View and
select Resource Sheet.

70
00:03:25.030 --> 00:03:29.040
And when I do that, I automatically start
to see some of the resources that I have

71
00:03:29.040 --> 00:03:33.060
available to me and
what has already happened.

72
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:35.220
And you start seeing
these over allocations.

73
00:03:35.220 --> 00:03:39.490
And that is because they're actually over
scheduled here inside of my project.

74
00:03:39.490 --> 00:03:43.490
But notice that each one of these
resources has a lot of information also

75
00:03:43.490 --> 00:03:45.060
attached to it, and so

76
00:03:45.060 --> 00:03:48.720
what we want to do is we want to put
as much information in here as we can.

77
00:03:48.720 --> 00:03:52.990
So when we take a look at entering in
a resource, if you don't remember, what

78
00:03:52.990 --> 00:03:56.490
you're gonna do is actually select the
line, let's say down here under number 13.

79
00:03:56.490 --> 00:04:02.910
And then add in another resource, and
I'm just gonna call this one Resource 1.

80
00:04:02.910 --> 00:04:07.400
And that is kind of at least the most
basic information and generic information.

81
00:04:07.400 --> 00:04:10.830
Now, if I had names that
we wanted to add in,

82
00:04:10.830 --> 00:04:13.070
hopefully at this point in
my project I went ahead and

83
00:04:13.070 --> 00:04:17.050
actually switched those names over, but
I just left some generic names instead.

84
00:04:17.050 --> 00:04:20.660
But you wanna select the type of
resource that you also have available

85
00:04:20.660 --> 00:04:21.820
to you as well.

86
00:04:21.820 --> 00:04:25.620
So on Resource 1, I can make it a work
resource, a material resource, or

87
00:04:25.620 --> 00:04:27.780
a cost resource as well.

88
00:04:27.780 --> 00:04:31.898
Most of the time a person resource,
one that works by the hour,

89
00:04:31.898 --> 00:04:34.788
is gonna be considered
a work resource too.

90
00:04:34.788 --> 00:04:38.847
And that means you're gonna pay them
an hourly wage or a yearly salary or

91
00:04:38.847 --> 00:04:39.938
some type of wage.

92
00:04:39.938 --> 00:04:42.899
You're gonna pay them and
it's actually gonna be recurring over and

93
00:04:42.899 --> 00:04:44.880
over again during your project.

94
00:04:44.880 --> 00:04:49.430
Material resources are consumables
that we'll use in the making of our

95
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:54.325
project a lot of times, so you can take
a look up here on lines six and seven.

96
00:04:54.325 --> 00:04:58.330
Or actually put in some plenum cables
since we were also running some lines,

97
00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:01.240
not only in our ceiling, but
also of course drop cables for

98
00:05:01.240 --> 00:05:06.360
each of the drops that we also have
in place for our thin clients.

99
00:05:06.360 --> 00:05:09.409
So you can see that, and
notice the term material, and

100
00:05:09.409 --> 00:05:13.387
we're gonna actually use those
materials up at some point as well, and

101
00:05:13.387 --> 00:05:16.787
then there's also a cost resource
that we may also have too.

102
00:05:16.787 --> 00:05:21.526
Now if we select a cost resource, this is
the one that's actually the trickiest of

103
00:05:21.526 --> 00:05:24.426
them all in what
the information's you can have.

104
00:05:24.426 --> 00:05:29.452
Notice that with a work resource I
can reassign in max units how long

105
00:05:29.452 --> 00:05:35.060
that particular unit can work per day
on that task that we have in hand.

106
00:05:35.060 --> 00:05:37.520
It's standard rate,
it's overtime, and whether or

107
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:41.260
not we actually have a cost per use if we
did that, and of course the accrual rate.

108
00:05:41.260 --> 00:05:44.920
But then if I select Material,
you'll notice it only says,

109
00:05:44.920 --> 00:05:47.470
hey, how much is this thing gonna cost?

110
00:05:47.470 --> 00:05:49.560
And I'm going to actually use it again.

111
00:05:49.560 --> 00:05:51.110
Cost per use of that.

112
00:05:51.110 --> 00:05:52.838
But then if I go down to Cost,

113
00:05:52.838 --> 00:05:56.239
I can't actually enter any
of this other information.

114
00:05:56.239 --> 00:05:59.684
If I try and do the standard rate for
the cost of something, I can't do that.

115
00:05:59.684 --> 00:06:03.380
So you see my Dell servers
that we also put in here.

116
00:06:03.380 --> 00:06:05.970
There's no resource I can enter in here.

117
00:06:05.970 --> 00:06:08.850
And that's going to be important, because
we actually have to enter that information

118
00:06:08.850 --> 00:06:11.400
somewhere else when we're
actually ready to that.

119
00:06:11.400 --> 00:06:13.020
That's when it's going
to actually account.

120
00:06:13.020 --> 00:06:15.850
If not, you're not going to account for
the cost that the overall

121
00:06:15.850 --> 00:06:19.290
project is going to have on hand to
be able to do some of those things.

122
00:06:19.290 --> 00:06:21.170
And we'll enter in those
a little bit later.

123
00:06:21.170 --> 00:06:23.810
So it's right here that you
want to make sure that you can

124
00:06:23.810 --> 00:06:26.080
enter in as much information as you can.

125
00:06:26.080 --> 00:06:28.935
Remember that if you've come
to this field and you say,

126
00:06:28.935 --> 00:06:32.520
hey, it's a material resource and
you decide you're going to try and

127
00:06:32.520 --> 00:06:36.160
attach it to a calendar,
it's also not going to work for you too.

128
00:06:36.160 --> 00:06:37.580
Usually for most of us,

129
00:06:37.580 --> 00:06:41.440
especially we actually are having
people work on our project.

130
00:06:41.440 --> 00:06:43.850
We're going to instead
select the work resource.

131
00:06:43.850 --> 00:06:48.260
And then we will fill it out right
here as much information as we can.

132
00:06:48.260 --> 00:06:52.100
So from here, lets say I'm
going to work on this project.

133
00:06:52.100 --> 00:06:56.120
And we can actually enter in my
initials and I can actually work up

134
00:06:56.120 --> 00:07:00.290
to an eight hour day based on this
terminal server project calendar.

135
00:07:00.290 --> 00:07:02.980
And lets say that I work at $10 an hour.

136
00:07:02.980 --> 00:07:06.531
And my overtime, depending on where I am,
let's see it's going to be $15 an hour.

137
00:07:08.000 --> 00:07:10.010
So, I can select that and there it is.

138
00:07:10.010 --> 00:07:13.510
There's my first way that
I can enter in a resource.

139
00:07:13.510 --> 00:07:17.880
And now,
if I use that resource in my project,

140
00:07:17.880 --> 00:07:22.420
it will start accounting for that right
away to be able to do something like that.

141
00:07:22.420 --> 00:07:25.730
So, being able to enter and
assign the resources is what our goal is.

142
00:07:25.730 --> 00:07:27.690
So now that I have these resources,

143
00:07:27.690 --> 00:07:33.490
there's multiple ways we can assign
a resource now to our project as well.

144
00:07:33.490 --> 00:07:36.930
So I can select Resource 1
directly from the resource sheet,

145
00:07:36.930 --> 00:07:39.360
and I just double click on him.

146
00:07:39.360 --> 00:07:42.250
And I go to Cost here.

147
00:07:42.250 --> 00:07:46.062
There's actually a couple of different
things that we can see right here as well,

148
00:07:46.062 --> 00:07:47.676
and some of the other details too.

149
00:07:47.676 --> 00:07:49.934
So I actually skipped over a group.

150
00:07:49.934 --> 00:07:52.791
If I actually had a group
of people working,

151
00:07:52.791 --> 00:07:57.748
remember that I may also associate them
with the development team instead.

152
00:07:57.748 --> 00:08:00.232
And then I can actually
group them together and so

153
00:08:00.232 --> 00:08:03.031
I can actually print reports
based off of them as well.

154
00:08:03.031 --> 00:08:05.357
Now I didn't wanna go
to that resource team.

155
00:08:05.357 --> 00:08:08.237
I wanted to actually see
where I could assign them

156
00:08:08.237 --> 00:08:10.650
to an actual task at this point.

157
00:08:10.650 --> 00:08:14.780
I'm gonna simply click back on task and
go back to my gant view.

158
00:08:14.780 --> 00:08:18.080
And this is where we can actually
assign resources as well.

159
00:08:18.080 --> 00:08:20.230
We can select a particular
task if we want to.

160
00:08:20.230 --> 00:08:23.704
I'm just gonna select one of these
down here that's actually not over

161
00:08:23.704 --> 00:08:24.730
allocated for right now.

162
00:08:25.760 --> 00:08:30.970
Let's scroll over here, and then under
resource name, I have this drop down.

163
00:08:30.970 --> 00:08:33.390
So as you select these different ones,

164
00:08:33.390 --> 00:08:37.390
that will now add in a cost associated
with using that resource, for

165
00:08:37.390 --> 00:08:42.320
that task, for the duration of work
that's also setup right here as well.

166
00:08:42.320 --> 00:08:45.910
So all that actually starts
to add up in the background

167
00:08:45.910 --> 00:08:50.330
inside of Microsoft Project if we were
actually going to do something like that.

168
00:08:50.330 --> 00:08:52.690
And they will account
a little bit differently.

169
00:08:52.690 --> 00:08:54.599
Let me scroll down a little bit here.

170
00:08:54.599 --> 00:08:58.325
So that will actually account for
the hourly rate, but

171
00:08:58.325 --> 00:09:03.428
down here under my deploying phase,
I have the installing and configuring

172
00:09:03.428 --> 00:09:08.782
the 2008 servers, and I'm gonna scroll
over here to the right hand side.

173
00:09:08.782 --> 00:09:12.110
And you actually see that I
have both of those machines.

174
00:09:12.110 --> 00:09:15.030
We're gonna cluster them together to
give us better load balancing and

175
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:16.310
better performance.

176
00:09:16.310 --> 00:09:20.030
And then I have a couple of other
technicians working on those too.

177
00:09:20.030 --> 00:09:23.440
Well, remember I did not have
a cost associated with them

178
00:09:23.440 --> 00:09:25.660
inside of my resource sheet.

179
00:09:25.660 --> 00:09:32.870
So, if I right click on that task, and I
go to information, and under information,

180
00:09:32.870 --> 00:09:39.180
if I now select resources, you'll see,
look at what it already started to do.

181
00:09:39.180 --> 00:09:42.920
For this technician because we actually
have three days and I just assigned some

182
00:09:42.920 --> 00:09:46.900
random salary and information,
it's already telling me that for

183
00:09:46.900 --> 00:09:50.740
this particular task so far,
the infrastructure technician as well as

184
00:09:50.740 --> 00:09:54.940
the server admin technician, well,
they're gonna cost about the same rate.

185
00:09:54.940 --> 00:09:59.480
And so at this point,
let's talk about $1650 or so.

186
00:09:59.480 --> 00:10:00.370
Is what it's gonna cost, but

187
00:10:00.370 --> 00:10:05.170
notice the two servers that I have
right here that I've not yet set up.

188
00:10:05.170 --> 00:10:08.280
Well, the only thing that actually gives
me the ability to do right here is to set

189
00:10:08.280 --> 00:10:11.780
the cost of those things up and I don't
actually remember how much they were, so

190
00:10:11.780 --> 00:10:13.810
I'm just going to say $2,500.

191
00:10:13.810 --> 00:10:17.280
That's probably low end, I would assume,
but I don't really know for

192
00:10:17.280 --> 00:10:21.490
sure, and
that's where you can assign those costs.

193
00:10:21.490 --> 00:10:23.860
They don't appear in that resource table.

194
00:10:23.860 --> 00:10:28.260
When you actually first use them,
that's where you can assign the cost for

195
00:10:28.260 --> 00:10:30.360
those cost resources.

196
00:10:30.360 --> 00:10:33.320
So they don't just show up
as just a resource per cost.

197
00:10:33.320 --> 00:10:37.010
You're gonna actually have to put them in
manually if you are gonna use that cost

198
00:10:37.010 --> 00:10:37.850
based resource.

199
00:10:37.850 --> 00:10:40.130
It doesn't affect the schedule, so

200
00:10:40.130 --> 00:10:43.610
it's not gonna actually do anything to
adjust your schedule if you do that.

201
00:10:43.610 --> 00:10:47.267
But what you're now doing
is you're accounting for

202
00:10:47.267 --> 00:10:50.682
the cost of that being
used inside your project.

203
00:10:50.682 --> 00:10:52.070
And so we can also do that.

204
00:10:52.070 --> 00:10:55.303
So, being able to assign work resource and
material resources

205
00:10:55.303 --> 00:10:59.550
to be able to be used inside your project,
you want to be able to understand.

206
00:10:59.550 --> 00:11:01.791
That's a big part of what we have, right?

207
00:11:01.791 --> 00:11:06.403
Because all that information is gonna
come down to us getting access to some

208
00:11:06.403 --> 00:11:09.490
information that's running
in the background.

209
00:11:09.490 --> 00:11:13.480
In other words, all that cost is actually
going to generate a nice little report and

210
00:11:13.480 --> 00:11:15.740
a view for us that we actually need.

211
00:11:15.740 --> 00:11:17.750
So let me show you where
that normally shows up.

212
00:11:17.750 --> 00:11:19.040
We're not gonna go into reports yet

213
00:11:19.040 --> 00:11:22.230
because we actually have
a whole episode on reports.

214
00:11:22.230 --> 00:11:24.250
But if I go to project and

215
00:11:24.250 --> 00:11:28.300
I select project information,
now that I think that everything is

216
00:11:28.300 --> 00:11:32.000
ready I can come down here to lower
left hand corner and select statistics.

217

>> Yeah, and we see this more,

it is a great way to see that and

Otherwise our project is

what if his rates actually change

In other words, as he got busier

no if you need me during this time of

So since I have this

Now what we're looking for

Well, I already him I know, for a certain

Let's say we have another contractor

Well, then you also have to account for

>> Yeah, absolutely, and you might also

Well, on each of these resources then,

So you can say that A rate table is

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don show how to model the material resource cost of a project plan.  Materials are normally resources we use up, consume, during our project.  We have materials that are used up over time and other material that we may cost us all at one time. The guys show how to account for both possible types of material resource modeling.

00:11:27.910 --> 00:11:28.980
do that and get it done.

235
00:11:28.980 --> 00:11:32.730
So that's what we're trying to do
on the modelling of those costs for

236
00:11:32.730 --> 00:11:33.960
things like that.

237
00:11:33.960 --> 00:11:36.330
Sometimes we do have those
fixed costs as well, right Don?

238
00:11:36.330 --> 00:11:38.290
>> Yeah, and this is important.

239
00:11:38.290 --> 00:11:42.690
One of the things that I really like, what
we're doing as we're putting our cost into

240
00:11:42.690 --> 00:11:46.300
the project, and we're attaching the
activities, which gives them a date to.

241
00:11:46.300 --> 00:11:49.170
So at the end of the day when Ronny's done
adding all this stuff in we'll enough,

242
00:11:49.170 --> 00:11:50.800
exactly how much this
project is gonna cost?

243
00:11:50.800 --> 00:11:53.170
Maybe it's $1.2 million project.

244
00:11:53.170 --> 00:11:57.210
So, does that mean I need a check for
$1.2 million project on day one?

245
00:11:57.210 --> 00:11:58.810
Well, you could do it that way, right?

246
00:11:58.810 --> 00:12:01.310
Your company could say, here it is,
you've got your budget.

247
00:12:01.310 --> 00:12:03.120
Here's $1.2 million sitting in the bank,

248
00:12:03.120 --> 00:12:05.680
dole it out as your project
needs all the way to completion.

249
00:12:05.680 --> 00:12:08.090
Right, but
most companies don't work that way.

250
00:12:08.090 --> 00:12:09.150
Most companies say, okay,

251
00:12:09.150 --> 00:12:13.300
you've got a $1.2 million project,
how much money do you need per month?

252
00:12:13.300 --> 00:12:14.910
And let's dole out on a monthly basis.

253
00:12:14.910 --> 00:12:17.240
Well, Ronnie can pull up all
the activities for August.

254
00:12:17.240 --> 00:12:18.120
And sorry, what's that add up to?

255
00:12:18.120 --> 00:12:20.030
All right, my budget for
August is only $200,000.

256
00:12:20.030 --> 00:12:22.070
So, I just need $200,000 for August.

257
00:12:22.070 --> 00:12:25.770
My company might not
even have $1.2 million.

258
00:12:25.770 --> 00:12:28.320
It might just know,
hey this is a six month project.

259
00:12:28.320 --> 00:12:31.360
Over the course of six months,
we'll make $1.2 million, and

260
00:12:31.360 --> 00:12:33.170
so let's just dole it out as we get it.

261
00:12:33.170 --> 00:12:36.220
So now there's a little risk there, the
money might dry up and you might lose it.

262
00:12:36.220 --> 00:12:40.180
But by putting it in like Ronnie was
doing here, we can do a cost schedule.

263
00:12:40.180 --> 00:12:42.680
We can look at our calendar and
figure out when we need that money.

264
00:12:42.680 --> 00:12:43.800
That's a very valuable thing.

265
00:12:43.800 --> 00:12:46.640
We'll see that more in the reporting
section of this show, but

266
00:12:46.640 --> 00:12:49.920
for now just understand there's
a two-fold benefit to this.

267
00:12:49.920 --> 00:12:52.060
Now a big cost,
like you mentioned Ronnie, so

268
00:12:52.060 --> 00:12:56.350
let's say I know that I'm gonna
need a dump truck for this project.

269
00:12:56.350 --> 00:13:01.365
I'm gonna need it so much that it makes
sense to buy it versus renting it, right.

270
00:13:01.365 --> 00:13:03.320
>> [LAUGH]
>> You have to do that, the whole make or

271
00:13:03.320 --> 00:13:06.210
buy decision and stuff,
that occurs inside of a project.

272
00:13:06.210 --> 00:13:10.250
So maybe you put it in here as rentals
originally, and then we add up all

273
00:13:10.250 --> 00:13:13.160
the rentals and we're like, holy molly
we can just buy the thing, right?

274
00:13:13.160 --> 00:13:14.490
So we turn around and we buy one.

275
00:13:14.490 --> 00:13:18.310
Well, if you're gonna buy that dump truck,
there's a cost associated with that right?

276
00:13:18.310 --> 00:13:21.580
And you could do that as
a cost to your company, and

277
00:13:21.580 --> 00:13:26.020
then your project benefits from it or you
can do it as a cost to the project itself.

278
00:13:26.020 --> 00:13:29.840
And that's something we need to track,
that's like a one-time purchase.

279
00:13:29.840 --> 00:13:31.260
And you have to make
a tough decision there,

280
00:13:31.260 --> 00:13:33.940
because we could do that as a material or
a cost, couldn't we, Ronnie?

281
00:13:33.940 --> 00:13:37.215
>> We really can, and so
depending on how you set that up.

282
00:13:37.215 --> 00:13:39.735
That's what's gonna end up happening is
that either you're gonna actually say,

283
00:13:39.735 --> 00:13:41.795
look I assigned this now as a material.

284
00:13:41.795 --> 00:13:43.355
What's gonna end up happening?

285
00:13:43.355 --> 00:13:46.285
Well, remember what we're actually
normally saying with material is

286
00:13:46.285 --> 00:13:47.865
we're gonna kind of prorate that.

287
00:13:47.865 --> 00:13:49.695
In other words, over that schedule and

288
00:13:49.695 --> 00:13:51.622
that time kind of be able
to distribute it out.

289
00:13:51.622 --> 00:13:55.810
But if we do that fixed cost,
just as a cost resource.

290
00:13:55.810 --> 00:13:58.852
We're just gonna say look, we're gonna
come out with the money for right here,

291
00:13:58.852 --> 00:13:59.692
right now.

292
00:13:59.692 --> 00:14:03.482
And we're saying that that money is spent,
and it's done and it's over with.

293
00:14:03.482 --> 00:14:07.122
So it really depends on how you need
to look at it inside of your project.

294
00:14:07.122 --> 00:14:08.422
>> Yeah, another thing is.

295
00:14:08.422 --> 00:14:10.900
Let's pull your project up again, Ronnie.

296
00:14:10.900 --> 00:14:13.370
Ronnie has some activities like
installing the cable, right?

297
00:14:13.370 --> 00:14:16.980
If you look at activity 3.1 there,
install premise cabling, right?

298
00:14:16.980 --> 00:14:20.750
Well, that activity is
actually installing the cable.

299
00:14:20.750 --> 00:14:24.060
We really should already have
the cable by that point, right?

300
00:14:24.060 --> 00:14:26.980
So what I'll typically do is break these
down, and we have to careful, all right?

301
00:14:26.980 --> 00:14:29.650
If you're PMI trained about the 880 rule,

302
00:14:29.650 --> 00:14:34.660
which is every activity should be more
than eight hours, but less than 80 hours.

303
00:14:34.660 --> 00:14:38.350
If it's less than eight hours
then you're micromanaging.

304
00:14:38.350 --> 00:14:40.490
If it's more than 80 hours,
you're not breaking it down enough.

305
00:14:40.490 --> 00:14:42.010
And you're setting yourself up for
failure.

306
00:14:42.010 --> 00:14:44.950
But that's not a hard, fast rule,
that's just like PMI's guideline.

307
00:14:44.950 --> 00:14:48.650
So, when you look at something like
installing the cabling-well, Ronnie's got

308
00:14:48.650 --> 00:14:52.570
72 hours assigned over 3 days, so
it's a good bit- 72 hours over 3 days?

309
00:14:52.570 --> 00:14:55.350
How many people are assigned to that?

310
00:14:55.350 --> 00:14:57.680
So, anyhow,
it's a good bit of work, right?

311
00:14:57.680 --> 00:15:01.860
But, if they come in that morning,
we just ordered the cable that morning.

312
00:15:01.860 --> 00:15:03.532
How much work did they need to get done?

313
00:15:03.532 --> 00:15:04.032
>> None.
>> None?

314
00:15:04.032 --> 00:15:05.730
We need to get the cable ahead of time.

315
00:15:05.730 --> 00:15:07.810
We normally break this apart even more and

316
00:15:07.810 --> 00:15:11.870
say, yeah we're not gonna install
the cable until July 1st.

317
00:15:11.870 --> 00:15:15.150
But we need to order the cable June 15th

318
00:15:15.150 --> 00:15:17.250
to make sure we have it in time for
July 1st.

319
00:15:18.250 --> 00:15:23.150
So now the cost, this material cost
that we think of as attached to this one

320
00:15:23.150 --> 00:15:27.410
activity is actually a few weeks
ahead of time as part of that.

321
00:15:27.410 --> 00:15:30.330
And so what we'll normally do
is create a separate task,

322
00:15:30.330 --> 00:15:34.690
which is purchase cabling, or
purchase materials for cable install.

323
00:15:34.690 --> 00:15:38.060
Keep it real generic and
attach the materials there,

324
00:15:38.060 --> 00:15:41.150
as opposed to attaching the materials
to the actual installation.

325
00:15:41.150 --> 00:15:42.410
Because we should purchase them and

326
00:15:42.410 --> 00:15:44.860
have them available before
we move on to the next one.

327
00:15:44.860 --> 00:15:46.460
And you can create a dependency.

328
00:15:46.460 --> 00:15:48.080
Between those two activities and

329
00:15:48.080 --> 00:15:51.220
set a lead time in there that
matches your shipping time.

330
00:15:51.220 --> 00:15:53.240
Or it would be a lag time in this case,
right?

331
00:15:53.240 --> 00:15:55.640
So if it took two weeks for
me to procure the cables and get them.

332
00:15:55.640 --> 00:15:57.940
I need a two week lag time
in there to put the delay.

333
00:15:57.940 --> 00:15:59.644
And that way if I move the activities,

334
00:15:59.644 --> 00:16:01.834
that'll move them around
based on their needs.

335
00:16:01.834 --> 00:16:04.542
So you can get kind of specific on this.

336
00:16:04.542 --> 00:16:07.792
And it is important to be that way
because you need to make sure.

337
00:16:07.792 --> 00:16:09.543
Hey, they're gonna be installing
that cabling on Monday.

338
00:16:09.543 --> 00:16:11.000
Have we received that cabling?

339
00:16:11.000 --> 00:16:11.834
Has that happened?

340
00:16:11.834 --> 00:16:16.058
So you might set a order the cabling,
and then create a milestone for

341
00:16:16.058 --> 00:16:18.230
receive the shipment.

342
00:16:18.230 --> 00:16:21.350
And as that milestone approaches you
can say, have we received it yet?

343
00:16:21.350 --> 00:16:22.410
Is the cable on back order?

344
00:16:22.410 --> 00:16:23.520
Do we need to find another vendor?

345
00:16:23.520 --> 00:16:25.510
Do we need to order that or
expedite the shipping?

346
00:16:25.510 --> 00:16:29.240
Do we need to throw a little extra money
in there to get this thing done faster?

347
00:16:29.240 --> 00:16:30.260
Or are we doing okay?

348
00:16:30.260 --> 00:16:31.850
We got the cable, the milestone hits.

349
00:16:31.850 --> 00:16:32.740
We've got everything.

350
00:16:32.740 --> 00:16:34.500
We are ready to install on Monday, right.

351
00:16:34.500 --> 00:16:37.040
That's all part of
managing these materials.

352
00:16:37.040 --> 00:16:40.260
Just because you've attached them there
doesn't mean the materials are gonna

353
00:16:40.260 --> 00:16:41.972
magically manifest themselves.

354
00:16:41.972 --> 00:16:43.991
We need, that would be kinda cool.

355
00:16:43.991 --> 00:16:45.295
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we do need to make sure that we've

356
00:16:45.295 --> 00:16:46.905
ordered them and that we've procured them.

357
00:16:46.905 --> 00:16:50.155
So there might be some other accounting
practices that have to happen.

358
00:16:50.155 --> 00:16:50.685
>> Right.
So

359
00:16:50.685 --> 00:16:52.545
when we start taking a look
at something like that,

360
00:16:52.545 --> 00:16:55.875
remember once you actually figure out
how you're going to get it ordered and

361
00:16:55.875 --> 00:16:59.205
put into place, I didn't do any
of that purchasing side of it.

362
00:16:59.205 --> 00:17:01.755
So the only thing I actually did,
and Don would know this,

363
00:17:01.755 --> 00:17:03.891
is he just said, here's the switch,
Ronnie, put it in.

364
00:17:03.891 --> 00:17:04.545
>> [LAUGH] Get to work.

365
00:17:04.545 --> 00:17:07.960
So when I did it, yeah,
it was just, get it to work.

366
00:17:07.960 --> 00:17:12.070
I didn't think about that cost side Don,
but right here I went ahead and

367
00:17:12.070 --> 00:17:14.520
also accounted for the switch as well.

368
00:17:14.520 --> 00:17:17.980
If you go ahead and do that then you
simply go ahead and assign that.

369
00:17:17.980 --> 00:17:19.540
Let me see if I can go
back to the information.

370
00:17:20.640 --> 00:17:24.600
And on installing that switch,
I go down to resources here.

371
00:17:24.600 --> 00:17:28.630
And this one I think I set
up as a material resource.

372
00:17:28.630 --> 00:17:29.460
I'm not sure exactly.

373
00:17:29.460 --> 00:17:30.420
Let's see.
Nope.

374
00:17:30.420 --> 00:17:33.400
I set it up as just a one time cost here.

375
00:17:33.400 --> 00:17:36.300
So let's say we got a 3640 switch, and

376
00:17:36.300 --> 00:17:38.380
I don't have a clue how
much that thing costs.

377
00:17:38.380 --> 00:17:41.460
I'm gonna say $1200.

378
00:17:41.460 --> 00:17:45.660
I can add that in there for
that one cost and associate that.

379
00:17:45.660 --> 00:17:47.770
And then if I right click and
go back to information,

380
00:17:49.630 --> 00:17:53.200
I can see under the resources now it
also added in that cost for us for

381
00:17:53.200 --> 00:17:57.220
that one time piece that we're also
associating with that one task.

382
00:17:57.220 --> 00:17:59.130
So it is helpful, right?

383
00:17:59.130 --> 00:18:01.800
Because we're not actually
working on the project yet.

384
00:18:01.800 --> 00:18:05.360
We're trying to model all the cost
that we're gonna have associated

385
00:18:05.360 --> 00:18:08.150
with this particular project so

386
00:18:08.150 --> 00:18:12.440
that when it does get time and ready then
I can hand that to Don, say here it is.

387
00:18:12.440 --> 00:18:14.800
And Don says,
well you're $4000 over budget.

388
00:18:14.800 --> 00:18:18.220
Or Don says, oh no you're well within
budget, let's go ahead and get started and

389
00:18:18.220 --> 00:18:20.170
start ordering everything that we need to.

390
00:18:20.170 --> 00:18:21.360
And that's what we're trying to do.

391
00:18:21.360 --> 00:18:24.970
We wanna make sure that we account for not
only work resources, material resources,

392
00:18:24.970 --> 00:18:29.760
as well as those fixed cost resources
inside of our project plan that we have

393
00:18:29.760 --> 00:18:35.090
a nice full accounting of just about
everything that we can think of.

394
00:18:35.090 --> 00:18:38.310
>> It is important to know though
that Ronnie, your way is not wrong.

395
00:18:38.310 --> 00:18:40.860
It all comes down to how we use Project.

396
00:18:40.860 --> 00:18:45.850
If you're strictly using Project just
as the project management piece for

397
00:18:45.850 --> 00:18:49.030
managing the employees and making sure
things are where they're supposed to be,

398
00:18:49.030 --> 00:18:50.930
then doing it Ronnie's way makes sense.

399
00:18:52.670 --> 00:18:55.910
But Ronnie's way requires us
to have some kind of extra

400
00:18:55.910 --> 00:18:57.120
piece to manage the other things.

401
00:18:57.120 --> 00:18:57.770
And a lot of companies do.

402
00:18:57.770 --> 00:18:59.770
You might have procurement software.

403
00:18:59.770 --> 00:19:01.350
You might have procurement agents.

404
00:19:01.350 --> 00:19:02.770
And they manage that stuff.

405
00:19:02.770 --> 00:19:04.190
So they look at the project and
they're like wow,

406
00:19:04.190 --> 00:19:07.060
Ronnie's expecting to have 1,000
feet of cabling on Monday.

407
00:19:07.060 --> 00:19:10.870
I need to go into my software and
make sure the purchase is entered in.

408
00:19:10.870 --> 00:19:12.040
You see this with governments.

409
00:19:12.040 --> 00:19:13.330
Look at the United States government.

410
00:19:13.330 --> 00:19:16.850
We gotta look for the GSA schedule that
includes purchasing, that cabling, and

411
00:19:16.850 --> 00:19:18.220
go through that process.

412
00:19:18.220 --> 00:19:19.820
Project can't do that.

413
00:19:19.820 --> 00:19:21.650
So that's completely outside of project.

414
00:19:21.650 --> 00:19:25.190
So if you've got a secondary
system that's handling purchasing,

415
00:19:25.190 --> 00:19:28.310
then sending up the way that Ronnie
did is the way you want to do it.

416
00:19:28.310 --> 00:19:31.210
But if you're using Project to track
it off, you're trying to be holistic,

417
00:19:31.210 --> 00:19:32.860
capture the whole set of events,

418
00:19:32.860 --> 00:19:36.840
including the accounting practices,
then you want to create those extra ones.

419
00:19:36.840 --> 00:19:38.270
It's not about one being right or

420
00:19:38.270 --> 00:19:41.210
wrong, it's about which one
works in your environment.

421
00:19:41.210 --> 00:19:43.956
And everybody's environment's a little
bit different, as far as the resources,

422
00:19:43.956 --> 00:19:46.740
I mean the project management
resources you have available.

423
00:19:46.740 --> 00:19:48.960
Not necessarily the resources
on your project.

424
00:19:48.960 --> 00:19:49.990
That's confusing, isn't it?

425
00:19:49.990 --> 00:19:50.698
>> It really is.

426
00:19:50.698 --> 00:19:52.628
>> That's not a good way to end the show.

427
00:19:52.628 --> 00:19:55.980
So just take into account the things
that your company has, right?

428
00:19:55.980 --> 00:19:57.690
Your organizational process assets,

429
00:19:57.690 --> 00:19:59.760
I'm gonna break out all
the cool PMI keywords today.

430
00:19:59.760 --> 00:20:00.630
>> You should.

431
00:20:00.630 --> 00:20:03.025
>> So all of the things that are part
of how your company does business,

432
00:20:03.025 --> 00:20:05.225
that's gonna influence
how you use Project.

433
00:20:05.225 --> 00:20:06.065
All right,

434
00:20:06.065 --> 00:20:09.415
well, Ronnie, I think that's a pretty
good run down of our material resources.

435
00:20:09.415 --> 00:20:10.625
You got anything else to throw in?

436
00:20:10.625 --> 00:20:13.545
>> Just remember, the more that you work
with it, the better you're gonna be at it.

437
00:20:13.545 --> 00:20:17.170
There are so many little details in
here that can really trip you up.

438
00:20:17.170 --> 00:20:21.090
Handling resources, getting everything
ready for our project plan to get in use,

439
00:20:21.090 --> 00:20:24.300
is really part of the goal
of why we use Project, so

440
00:20:24.300 --> 00:20:25.770
that we can monitor everything.

441
00:20:25.770 --> 00:20:26.800
So, let's go ahead and

442
00:20:26.800 --> 00:20:29.570
make sure that you're actually
working with it as much as you can.

443
00:20:29.570 --> 00:20:31.700
>> Yeah, and work smarter,
not harder, right?

444
00:20:31.700 --> 00:20:33.170
That's the rule.

445
00:20:33.170 --> 00:20:35.080
All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,
we'll go ahead and wrap it up here.

446
00:20:35.080 --> 00:20:36.540
Hope you guys enjoyed the show.

447
00:20:36.540 --> 00:20:39.090
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pizet.

448
00:20:39.090 --> 00:20:41.520
>> I'm Ron Wong.
>> And we'll see you next time.

449
00:20:41.520 --> 00:20:44.419
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie introduces to using baselines within our project plan.  Baselines allow us to create a snaphot of project start and finish dates, work, cost and duration data. This will allow us to track the progress of our plan without losing track of the original project plan data.  Then a Project manager can compare against to baseline to measure whether the current project is on schedule, on budget and on goal or not by using baselines.
episodes.title: Setting Baselines
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.750
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.750 --> 00:00:14.380
Welcome to another exciting
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.380 --> 00:00:17.230
Today we're specifically taking
a look at Microsoft Project.

4
00:00:17.230 --> 00:00:19.080
I'll be your host, Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:19.080 --> 00:00:21.440
As we start taking a look
at Microsoft Project,

6
00:00:21.440 --> 00:00:23.890
we can actually set
what we call baselines.

7
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:26.060
Now you may be wondering about
what the heck is a baseline and

8
00:00:26.060 --> 00:00:27.730
why would we actually want to use it.

9
00:00:27.730 --> 00:00:30.765
But up into this point,
what we've done in our series so

10
00:00:30.765 --> 00:00:34.834
far is that we went ahead and was able
to start putting all of the information

11
00:00:34.834 --> 00:00:38.793

229
00:14:15.780 --> 00:14:19.930
about the original baselines that I
have set before I begin my project.

230
00:14:19.930 --> 00:14:22.470
I just want to actually
make this my new base line.

231
00:14:22.470 --> 00:14:25.370
Well simple,
if you wanted to do something like that.

232
00:14:25.370 --> 00:14:29.970
If I go back up to the set base line and
choose that option again,

233
00:14:31.020 --> 00:14:35.420
what I can do is select the baseline
that I want to overwrite.

234
00:14:36.660 --> 00:14:39.640
So, let's say I select that original one,
and I'm gonna do this for

235
00:14:39.640 --> 00:14:41.250
the entire project and click okay.

236
00:14:41.250 --> 00:14:46.110
When I do so, it's gonna say, hey, are you
sure you want to overwrite this data?

237
00:14:46.110 --> 00:14:50.500
If I am, then it's at that point
I would go ahead and say yes.

238
00:14:50.500 --> 00:14:54.570
And then I would now have ended up
overwriting that new baseline or

239
00:14:54.570 --> 00:14:55.910
that old baseline.

240
00:14:55.910 --> 00:14:57.730
I go back into project information and

241
00:14:57.730 --> 00:15:02.890
statistics, I can now see that
it updated my original baseline.

242
00:15:02.890 --> 00:15:05.980
So if you're not really interested
in keeping track of that historical

243
00:15:05.980 --> 00:15:10.140
information for comparison, later on
as your project continues to develop

244
00:15:10.140 --> 00:15:14.220
then overriding baselines is another
option for you to be able to do.

245
00:15:14.220 --> 00:15:18.740
Now everything that I've done up in this
point has really helped me to go ahead and

246
00:15:18.740 --> 00:15:20.120
be able to select baselines for

247
00:15:20.120 --> 00:15:24.630
the entire project, and that normally
is what small projects end up doing.

248
00:15:24.630 --> 00:15:27.700
It's that they wanna see that
comparison between the beginning and

249
00:15:27.700 --> 00:15:31.500
the ends there, and you may take
those baselines at different times.

250
00:15:31.500 --> 00:15:35.970
So you may actually choose a baseline
when you finish a particular phase.

251
00:15:35.970 --> 00:15:41.120
So let's say that I finish my terminal
testing phase here on my project,

252
00:15:41.120 --> 00:15:44.180
I may go ahead and just choose
to baseline that for right now.

253
00:15:44.180 --> 00:15:45.130
And then later on,

254
00:15:45.130 --> 00:15:49.050
as I finish up the deploying phase,
I may choose to do another baseline.

255
00:15:49.050 --> 00:15:52.080
So we can do that, and then that
testing phase, choose another one, and

256
00:15:52.080 --> 00:15:54.990
set up all three of those so
that I can compare them

257
00:15:54.990 --> 00:15:57.540
against the original baseline and
be able to track them.

258
00:15:57.540 --> 00:16:02.180
If I go to that baseline view I can add in
all that information and be able to track

259
00:16:02.180 --> 00:16:06.240
the differences between all of them,
task by task if I've choose to.

260
00:16:06.240 --> 00:16:09.460
So, that's is an option that you
have available to you to be able

261
00:16:09.460 --> 00:16:11.130
to do something like that.

262
00:16:11.130 --> 00:16:14.310
But, the other thing you
might actually do instead

263
00:16:14.310 --> 00:16:17.920
is just baseline selected task instead.

264
00:16:17.920 --> 00:16:22.309
And you might do this if you were doing
something that we call a rolling phase or

265
00:16:22.309 --> 00:16:26.120
a type of deployment or
change in your project.

266
00:16:26.120 --> 00:16:28.970
So it might be where it actually is that,
where you're actually only working on

267
00:16:28.970 --> 00:16:32.520
certain pieces at certain times and
it's actually rolling along.

268
00:16:32.520 --> 00:16:36.736
And what you want to do instead is that
you don't want to actually baseline

269
00:16:36.736 --> 00:16:39.000
the entire project every time.

270
00:16:39.000 --> 00:16:40.920
Just like what I was talking about, right.

271
00:16:40.920 --> 00:16:44.060
At the end of tuning phase I'm going
to baseline the entire project.

272
00:16:44.060 --> 00:16:47.190
At the end of the deploying phase
I'm going to do the whole thing.

273
00:16:47.190 --> 00:16:51.260
I may choose instead just to
baseline just that section.

274
00:16:51.260 --> 00:16:54.950
Lets say in the deployment phase
I went ahead and I said look,

275
00:16:54.950 --> 00:16:58.780
I wanna go ahead and
baseline this entire thing here.

276
00:16:58.780 --> 00:17:02.740
I can choose all of these tasks here, and

277
00:17:02.740 --> 00:17:08.480
then I can go to Set Baseline and
from there select Select a Task and

278
00:17:08.480 --> 00:17:13.190
I can either roll up those baselines if I
want to, the Summary Task or also do that.

279
00:17:13.190 --> 00:17:17.400
I'm just gonna leave it at it's default
right now under Select a Task and

280
00:17:17.400 --> 00:17:18.070
click okay.

281
00:17:18.070 --> 00:17:21.220
It says, hey, there's already a base
line used here, so let me go ahead and

282
00:17:21.220 --> 00:17:24.710
select another date, or
another base line, I should say.

283
00:17:24.710 --> 00:17:26.970
And then I can do that.

284
00:17:26.970 --> 00:17:28.560
Now, you might be wondering,
why would I do that?

285
00:17:28.560 --> 00:17:34.550
Well, what if I only wanted to compare my
original deploying phase to now a new one?

286
00:17:34.550 --> 00:17:36.220
Well, then we can go ahead and do that.

287
00:17:36.220 --> 00:17:38.780
I've now saved this original base line,

288
00:17:38.780 --> 00:17:44.010
as now other things start getting added
in or start to change in my project plan.

289
00:17:44.010 --> 00:17:47.440
Well I can now actually go to
the baseline number three.

290
00:17:47.440 --> 00:17:51.750
And now save that information and
then I can compare those two

291
00:17:51.750 --> 00:17:56.490
without actually having to see the entire
project plan and baseline to that too.

292
00:17:56.490 --> 00:17:59.917
So being able to select certain phases or
just certain tasks to baseline,

293
00:17:59.917 --> 00:18:05.520
being able to baseline the entire
project plan itself really is about

294
00:18:05.520 --> 00:18:09.050
you comparing to what you thought was
actually the best of the original project

295
00:18:09.050 --> 00:18:13.210
that you had versus what is actually
starting to happen on your project

296
00:18:13.210 --> 00:18:17.350
as you're now getting information coming
in as you're actually starting to track.

297
00:18:17.350 --> 00:18:18.870
So it's a great tool for

298
00:18:18.870 --> 00:18:22.050
you if you are actually having to do
those comparisons, and normally you are.

299
00:18:22.050 --> 00:18:23.240
You're gonna actually try and

300
00:18:23.240 --> 00:18:27.470
compare, this is where I should be
in my project but right now I'm not.

301
00:18:27.470 --> 00:18:31.840
If there's a work stoppage at some point
due to a hurricane coming through Florida,

302
00:18:31.840 --> 00:18:35.920
like that doesn't happen, and
you have to actually start two weeks

303
00:18:35.920 --> 00:18:39.530
later than you thought or you actually
have to stop work and restart it again.

304
00:18:39.530 --> 00:18:43.360
Doing those types of baselines will really
help you as you're setting new ones and

305
00:18:43.360 --> 00:18:44.890
even those interim project plans as well.

306
00:18:44.890 --> 00:18:50.210
All right, so that's actually a good
place for us to go ahead and finish up.

307
00:18:50.210 --> 00:18:52.910
Remember that what we took a look
at here is the idea of setting up

308
00:18:52.910 --> 00:18:56.130
different baselines, making sure
that we can actually take a look and

309
00:18:56.130 --> 00:19:00.080
see where the information's coming
from and how we also do it.

310
00:19:00.080 --> 00:19:01.960
Well, that's all that we have for
this show.

311
00:19:01.960 --> 00:19:05.415
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

312
00:19:05.415 --> 00:19:10.574
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie shows how to begin to update progress within a project plan.  He shows multiple ways that task progress can be recorded.  Also discussed is how to reschedule uncompleted task.
episodes.title: Update Progress
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.167 --> 00:00:10.376
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.376 --> 00:00:13.700
Welcome to another exciting
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.700 --> 00:00:15.130
My name is Ronnie Wong,
I'll be your host today.

4
00:00:15.130 --> 00:00:18.906
And today we're taking a look
at Microsoft Project 2013.

5
00:00:18.906 --> 00:00:22.491
And we're actually finally starting
to get to this point in which

6
00:00:22.491 --> 00:00:26.960
we are actually entering in, well,
updating the project plan itself.

7
00:00:26.960 --> 00:00:30.620
In other words we are now beginning
to monitor and track progress.

8
00:00:30.620 --> 00:00:33.074
So of course today what we wanna do is,

9
00:00:33.074 --> 00:00:36.605
we wanna walk you through how
to actually take tasks and

10
00:00:36.605 --> 00:00:41.390
update them as our progress and
our project plan continues through time.

11
00:00:41.390 --> 00:00:44.173
Making sure that you understand that there
are actually some different techniques

12
00:00:44.173 --> 00:00:45.495
that we can use.

13
00:00:45.495 --> 00:00:49.250
And also to actually let you
know what you do tend to update

14
00:00:49.250 --> 00:00:52.220
during the progress of a project as well.

15
00:00:52.220 --> 00:00:56.980
So let's go ahead and get started as
we take a look at Microsoft Project and

16
00:00:56.980 --> 00:00:59.550
of course updating the progress itself.

17
00:00:59.550 --> 00:01:01.770
So on my computer, I went ahead and

18
00:01:01.770 --> 00:01:06.080
brought up a project plan that we've been
working with throughout the course here.

19
00:01:06.080 --> 00:01:10.908
So as we get started, we wanna take a look
at some of the different methods that we

20
00:01:10.908 --> 00:01:13.156
can use to update a project plan too.

21
00:01:13.156 --> 00:01:16.930
Now when we start talking about updating,
well what are we normally updating?

22
00:01:16.930 --> 00:01:18.990
Well remember that now
that we have our task,

23
00:01:18.990 --> 00:01:23.810
in other words what we need to do,
we now have the people assigned to it, so

24
00:01:23.810 --> 00:01:27.200
that we actually know who's gonna
be working on that particular task.

25
00:01:27.200 --> 00:01:32.530
Well, we need to now begin to account for,
well, as time is beginning to work on,

26
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:35.920
how much of that task that
they're actually completing.

27
00:01:35.920 --> 00:01:37.060
Now it's fairly easy,

28
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:39.870
you can do a couple of different
things to help you out here, right?

29
00:01:39.870 --> 00:01:41.590
Since we don't have
anything in there already,

30
00:01:41.590 --> 00:01:43.680
we can just mark the task
as being 100% complete.

31
00:01:44.880 --> 00:01:48.220
And if we do that we're saying, hey,
all of it's done we're accounting for it.

32
00:01:48.220 --> 00:01:50.880
And we're gonna do that right now,
and that's perfectly fine.

33
00:01:50.880 --> 00:01:53.908
But the reality is that
that's not always the truth.

34
00:01:53.908 --> 00:01:57.450
And right then at that moment, that's
when you're needing to give a report.

35
00:01:57.450 --> 00:02:01.280
If you actually need to know what
the progress of your project is gonna be,

36
00:02:01.280 --> 00:02:04.500
well then you're not actually
giving an accurate progress report.

37
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:07.920
So what we wanna do is we want to take you
through what is it that we actually need

38
00:02:07.920 --> 00:02:12.290
to update and how do we actually do
that inside of Microsoft Project itself?

39
00:02:12.290 --> 00:02:13.810
Of course, like anything else,

40
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:17.190
Microsoft gives you a thousand
ways to give yourself a paper cut.

41
00:02:17.190 --> 00:02:20.020
And here inside a project it is
no different when it comes to

42
00:02:20.020 --> 00:02:22.970
updating progress inside of our project.

43
00:02:22.970 --> 00:02:24.668
They give you so many different ways,

44
00:02:24.668 --> 00:02:28.240
it's hard to know which way is actually
the way that you should do it.

45
00:02:28.240 --> 00:02:31.700
So it comes down to your preference
as to what it actually comes down to,

46
00:02:31.700 --> 00:02:33.965
when we first begin to take a look here.

47
00:02:33.965 --> 00:02:36.750
So let me give you an example
of what I'm talking about.

48
00:02:36.750 --> 00:02:39.050
So I've just selected one of these tasks.

49
00:02:39.050 --> 00:02:41.660
Let's say that we've already gone
through the testing phase, and

50
00:02:41.660 --> 00:02:44.990
we are now in the midst of
our deploying phase here.

51
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:47.430
There's a couple of things
that you might need to do.

52
00:02:47.430 --> 00:02:50.410
So let's go ahead and
take a look at the first thing.

53
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:54.560
Even though it isn't actually for
our time period right now,

54
00:02:54.560 --> 00:02:58.970
we are actually a month away from
this project plan getting started.

55
00:02:58.970 --> 00:03:01.570
But let's say that I was
beginning to track it already.

56
00:03:01.570 --> 00:03:04.400
In other words,
let's say we're already there at

57
00:03:04.400 --> 00:03:09.770
the 20th of August,
to actually get started.

58
00:03:09.770 --> 00:03:13.190
Well if I go ahead and
start entering in information right now,

59
00:03:13.190 --> 00:03:16.190
well today's date is actually
about a month before that.

60
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:20.001
So the progress is not gonna actually seem
like what it needs to in the reality of

61
00:03:20.001 --> 00:03:21.195
what we're tracking.

62
00:03:21.195 --> 00:03:27.130
So if I can go up to Project and
I can go to Project Information.

63
00:03:27.130 --> 00:03:29.100
Inside of my Project Information for

64
00:03:29.100 --> 00:03:33.770
my Project Plan,
I wanna actually change the current date.

65
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:38.700
If I thought that I was actually now,
let's say a couple of days into it.

66
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:43.400
So let's say that I should go to
August 2015 and instead of it actually

67
00:03:43.400 --> 00:03:48.190
being the 20th, let's say it is
the 24th at this point in time instead.

68
00:03:48.190 --> 00:03:49.540
And I click OK.

69
00:03:49.540 --> 00:03:52.870
And it doesn't actually look
like it makes any change at all.

70
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:54.840
But it's right there that
what I'm actually saying is,

71
00:03:54.840 --> 00:03:59.020
I've now gotten some information and
I need to begin updating my progress.

72
00:03:59.020 --> 00:04:02.110
And so I'm actually looking
back in four days of time, and

73
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:04.230
what can actually happen from that point.

74
00:04:04.230 --> 00:04:07.358
So we can update the very current date
that we're on to actually say hey,

75
00:04:07.358 --> 00:04:10.150
here's when we're actually
making this report from instead.

76
00:04:10.150 --> 00:04:13.687
And that way we can model that,
as well as we take a look at.

77
00:04:13.687 --> 00:04:18.458
So once I have that locked in as
far as the current start date, or

78
00:04:18.458 --> 00:04:19.908
the current date.

79
00:04:19.908 --> 00:04:24.430
Well, what I want to do then is
I wanna update this one task.

80
00:04:24.430 --> 00:04:29.420
Well, the easiest way to update a single
task is normally by the default update

81
00:04:29.420 --> 00:04:31.308
which is what we call percentage complete.

82
00:04:31.308 --> 00:04:35.780
If I right-click on that task,
I can go down to Information.

83
00:04:36.860 --> 00:04:42.840
And, inside of that task information
dialogue box, if I select the Advanced

84
00:04:42.840 --> 00:04:46.560
tab, you can see where it talks
about an earned value method.

85
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:51.226
The earned value method is actually
the idea here of a ratio of what was

86
00:04:51.226 --> 00:04:54.051
scheduled versus what is now completed.

87
00:04:54.051 --> 00:04:56.800
And that's why it shows up
as a percentage completed.

88
00:04:56.800 --> 00:05:00.820
Now you can also have a physical
percent complete as well,

89
00:05:00.820 --> 00:05:02.620
which shows up as work hours instead.

90
00:05:02.620 --> 00:05:07.520
So this one is actually doing it based
off of durations when we take a look

91
00:05:07.520 --> 00:05:09.700
at the task information.

92
00:05:09.700 --> 00:05:14.471
So even though I set that up, it doesn't
look like right here inside of this

93
00:05:14.471 --> 00:05:17.890
particular view that I
can actually see a lot.

94
00:05:17.890 --> 00:05:20.660
But notice I can update it if I wanted to.

95
00:05:20.660 --> 00:05:25.800
So right here on the General tab, you
can see where it says Percent complete.

96
00:05:25.800 --> 00:05:30.520
So if I wanted to I could say at this
point here on the three day task.

97
00:05:30.520 --> 00:05:34.060
Let's say it's two days into it, and
what I can do is I can scroll up and

98
00:05:34.060 --> 00:05:36.490
it does it by 5% at a time.

99
00:05:36.490 --> 00:05:39.920
I can say,
let's say it's 65% complete at this point.

100
00:05:39.920 --> 00:05:42.170
I can go ahead and click OK.

101
00:05:42.170 --> 00:05:43.100
And now when I take a look,

102
00:05:43.100 --> 00:05:45.390
you're like, Ronnie that's not
actually fairly impressive.

103
00:05:45.390 --> 00:05:49.020
And it really isn't that
impressive right now visually.

104
00:05:49.020 --> 00:05:54.070
But if I go to my scroll to task, I will
begin to see a visual difference here.

105
00:05:54.070 --> 00:05:58.660
So you can see right now, that as you
take a look at the Gant chart view,

106
00:05:58.660 --> 00:06:01.290
you can see of course the bar itself.

107
00:06:01.290 --> 00:06:05.120
And then that little blue bar
inside is actually what is now our

108
00:06:05.120 --> 00:06:06.980
progress line inside.

109
00:06:06.980 --> 00:06:09.870
And we can see that just
visually right now.

110
00:06:09.870 --> 00:06:11.590
It tells us when it's actually started and

111
00:06:11.590 --> 00:06:15.040
when it's actually supposed to be
completed, which is through the 21st.

112
00:06:16.400 --> 00:06:19.530
And then, if I hover over that
tiny blue line I can see at this

113
00:06:19.530 --> 00:06:21.679
point it's 65% complete.

114
00:06:21.679 --> 00:06:25.340
So that's one way where we
can do that fairly quickly.

115
00:06:25.340 --> 00:06:28.634
If I wanted to be that detailed
as far as the 60% complete.

116
00:06:28.634 --> 00:06:30.980
Now I'm gonna change that number, instead.

117
00:06:30.980 --> 00:06:35.270
Let me go back in and
just get rid of that right now.

118
00:06:35.270 --> 00:06:38.720
And show you another method
that you can also use, too.

119
00:06:38.720 --> 00:06:40.170
Usually, if you're actually in a hurry,
and

120
00:06:40.170 --> 00:06:42.860
you're just trying to get
some rough numbers in there.

121
00:06:42.860 --> 00:06:48.793
Normally we actually start seeing that
project has some default numbers that we

122
00:06:48.793 --> 00:06:54.920
can use which is 0, 25%, 50%,
75%, and 100% complete instead.

123
00:06:54.920 --> 00:06:58.776
So inside of Project 2013,
if you're on the Task tab,

124
00:06:58.776 --> 00:07:04.730
in the scheduling grouping, notice that
there are also these percentages up here.

125
00:07:04.730 --> 00:07:09.050
And these are actually marking that
earned value in this completion as well.

126
00:07:09.050 --> 00:07:12.520
Remember that the blue bar that represents
what is scheduled to work on that

127
00:07:12.520 --> 00:07:13.740
particular task.

128
00:07:13.740 --> 00:07:16.960
So for us on that three day example,
it would be right here,

129
00:07:16.960 --> 00:07:18.260
that's the whole thing.

130
00:07:18.260 --> 00:07:22.160
And then it's a ratio versus
what has actually been completed

131
00:07:22.160 --> 00:07:23.630
when you take a look.

132
00:07:23.630 --> 00:07:27.020
So all I have to do if I actually
wanna use those is fairly simple.

133
00:07:27.020 --> 00:07:28.760
I just select the task, and

134
00:07:28.760 --> 00:07:32.530
then I can come in here and say,
oh, I'm 50% complete on that task.

135
00:07:32.530 --> 00:07:35.064
Or, and maybe 75% complete.

136
00:07:35.064 --> 00:07:37.560
And notice that it
actually adjusted it for

137
00:07:37.560 --> 00:07:40.480
me in its progress over
here on the blue bar.

138
00:07:40.480 --> 00:07:43.869
So, I can go ahead and
make estimates like that if I need to and

139
