356
00:21:04.610 --> 00:21:07.850
If I wanna do it just for
the selected task, I can do that.

357
00:21:07.850 --> 00:21:09.680
But for right now, that's all I wanna do.

358
00:21:09.680 --> 00:21:13.360
I don't actually have any of the other
work that's actually been unscheduled.

359
00:21:13.360 --> 00:21:18.790
And so you do wanna be careful,
right, if you are updating

360
00:21:18.790 --> 00:21:22.510
all your tasks at the same time, and you
do have tasks that are actually finishing,

361
00:21:22.510 --> 00:21:25.069
and they're just updating,
they're not completely finished, right,

362
00:21:25.069 --> 00:21:28.720
what could happen is when I actually
select for the entire project,

363
00:21:28.720 --> 00:21:32.220
that takes every one of those tasks
that we're actually updating and

364
00:21:32.220 --> 00:21:34.230
actually goes ahead and
moves them to that date.

365
00:21:34.230 --> 00:21:39.210
So instead, make sure I've selected
on a proper task and click OK, and

366
00:21:39.210 --> 00:21:44.590
when I do that, you can now see,
visually, actually you can't see it,

367
00:21:44.590 --> 00:21:48.520
let me see if I can move that over
a little bit more so that we can see this.

368
00:21:49.730 --> 00:21:54.210
Over here on task number 19, you can see
where part of the work was actually done,

369
00:21:54.210 --> 00:21:56.610
here, which is what we
wanted to account for.

370
00:21:56.610 --> 00:22:00.530
And then instead of actually paying for
all this time in the middle by extending

371
00:22:00.530 --> 00:22:05.700
out the duration of that task,
instead we reschedule the other

372
00:22:05.700 --> 00:22:10.770
part of that work to be done over here,
let's say on the eighth instead.

373
00:22:10.770 --> 00:22:13.440
So, it's something that you actually do,
and

374
00:22:13.440 --> 00:22:16.550
you can actually account for
when things happen, right?

375
00:22:16.550 --> 00:22:20.480
Work does get interrupted plenty of times,
and you just have to actually

376
00:22:20.480 --> 00:22:23.830
be able account for it instead of just
going, oh, let me extend that task out.

377
00:22:23.830 --> 00:22:27.870
And that begins to blow your budget
a little bit more out of water as well.

378
00:22:27.870 --> 00:22:32.390
So there are multiple things that
we can actually do to update our

379
00:22:32.390 --> 00:22:34.160
progress here, too.

380
00:22:34.160 --> 00:22:37.950
Now, we've got a little bit of time here,
we also wanna go ahead and take a look at

381
00:22:37.950 --> 00:22:42.070
just a couple of other options that
are also available to us too, okay.

382
00:22:42.070 --> 00:22:46.910
So if I go back to Project Information,
notice that I also

383
00:22:49.350 --> 00:22:52.950
can change the status date as well.

384
00:22:52.950 --> 00:22:58.500
If you know that your project's gonna
be happening over a series of time and

385
00:22:58.500 --> 00:23:02.790
events, months, weeks, years,
whatever it might be, you might go ahead

386
00:23:02.790 --> 00:23:06.940
every week and set up when you actually
want this status update to happen.

387
00:23:06.940 --> 00:23:11.380
So that way, it will actually go ahead and
begin to track that too, about when you

388
00:23:11.380 --> 00:23:15.200
wanna set the next status date up so that
you can update your progress plan as well.

389
00:23:15.200 --> 00:23:19.210
And so that gives you that ability to
have a little reminder there that, hey,

390
00:23:19.210 --> 00:23:21.500
it's time for a status update.

391
00:23:21.500 --> 00:23:24.280
And when you're actually doing this for
an individual task, this is doing it for

392
00:23:24.280 --> 00:23:25.700
the overall project.

393
00:23:25.700 --> 00:23:29.420
That way you know that you're checking
in with all the people that's working on

394
00:23:29.420 --> 00:23:31.710
your project, and
be able to get the update.

395
00:23:31.710 --> 00:23:33.200
So you might choose to set that up for

396
00:23:33.200 --> 00:23:36.310
the, well,
let's say it's the 31st here as well, and

397
00:23:36.310 --> 00:23:39.870
that way you know that a new project
status date is also coming up soon.

398
00:23:39.870 --> 00:23:44.460
And so, once you do that, you can
actually select that date, no big deal.

399
00:23:44.460 --> 00:23:47.730
It gives you now a reminder
a little bit later on

400
00:23:47.730 --> 00:23:51.650
that you will also have an update
that's also coming up for you, too.

401
00:23:51.650 --> 00:23:54.290
So that's what you're also able to do.

402
00:23:54.290 --> 00:23:58.200
So there's a lot of different ways
that you and I can take a single task,

403
00:23:58.200 --> 00:24:02.260
as well as the entire project,
and begin to update those tasks.

404
00:24:02.260 --> 00:24:06.580
Taking a look at some of the different
views that you have available to you

405
00:24:06.580 --> 00:24:11.190
under the tables, especially using
that tracking table, is another one.

406
00:24:11.190 --> 00:24:14.070
Remember, you don't have to fill
in every thing that you have.

407
00:24:14.070 --> 00:24:16.900
You really just need a couple
of pieces of information, and

408
00:24:16.900 --> 00:24:18.880
watch what ends up happening.

409
00:24:18.880 --> 00:24:21.970
Most of us probably are not gonna
do it by the percentage complete.

410
00:24:21.970 --> 00:24:23.830
Most of us,
we're actually managing it, right?

411
00:24:23.830 --> 00:24:28.100
We're actually saying, how many hours did
you spend, Ronnie, working on a task?

412
00:24:28.100 --> 00:24:31.830
And then we can put that in there, and
the rest of it will begin to fill in for

413
00:24:31.830 --> 00:24:32.630
us if we need to.

414
00:24:33.640 --> 00:24:37.140
So there's a lot of ways
that you can use Project to

415
00:24:37.140 --> 00:24:41.515
really help you to begin to track
the way that your progress is going.

416
00:24:41.515 --> 00:24:46.845
And from there, you can now actually see
that progress is starting to happen,

417
00:24:46.845 --> 00:24:49.325
and you can start seeing where
you're falling behind or

418
00:24:49.325 --> 00:24:52.445
your schedule or
you're spending too much money already or

419
00:24:52.445 --> 00:24:56.440
where you actually may actually be able
to add in additional resources as well.

420
00:24:56.440 --> 00:24:58.730
That's all that we have for
Microsoft Project today.

421
00:24:58.730 --> 00:25:00.180
Thank you for joining us.

422
00:25:00.180 --> 00:25:02.482
I'm Ronnie Wong signing off for ITProTV.

423
00:25:02.482 --> 00:25:08.020
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie talks about he need to track variance within the Project Plan.  Once a baseline is stored, you begin to track progress and variance is created.  Changes to the plan not only needs to be updated but seed a variance to the original plan.  Here we see the date, work an cost variance so that good decisions can be made to keep the project on schedule.
episodes.title: Baseline Variances
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.050 --> 00:00:13.621
All right, welcome to another
exciting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.621 --> 00:00:17.150
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and
today we'll be taking a look at

4
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:20.800
Microsoft Project,
specifically with working with variances.

5
00:00:20.800 --> 00:00:25.030
So when we take a look at variances
in our Microsoft project plan,

6
00:00:25.030 --> 00:00:29.250
what we want to be able to do, of course,
is be able to see where our progress

7
00:00:29.250 --> 00:00:34.220
inside of our project plan is beginning
to diverge from the original base line.

8
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:36.400
When you take a base line
inside of Microsoft Project,

9
00:00:36.400 --> 00:00:40.470
it normally happens after you get all
the information entered in that you want

10
00:00:40.470 --> 00:00:42.820
the task you're actually going to work on,

11
00:00:42.820 --> 00:00:47.400
the resources you need to work on those
tasks, as well as their material or

12
00:00:47.400 --> 00:00:51.700
they're work related or they're cost
resources and then we want to assign them.

13
00:00:51.700 --> 00:00:56.230
Taking a task and assigning resources
to it is going to begin to show us

14
00:00:56.230 --> 00:01:00.190
how much each task is going to cost and
how long it may take for

15
00:01:00.190 --> 00:01:02.850
that task to finish and complete as well.

16
00:01:02.850 --> 00:01:05.630
Well, once we have everything in place and

17
00:01:05.630 --> 00:01:09.950
we believe that is our perfect project
plan, as close as we're going to get to

18
00:01:09.950 --> 00:01:14.060
perfection, then what we're going
to do is take that baseline.

19
00:01:14.060 --> 00:01:18.520
A baseline is essentially a snapshot
of the entire project plan.

20
00:01:18.520 --> 00:01:22.630
It normally helps us to ensure that we
can historically keep track of the finish

21
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:25.980
date, as well as the start date
inside of Microsoft Project,

22
00:01:25.980 --> 00:01:28.780
it keeps track of work information for us.

23
00:01:28.780 --> 00:01:32.760
It keeps track of resource information,
task information as well, so

24
00:01:32.760 --> 00:01:36.980
that if we ever need to, we can then
take all those pieces of information and

25
00:01:36.980 --> 00:01:40.390
use them to build and compare against,
and that way we can know whether or

26
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:43.200
not our current project plan is actually

27
00:01:43.200 --> 00:01:48.400
on schedule in the way that we think that
it is based on time as well as on cost.

28
00:01:48.400 --> 00:01:52.580
Or whether we're beginning to
slip behind in those tasks too.

29
00:01:52.580 --> 00:01:56.340
So that is what we want to start off with
when we take a look at actually trying to

30
00:01:56.340 --> 00:01:57.670
work with variances.

31
00:01:57.670 --> 00:02:01.445
Variances allow us then to see
when we are actually moving away

32
00:02:01.445 --> 00:02:06.035
from that original baseline, and that
happens over time, as well as account for

33
00:02:06.035 --> 00:02:09.885
things we just can't account for
at the time we took the original baseline.

34
00:02:09.885 --> 00:02:12.565
So that's where everything
really does begin for us.

35
00:02:12.565 --> 00:02:14.195
And we want to be able to mark that and

36
00:02:14.195 --> 00:02:17.835
understand that it didn't happen
inside the original project plan, but

37
00:02:17.835 --> 00:02:21.625
as we started seeing more progress, that
we are able to see and keep track of those

38
00:02:21.625 --> 00:02:25.910
changes, know when they happen and even
how much they're gonna end up costing.

39
00:02:25.910 --> 00:02:29.370
So let's show you how to do that
inside of Microsoft Project.

40
00:02:29.370 --> 00:02:33.100
So when we take a look at Microsoft
Project, let's go ahead and kind of give

41
00:02:33.100 --> 00:02:35.790
an example of some of the different things
that we're going to go ahead and do.

42
00:02:35.790 --> 00:02:39.690
So let's say that this project plan is
just about complete and everything that we

43
00:02:39.690 --> 00:02:43.540
actually need, but there is just a couple
of things that I have left to do.

44
00:02:43.540 --> 00:02:48.480
So, let me go down here to task 3.1,
uninstalling premise cabling.

45
00:02:48.480 --> 00:02:51.520
And if I go ahead and
take a look at that one task,

46
00:02:51.520 --> 00:02:55.600
you can see that I've added in some
resources, but I forgot to add in

47
00:02:55.600 --> 00:02:59.780
some of the important things like
the material resource, such as my cabling.

48
00:02:59.780 --> 00:03:04.020
So if I click on that drop down I can
select plenum cable to run inside,

49
00:03:04.020 --> 00:03:06.560
of course, the walls and
the false ceilings here.

50
00:03:06.560 --> 00:03:10.660
And let's say that I believe it's
gonna actually take about 750 feet

51
00:03:10.660 --> 00:03:15.720
of that cabling to be able to do that,
and so I'll go ahead and click okay.

52
00:03:15.720 --> 00:03:20.110
So if now I'm just about complete and I
believe that now my project plan is ready

53
00:03:20.110 --> 00:03:26.570
to proceed forward, I'm gonna use this now
to track and to start managing my project.

54
00:03:26.570 --> 00:03:30.500
I want to click on project and
then, under the schedule grouping,

55
00:03:30.500 --> 00:03:33.650
I want to select Set Baseline.

56
00:03:33.650 --> 00:03:35.510
When I click on Set Baseline,

57
00:03:35.510 --> 00:03:39.960
now it's gonna save all that project
plan information for me as a snapshot.

58
00:03:39.960 --> 00:03:44.070
It's just like looking back on a regular
snapshot that you're comparing now,

59
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:47.530
what's gonna happen from this point
on to that original snapshot.

60
00:03:47.530 --> 00:03:51.470
Remember that Project actually allows you
to take up to 11 different baselines.

61
00:03:51.470 --> 00:03:54.580
And if you wanna take a look at setting
up those different baselines, we do have

62
00:03:54.580 --> 00:03:58.480
another complete episode there that
you can take a look on how to do that.

63
00:03:58.480 --> 00:04:00.740
But it's fairly simple,
you see it's just a couple of clicks and

64
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:02.270
you're now ready to go.

65
00:04:02.270 --> 00:04:04.340
So now my project plan is ready.

66
00:04:04.340 --> 00:04:09.360
If I click on project information and
I select statistics, the way I know that

67
00:04:09.360 --> 00:04:14.600
I've actually got a baseline stored is
right here in the second row as you see.

68
00:04:14.600 --> 00:04:15.560
Where it says baseline,

69
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:19.040
you actually see both of those
rows has the word baseline in it.

70
00:04:19.040 --> 00:04:20.500
If I had not yet set a base line,

71
00:04:20.500 --> 00:04:25.530
you'd probably see N/A in each of these
columns in the row that says base line.

72
00:04:25.530 --> 00:04:28.910
And, notice that the actual cost
essentially are identical and

73
00:04:28.910 --> 00:04:32.380
that's because I just took that and it's
actually compared against the current.

74
00:04:32.380 --> 00:04:35.700
Current is now actually saying, hey,
this is what I'm ready to do and

75
00:04:35.700 --> 00:04:37.630
it'll actually begin to adjust.

76
00:04:37.630 --> 00:04:41.970
Whereas the baseline costs probably
will not actually adjust for us.

77
00:04:41.970 --> 00:04:45.240
So just kinda remember that that's where
you actually see if you actually have

78
00:04:45.240 --> 00:04:47.660
correctly set a baseline for you.

79
00:04:47.660 --> 00:04:52.160
So as we start now to track and
monitor progress, what we

80
00:04:52.160 --> 00:04:56.280
should see in this box then is that
that current line will begin to change.

81
00:04:56.280 --> 00:05:00.810
Whether it's in duration or the amount of
work, or the cost, that's the number that

82
00:05:00.810 --> 00:05:03.410
should change whereas the original
baseline cost should not.

83
00:05:03.410 --> 00:05:07.525
And you'll see also actual
start to change as well.

84
00:05:07.525 --> 00:05:09.920
So let me show you an example
of what we're talking about and

85
00:05:09.920 --> 00:05:11.828
then we'll come back to this and see it.

86
00:05:11.828 --> 00:05:15.050
So I'm gonna remain on this
task to kind of show an example

87
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:17.200
of what can begin to happen.

88
00:05:17.200 --> 00:05:22.310
So right now on task 3.1, I have
single task that lasts three days, and

89
00:05:22.310 --> 00:05:24.010
I've got 72 hours of work scheduled.

90
00:05:24.010 --> 00:05:26.210
You're probably like why
is it 72 hours of work?

91
00:05:26.210 --> 00:05:28.810
Well, I've got a few different
resources assigned here, right?

92
00:05:28.810 --> 00:05:33.365
I've got the infrastructure tech, the
support tech, and the network technician

93
00:05:33.365 --> 00:05:36.625
running these cables to be able
to do stuff like this, right?

94
00:05:36.625 --> 00:05:38.575
So when you add them up over three days,

95
00:05:38.575 --> 00:05:41.375
each one of them is essentially
an eight hour day, right?

96
00:05:41.375 --> 00:05:43.935
So they'll actually add
in 24 hours times three.

97
00:05:43.935 --> 00:05:45.475
That's where you get those 72 hours.

98
00:05:45.475 --> 00:05:47.133
Now that's unrealistic, but

99
00:05:47.133 --> 00:05:50.520
just bear with me in this example
as you take a look at it, okay?

100
00:05:50.520 --> 00:05:54.464
So we have those resources that
are actually there and available to us.

101
00:05:54.464 --> 00:06:00.003
And let's say that they finish
that task on time and on schedule.

102
00:06:00.003 --> 00:06:04.728
So I'm going to click on task and I'm just
going to mark it as being 100% complete.

103
00:06:04.728 --> 00:06:09.035
Now, when I select that, let me go back
to Project and Project Information for

104
00:06:09.035 --> 00:06:11.500
a moment and click on Statistics.

105
00:06:11.500 --> 00:06:14.850
And now you can start seeing
a couple of different things.

106
00:06:14.850 --> 00:06:16.440
Now I could have marked a little bit more,
but

107
00:06:16.440 --> 00:06:20.060
what we're looking at here is
actually the actual line as well.

108
00:06:20.060 --> 00:06:25.140
So as I begin to start to do stuff,
so we're actually now

109
00:06:25.140 --> 00:06:30.290
entering in progress information,
the actual line will begin to fill in.

110
00:06:30.290 --> 00:06:35.220
And you can see, there it is,
it took 1.7 days, 72 hours of work.

111
00:06:35.220 --> 00:06:37.670
Here is the overall cost that we had

112
00:06:37.670 --> 00:06:40.785
in everything is based on
our perfect calculation.

113
00:06:40.785 --> 00:06:46.910
100% everything that has gone there
including the amount of material we spent.

114
00:06:46.910 --> 00:06:52.850
Right click and go on task information and
then I select resources here.

115
00:06:52.850 --> 00:06:57.090
Notice there is 750 feet and
it cost me an additional $82.50.

116
00:06:57.090 --> 00:07:01.480
Perfectly fine, we are more than happy
to actually account for that, okay.

117
00:07:01.480 --> 00:07:05.890
So once we've got that done, that should
be it, we should be fine and ready to go.

118
00:07:05.890 --> 00:07:08.790
But let's say that what
we actually get now

119
00:07:08.790 --> 00:07:11.710
is that now that we've entered in that
it's actually completed, somebody said,

120
00:07:11.710 --> 00:07:14.810
hey it's all done,
then they come back and go, oh,

121
00:07:14.810 --> 00:07:20.530
by the way, we used a lot more cable
than we thought we were going to use.

122
00:07:20.530 --> 00:07:23.520
So, we need to also account for that.

123
00:07:23.520 --> 00:07:27.640
So all I have to do to do that is
I can right-click on that task and

124
00:07:27.640 --> 00:07:29.510
go to information, and

125
00:07:29.510 --> 00:07:33.910
in that same place where it says
resources, I can simply update this.

126
00:07:33.910 --> 00:07:36.300
So of course I say, hey,
how much more did we use?

127
00:07:36.300 --> 00:07:39.500
Well we used about let's
say 825 feet instead.

128
00:07:40.560 --> 00:07:44.280
I go ahead and click okay and
now it's been updated.

129
00:07:44.280 --> 00:07:47.170
Okay, so now that that's
actually been updated here,

130
00:07:47.170 --> 00:07:51.980
let's see if that makes any change inside
our project information in statistics.

131
00:07:51.980 --> 00:07:55.980
And now you can start to see it actually
added in a little bit more money.

132
00:07:55.980 --> 00:07:57.877
But overall though, everything is fine.

133
00:07:57.877 --> 00:08:02.813
Notice did not change the overall duration
and the variance that we're tracking here,

134
00:08:02.813 --> 00:08:06.627
but it did actually vary my project Right,
I could've added it in.

135
00:08:06.627 --> 00:08:10.602
And if I actually accounted for
it right then and there and I don't

136
00:08:10.602 --> 00:08:15.442
do anything else, I don't know if at the
very beginning if you were to go back and

137
00:08:15.442 --> 00:08:20.900
ask me about task 3.1, well, how much did
we spend and when did it actually occur?

138
00:08:20.900 --> 00:08:23.910
Well, I can tell you
that we used 825 feet.

139
00:08:23.910 --> 00:08:27.860
But if I didn't know what the original
footage was that I assigned for it, well

140
00:08:27.860 --> 00:08:31.330
now I just kind of assume that this is
the way it's been from the very beginning.

141
00:08:31.330 --> 00:08:35.804
I might be able to check the Notes tab,
and I might have actually put in

142
00:08:35.804 --> 00:08:40.434
a note here that said originally on
the baseline it was 750 feet, and

143
00:08:40.434 --> 00:08:42.842
now it's 825 feet if I wanted to.

144
00:08:42.842 --> 00:08:45.633
And that might be something that's there,
but it may not.

145
00:08:45.633 --> 00:08:48.125
Or I could do it while I'm

variances that I need to and

367
00:21:47.160 --> 00:21:50.530
then get everything back on track
the way that I want to as well.

368
00:21:50.530 --> 00:21:54.320
So inside of Microsoft Project
there are a ton

369
00:21:54.320 --> 00:21:58.880
of different ways that we can track
the cost scheduling and the variances.

370
00:21:58.880 --> 00:22:01.914
We can track of course the word
appearances as well as the date

371
00:22:01.914 --> 00:22:03.500
variances as well.

372
00:22:03.500 --> 00:22:07.680
So being able to see all that makes you
a more effective project planner and

373
00:22:07.680 --> 00:22:11.670
allows you to be able to use Project
to it's fullest ability as you begin to

374
00:22:11.670 --> 00:22:16.720
track the progress and begin to see those
variances inside a Microsoft project.

375
00:22:16.720 --> 00:22:21.020
So by doing that, you become a better and
more effective project planner and

376
00:22:21.020 --> 00:22:25.550
that way you can actually use it as a tool
to help you out to be able to maintain

377
00:22:25.550 --> 00:22:27.380
the schedule of your project as well.

378
00:22:28.460 --> 00:22:32.520
And that finishes up our show on Microsoft
Project and working with variances.

379
00:22:32.520 --> 00:22:33.620
Thank you for watching.

380
00:22:33.620 --> 00:22:35.240
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

381
00:22:35.240 --> 00:22:39.105
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie demonstrates some of the tools that are built into Microsoft Project 2013 that alerts, identifies and even helps when scheduling issues appear.  Though these are built it, you may find them doing more than you want. So we also see the manual way to deal with overallocations.
episodes.title: Resolve Schedule Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.046 --> 00:00:15.140
All right, welcome to another
exciting episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.140 --> 00:00:16.660
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:16.660 --> 00:00:20.130
today, we'll be taking a look at
working with Microsoft Project.

5
00:00:20.130 --> 00:00:23.790
Specifically, dealing with some of
the different scheduling issues

6
00:00:23.790 --> 00:00:24.963
that can actually arise, and

7
00:00:24.963 --> 00:00:28.700
we're gonna actually be taking a look at
how Microsoft project helps us to identify

8
00:00:28.700 --> 00:00:33.650
those issues as well as to resolve some
of those issues if we run across them.

9
00:00:33.650 --> 00:00:35.790
That's what we want to take a look at and
do.

10
00:00:35.790 --> 00:00:40.256
To actually be able to say Microsoft gives
us the ability to actually work a little

11
00:00:40.256 --> 00:00:42.962
bit quicker if we take
advantage of those tools.

12
00:00:42.962 --> 00:00:46.247
Now, when we have scheduling
issues inside a Microsoft project,

13
00:00:46.247 --> 00:00:50.980
a lot of us if we've been working with
Microsoft Project were used to doing this.

14
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:54.990
Really by just some of the hints that it
gives us and then we manually go in and

15
00:00:54.990 --> 00:00:58.820
we adjust the scheduling options and
we adjust everything that we need to

16
00:00:58.820 --> 00:01:02.180
to make sure that we can actually
keep everything on track.

17
00:01:02.180 --> 00:01:05.560
That's what we'd really want to be able
to do is to make sure everything stays on

18
00:01:05.560 --> 00:01:06.570
track here.

19
00:01:06.570 --> 00:01:10.190
In the way that our project plan
actually says that they're supposed to.

20
00:01:10.190 --> 00:01:14.050
So when we start taking a look at
making sure that we're doing this,

21
00:01:14.050 --> 00:01:16.560
sometimes it's very difficult if
we're actually just beginning,

22
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:19.380
to actually figure out what's
happening on our project.

23
00:01:19.380 --> 00:01:21.130
And then, once we get used to that,

24
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:24.890
then actually figuring what happens when
some of these other indicators pop up, and

25
00:01:24.890 --> 00:01:27.850
then, that way, we actually can work
with them and see what's happening.

26
00:01:27.850 --> 00:01:30.830
Let me show you an example of
what we're talking about here.

27
00:01:30.830 --> 00:01:33.300
So, I've got my project plan pulled up.

28
00:01:33.300 --> 00:01:36.930
And, remember that what we have here is
a project plan that is now ready to go.

29
00:01:36.930 --> 00:01:41.050
If everything is actually set and
ready, then we're fine and

30
00:01:41.050 --> 00:01:42.670
we just continue to work with it.

31
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:47.510
But, let's say that we are right before
being able to take our snapshot of

32
00:01:47.510 --> 00:01:48.780
our project plan.

33
00:01:48.780 --> 00:01:52.150
In other words, we think everything's
actually set up the way that we want to.

34
00:01:52.150 --> 00:01:56.140
But before we do so, we're starting
to notice some of the issues, and

35
00:01:56.140 --> 00:01:59.800
what we're looking at now is actually
underneath this column right here, over to

36
00:01:59.800 --> 00:02:06.010
the far left hand side, to the left of
the task mode, which says indicators.

37
00:02:06.010 --> 00:02:11.160
Indicators are little icons that end up
showing up and if you take a look at them,

38
00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:15.000
there's actually many different types
of indicators that you can see.

39
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:16.570
The one that you're probably looking for,

40
00:02:16.570 --> 00:02:20.490
especially when we start dealing with
scheduling conflicts, it's usually due to

41
00:02:20.490 --> 00:02:25.050
the very fact that resources have
been over allocated a lot of times.

42
00:02:25.050 --> 00:02:28.620
When you start seeing stuff like that,
it actually is just a little red icon.

43
00:02:28.620 --> 00:02:30.100
It's supposed to be an individual person.

44
00:02:30.100 --> 00:02:31.890
And when you hover over it,

45
00:02:31.890 --> 00:02:34.880
it tells you that this task has
been over allocated resource.

46
00:02:34.880 --> 00:02:36.580
And then we can right click for options.

47
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:41.130
But notice that there are other indicators
as well that are trying to give us hints

48
00:02:41.130 --> 00:02:45.280
about why this task is well,
really doing what it's doing.

49
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:48.820
So you might actually find out
that as you start doing the auto

50
00:02:48.820 --> 00:02:51.800
scheduling of the project,
everything is working out.

51
00:02:51.800 --> 00:02:55.530
Until the point where you start
seeing a lot of different icons.

52
00:02:55.530 --> 00:02:58.290
And some of them are just static
pieces of information like what we

53
00:02:58.290 --> 00:02:59.770
find inside of notes.

54
00:02:59.770 --> 00:03:01.960
Inside of notes we might find the reason,

55
00:03:01.960 --> 00:03:06.405
the logical reason why this
task was set up the way it was.

56
00:03:06.405 --> 00:03:09.205
We might also see that
there's a task constraint

57
00:03:09.205 --> 00:03:13.345
to ensure that when Project is starting
up, it actually will work that way in

58
00:03:13.345 --> 00:03:17.305
the way that we've actually said it should
work and it's not auto adjusting to that.

59
00:03:17.305 --> 00:03:19.255
So we're essentially
setting that override.

60
00:03:19.255 --> 00:03:22.725
And we may also find out this has also
been assigned to a different calendar as

61
00:03:22.725 --> 00:03:26.405
well, or to a specific one, and then
whether or not there's over allocations.

62
00:03:26.405 --> 00:03:28.510
So there's plenty of that going on.

63
00:03:28.510 --> 00:03:30.650
Now on this project,
you might be wondering Ronnie,

64
00:03:30.650 --> 00:03:33.770
it looks like every other task
is actually over allocated.

65
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:36.970
That's because I have a small
set of work resources, and

66
00:03:36.970 --> 00:03:39.480
they're kind of assigned
to every single project.

67
00:03:39.480 --> 00:03:42.720
But let's show you how a work
resource gets over allocated.

68
00:03:42.720 --> 00:03:47.190
The easiest way to do that is I'm gonna
bring up a brand new project here.

69
00:03:47.190 --> 00:03:50.140
So that we can go ahead and
see it from scratch when we do that

70
00:03:50.140 --> 00:03:52.600
instead of one that I already
worked with at this point.

71
00:03:52.600 --> 00:03:58.850
So, I'm simply gonna make a very
generic project plan for us.

72
00:03:58.850 --> 00:04:00.797
And I'm gonna add in just
a few different tasks.

73
00:04:04.130 --> 00:04:07.190
And I'm gonna add in
durations here as well.

74
00:04:07.190 --> 00:04:10.280
23 days, that's a little bit
longer than I wanted to.

75
00:04:10.280 --> 00:04:13.495
Three, four days, perfectly fine so

76
00:04:13.495 --> 00:04:17.921
we now have a task in our
duration that we have setup.

77
00:04:17.921 --> 00:04:22.270
And then from that point I can go ahead
and set a different view here under

78
00:04:22.270 --> 00:04:26.910
Format I'm gonna do a project summary
task so that we can see that the overall

79
00:04:26.910 --> 00:04:31.540
duration for everything that we've
got set up right now is four days.

80
00:04:31.540 --> 00:04:34.580
Everything is starting on
the same day perfectly fine, but

81
00:04:34.580 --> 00:04:37.880
I don't have any resources set up for
these tasks yet.

82
00:04:37.880 --> 00:04:40.695
So, I need to go ahead and
also assign some different resources.

83
00:04:40.695 --> 00:04:46.260
I'm gonna click on Resource and then I'm
gonna select a resource pool that I have

84
00:04:46.260 --> 00:04:51.090
up and available for my company resources
and go ahead and add those in there.

85
00:04:51.090 --> 00:04:55.450
Now when I do that,
then I can use the dividing bar and

86
00:04:55.450 --> 00:04:58.640
under resource name for
task one, I can go ahead and

87
00:04:58.640 --> 00:05:02.070
start assigning some of the different
resources that I might have available.

88
00:05:02.070 --> 00:05:08.590
So this is not exactly anything that
I'm doing here overwhelmingly neatly so

89
00:05:08.590 --> 00:05:13.270
I'm going to select network technician and
support technician for the second one

90
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:19.860
and continue to do this all the way down
network technician, support technician.

91
00:05:19.860 --> 00:05:22.670
Even here, and then even this one, and

92
00:05:22.670 --> 00:05:27.900
do the same thing, Network Technician and
also the Support Technician as well, okay?

93
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:30.290
So if my project plans are all starting,

94
00:05:30.290 --> 00:05:33.900
let's say on the very same day,
which is today's date here.

95
00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:38.430
I can also use that little
dividing bar and drop on down.

96
00:05:38.430 --> 00:05:40.880
Notice that what happened
immediately is that,

97
00:05:40.880 --> 00:05:46.260
over here on the left hand side,
it went ahead and gave me an indication.

98
00:05:46.260 --> 00:05:50.000
Now, on this day,
on the start date of this project, and

99
00:05:50.000 --> 00:05:52.980
that would actually be following
this blue line right here,

100
00:05:52.980 --> 00:05:56.610
notice that a network technician has
actually been assigned all four of those.

101
00:05:56.610 --> 00:06:00.000
Now you and
I are used to looking at things linearly.

102
00:06:00.000 --> 00:06:03.610
And what that means is that what we're
seeing a lot of times in our mind is that

103
00:06:03.610 --> 00:06:06.850
Network Technician 1, well,
he's gonna do that one task and

104
00:06:06.850 --> 00:06:10.600
then he'll start the second task and
then he'll start the third task and

105
00:06:10.600 --> 00:06:12.370
then he'll start the fourth task.

106
00:06:12.370 --> 00:06:17.370
But the way that our project schedule is
showing up is that here on the Tuesday,

107
00:06:17.370 --> 00:06:19.260
the 21st, which is today.

108
00:06:19.260 --> 00:06:23.670
He's actually starting on all four
tasks really at the same time.

109
00:06:23.670 --> 00:06:26.900
And you can actually see that for
all four of those tasks.

110
00:06:26.900 --> 00:06:30.110
And when we do something like that, if
it's on the standard scheduled calendar,

111
00:06:30.110 --> 00:06:32.550
which this one is cuz I
didn't change the calendar,

112
00:06:32.550 --> 00:06:35.270
well that means he's gonna
work an eight hour day.

113
00:06:35.270 --> 00:06:39.903
And in theory he's gonna work eight hours
on task one, eight hours on task two,

114
00:06:39.903 --> 00:06:43.480
eight hours on task three,
eight hours on task four.

115
00:06:43.480 --> 00:06:46.650
So on that one day,
he's actually scheduled really for

116
00:06:46.650 --> 00:06:52.620
well 32 hours on a 24 hour day,
which is just about impossible.

117
00:06:52.620 --> 00:06:55.380
Unless you're traveling
back through time or

118
00:06:55.380 --> 00:06:57.580
you're part of Harry Potter or something.

119
00:06:57.580 --> 00:06:59.940
So, it's actually not
working this way right?

120
00:06:59.940 --> 00:07:03.340
But the good thing is Project
automatically saw this.

121
00:07:03.340 --> 00:07:05.880
And we can see what's actually happening.

122
00:07:05.880 --> 00:07:09.000
So even though you may not actually
look at it, if you're new to Project and

123
00:07:09.000 --> 00:07:10.580
you're like why is this happening?

124
00:07:10.580 --> 00:07:13.420
One of the good thing this
Project tries to help you out.

125
00:07:13.420 --> 00:07:16.940
So if I right click on let's
say one of these tasks,

126
00:07:16.940 --> 00:07:20.500
notice it also gives me a couple
of options here, right?

127
00:07:20.500 --> 00:07:23.840
So on an over allocation
of a specific resource,

128
00:07:23.840 --> 00:07:26.880
you really have just a couple
of things that you can do.

129
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:28.400
So, when you take a look at it,

130
00:07:28.400 --> 00:07:31.337
here are some of the manual
options that it's telling you.

131
00:07:31.337 --> 00:07:34.680
One It says reschedule
to an available date.

132
00:07:34.680 --> 00:07:36.260
On an over allocation,

133
00:07:36.260 --> 00:07:40.330
what would normally end up happening here
is that you move this particular task

134
00:07:40.330 --> 00:07:44.370
to a day where he is not actually
being scheduled on that same day.

135
00:07:44.370 --> 00:07:46.968
Let me show you what we can do manually.

136
00:07:46.968 --> 00:07:51.812
So, notice that all I really need to do is
let's take this one task here on task one

137
00:07:51.812 --> 00:07:52.823
and I can click.

138
00:07:52.823 --> 00:07:56.096
And let me drag it all the way over here,
let's say to, well, Monday.

139
00:07:56.096 --> 00:07:56.821
Okay?

140
00:07:56.821 --> 00:07:58.809
When I do something, oh,
I dragged it on Saturday.

141
00:07:58.809 --> 00:08:00.302
Let me do it a little bit further.

142
00:08:00.302 --> 00:08:01.220
There we go.

143
00:08:01.220 --> 00:08:03.550
When I dragged it to the Monday,
which is a working day,

144
00:08:03.550 --> 00:08:09.240
that's why we were still here, notice it
allows me to actually be able to do that.

145
00:08:09.240 --> 00:08:13.350
And when it does it, it automatically
now has removed that over allocation.

146
00:08:13.350 --> 00:08:16.600
But something I did even by accident
was actually kind of a good thing for

147
00:08:16.600 --> 00:08:18.040
us to also note.

148
00:08:18.040 --> 00:08:20.965
Every once in while,
when we are manually doing things and

149
00:08:20.965 --> 00:08:26.110
we're not paying attention, let's say that
I had absolutely thought I had assigned it

150
00:08:26.110 --> 00:08:31.160
to the right day and I contact the network
technician and I tell him that he is

151
00:08:31.160 --> 00:08:37.780
scheduled to work on July 25th, which
right here is actually a non working day.

152
00:08:37.780 --> 00:08:41.410
Well, notice the over allocation
shows up immediately, so

153
00:08:41.410 --> 00:08:43.190
it doesn't mean that I can't call and

154
00:08:43.190 --> 00:08:47.520
make a mistake, it means that project says
look, here reporting to this calendar.

155
00:08:47.520 --> 00:08:48.950
This is a non working day and

156
00:08:48.950 --> 00:08:53.490
you should not actually schedule that
resource to work on that day, so

157
00:08:53.490 --> 00:08:57.460
visually it gives us a nice little
indicator of what can be done.

158
00:08:57.460 --> 00:09:02.366
Now if I go back, let me put everything
back to the original date here.

159
00:09:05.440 --> 00:09:08.640
All the way back,
one day before that, let's do this.

160
00:09:10.160 --> 00:09:11.470
Oh, if it lets me move it.

161
00:09:11.470 --> 00:09:12.230
There we go.

162
00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:13.750
Took a little bit of time there.

163
00:09:13.750 --> 00:09:15.640
So if I move it back, I can do that.

164
00:09:15.640 --> 00:09:17.080
So I can manually do that.

165
00:09:17.080 --> 00:09:20.800
Now more than likely, you can do
that just using a view like this.

166
00:09:20.800 --> 00:09:21.350
Most of us,

167
00:09:21.350 --> 00:09:25.130
if we're going to be trying to manually
adjust the over allocations themselves,

168
00:09:25.130 --> 00:09:29.330
we instead are probably gonna end up using
that team planner view to do it instead.

169
00:09:29.330 --> 00:09:32.810
So that's a possible option that
you have available to you, and

170
00:09:32.810 --> 00:09:35.240
you'll actually now be
able to use it as a table.

171
00:09:35.240 --> 00:09:39.390
You'll actually be able to click and drag
those resources where you need them, and

172
00:09:39.390 --> 00:09:42.920
even be able to see if there's
any unassigned tasks as well.

173
00:09:42.920 --> 00:09:47.520
Now the other thing that we can also do to
help us prevent this over-allocation is

174
00:09:47.520 --> 00:09:48.040
simple.

175
00:09:48.040 --> 00:09:52.620
Notice that on this one day task,
because he's over-allocated,

176
00:09:52.620 --> 00:09:57.300
I might be able add in more resources
if this is an effort driven task.

177
00:09:57.300 --> 00:09:57.910
Okay?

178
00:09:57.910 --> 00:10:01.520
So on task number one, let me see
what happens here if I go ahead and

179
00:10:01.520 --> 00:10:04.310
assign an additional resource instead.

180
00:10:04.310 --> 00:10:08.930
So, I could possibly assign,
let's say the project manager here.

181
00:10:11.070 --> 00:10:15.266
And let me go ahead and assign another
one and see what happens as well.

182
00:10:15.266 --> 00:10:17.890
Let's see, let's do the Support Technician
and assign him too.

183
00:10:19.627 --> 00:10:23.007
And now, notice the even with
those three actually going on,

184
00:10:23.007 --> 00:10:26.050
well why didn't that actually change for
him?

185
00:10:26.050 --> 00:10:30.670
Well because according to this,
he's still assigned, well, 72 hours.

186
00:10:30.670 --> 00:10:33.460
So even though I added
in all of this stuff.

187
00:10:33.460 --> 00:10:38.040
Or he's assigned to not 72 hours,
32 hours over that same day, right?

188
00:10:38.040 --> 00:10:43.340
Adding in more resources sometimes can
help if you're dividing up that work.

189
00:10:43.340 --> 00:10:47.230
Now, you can also right
click on that task and

190
00:10:47.230 --> 00:10:51.240
go under resources and
actually change the units here.

191
00:10:51.240 --> 00:10:53.480
So let's say instead that
I changed him down to,

192
00:10:53.480 --> 00:10:58.265
let's say 25 oercent if
I can get him there.

193
00:10:58.265 --> 00:11:03.479
25 percent of his working time and then
I'd have to go to another task that day

194
00:11:03.479 --> 00:11:08.470
and also, let's say I assigned them
to 25 percent of that working time,

195
00:11:12.335 --> 00:11:14.725
And do the same thing for
those other two tasks.

196
00:11:16.725 --> 00:11:18.735
Let me see if I can get
that done quickly here.

197
00:11:19.815 --> 00:11:24.828
25 percent, and
let's do the same thing here.

198
00:11:27.182 --> 00:11:31.640
25% as well.

199
00:11:31.640 --> 00:11:35.310
And even though it actually is now showing
100 percent, in other words, two hours per

200
00:11:35.310 --> 00:11:38.530
task, there's a bunch of other things
that are also going on as well.

201
00:11:38.530 --> 00:11:42.940
So now if I take a look under
this task resource assignment,

202
00:11:42.940 --> 00:11:47.990
now if I hover over it, it's saying,
hey this task is still over allocated.

203
00:11:47.990 --> 00:11:49.280
If I right click and

204
00:11:49.280 --> 00:11:55.220
I select Fix in Task Inspector,
now we can start to see something.

205
00:11:55.220 --> 00:11:58.430
Well the reason why it actually
didn't work is because now

206
00:11:58.430 --> 00:12:02.690
the network technician is not the one
that's been over allocated here,

207
00:12:02.690 --> 00:12:07.550
what we start to see is that the resources
are allocated is the support tech.

208
00:12:07.550 --> 00:12:10.680
So sometimes you might see
issues like that that arrive for

209
00:12:10.680 --> 00:12:11.890
you to be able to do that.

210
00:12:11.890 --> 00:12:16.020
And here they show you a couple of
different options that you can also use.

211
00:12:16.020 --> 00:12:18.980
Notice that under the actions
you can reschedule the task.

212
00:12:18.980 --> 00:12:22.918
And that's what we're ready to talk about,
is to manually reschedule the task.

213
00:12:22.918 --> 00:12:27.690
We can re-assign the units of
allocation just like we did,

214
00:12:27.690 --> 00:12:29.800
if we're taking about manually doing it.

215
00:12:29.800 --> 00:12:34.300
We can also assign additional
resources as an effort driven task.

216
00:12:34.300 --> 00:12:38.230
Normally that time period then would
be split up among the three, and

217
00:12:38.230 --> 00:12:40.280
we can also do that as well.

218
00:12:40.280 --> 00:12:43.240
And the other thing that we can
do is just simply remove that

219
00:12:43.240 --> 00:12:46.890
one task if we needed to,
to just get it out of the picture.

220
00:12:46.890 --> 00:12:48.630
Now of course, that might not be up to us.

221
00:12:48.630 --> 00:12:52.100
In other words, if we're removing one of
the task requirements that may actually

222
00:12:52.100 --> 00:12:55.230
have to involve, of course, a medium
that says look, we really can't do that,

223
00:12:55.230 --> 00:12:58.190
we're over allocated and
this is the task I think we should remove.

224
00:12:58.190 --> 00:13:00.860
So you might actually have to go back
to your project stake holders to do

225
00:13:00.860 --> 00:13:02.200

226
00:13:02.200 --> 00:13:04.950
But, lets say that we're not
going to do any of that.

227
00:13:04.950 --> 00:13:09.420
So instead, the good thing is since
project does have this task inspector, and

00:13:09.420 --> 00:13:12.010
it's a really incredible tool here.

It tells me what do the two that I might
actually choose to go ahead and do.

00:13:15.680 --> 00:13:19.200
So it says we can move the resource
to the next available time.

231
00:13:19.200 --> 00:13:22.740
Let's see what happens if I do that and
see where project would put this task.

232
00:13:22.740 --> 00:13:23.470
So if I go ahead and

00:13:23.470 --> 00:13:28.370
reschedule that task, notice that he did
exactly what I would do, which is he

234
00:13:28.370 --> 00:13:32.640
moved that to the following week to go
ahead and get started there instead.

235
00:13:32.640 --> 00:13:34.530
So we could do something
like that as well.

236
00:13:34.530 --> 00:13:39.070
Now, notice that we also can go ahead and
auto schedule too and so

237
00:13:39.070 --> 00:13:43.090
it's telling us here's the best way to
start fixing stuff, so that that way it's

238
00:13:43.090 --> 00:13:47.260
starts to adjust it automatically if other
things start to happen to our schedule.

239
00:13:47.260 --> 00:13:50.910
So the task inspector is one of these
things that we can go ahead and

240
00:13:50.910 --> 00:13:54.000
take a look at to be able to do as well.

241
00:13:54.000 --> 00:13:57.830
Now once we start doing that and
we get everything in line here,

242
00:13:57.830 --> 00:13:59.830
well we still have to do
a couple of other things for

243
00:13:59.830 --> 00:14:02.210
our project to make
a little bit more sense.

244
00:14:02.210 --> 00:14:06.660
So I'm gonna select all four of
those tasks and link them together.

245
00:14:08.450 --> 00:14:12.890
When I do that notice that they
actually stop being over allocated.

246
00:14:12.890 --> 00:14:16.060
And once you start seeing stuff like that,

247
00:14:16.060 --> 00:14:20.190
now you can see if I can move this
scan bar over just a little bit here.

248
00:14:20.190 --> 00:14:23.140
You now start to see where
they're scheduled in a finish to

249
00:14:23.140 --> 00:14:25.890
start relationship which
is perfectly fine.

250
00:14:25.890 --> 00:14:29.010
And that's what we really want to see
a lot of times when we're actually having

251
00:14:29.010 --> 00:14:30.520
these tasks do what they need to do.

252
00:14:30.520 --> 00:14:34.990
Now if they have to be scheduled on the
same day then they have to, but remember,

253
00:14:34.990 --> 00:14:37.740
your resources may not actually
be able to spend all the time

254
00:14:37.740 --> 00:14:40.560
that you've devoted in your
project plan in doing that.

255
00:14:40.560 --> 00:14:43.830
So remember that, that when you start
dealing with over-allocations or

256
00:14:43.830 --> 00:14:46.600
resource issues that are gonna
cause scheduling issues here,

257
00:14:46.600 --> 00:14:50.280
you have to take a look and see whether or
not, even if you used a task inspector,

258
00:14:50.280 --> 00:14:53.990
whether or not that's going to actually
be appropriate to your schedule.

259
00:14:53.990 --> 00:14:57.910
Is this too far to push out for
four different tasks instead.

260
00:14:57.910 --> 00:15:01.860
And if it is, you actually have to figure
that out and what else you can do as well.

261
00:15:01.860 --> 00:15:03.550
So not only can we see that, but

262
00:15:03.550 --> 00:15:08.500
let's see what also happens then with
a task and what can be affected.

263
00:15:08.500 --> 00:15:13.430
So when we take a look at task number one,
this one task, and it's actually

264
00:15:13.430 --> 00:15:19.270
in this relationship, notice it affected
all the other tasks it ends up following.

265
00:15:19.270 --> 00:15:23.050
We might also want to see what
task directly effects this task.

266
00:15:23.050 --> 00:15:26.395
And that way we might find out that we
can actually do some adjustments up there

267
00:15:26.395 --> 00:15:27.935
in the over allocation.

268
00:15:27.935 --> 00:15:30.855
Assign different resources that would
shorten the task before that and

269
00:15:30.855 --> 00:15:35.045
allow this task to expand out the way
it needs to, or we may find out that

270
00:15:35.045 --> 00:15:38.685
if I don't do anything about this
task what's also gonna be effected.

271
00:15:38.685 --> 00:15:40.935
So, let's take a look at that as well.

272
00:15:40.935 --> 00:15:44.960
So let me go back to my
larger project plan here.

273
00:15:44.960 --> 00:15:47.496
I just wanted to show you some
of the ways that the ins and

274
00:15:47.496 --> 00:15:50.546
outs actually work without affecting
my schedule too much here.

275
00:15:50.546 --> 00:15:55.988
So let's say that right here on
this installing the cubicles here.

276
00:15:55.988 --> 00:15:58.863
On this one task I want to see,

277
00:15:58.863 --> 00:16:04.506
What task is actually going
to be driving this one, okay?

278
00:16:04.506 --> 00:16:05.486
In other words,

279
00:16:05.486 --> 00:16:10.880
is there a preceding task that affects
the schedule of this task itself, okay?

280
00:16:10.880 --> 00:16:16.370
I also want to be able to see whether or
not this task itself and what

281
00:16:16.370 --> 00:16:20.560
are the other tasks that will be affected
by it if I change that schedule as well.

282
00:16:20.560 --> 00:16:22.730
Now, sometimes you don't wanna
do that inside a project.

283
00:16:22.730 --> 00:16:24.570
You just wanna see it, right?

284
00:16:24.570 --> 00:16:28.980
So, the good thing is,
inside a project, I can go to Project.

285
00:16:28.980 --> 00:16:30.170
Oh, it's not in Project, is it?

286
00:16:31.240 --> 00:16:31.750
Let me make sure.

287

Oh, Format.

00:16:32.440 --> 00:16:33.650
See, I always forget.

289
00:16:33.650 --> 00:16:35.710
So, it's actually under Format here.

290
00:16:35.710 --> 00:16:40.400
Under Format, what I'm looking for is
another utility that you find right here

291
00:16:40.400 --> 00:16:45.100
only really in Project 2013,
which is called the Task Path.

292
00:16:45.100 --> 00:16:48.830
And what this will do instead is it
will highlight those paths for us.

293
00:16:48.830 --> 00:16:50.295
So let me show you what I'm talking about.

294
00:16:50.295 --> 00:16:54.610
I've selected 3.5 on
the cubicle installation.

295
00:16:54.610 --> 00:16:56.360
Let me see, is that a good one to select?

296
00:16:56.360 --> 00:16:59.480
Let's do 3.1, because I already
have a constraint on that one.

297
00:16:59.480 --> 00:17:01.020
Actually, yeah, let's do that.

298
00:17:01.020 --> 00:17:02.810
Okay.
Now I'm gonna select Task.

299
00:17:02.810 --> 00:17:05.742
And then notice I can select Predecessors.

300
00:17:05.742 --> 00:17:09.390
And when I do that, it doesn't look like
it actually has been affected by anything.

301
00:17:09.390 --> 00:17:10.920
But it's not right there.

302
00:17:10.920 --> 00:17:12.510
It's under the Gantt chart.

303
00:17:12.510 --> 00:17:13.140
Right?

304
00:17:13.140 --> 00:17:18.520
So if I scroll the Gantt chart over,
you can now see that in yellow,

305
00:17:19.610 --> 00:17:22.830
here are all the tasks that did proceed

306
00:17:22.830 --> 00:17:27.730
that are also going to affect the start
date of this task as well, except for

307
00:17:27.730 --> 00:17:31.220
this little lag time that I
have adjusted right here.

308
00:17:31.220 --> 00:17:34.590
So it actually shows me
all those preceding tasks.

309
00:17:34.590 --> 00:17:39.450
So if I go ahead and select that again,
I can select Driving Predecessor, and

310
00:17:39.450 --> 00:17:40.610
notice if I select that, it says,

311
00:17:40.610 --> 00:17:43.840
Highlight predecessors that
directly affect the selected task.

312
00:17:43.840 --> 00:17:48.200
If I select that one, I actually don't see
that, cuz that was supposed to turn it

00:17:48.200 --> 00:17:51.710
into an orange one, so it doesn't
look like there was anything driving.

314
00:17:51.710 --> 00:17:54.440
And the reason why it's not a driving

00:17:54.440 --> 00:17:59.010
force right now is because
of that task constraint.

316
00:17:59.010 --> 00:18:02.180
So that constraint that actually let it
go over the weekend before it started is

317
00:18:02.180 --> 00:18:03.340
probably not gonna do that.

318
00:18:03.340 --> 00:18:06.710
But then I can see what

00:18:06.710 --> 00:18:11.940
So when I take a look here, by affecting
that one task in the cubicle installation,

00:18:11.940 --> 00:18:16.230
notice it affects all of the other
tasks that follow it down here as well.

321
00:18:16.230 --> 00:18:19.580
And notice that I'm not actually

322
00:18:19.580 --> 00:18:22.480
I'm not having to put it in

00:18:22.480 --> 00:18:24.950
I'm trying to see if I
were to adjust anything,

324
00:18:24.950 --> 00:18:28.200
what would actually be the one that
I want, and then driven successors.

325
00:18:28.200 --> 00:18:31.370
It shows me that, hey,
this one task actually affected

326
00:18:31.370 --> 00:18:35.280
the progress of all these other
tasks that are also available too.

327
00:18:35.280 --> 00:18:39.960
So there are a couple of different ways
that you can begin to take a look and

see that information

329
00:18:42.560 --> 00:18:45.380
And then, that way you can make
the decisions that you need to.

330
00:18:45.380 --> 00:18:49.920
So by being able to take a look at
some of the different indicators

331
00:18:49.920 --> 00:18:54.070
that you see over here in the indicator

00:18:56.580 --> 00:19:00.150
of the Task Inspector, which I can't

00:19:00.150 --> 00:19:03.800
the Task Inspector as

00:19:03.800 --> 00:19:08.380
you're able to use some of those tools to
show you how you can deal with some of

00:19:08.380 --> 00:19:11.480
those resource scheduling conflicts
that you may come up with.

336
00:19:11.480 --> 00:19:14.620
But usually,
most of us have been working with Project.

337
00:19:14.620 --> 00:19:18.630
Instead of relying on those tools,
it's a lot better at times to go ahead and

338
00:19:18.630 --> 00:19:21.770

339
00:19:21.770 --> 00:19:25.530
the information right in front of you, and
not just relying on those project tools.

340
00:19:25.530 --> 00:19:30.000
But they are there for you to be able to
work with, for you to take advantage of,

341
00:19:30.000 --> 00:19:33.550
so a lot of times if you actually are
trying to make a lot of those decisions,

342
00:19:33.550 --> 00:19:36.570
the Task Inspector will

343
00:19:36.570 --> 00:19:40.270
But remember, it's actually gonna use

344
00:19:40.270 --> 00:19:42.230
proper way to do what it needs to do.

345
00:19:42.230 --> 00:19:46.410
And sometimes in reality, right, we need
Project to actually show the way that

346
00:19:46.410 --> 00:19:48.930

347
00:19:48.930 --> 00:19:52.980
So take advantage of the tools,
but remember, rely on your

00:19:52.980 --> 00:19:57.940

349
00:19:57.940 --> 00:20:02.270
Well, that wraps it up for us for our
Microsoft Project and dealing with some of

350
00:20:02.270 --> 00:20:06.010
the different resource scheduling
conflicts that we may come up with.

351
00:20:06.010 --> 00:20:08.060
We're glad that you're actually
able to watch us today.

352
00:20:09.140 --> 00:20:12.342
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

353
00:20:12.342 --> 00:20:14.838
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie take a look at displaying critical path information. The critical path is the string of tasks linked together in which every task must finish on schedule if the project is to finish on schedule.  Displaying this can help a project manager to see where to best apply resources and see all the tasks he must manage if he is to have the scheduled finish date.
episodes.title: Display Critical Path
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.962
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.962 --> 00:00:13.210
Welcome to another exciting
episode here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:13.210 --> 00:00:14.470
I'm your host, Ronny Wong and

4
00:00:14.470 --> 00:00:18.840
today we'll be taking a look at
Microsoft Project, taking a look at being

5
00:00:18.840 --> 00:00:22.320
able to display what we call the critical

6
00:00:22.320 --> 00:00:26.650
When we take a look at displaying the

the project as it starts to go ahead and

00:00:31.015 --> 00:00:34.415

tasks that are in line.

That if we affect any one of those

10
00:00:37.975 --> 00:00:42.797

11
00:00:42.797 --> 00:00:45.757
So you can actually take
a look at doing this manually.

00:00:45.757 --> 00:00:51.117
And if you want to, make sure you head on

a look, and go ahead and manually show you

00:00:55.327 --> 00:00:58.387
But since you're working

you're working with this project

00:01:01.620 --> 00:01:05.920

if you will have all this stuff in here,

00:01:09.430 --> 00:01:10.170

It is actually inside of

00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:21.170
that if you affect the duration of
any one task inside of that path,

22
00:01:21.170 --> 00:01:24.700
it's gonna affect the overall

23
00:01:24.700 --> 00:01:29.260
So that gives you the ability, then, to
know that if you add in another resource

24
00:01:29.260 --> 00:01:33.680
along your project plan, is it really
gonna affect the duration or not?

25
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:36.590
So you want to be able to figure that out

26
00:01:36.590 --> 00:01:41.870

00:01:41.870 --> 00:01:44.640
so that you know that you're actually
adding in tasks where they're actually

00:01:44.640 --> 00:01:46.630
gonna give you the most bang for

29
00:01:46.630 --> 00:01:50.200
So we wanna be able to see how we can
see something like that, and of course

30

we wanna show you how you can actually
do that inside of Microsoft Project, so

31
00:01:53.340 --> 00:01:55.120
let's go ahead and take a look.

32
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:58.040
So I'm just using the same project that
I've been using throughout our series

00:01:58.040 --> 00:02:00.510
here, and taking a look at some

34
00:02:00.510 --> 00:02:03.630
Remember that when we talk about this
critical path and being able to see it, so

35
00:02:03.630 --> 00:02:07.080
that way we know where exactly we
want to assign those resources

36
00:02:07.080 --> 00:02:10.890
that should help us to make sure that
our project is actually on schedule and

37
00:02:10.890 --> 00:02:12.660

38
00:02:12.660 --> 00:02:15.670
So along our entire project we've
had those three phases, testing,

39
00:02:15.670 --> 00:02:18.770

then there's also the tuning phase, but

40
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:22.740
where is it that it's actually gonna be
most effective that if I need to try and

41
00:02:22.740 --> 00:02:26.190
shorten up the project plan itself, or if
something was actually starting to slip,

00:02:26.190 --> 00:02:28.540
I would actually start

00:02:28.540 --> 00:02:33.290
The easiest way to do that is by selecting

00:02:33.290 --> 00:02:38.770
and then under the bar styles
grouping click on the critical tasks.

00:02:38.770 --> 00:02:42.810
Once we do that if you hover over it,
it tells exactly what we need here.

46
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:45.720
All of the bars in the Gant chart
that are in this critical path

00:02:45.720 --> 00:02:47.190
is gonna show up as red.

48
00:02:47.190 --> 00:02:51.030
And then it also gives us a nice little

the project to finish on schedule as well.

50
00:02:56.920 --> 00:03:01.470
So if that task actually finishes late,

00:03:01.470 --> 00:03:04.120
again, extend out a little bit further.

52
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:06.780
So now if I scroll down and

00:03:06.780 --> 00:03:10.150
I'm gonna move this divider bar over so

00:03:10.150 --> 00:03:14.130
You can see where I have these

The red bar is the indication

So from here if we actually ended up,

So anything in here is actually going

But let's say that I come back up here

If I do that, now notice what also

00:04:18.990 --> 00:04:22.950
So if I adjust that back down to what I
had it, which was I think three days here.

70
00:04:24.520 --> 00:04:27.010
So we can increase the critical path and

71
00:04:27.010 --> 00:04:29.940
we can actually end up seeing
where we can remove some of those.

72
00:04:29.940 --> 00:04:33.150
A lot of times under the effort driven

00:04:33.150 --> 00:04:36.200
path, assigning more resources may help,

00:04:39.130 --> 00:04:43.520

sure that all of the tasks that you have

00:04:43.520 --> 00:04:47.310
ready to have go on that critical
path are going to finish on time.

77
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:51.550
Now every once in a while, you might be
wondering, how did we get to this point?

78
00:04:51.550 --> 00:04:54.240
Where did it happen that it
switched from here to here?

79
00:04:54.240 --> 00:04:57.000
And you might want to actually
figure out how you can do that.

80
00:04:57.000 --> 00:05:02.250
Well, up here, under the bar
stalls I can also select slack.

81
00:05:02.250 --> 00:05:05.620
And this way you can barely see it,
but right here let me go ahead and

82
00:05:05.620 --> 00:05:08.120
click on it again and
maybe we can actually see it as well.

83
00:05:08.120 --> 00:05:10.780
The blue bar actually doesn't
have anything under it, and

84
00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:16.900
now if I select slack it's right here
because of this delay, or this lag time,

85
00:05:16.900 --> 00:05:21.050
that we saw that pushed this portion
of my project into that critical path.

86
00:05:21.050 --> 00:05:24.430
So you can also see where
something like that can happen.

87
00:05:24.430 --> 00:05:27.870
If I hover exactly over,
I don't think I can do that exactly.

88
00:05:27.870 --> 00:05:29.720
I'm trying to.
A lot of times you get a little

89
00:05:29.720 --> 00:05:32.380
message that says,
here is your slack time.

90
00:05:32.380 --> 00:05:36.850
In other words, you may be able to tighten
up the schedule a little bit right here.

91
00:05:36.850 --> 00:05:39.650
Make sure that things actually start
happening a little bit better and

92
00:05:39.650 --> 00:05:40.160
you can do that.

93
00:05:40.160 --> 00:05:41.980
Well, you have to deal with constraints.

94
00:05:41.980 --> 00:05:44.280
So even though it looks like
I could start on Monday,

95
00:05:44.280 --> 00:05:47.910
well I have this little indication over
here that tells me that, hey, they're not

96
00:05:47.910 --> 00:05:51.110
actually going be delivered until Tuesday,
so there's no use in doing that.

97
00:05:51.110 --> 00:05:54.450
So I may not be able to adjust
anything right there, as well.

98
00:05:54.450 --> 00:05:57.520
So being able to display stuff
like that is a part of it.

99
00:05:57.520 --> 00:06:01.385
Now, the other thing that we can do in
the Gantt chart to help us to see this,

100
00:06:01.385 --> 00:06:03.300
is compared against the baseline.

101
00:06:03.300 --> 00:06:05.700
Now let's see,
do I actually have a baseline set here?

102
00:06:05.700 --> 00:06:07.300
Let me see if I do.

103
00:06:07.300 --> 00:06:07.990
Yep, I do.

104
00:06:09.160 --> 00:06:12.500
So now that I've actually adjusted
a couple of things, let me go ahead and

105
00:06:12.500 --> 00:06:14.800
adjust another things as well.

106
00:06:14.800 --> 00:06:16.580
So, let's see, I'm gonna do.

107
00:06:18.330 --> 00:06:19.210
What did I do?

108
00:06:19.210 --> 00:06:23.590
Oh, premise claim that's the one that

109
00:06:23.590 --> 00:06:25.060
let's do that six days again.

110
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:31.180
And now look at what happens the entire
project goes to the critical path, and

111
00:06:31.180 --> 00:06:36.250
then from this point, if I go back
to format, and I select baseline,

112
00:06:36.250 --> 00:06:41.160
I can compare it to this baseline and
now inside of my Gantt chart,

113
00:06:41.160 --> 00:06:44.970
I can see where things started
to happen right away to.

114
00:06:44.970 --> 00:06:48.740
So notice that up until the point where we
started installing the premise cabling,

115
00:06:48.740 --> 00:06:51.310
the premise cabling taking
linger than it should,

116
00:06:51.310 --> 00:06:55.290
really did push everything
else off of its base line.

117
00:06:55.290 --> 00:06:56.780
So we can actually go ahead and

00:06:56.780 --> 00:07:00.670
do that as well, visually being able to
see it is one of the quickest ways you and

119
00:07:00.670 --> 00:07:04.240
I can make decisions,
based off of that critical path as well.

120
00:07:05.240 --> 00:07:09.600
So being able to see the critical path
is something that we all need to do.

121
00:07:09.600 --> 00:07:13.140
If we know that our project is right
there where we need to go ahead and say,

122
00:07:13.140 --> 00:07:17.720
where's the best place I'm gonna need to
add in some resources that may help me to

123
00:07:17.720 --> 00:07:20.880
maintain and
finish all my tasks on schedule.

124
00:07:20.880 --> 00:07:23.630
It's gonna be in those areas
where we're going to see the red.

125
00:07:23.630 --> 00:07:27.070
If we need to make sure that we can see
that notice that project gives us a very

126
00:07:27.070 --> 00:07:30.780
easy way to be able to do that and then
we can adjust it to actually go ahead and

127
00:07:30.780 --> 00:07:33.800
see that, hey if I change
something in the schedule is that

128
00:07:33.800 --> 00:07:37.990
now actually gonna affect the rest of
my schedule, and it absolutely did.

129
00:07:37.990 --> 00:07:41.530
So inside of Microsoft Project, it's
fairly easy to display the critical path,

130
00:07:41.530 --> 00:07:42.980
and see what needs to be done.

131
00:07:42.980 --> 00:07:47.310
Now understanding that critical path
methodology requires a little bit of math.

132
00:07:47.310 --> 00:07:51.420
Knowing about early start dates, and
late start dates, and finish dates, etc.

133
00:07:51.420 --> 00:07:54.680
You need to be able to understand that
as well and if you want to remember

134
00:07:54.680 --> 00:07:58.020
take a look at those PNP shows and
that will help you out as well.

135
00:07:58.020 --> 00:08:02.620
So that for us ends our show here on
taking a look at the critical path method

136
00:08:02.620 --> 00:08:05.310
inside of Microsoft Project.

137
00:08:05.310 --> 00:08:07.350
Well thank you for watching today.

138
00:08:07.350 --> 00:08:10.440
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Ronnie Wong.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don walk through the options to customize how Project 2013 will project data.  They show the simple filtering options and show some of the data display options for highlighting and grouping too.  They also show how you can reuse project information by using the organizer to share specific items between different project plans.
episodes.title: Applying Custom Views

A database on the back end and
